The 1660s: Chronology

1666/1 Demetrio Music by Carlo Pallavicino!

[DEMETRIOS]
A dramma per musica Text by Giacomo dall' Angelo

im Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1666-01-04~

is) Dedicated to three owners of the theater*
In this partly fictional account, Demetrios, the son of the deposed king of Syria, who had reigned in
the second century BC, was now married to Euridice, who is disguised as the warrior Aristandros.
Stratonica, a daughter by his first marriage, was in love with Seleukos, the son of Antiochos, the king
of Phrygia. Kleitarchos/Clitarco, the general of Demetrios's army, loved Lamia, with whom Demetrios
had now fallen in love.

ics) Given that the winter of 1666 offered a pre-Lenten season of maximum extent, the large number of

offerings with libretti dated in this year is no surprise. All could have been performed in the generous

' Carlo Pallavicino (c. 1640-1688) was to be the most prominent Italian opera composer in the 1670s and 1680s. Born in Sald (on the southwest
shore of Lake Garda), he served as a tenor (from 1649) and then as the organist for instrumentalists (organista ai concerti; from 1665) at
the church of Sant' Antonio in Padua. He appeared in operas in Venice from 1654. From c. 1667 to 1672, he worked at the Saxon court in
Dresden as vice Kapellmeister to the aging Heinrich Schiitz. After Schiitz's death (1672), Pallavicino returned to Venice, which remained
his principal residence until 1685. However, he maintained strong ties with the Saxon court, where his son (Stefano Benedetto, b. 1672) was
to serve as court poet (see Selfridge-Field, intro. to Pallavicino: MESSALINA, DMV, viii). This was Pallavicino's first opera.

? Like Aureli, Minato, and Businello, he was a member of the Accademia deg' Imperfetti, which exalted history and classical subjects.

3 The words ballo and balli have been retained on the advice of the late Irene Alm, whose extensive study of theatrical dance was truncated
by her untimely death (2000). It was her view that the modern English words dance and ball do not convey the same theatrical implications
as the Italian seicento word ballo. The performers were always in costume. Balli could have their own scenery; their music was often divorced
from surviving scores (and is therefore difficult to locate and identify). By the mid-eighteenth century, ba/li frequently had their own libretti,
could enjoy independent performance, and were more akin to the French ballet than an integral component of opera.

L.e., Giovanni da Mula, Matteo Pisani, and Matteo da Lezze. In 1661 da Lezze was one of three purchasers of a supernumerary position as
a procurator of San Marco (I-Fn A). His peers included Marco Contarini and Daniel Dolfin.

5 Cesti (1623-69), a priest from Arezzo, was best known for his operas of the 1650s and early 1660s. His works were very highly esteemed

The first ballo may have presented a comic scene within a dignified formation, for the libretto says
that six pageboys were to display an insolent attitude towards the antics of the Old Woman and
Gellido before forming the dance. The choreography for the second ballo was also choreographed
for stage machinery: Apollo appeared in a cloud, Harmony ascended into the sky, and Celestial Rays
made a formation to present the actual ballo. The sets were designed by Gio. Battista Lambranzi, the
costumes by Orazio Franchi.

L'Orontea Music by Antonio Cesti
[ORONTEA]

A dramma per musica Text by Giacinto Andrea Cicognini
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a prologue' and balli SORTING DATE: 1666-01-11~

Dedicated to Maria Mancini Colonna

The Egyptian queen Orontea was quite forward in expressing her love for an apparent stranger and
commoner, Alidoros, who proved to be the Phoenician prince Floridano in disguise and therefore a
suitable match. The work contained numerous comic roles and five cori.

This was one of several works by Cesti which had been performed to great acclaim (Innsbruck, 1656),
but the text had been used in a setting by Francesco Lucio given in 1649 at the Teatro de' SS. Apostoli.
The dedication for this production was signed on 10 January 1666. Matteo Melissa, a musician in the
employ of Johann Seyfried, prince of Eggenberg, wrote from Aquileia on 12 March 1666 that he had
been impressed by all the operas he heard in Venice during this season. He singled out this work as
the most beautiful. The role of Hypsipyle/Issipile was taken by Signora Helena, who, he said, was
in the employ of the Colonna family. He said that SS. Giovanni e Paolo surpassed the other theaters
in the charm of its scenery, the unusual costumes, and the virtue of its famous singers. L 'Orontea
was revived at SS. Giovanni e Paolo as 1683/7.

The theater had contracted with Gasparo Mauro the preceding March to serve as impresario for the
1665-66 season. His contract stipulated that two operas should be produced during this period. Mauro
was paid the fee of 100 ducats. It appears that one of the works was to have been a setting of Giovanni
Faustini's Doriclea, but ten days prior to the writing of the dedication for L 'Orontea, that production
was postponed in favor of this one. Current costs, though undocumented, are unlikely to have been
changed from two years previously, when the theater had charged 4 Jire per seat and 2 lire for each
ticket (bolletino).'

1666/3 La Zenobia Music attributed to Giovanni Antonio Boretti"'
[ZENOBIA]
A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
im Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's?)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1666-01-18~
& Dedicated to Filippo Giuliano Mazarin Mancini?

The reign of Zenobia, the queen of Palmyra, was threatened by the Roman emperor Aurelian (270-275
AD), who was favored by her adversary, the governor of Palmyra. In this work, Zenobia's virtue stood
her in good stead.'* Zenobia included five cori, one of them consisting of Amazons.'

Oo This is one of only two musical works given at San Cassiano between 1659 and 1679. (The theater's
schedule generally favored comedy.) The title-page merely gives the date 1666, but Zenobia would
certainly have run in the winter, perhaps somewhat later than suggested here. As Zenobia e Radamisto,
Noris's text enjoyed a substantial following. Legrenzi's setting of it was given in Ferrara (1665), Brescia
(1666), Verona (1667), and Macerata (1669). Indeed there would seem to be some possibility, in light
of its dedicatee, that this production was based on Legrenzi's setting, which was also to be given at
SS. Giovanni e Paolo as 1677/2.

A No musical sources known'
Listed as Galvani SCas 20, Bonlini 97, Groppo 100, Alm 136

1666/4 Seleuco Music by Antonio Sartorio"
[SELEUKOS]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Nicole Minato'
M1 Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1666-01-23~
& Dedicated to Paolo Spinola

The apocryphal story of the founding of the Seleukid dynasty by a general of Alexander the Great was
often recounted in Venetian opera. In this alternative to Demetrio (1666/1) the retired general Seleukos,
now king of Syria, made a politically advantageous marriage at an advanced age to the young Asian
princess Stratonica. Discovering herself to be in love with her step-son Antiochos, Stratonica asked

"'Itmay have been based on Legrenzi's setting (see below). The Roman bass Gio. Antonio Boretti (1638-72) had sung at Sant' Antonio, Padua,
from 1659 to 1661. He was thereafter active in Venice. The libretto stated that Boretti would appear in the role of the satrap king and that the
scenery was designed by Francesco Santurini.

 The Venetian poet Matteo Noris was to write almost three dozen drammi per musica, the bulk of them set by Pallavicino, Legrenzi, and
C. F. Pollarolo. His texts were typically dedicated to the most powerful rulers who visited Venice in a given season.

'' Filippo Giuliano [Philippe Julien] Mancini, the duke of Nevers, was the brother of Maria Mancini Colonna. He was more likely to accompany
her to the theater than her errant husband.

'\ The story was recast by Marchi for Albinoni as 1694/5.

'S In Greek legend, the Amazons, a race of female warriors from Asia Minor, engaged various heroes in battle. In the Venetian lore of the later
seventeenth century, Amazons were contemporary heroines because they exhibited the courage and valor desired in the Republic's defenders.
On a comprehensive discussion of Amazons in Baroque opera, see Freeman, Amazons.

6 The third act of an anonymous Zenobia in A-Wn may be linked to this production.

7 Sartorio (c. 1630-1680), Kapellmeister to Duke Johann Friedrich of Brunswick-Liineburg, spent most of his time in Hanover for the next
nine years. He served as vice maestro di cappella at San Marco from 1676 until his death.

' Count Minato (c. 1627-1698), from Bergamo, had written the libretti for a number of Francesco Cavalli's most celebrated operas (among
them Scipione africano, Muzio Scevola, and Pompeo Magno). All carried dedications to members of the Colonna family  Lorenzo Onofrio
Colonna, his wife, Maria Mancini, and her brother, Filippo Giuliano Mancini. Here Minato's authorship night be questioned on the basis of
statements in the note to the reader alluding to Neapolitan origins and an author who was far away.

 Spanish duke of Sesto and marquis of Los Balbases. He was the general of the cavalry of Milan. His family held lands in the region of Naples
and in Spain.

accompanied by the continuous playing of instruments.' Seleuco was revived as 1668/1. A setting by

1666/5 Il Tito Music by Antonio Cesti
[Titus]

A melodramma Text by Nicold Beregan

"1 Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)

With balli SORTING DATE: 1666-02-13

& Dedicated to Maria Mancini Colonna, Lorenzo Onofrio Colonna, and Filippo Giuliano Mazarin Mancini

&S Titus, the son of Vespasian, led Roman legions in their attack on Jerusalem in the first century A.D.
This attack was featured in the opening scene of the work, which devolved into a tangle of amorous
complications involving Agrippa and his sister Berenice, her admirer Ptolemy, Titus's brother Domitian,
and his cousin Flavia. Horses, camels, and elephants were seen in the army's camp. Titus was shown
in a billowing cape upon a very muscular horse on the frontispiece. Other scenes were full of statues,
palm trees, gardens, and fountains.

O@ JI Tito opened on 15 February 1666 (GB-Lpro); the libretto had been dedicated on the 13th. It was the
second of the two works produced during the season by Gasparo Mauro. Pietr' Andrea Ziani compared
its reception with that of Pompeo Magno (1666/8) ina letter written the following June. He observed
that Beregan should be thanked for having recruited the virtuosa from Rome who carried the work.
Mancini Colonna left her own account of the work, about which she was highly enthusiastic. She
identified four singers, among whom Gio. Antonio Cavagna made the greatest impression. She praised
the sweetness of the voices, the style of acting, and the beauty of the piece, which was applauded by
everyone and which was assuredly among the most beautiful works I have ever seen in my life.

? He sang arias for Seleuco in a later concert at the convent of San Daniele. See the commentary under Pompeo Magno (below).

2! The claim in Alm, Winged Feet, p. 228 that this was the first social dance in Venetian opera is undermined by accounts of similar scenes
in earlier works, such as Achille in Sciro (Suppl. 2a, 1664). A further excerpt appears on pp. 260f.

 Beregan (1627-1713), a lawyer from Vicenza, was renowned for his knowledge of classical subjects. In 1657 he had been deprived of his
nobility and banned from the Venetian Republic (apparently for carrying weapons; see I-Vas, Consiglio dei Dieci, Proclame a stampa, Filza
2, proclamation of 5 Febraro 1656 [M. V.]), but his sentence was reversed within the year (I-Vas, CX, Proclame, Busta 29, entry of 22 Dicembre
1657).

3 Lorenzo Onofrio Colonna later built two theaters in Rome  the Tordinona for comedy and the Colonna (inside the family palazzo) for
opera (these are the subject of Tamburini's monograph, Due teatri per il prencipe). Between 1664 and 1678 some eleven Venetian operas
were dedicated to one or more members of the extended Colonna family. Several productions were among the most lavish ever to be given
in Venice.

> Letter of 9 June 1666 to Marco Faustini, quoted in Rosand, Opera, p. 437.

5 Tamburini, Due teatri, pp. 96f. The other singers were Sebastiano Cioni and Antonia and Nicold Coresi.

1666/6 Tl Giasone Music attributed to Francesco Cavalli?'
[JASON]
A dramma per musica Text by Giacinto Andrea Cicognini
Md Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a prologue and balli SORTING DATE: 1666-02-23
w& Dedicated to Benedetto Zorzi, Giacomo Celsi, and Carlo Andrea Tron

In his quest for the golden fleece, Jason/Giasone, the captain of the argonauts, abandoned Hypsipyle.
He then fell in love with a stranger, who proved to be Medea in disguise. He discovered her identity
only the night before he was to sail, when she attempted to negotiate a successful outcome to his mission
through her incantations, with which this work opens.

Oo- With this revival, Giasone, which had most recently been given at the Teatro ai Saloni (1664; Suppl.
7), returned to its original venue.* Cicognini's text was dedicated on 23 February 1666, which must
be new-style because of the long Carnival season in 1666 (in 1667 the 23rd was Ash Wednesday). The
prologue was new. Rosand claims that // Giasone was the most frequently performed dramma per musica
of its century (it enjoyed at least twenty-two productions in Italy through 1690).*! The text for this
production was exceptionally long.*? Crescimbeni, while respecting its dramatic construction, later (1700)
condemned its mixing of literary genres and the intrusiveness of its arias.

1666/7 _L'Aureliano Music attributed to Carlo Pallavicino
[AURELIAN]
A dramma per musica Text by Count Giacomo dall' Angelo
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a prologue and balli SORTING DATE: 1666-02-25
rai) Dedicated to Ippolito and Ferrante Bentivoglio

The Roman emperor Aurelian, after conquering the Goths and the Scythians, fixed his sights on the
lands ruled by Zenobia, queen of the entire Orient. Many of the episodes introduced were freely
invented, quite in contrast to Noris's Zenobia (1666/3), which ran a month earlier. The work had a large
cast. The prologue featured seven gods and represented four continents.

OE The libretto for L 'Aureliano was dedicated on 25 February 1666, which must be new-style (see 1666/6
and 1666/8). One performance of the work was apparently interrupted by the remonstrations of Zuane

through the musical ranks at San Marco to become the Ducal Chapel's maestro di cappella (1668-76).

1666/8 Pompeo Magno Music attributed to Francesco Cavalli
[POMPEY THE GREAT]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Nicold Minato
rr Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1666-02-27
& Dedicated to Maria Mancini Colonna

After Pompey the Great had imprisoned Hypsicrateia/Ipsicratia, the queen of Pontos, and her son
Pharnakes/Farnace, in Rome, his son Sextus/Sesto was wrongly accused of the murder of Hypsicrateia's
lady-in-waiting. Pompey entertained thoughts of adopting Pharnakes, who betrayed his father, Mithridates,
as he plotted to kill Pompey.

 Documentary evidence and dates of dedication in printed libretti give contrary readings of the order
of works given at San Salvatore in the winter of 1666. The year itself can easily be distinguished by
its maximally late dates for Shrove Tuesday (9 March) and Easter (25 April). An opera rehearsal which
took place at the convent of San Daniele on 26 February 1666 included arias for Seleuco** (see 1666/4).
Other indications suggest that the work in preparation late in February should have been Pompeo Magno
[libretto dedicated on 20 February 1666]. In this case, Seleuco could be the person who took the role
of Seleukos [Francesco Galli] in the preceding work. The British resident [consul] noted, also on 26
February, the arrival of the prince of Bavaria, the duke of Sesto, and other foreigners and said that
a new work was recited at San Salvatore the previous evening.*

 The three ball/i were entertainments in their own right, although the first two were taken over from the
earlier Cavalli opera Muzio Scevola. The first called for four live horses with mounted riders, the second
for eight mad people, and the third for twelve ghosts. The supernumeraries of the cast included comics,
allegorical figures, choruses, servants, slaves, prisoners, gentlewomen, gentlemen, pages, soldiers, Moors,
and ordinary people  in addition to fifteen roles. The principal members of the cast would have been
as indicated in Vio's documentation (see 1666/4)  Francesco Galli, Antonio Fontana (Formenti),
Alessandro da Livorno (a 15-year-old soprano), Stefano di Bentivoglio, Paolo da Rivani (who played
the old woman), and the blind singer from Milan.

* The libretto for Seleuco (1666/4) was dedicated on 16 January 1666. According to Vio, I monasteri, pp. 306ff, on the last Friday of the
month (26 February), the protectors of San Salvatore and their wives smuggled four singers into the convent of San Daniele, so they could
rehearse without the interruptions they were encountering in the theater. They presented most of an opera, from after the midday meal until
23:00 O.V. The theater owners were Pietro [Piero] Foscarini, Pietro [Piero] Dolfin, and Tomaso Corner. The wives of the first two collected
two of the singers in their gondola and brought them to a water entrance at the convent so that they would not be seen arriving on the street.

+5 The duke of Sesto was the dedicatee of Seleuco, while the Bavarian royals were fans of Seleuco's composer, Sartorio. An unanswered question
is how much earlier the other visitors had arrived.

% Reported in GB-Lpro, SPV, Ser. 101, Box 83 (1667-1714), entry of 26 Febbraio 1666, f. 2r. Taken together with Vio's documentation,
one reading is that the singers had given a dress rehearsal on the 25th which was marred by distractions and absences, necessitating the secret
rehearsal in the convent to better prepare for an imminent formal opening.

3 This is the only work known to have included an equestrian exhibition within an opera in Venice, although large live animals appeared in
several other works, e.g., Tito (1666/5); see also Suppl. Se. The depiction in Pompeo Magno was accompanied by trumpets and other instruments.
In the ballo for pazzi which concluded Act One, two of the madmen were mad for alchemy, two for painting, two for music, and two for poetry.

Various nuns assisted (in unspecified ways) in the convent rehearsal, at which no independent

instrumentalists were present. The singers took turns accompanying each other. The contrast between

that event and the work as staged could not be starker. The participants (in particular Formenti, who

had sung in convents before) were severely reprimanded by the authorities for violating protocol.

1666/9 L'Alciade Music by Pietr' Andrea Ziani'
[ALKIADES]
A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Faustini
rd Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Autumn (St. Andrew's?)
With a prologue and balli* SORTING DATE: 1666-12-14~
& Dedicated to Gio. Carlo and Vincenzo Grimani, NN.VV.
 Alkiades/Alciade,TM the disinherited king of Sicania [the ancient name for Sicily], was in love with the

beautiful Charisde, who was thought to be the daughter of Helenos/Eleno. She was the wife of the Sicilian
prince Eurystheos/Euristeo, whose sister, Idiotheia, was in love with Alkiades. Recognizing that Charisde
was not obtainable, Alkiades set sail for Sardinia. The action began in Calabria, where the wedding
of the king was being celebrated. Given that the dedication is undated, that the title-page is dated 1667,
and that another production (La Dori, 1667/1) was to follow this one in mid-January, it seems likely
that Alciade opened in mid-December 1666.

 The identity of various members of the cast can be ascertained from a series of surviving letters written
between July 1665 and November 1666, the period over which the work was evidently in gestation
and preparation. The same series of letters also documents how malleable works were while issues
of casting, composition, and performance were under negotiation. Antonio Cavagna complained in
October 1665 that the opera company [at SS. Giovanni e Paolo] was changed. It lacked good female
singers, he said, and did not have an adequate number of male singers. He wanted to sing with instruments
which would be tuned to Roman pitch [lower than the Venetian], a practice which would be congenial
for his voice, as it had in his previous appearances in Statira [1655] and Teseo [Elena rapita da Teseo,
1653].
Ziani noted that Cavagna (Cavagnino) was to sing the second-act lament (Pil per me non vi e
contenti) very slowly with a discreet accompaniment of viole. The soprano Giulio Cesare was cast
as Eurystheos. The part of the boat captain (// Nocchiero) was scored for the baritone Giacinto, and
that of Lerilda [for whom no role is indicated in the libretto] for any competent soprano. Antonio

*" 4 Lateran canon, Ziani (1616-84) enjoyed an illustrious career as a composer, serving as vice Kapellmeister to the dowager empress at the
Imperial court (1662-69), then as organist at San Marco (1669-76) and lastly as organist and later maestro di cappella at the Viceregal Chapel
in Naples for the final years of his life.

* One of the most important of the first generation of opera librettists, Faustini wrote the texts for approximately twenty drammi per musica.
The works were produced at San Cassiano, SS. Apostoli, and SS. Giovanni e Paolo, where his brother Marco was the impresario. Extensive
information on the Faustinis' negotiations with SS. Giovanni e Paolo can be found in recent writings by Ellen Rosand, Beth Glixon, the late
Thomas Walker, and others.

* The second ballo was for acrobats (saltatori).

* Alciade(s), although not generally recognized as a Greek name, was one widely used in Italian drama. Many names used in Venetian opera
were invented, although usually they occurred as assumed names or for characters of humble origin. The hero of this story is not the same
as the figure whose son, according to Herodotus, defended Greece against the Egyptians.

da Murano (Idiotea) was asked to double as the old woman Clipea in Act Three. As the production

1667/1 La Dori, overo Lo schiavo reggio Music by Antonio Cesti
[Dor!, OR THE ROYAL SLAVE]
A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Filippo Apolloni**
im Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a prologue and balli SORTING DATE: 1667-01-20~
& Dedicated to Maria Mancini Colonna

The Persian king Artaxerxes and the Nicaean king Archelaos agreed when their children were infants
that Orontes, the son of the first, would marry Dori, the elder daughter of the second. The enemies of
these royal friends upset this arrangement so that Orontes, seeking to claim his bride, was redirected
first to Arsinoe and then to the Egyptian imposter Dori. The real Dori had been kidnaped by pirates
and taken to Babylonia. The work was situated on the banks of the Euphrates. The scenes from the
Babylonian serraglio found in earlier versions of the work were replaced here by military exercises.

io) The dedication date of 16 January 1667 must be new-style; the opening of Carnival was anticipated
on the 14th (GB-Lpro). The production was a revival specially arranged for the dedicatee. The text
was revised in eight days. An explanatory note in the libretto relates that it was difficult to find the original
score for the music (which had been given in 1663 at San Salvatore).

Oo La Dori was, in its time, a truly famous work. First staged in 1657 on a grand scale in Innsbruck, the
score left a long trail of copies. Bonlini wrote of the 1663 production at San Salvatore that it merited
universal applause.*' Gasparo Origo [the impresario?] wrote to Marco Faustini in October 1666 to
suggest that Giulia [Masotti] should be cast in one of the principal roles. Masotti's reputation as a
singer was difficult to disentangle from her performances in the role of Dori. The work was revived
at SS. Giovanni e Paolo (1670/6).

 Pietr' Andrea Ziani to Marco Faustini, letter of 28 November 1665[!], transcribed in Rosand, Opera, p. 437. It may be that a production was
envisioned one year earlier. Numerous remarks in the letter leave no doubt that the work discussed was Alciade. It seems most likely that Ziani
composed the work a year before its production. Ziani had written to Faustini on 25 Luglio 1665 (op. cit., p. 436) saying that the work [submitted
to him] seems a bit dry, especially the soliloquies, and is devoid of canzonettes.... Long soliloquies are abhorred today. He goes on to state
that he would like 200 ducats, just as he had received for setting L amor guerriero (1663). No role for La vecchia Clipea survives in the
libretto, which suggests (as does the name itself) that it was a comic role.

' Letters of 3 Novembre 1666 (Coresi) and 14 Novembre 1666 (Cavagna) transcribed in Rosand, Opera, p. 438. Additional information on
Masotti from Bianconi, // teatro, p. 21.

8 Often called Apollonio Apolloni, this librettist (c. 1635-1688) from Arezzo served the Austrian court at Innsbruck (1653-59) before entering
the service of Cardinal Chigi in Rome (1660-88).

 In the 1663 version the satrap was Artaxerxes, the tutor of Orontes. In this version the role is simply called Satrape.

La prosperita d'Elio Seiano Music by Antonio SartorioTM
[THE GOOD FORTUNE OF HELVIUS SEJANUS]

A dramma per musica Text by Nicolo Minato
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival, Fat Week)
With a prologue and balli SORTING DATE: 1667-01-22~

Dedicated to Johann Friedrich, Duke of Brunswick

Helvius Sejanus, who faithfully served the emperor Tiberius [14-37 AD], passed through the rank of
captain of the praetorian guard before succeeding his master. The path to this succession was strewn
with obstacles presented by envious enemies and was complicated both by Tiberius's wish that his
successor should marry Agrippina, the sister of Gaius Caesar, and by the ghost of Tiberius's son Drusus,
whom Sejanus had killed in battle.

The dedication date of 15 January 1666 must be old-style  both because the note to the reader explains
that this work was intended to be performed in regular night-by-night alternation with La caduta di
[Elio] Seiano, for which the dedication was dated 1667 (see below), and because the theater was otherwise
engaged in 1666. It is likely that, in common with 1667/3, the performance included two singers from
the Brunswick court. The harmony of [Sartorio's] notes was guaranteed to delight the audience,
according to the libretto. The work was given in a setting by Draghi (with arias by Leopold 1) in Vienna
on the emperor's birthday (6 June) in 1671. See also 1729/11.

Scores in I-Ne, Rvat, Rps; arias in -MOe, Nc, Rvat, Vmc, Vqs
Listed as Galvani SSal 9, Bonlini 105, Groppo 108; Alm 147, 148

L' Alessandro amante Music by Giovanni Antonio Boretti
[ALEXANDER AS LOVER]

A dramma per musica Text by Giacinto Andrea Cicognini, rev. Sebastian Enno?>
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)

This adaptation of Cicognini's text for Gliamori d'Alessandro e di Rossane (SS. Apostoli, 1651) focused
on the battle of the Macedonians and the satraps.* The Macedonian leader, Alexander the Great, fell
in love with Roxane/Rossane, the daughter of the Satraps' barbarous leader (in which role the composer
appeared). She was attended by a nurse and numerous ladies-in-waiting.

The production must have opened shortly after the dedication of the libretto (28 January 1667). Sebastian

Enno, the canon of San Pietro di Castello, agreed on 11 December 1666 to sell two libretto texts by
Cicognini (Alessandro and Nino) to the printers Francesco and Stefano Curti. The agreement expressed

1667/4 La caduta d'Elio Seiano Music by Antonio Sartorio
[THE FALL OF HELVIUS SEJANUS]
A dramma per musica Text by Nicole Minato
im Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival, Fat Week)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1667-02-03
&o Dedicated to Amalia, Queen of Denmark and Norway

Continuing the story of La prosperita (1667/2), Agrippina had now become the estranged wife of
Germanicus, brother of the widow of Drusus. Her father, Vespanius, discovering her situation, sought
revenge. The death of Claudius, the brother of Germanicus, intensified the conflict.

 The year in the dedication date (3 February 1667) must be new-style because La caduta was intended
to be performed in alternation with La prosperita d'Elio Seiano (see above). However, the only date
for which a performance the work can be confirmed is 22 February 1667 (GB-Lpro), which was Shrove
Tuesday. While the year of both works taken together is unambiguous, the three-week separation in
dedication dates suggests either that the first was not performed until later than its dedication suggests,
that the dedication of La caduta was from a second printing, or that the works were performed in the
usual serial manner  with one completing its run before the next began.

[THE TYRANT WHO WAS HUMILIATED BY LOVE, OR MERASPES]

*8 Enno's agreement with the Curti (who printed the libretto) and Zuliani settled the price of the set at 205 ducats. Enno could decide to whom
the works should be dedicated. Any gifts forthcoming from dedications would be retained by the seminary. Enno would be given twenty-five
publications of his own choice from the press. In the event that either work was not performed, Enno was to return the corresponding compensation.
The signatories were Enno, Agostino Mora, Lunardo Corona, Francesco Nicolini, and Stefano Curti. The current location of this agreement,
transcribed in c. 1954 by the late Emil Paul and made available recently by Dwayne Rosengard and Micky White, is not specifically recorded,
apart from a general indication that it comes from notaries' acts in I-Vas. The work called Nino in the contract was obviously not produced
during this season. The next work which included a role for Nino was Moniglia's Semiramide (1670/4). The decision not to produce Nino
came quickly: While Enno agreed on the 12th to repay Stefano Curti 105 ducats (and left the choice of a dedicatee for Nino to the printer),
the actual repayment was made in numerous installments over the next several years.

* Mancini et al., Teatri, i, 186.

of two singers from the court of Brunswick.

! Faustini (termed in a note to the reader of this libretto the Sophocles of the stage and the Euripides of the modern theater) had written

92 A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

With prologue and balli SORTING DATE: 1667-12-14~
& Dedicated to Don Gasparo de Teves y Cordova
 The libretto for this work is an invented story concerning Meraspes, the tyrannical king of Menfi [Sicily],

who interacted with ten other terrestrial characters. The work also required seven allegorical characters,
eight silent cori, and two baili for pages. In the opening prologue, situated on the banks of the Nile,
two chained lions pulled the blood-stained chariot of Tyranny onto the stage. The libretto, which had
been completed after Faustini's death by Count Beregan, was here identified as a work for autumn.
The production opened shortly before the Novena of Christmas: the dedication was dated 12 December
1667. II tiranno was in progress before the 15th and was still running (no doubt with a break from
16-25 December) on 30 December (GB-Lpro).

 II tiranno umiliato represented the passing of authority from the Faustini family, on whom SS. Giovanni
e Paolo had relied for most of the decade, to the young Grimani brothers, who were to play a leading
role in Venetian theater management for the next four decades. The change was immediately visible
in the increased military emphasis favored by the Grimani. This work featured four groups of Romans
(among them soldiers) and four groups of Arabs (among them prisoners) together with thirteen principal
roles and seven allegorical ones.

 Between June and September prospective singers sent Marco Faustini a stream of complaints about
the weaknesses of the work. They concerned the reuse of musical material already heard in Rome, the
lack of movement and harmonic definition in the basso continuo, a specific role which was too limited,
an overabundance of recitatives (versi), and a paucity of song. Giuseppe Maria Donati (Meraspe) merely
requested easy music. All the other complaints came from [Antonio] Coresi (Caristo). Faustini admitted
to Gasparo Origo in October that this text was less perfect than [his brother Giovanni] Faustini's Alciade,
which had run the previous winter. He said that while Beregan completed Act One [by adding arias
to his brother's recitatives], he tired of the job and the remaining acts were filled in...perhaps too
prolifically from other sources.

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1660-69) 93

Bassianus was named Roman emperor [218-222 AD] at the age of fifteen. Nicknamed Elagabalus after
the sun-god Baal, he ordered worship of the pagan deity. He flagrantly violated moral standards and
was extravagant in his tastes and edicts. He insisted, for example, that evening activities should take
place during the day and vice versa. He was ultimately murdered by praetorian guards. Many incidental
scenes in this work (such as a burlesque for court buffoons) were invented to portray his depravity.

The libretto for Eliogabalo was dedicated on 10 January 1667, which must be old-style (the title-page
is dated MDCLXVIII). The libretto itself must be revised from an earlier one, for the production appears
to have opened by 30 December 1667 (GB-Lpro). Allusion was made to the upcoming production on
15 December, perhaps because this work's predecessor (JI tiranno, 1667/5) was not well received.
Aureli's note to the reader pays tribute to the scenery of Ippolito Mazzarino, the machines of Gasparo
Mauro, and the costumes of Orazio Franchi as well as the admirable music of Boretti and the exquisite
contribution of the virtuosi. Boretti is likely to have taken one of the roles himself. Among the cori
were one of cavallieri and one of courtesans.

94 A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

With balli SORTING DATE: 1668-12-30~

a) Dedicated to Gio. Carlo and Vincenzo Grimani, NN.VV.

This work was based on the sibling rivalry between the sons  Artaxerxes, the first-born, and Cyrus,
the second-born  of the Persian king Xerxes. The latter had a fiery temper and a great desire for power.
The work was set in Susa, the capital of the Persian Empire.

Oo The libretto for Artaserse was dedicated on 28 December 1668; the production is likely to have opened
by the 30th. It must have been well received because it was apparently one of the two works still running
four weeks later. In the opening scene, Stateira held a festa teatrale in which Caprice and Invention
performed a balletto in an amphitheater, while two of Artaxerxes' musicians appeared on an overhead
machine. This beginning was in character with the rest of the production, which boasted cori of ladies,
gentlemen, pages, standard-bearers, soldiers, eunuchs, slaves, and hunters.

1669/1 L'Argia Music attributed to Antonio Cesti
[ARGEIA]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giovanni Filippo Apolloni
M1 Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a prologue and balli SORTING DATE: 1669-01-19~
& Dedicated to Alessandro Contarini, N.V.

The action, which took place on Cyprus at an indeterminate ancient time, concerned the love of Selinus,
the son of King Athamantes who was raised by the king of Thrace, and Argeia, the daughter of the king
of Euboea.

Oo The original six-hour performance had been warmly received in Innsbruck, where it was given before
the exiled queen Christina of Sweden in November 1655. By 1669 it was something of a legend. The
libretto for this abridged Venetian revival was dedicated on 13 January 1669. The production, which
must have opened soon thereafter, was in progress on 26 January 1668 M.V. (GB-Lpro). Most of the
lavish cori of the Innsbruck work were omitted. A work with the same title was given in the small court
theater in Mantua in 1674."

1669/2 Il Genserico Music attributed to Antonio Cesti and Gian Domenico PartenioTM
[GENSERIC]
A melodramma Text attributed to Nicold Beregan
im Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1669-02-04~
we Dedicated to Benedikte Henriette, Duchess of Brunswick
i) The plot concerned relations between the Goths and the Eastern Roman Empire upon the collapse of

the Western Roman Empire in the fifth century. Genseric [sometimes called Gaiseric], the king of the
Vandals and A fricans, was now called upon by Valentian's widow, Eudoxa/Eudossa, to ward offattacks
by the Huns. He also hoped to marry his son to her daughter.* As the work opened, Genseric had just
won a desert campaign and camels were seen on the stage. The libretto for Genserico was dedicated
on 31 January 1669 and the production should have opened shortly after the feast of Santa Maria Formosa
(Purification). Conflict with the Turks resulting in the fall of Candia (Crete) in December 1668 had
brought many northern allies to Venice to plot revenge (GB-Lpro), and the audience for this work should
have been substantial.

Radamisto, who was currently held captive by Tiridates. Rhadamisthos escaped too late to prevent

1669/4 L'Ermengarda, regina de' longobardi Music by Ant. Sartorio
[HERMENGARD, QUEEN OF THE LOMBARDS]
A dramma per musica Text by Pietro DolfinTM
r1 Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a ballo and esercizi cavallerschi SORTING DATE: 1669-12-26
& Dedicated to the Kind Reader
 Hermengard/Ermengarda, the first-born of the second marriage of Bertha, the countess of Arles, married

Adalbert, the marquis of Ivrea. Her political ambitions were challenged by her two brothers and her
step-brother. The action in this work took place in Pavia. Ermengarda had opened by 26 December
1669,' perhaps contrary to the wishes of the Council of Ten, which took steps to delay the official
opening of Carnival on account of the death of Pope Clement IX on 9 December. Four performances
had been given by 3 January.

@ Reports of the work's fortunes are contradictory. Dolfin anticipated on the 26th that the work should
have a good reception because of the sweetest music of Sartorio and the presence of my new
cantatrice, whom Francesco Maria Massi called a most beautiful sweet young singer (a bellissima

 In Bentivoglio's anachronistic plot, Tiridates was put on the Armenian throne by his brother Vologeses in 54 AD [the reign of Zenobia began
in 267]. In Venetian opera libretti, Rhadamisthos was variously Iberian or Armenian. (According to Tacitus, Rhadamisthos, the son of Pharasmenes,
the king of Iberia, was the nephew of Mithridates, the king of Armenia). The text for Handel's Radamisto (HWV 12a), usually attributed in
the main to Nicholas Haym, may also have debts to this work. The minor characters here are fictional ones.

! Shrove Tuesday fell on 5 March in 1669 and on 14 February in 1668. Legrenzi's presence in Venice can be confirmed for March 1668.
A production of this work may have been intended for the earlier year.

apologizes for having failed to find two books requested by his patron.

The 1670s: An Overview

he 1670s brought a degree of stabilization to Ve-
2 netian opera. Its reputation grew on the Italian
peninsula, in the Hapsburg spheres, and in France.

The appearance of the Giornale veneto de' letterati, first
published in February 1671, demonstrates the growing
importance of academic societies in promoting dramas
enhanced by music. Coverage of Venetian opera in the
Mercure galant (established in 1672), which began in 1677,
confirmed its importance.

The four theaters active in the 1660s  SS. Giovanni
e Paolo, San Salvatore, San Cassiano, and San Moise 
functioned as they had in the 1660s. The first two maintained
more or less predictable schedules. San Salvatore was
reinvigorated by modifications in interior design and new
management. The second two alternated as comedy houses
in some years and opera houses in others. The theatrical
landscape was changed in the last years of the decade with
the opening of Sant' Angelo (1677), San Giovanni Grisosto-
mo (1678), and a theater at the Contarini villa, Piazzola
(1679). (See Table 20.) Sant' Angelo and San Giovanni were
to survive all their peers as opera houses. They presented
drammi per musica exclusively until 1748 and 1747. One
significant difference distinguished these two new houses.
San Giovanni was the most opulent opera house of its time
anywhere. It was planned to dazzle, to overwhelm.
Sant' Angelo, in contrast, was always a struggling enterprise
tottering on the margins of total collapse. Their contributions
to opera were vastly different. Yet their durability was rough-
ly comparable. Sant' Angelo proved to be more durable, for
it survived into the nineteenth century.

While the dynamics of opera production changed little
in the 1670s, the recognition given to academies influenced
the marginalia of opera. Military strategies of antiquity were
re-enacted in battle scenes. New habits of dress and manners
were exhibited in balli and cori. In the Venetian Republic
it was a calm time, a pause between its two greatest cam-
paigns of the century.

It was not a calm time in the rest of Europe. France was
at war with the Netherlands for most of the decade. In 1674
the Holy Roman Empire joined the Dutch in opposing the
French. A growing rift between the Empire and France was

to have far-reaching implications for Venetian opera. The
Turks gathered strength on land, winning the Polish Ukraine
by treaty (1676). The vast debts which the Venetians had
accumulated during their war in Crete were little discussed
but continued to seriously erode the economy.

Cavalli was well on in years by 1670 and was relatively
inactive in the theater during his last years. His successors
at San Salvatore, Antonio Boretti and Antonio Sartorio, both
died young (possibly of overwork) before the decade was
ended. Giovanni Legrenzi was a notable newcomer. At SS.
Giovanni e Paolo, Pietr' Andrea Ziani was active until his
departure for the Chapel Royal at Naples in 1676. Carlo
Pallavicino, who already had ties to the Saxon court in Dres-
den, enjoyed a growing reputation in Venice and composed
some of the most arresting works given at San Giovanni
Grisostomo in its first years. Several operas were also staged
at the academic Teatro ai Saloni, where the academicians
themselves performed. The public was invited to attend
without charge. Most works given there had previously been
produced, often on a lavish scale, in Vienna (Suppl. 7).

No sooner had the new theaters opened than they were
upstaged by the entertainments of the doge's own family,
for in 1679 the first of several monumental productions was
given at the villa of the Contarini family at Piazzola, twenty
kilometers from Venice. The theater was the enterprise of
the doge's son Marco and it was he who was mainly
responsible for assembling what we know today as the
Contarini Codices, preserved in the Marciana National
Library in Venice. It is the largest surviving collection of
scores of Venetian opera. Operas given at Piazzola (a much
smaller number of works) were performed before an invited
noble audience. They were interactive: noblemen partici-
pated as extras on horseback and as machinery
engineers. In the eyes of the nobility of northern Italy, this
adventure, though brief, cannot have failed to dim the luster
of the works given indoors at the new theaters in the city.

The schedule of productions changed in the 1670s.
Openings in the first half of December continued steadily
in the first years of the decade, but the government intro-
duced measures to keep the theaters closed throughout the
liturgical season of Advent. Productions after Christmas

The 1670s: Chronology

Marcello in Siracusa Music by Giovanni Antonio Boretti

[MARCELLUS IN SYRACUSE]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
V1 Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)

With balli SORTING DATE: 1670-01-19
a Dedicated to Octavius of Taxis!

The Roman captain Marcellus was charged with capturing the walled seaport of Syracuse, which was
occupied by the Greeks. After considering available methods of land and sea attack, he built wooden
piers under the town wall to facilitate an assault. The Greeks' defense rested on Archimedes' design
for a concave mirror to focus solar rays onto wooden objects (such as Marcellus's ships and the newly
built piers) until they ignited. The Romans won, but Marcellus's plea to spare Archimedes' life was
ignored. Roman troops assassinated the scientist in his study, amid an array ofhis scientific instruments.

OR This revival (the work had first been given at SS. Giovanni e Paolo in 1660) is reported to have opened
to great applause on 19 January (GB-Lpro). The production fell apart on the second night because the
prima donna was sick. Someone less well prepared was substituted.? The work's reception was also
undermined by a paucity of foreign visitors. P. A. Ziani organized a production in Naples in 1673, and
the work was performed in numerous locales in northern Italy over the next several years.

Baron of the Holy Roman Empire, Taxis (1621-91) was the imperial postmaster for the Venice-Trent route, which led to Austria. His forebears
had developed the first imperial postal routes in the fifteenth century. The baron and the marquis Ornano were implicated in a scandal in Venice
two years later (see the letter from Nicolo Beregan of 1 Aprile 1672 in Vavoulis, Massi, p. 575).

? Noris credited Plutarch and Macrolichus with his tuition on the subject.
3 GB-Lpro, SPV, Ser. 101, Box 83, letter of 25 Gennaro 1670.

1670/2 L'Antigona delusa da Alceste Music by Pietr' Andrea Ziani
[ANTIGONE DELUDED BY ALCESTIS]
A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli*
im Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a prologue and balli SORTING DATE: 1670-01-20
& Dedicated to Antonio Teodoro Trivolzio

Alcestis, hearing that her husband Admetos, the king of Thessaly, was incurably ill, offered to sacrifice
herself for him. Admetos survived, but then discovered that his wife was gone. Princess Antigone, who
also loved Admetos, trapped him by adopting a male disguise, revealing her identity, and then castigating
him for his infidelity. In this revival (the work was originally given in 1660-61') much of the effort
seems to have been invested in incidental pieces  especially the prologue for six allegorical figures,
among which Music reigns supreme, and the coro for the Twelve Hours of the Day.

Ooo- The libretto for this revival was dedicated on 18 January 1669; the title-page is dated MDCLX. Aureli's
text was a source for Handel's Admeto, re di Tessaglia (HWV 22, 1727). Abbot Domenico Federici
reported to the empress on 8 February 1670 that the work at San Salvatore contained nothing beautiful
except the music, in which Ziani has captured all the good things [he has learned in] Vienna. It is not
so much a drama as a musical Iliad.

1670/3 L'Erismena Music by Francesco Cavalli
[ERISMENA]
A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli
I] Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Carnival (Fat Week)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1670-02-13
a Dedicated to Don Gasparo de Teves y Cordova'

Erismena, the daughter of an illicit union between the Median prince Erymanthos/Erimantes and the
Armenian princess Arminda, stood to inherit the throne if her true identity could be established." She
first appeared here disguised as a gentleman and was subsequently wounded in combat. Her lover, the
Iberian prince Hydraspes/Idraspe, was believed to be a follower of Erymanthos. His adopted sister
Aldimira, with whom Erismena's father was in love, was a slave. As the work opened, the Medians
had just defeated the Armenians.

and illness (see the transcription in Rosand, Opera, p. 440).

5 One ballo was for cavalieri di varie nazioni. Stage ensembles representing various nations were a staple of both French and Venetian
opera that can be traced back at least as far as Cavalli's Gli amori d'Apollo e di Dafni (1640). In some cases, the dancers could not agree on
the gestures, since they reflected different styles of dance (see Alm, Winged Feet, p. 259).

 A count of the Holy Roman Empire and a member of the Order of the Golden Fleece.

La Semiramide Music attributed to Pietr' Andrea Ziani
[SEMIRAMIS]

A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Andrea Moniglia'?
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Autumn (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1670-12-12

Dedicated to the brothers Gio. Carlo and Vincenzo Grimani

The Assyrian queen Semiramis exploited the fact that she and her son Ninias" were of strikingly similar
appearance. Unlike his late father Ninus, who founded a dynasty, Ninias proved incompetent at leading
an army. Creon/Creonte, the king of Babylonia, thinking the son an easy target, encountered the disguised
and much more bellicose Semiramis. The work, set in Susa, involved numerous groups of soldiers and
warriors.'* In one ballo, Moorish soldiers used their swords to spell out a poetic message.

The libretto for Semiramide was dedicated on 11 December 1670. The performance was in progress
onthe 12th.'* Although it was apparently intended to run into January (the title-page is dated MDCLXXD),
Semiramide was not well received. According to one account, it was still open on 19 December but
only because of a couple of exquisite singers.''A revival of La Dori (1670/6) was given when the
theater reopened on the 26th.

Abbot Federici consigned the score to Count Waldstein on 31 January 1671 in order to have it conveyed
to the court at Vienna. He suggests that it contained annotations of his own. In retrospect, he allowed
that Boretti (whom he claimed was a convert from Judaism) was an applauded composer but listed
as his chief defects his having married and his having composed ugly music for Dario (1671/2).
On the night of 4 January 1671(when the production would have resumed), the nobleman Giovanni

in the standard manner (between the columns of Sts. Mark and Theodore near the ducal palace) for
his crime.

In this derivation from Pierre Corneille, after the tyranny of the Eastern Roman Emperor Phocas [602-
610] and the imprisonment of his predecessor Maurice [582-602], Heraclius [610-641] defended
Byzantium against A fricans. The staging was particularly rich in grotesque scenes involving cadavers
and caves, which were sharply contrasted with the splendors (indoors and out) of imperial Constantinople.
The libretto was dedicated on 17 January 1671 and must have opened soon thereafter. The production
was still in progress on 6 February. L 'Eraclio was also produced in Naples in December 1673. It was
reported that Eraclio was so beautiful one can never have enough of it and that [Beregan] is deified
in this theater...he is unequaled in invention and ingenuity.

Dario in Babilonia Music attributed to Giovanni Antonio Boretti
[DaRIUS IN BABYLON]

A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Beverini*!
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1671-01-26

Dedicated to Lorenzo Tiepolo, N.V.

The plot was based on the efforts of Darius I (sixth century BC) to recapture Babylon (Mesopotamia).
The work opened with the Assyrians attacking the Persians at the wall of the city. The libretto for Dario
was dedicated on 24 January 1671 and the production must have opened within the next few days.
However, it had closed by the 31st, according to a letter from Abbot Federici to the Viennese court.
Federici claimed that Dario contained ugly music, was good for nothing, and was buried as soon
as it was born. Perhaps anticipating criticism, Beverini wrote in his preface that he did the best he
could to accommodate the work to the needs of the stage.

Massi had sent Duke Johann Friedrich a list of singers for the winter which included Giulia Masotti,
Lucrezia del Dolfin, Vincenzo [Olivicciani] from Florence, Giuseppino [Giuseppe Maria Donati] from
Bavaria, Alessandro from Livorno/Leghorn, the tenor Biancucci, and the bass [Ippolito] Fusari** No
theater was specified, but the first three named had prior associations with San Salvatore. Johann Friedrich
had boxes for the season in San Salvatore, SS. Giovanni e Paolo, and San Samuele.

1671/3 Claudio Cesare Music by Giovanni Antonio Boretti
[CLAUDIUS CAESAR]
A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli
i Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1671-12-14~
a Dedicated to Johann Friedrich, Duke of Brunswick-Liineburg

In this story from Tacitus, Claudius succeeded his late wife, Messalina, to serve as emperor [41-54
AD]. He married his niece Agrippina who, by a previous marriage, was the mother of Nero. A rebellion
occurred after he petitioned the Senate to deviate from Rome's legal traditions by allowing this marriage
to his niece.** Aureli pleaded in his note to the reader for tolerance towards the dramatic weaknesses
of the work. He explained that it has more canzoni and ariette than incidents [i.e., more musical numbers
than dramatic scenes]. It should suffice to say that it is a dramma per musica. What can one do if today
the caprices of Venice demand it? I give them what they want. To claim to conquer the heart is rash.
To be blessed with universal acclaim is a stroke of luck.

O The surviving libretto for this work was dedicated on 27 December 1672, but the correct year is now
believed to have been 1671, with a run extending into January 1672.** It appears, in fact, that Claudio
Cesare was the work which had opened at San Salvatore before the 17th, and therefore it probably
opened not later than the 14th. The second ballo recreated a gladiatorial battle. Although no singers
can be firmly associated with this work, Antonio Cavagna was a lodger in one of the dedicatee's houses
during the winter of 1671/2.%

A Scores in I-Nc, Vnm

& Dedicated to Johann Friedrich and Ernst August, Duke and Prince of Brunswick-Liineburg

Gaius Caligula, the son of Germanicus, succeeded Tiberius as emperor of Rome in 37 AD. Under the
spell of a love potion, he became embarrassingly entangled with an alluring Moroccan named
Adraspe, who was really Tigranes, the disguised king of Mauritania and a prisoner of Artabanos.
Separate balli featured painters and madmen.

* Aureli explains that many changes were made after the work went into rehearsal.

at Sant' Apollinare and later published in Ghisberti's Talia (Munich, 1675). It appears that only the prologue and a few numbers were set to

Caligola had opened by (and apparently on) 26 December 1671 (I-Rvat A).''' This libretto was dated
18 December 1672, an apparent error, since in 1672 there would have been a collision with Boretti's
Domiziano (1672/4). The title-page was dated 1672. With various revisions including the addition and
subtraction of roles, Caligola had thirteen other productions through 1696. Most fell between the current
one and 1680/10, which was given at SS. Giovanni e Paolo. Caligola and Massenzio (see 1673/1) were
both performed (as commedie) before Christina of Sweden at the Tordinona in Rome in 1674." It also
had an academic prototype in La pazzia in trono (Suppl. 7, 1660), a spoken play with arias by Cavalli.

The upcoming season was said to be attracting a large crowd of foreigners, including (prospectively)
the prince of Monaco (see 1672/1) and many gentlemen from Genoa and Milan (I-Rvat A).'! The skills
of Pagliardi and the exquisiteness of the singers were both praised in the libretto.

Attila Music attributed to Pietr' Andrea Ziani
[ATTILA]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1672-02-12

Dedicated to the Prince and Princess Grimaldi of Monaco*

The story related here concerned the three-sided conflict between the Vandals, Romans, and Franks
in the fifth-century environs of Aquileia. The perspective was that of Honoria, the sister of the emperor
Valentinian [d. 454], who, with her husband Torrismond, fled to avoid the wrath of Attila. In this
adaptation of Corneille's like-named play (1667), the leader of the Vandals imprisoned Theodoric, the
ruler of ancient Belgia* and most of Gaul.

The date of dedication of the libretto, 12 February 1672, must be new-style; the printer's date is
MDCLXXII (Carnival lasted until 1 March in 1672 but only until 14 February in 1673). The arrival
of the prince of Monaco was signaled in a notice of the opening of Caligola, the preceding work at
SS. Giovanni e Paolo. Trumpets, still a rarity in Venetian theaters,*' were used in the opening sinfonia
to accompany the march of the Vandal army and in the first (bellicose) ballo. Following the model of
Archimedes' study in Marcello in Siracusa [1670/1], the final scene of Attila was set in the rooms of
Philisthenes, where many astrological [sic] instruments were seen.*

Score in I-Bbor, Vnm; arias in I-Vqs
Listed as Galvani SSGP 53; Bonlini 129; Groppo 132; Alm 182

& Dedicated to Johann Friedrich, Duke of Brunswick-Liineburg

Oo Dolfin's story, an invented one set in Pavia in the tenth century, was based on historical figures 
Adalbert, the only son of Berengar, the ruler of Milan and second king of Italy; Adelaide, the widow
of Lothar/Lotario; and her companion Otto, who was not recognized because of his disguise. In a nod
to Teutonic culture, the balli depicted such subjects as miners and prison guards. The date of dedication
of the libretto, 19 February 1672, has to have been new-style; the same date in 1673 would have fallen
during Lent. The content was significantly changed from the academic work of 1670 (Suppl. 7). Elements
of the story survive in Handel's Lotario (HWV 26, 1729).

 Adelaide is often cited as the first Venetian opera in which trumpets were used. While it is plausible
that Sartorio introduced them, they could have been used in previous works such as Sartorio's
Ermengarda (1669/4, also on a text by Dolfin) and were present in Ziani's Attila (1672/1), which was
running concurrently. They may have symbolized the primitive culture of the Vandals more than the
glory of present-day rulers.

[ORPHEUS]
A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli
im Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Autumn (St. Andrew's)

& Dedicated to Gio. Battista Cornaro dalla Piscopia

The celebrated legend of Orpheus, son of Calliope and Apollo, and his tragic love for the Thracian nymph
Euridice had been the subject of Monteverdi's like-named work for Mantua (1607). This account included
many of the legendary episodes, among them the amorous interest of Aristaios, in flight from whom
the nymph suffered a mortal snake-bite. The work opened with the wedding of Orpheus and ended with
the arrival of the sea goddess Tethys on the beach of Thrace.

Oo L'Orfeo had been performed twice by 16 December 1672 (I-Rvat A). The dedication was dated 14
December 1672. The last performance was on 20 January 1673, when audiences were distressed to
learn that the production was closing.TM P. A. Ziani mounted a revival of the work in Naples in 1682.

ic) Domitian [81-96AD], according to the preface, was the most ruthless and lascivious of the Roman

emperors. The interest here is focused on Emilia, the wife of Domitian's general Appius, and her admirer
Florus. The libretto for Domiziano was dated 27 December 1672. Rehearsals were in progress by the
17th (I-Rvat A). Boretti died on the 29th (reportedly of exhaustion), which was said to be prior to the
opening of the work. The opening nonetheless was reported to have taken place by the 30th.

 The cast included Giulia [Masotti], who had brought her sweetness and tenderness to the theater by
9 December, and Cieccolino [Antonio Rivani], who had not yet arrived by that date. The cast also
included the little castrato Lassi but it lacked Lucrezia [del Dolfin], who had declined to sing in it,
and another (unnamed) pillar of previous seasons.* The Grimani brothers reportedly lost 3,000 on
this production. Audiences found the works at San Salvatore [Orfeo, 1672/3 and Massenzio, 1673/1]
more attractive. The Grimani cause was not helped by the fact that one of the male singers (unnamed)
was shot and killed while in a gondola with several other musicians.TM

1672/5 La costanza trionfante Music by Gian Domenico Partenio
[CONSTANCY TRIUMPHANT]
A dramma per musica Text by Cristoforo Ivanovich
im Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1672-12-30~
is) Dedicated to Jean Antoine de Mesmes, Count d'Avaux

The Egyptian king Belos had two sons  Danaos and Aigyptos/Egito  to whom he gave the lands
of Egypt and Arabia respectively. In this plot, Lynceus/Linceo, the son of Aigyptos, fell in love with
Hypermnestra/Ipermestra, the daughter of Danaos. She saved him from the fate that her many sisters
inflicted on his many brothers.

O@ Francesco Maria Massi, the agent of the duke of Brunswick, indicates that La costanza had opened
by 30 December 1672 and was still running on 20 January. Galvani, Bonlini, and Groppo all list the
work for spring 1673. GB-Lpro says that it had opened as the terza by 7 January 1673.! Lacostanza
was the first work to be given at San Moise since 1667. The libretto is the earliest in this study to offer
aprinted cast list. The singers were Carlo Lesma (Danao), Teresa Balsami (Jpermestra), Zannetto Carletti
(Linceo), Orsola Parmeni (Elmira), Bastianino Rosa (Arbante), Pietro Corte (Delmiro, Arsace), Sebastiano
Orfei (Barce), and Tonino Cola (Vafrino). The libretto also names the ballet-master (Bortolo Gorbissa),
the scenery-engineer (Stefano Santurini), the set-painter (Domenico Mauro), and the costume-maker
(Tomaso Zanoli). According to Massi, the work had little to recommend it, but the theater was still
enjoying full audiences on 20 January 1673.

 La ccostanza proved so popular, according to Massi's letters of 8 and 13 January 1673, that its abundant
attendance was hurting other theaters. Its success owed in part to the fact that no charge was being levied
at the entrance except for those who did not hold boxes. Box-holders automatically received four
complimentary bollettini (tickets of admission). A diplomatic report explains that this arrangement
resulted from the fact that the French ambassador [i.e., the dedicatee] had offered the theater a generous
gift, enabling the producers to avoid any investment of their own.

1673/1 Massenzio Music attributed to Antonio Sartorio
[MASSENTIUS]
A dramma per musica Text by Giacomo Francesco Bussani
i Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1673-01-28
a Dedicated to Almor6 Dolfin and Marin Zorzi, NN.VV.
Oo The tyrannical Maxentius was influenced by a wizard of the praetorian guard. His magic deceived many

and paved the way for the accession of Licinius, the brother-in-law of Constantine. The romantic interests
of the plot were invented. Although expected to open on 24 January 1673, Massenzio's premiere was
on the 28th. Audiences found the work admirable and considered the music to be most beautiful
and most marvelous. Nicola Gratianini (Gratianino) was singled out for his performance in the
title role in a cast noted for its exquisiteness. Antonio Rivani (Cieccolino) won praise in the
supporting role. The work brought immortal fame to Johann Friedrich [through the participation of
members of his court], while Dolfin found an unnamed virtuosa in the service of Leonardo Loredan
to be insufferable in a supporting role.

OR Cavalli had been asked to set the text, but the plan was scuttled by managers impatient with a lack of
spirited ariettas in the provisional work, according to Pietro Dolfin. Sartorio obliged them with a
work containing 78 arias and duets, which was said to have been composed in thirteen days, even
though he had turned down an opportunity to compose for SS. Giovanni e Paolo in November and had
recently declared himself too unwell to return to Hanover.

CHRONOLOGY OF OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1670-79) 111

Antigonos, the king of Phrygia, entered Egypt with the intention of marrying his daughter, Berenice,
to Ptolemy/Tolomeo. She, however, fell in love with the Cappadocian prince Cleanthes. Ptolemy's
loss of ground benefitted Lysimachos, the king of Thrace [323-281 BC].* The libretto, which attributed
the story to the escapades of the gods of War, Love, and Fortune, alluded to the many accomplishments
of the dramatist and composer in portraying the greatest [heroes] of the age in which the story was
situated. Since Ivanovich regarded the story as well known, several of the grand personages cited
were not actually present in the drama.

 The libretto for Lisimaco was dedicated on 10 December 1673. The production is likely to have opened
soon and to have continued after Christmas (Ivanovich said he intended the work for performance during
the coming Carnival). The title-page is dated M.DC.LXXIV [1674], but the genesis of the text was
earlier: Ivanovich had written to Pagliardi on 26 June to announce that it had been selected by the theater
for production. Preparations, including external repairs to the theater, had begun by 20 October.

) Enthusiastic comments preceded the arrival of the singer Orsola [Parmeni] from Rome. She was said
to be beautiful and socially adept. She had black eyes and was always smiling. She could probably upstage
another Roman singer, Zitellotta. In addition she could speak, sing, narrate, and act with skill. She
was also described as being as cunning as a devil.** The role of Berenice was apparently taken by
Lucia Cimini (that miraculous virtuosa), to whom an anonymous laudatory sonnet survives.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

In his first involvement in Venetian opera, Marc' Antonio Ziani, the nephew of Pietr' Andrea, revised
Cesti's score of La Semiramide, overo La schiava fortunata (Vienna, 1667) to create this work. The
libretto, dedicated on 1 January 1674, professes that many elements of the script were altered to produce
modern universal pleasure. This was an unusually lackluster year for Venetian theaters. San Salvatore
was undergoing renovation, and there was little else to draw visitors. The production of La schiava
cannot have opened earlier than 4 January; it is more likely to have begun around the 13th, roughly
a month before the end of Carnival.

Numa Pompilio Music by Giovanni Maria Pagliardi
[NuMaA PomPILIus]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1674-01-13~

Dedicated to Almore Dolfin

Raised as a shepherd, Numa Pompilius became the king of the Romans after the death of Romulus.
Although he was supposed to marry Claudia, the most beautiful woman in Rome, he fell in love with
the nymph Hegeria and, according to legend, married her. The libretto for Numa Pompilio (also given
in Vienna in 1674) was dedicated on 11 January 1674, and the production should have begun soon after.
Scores in A-Wn; I-Vnm

Listed as Galvani SSGP 56; Bonlini 137; Groppo 140; Alm 194

L'Almerico in Cipro Music by Antonio Dal Gaudio
[ALMERIC IN CYPRUS]

A dramma per musica Text by Girolamo Castelli*
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1674-12-01~

Dedicated to Alessandro Contarini, N.V.

Eager to find a wife who would be the most beautiful in the world, Almeric, the king of Cyprus, sent
ambassadors abroad to search for such a creature. Two princesses from Rhodes  Rosena and Laodikeia
made the short list. Because of rough seas, the latter did not arrive until after the decision was made.
L'Almerico opened after 30 November (the date of dedication of the libretto) but before 15 December
1674 (GB-Lpro). The work ended with a theater of Glory. The composer's beautiful harmonies
were praised in the libretto.

 This set a path for the rest of Ziani's life. Intermittently active in Mantua in the 1680s and 90s, his final years (1700-1716) were spent as
Kapellmeister at the imperial court. The story of Semiramide as related by Moniglia had been set by Ziani's uncle, Pietr' Andrea, for SS. Giovanni

e Paolo as 1670/4.

1674/4 Diocleziano' Music attributed to Carlo Pallavicino
[DIOCLETIAN]
A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
im Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1674-12-11
& Dedicated to Diana de Tiange, Duchess of Nevers''
Oo In this tale of imperial Rome, the emperor Diocletian, who was victorious in many battles, returned

triumphantly to Rome to celebrate the incarceration of the Persian king Narses and the wedding of his
own daughter, Valeria, to the duke Galerius. Diocleziano opened on 11 December 1674 (GB-Lpro);'
its libretto was dedicated on the 10th. Owing to his lengthy stay in Dresden, Pallavicino had not composed
an opera for Venice in seven years. This work was well received and attended (GB-Lpro). Among its
highlights were anonymous musico cast as a generic castrato to represent the musical practice of the
East and a ballo (the second) for Persian prisoners whose feet were chained.

1674/5 Eteocle e Polinice' Music by Giovanni Legrenzi
[ETEOCLES AND POLYNEICES]
A dramma per musica Text usually attributed to Tebaldo Fattorini'TM
MM Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1674-12-13
& Dedicated to the Ladies of Venice

Eteocles and Polyneices/Polinesso, the sons of Ulysses, decided after their father's death to rule Thebes
in annual alternation. When the first proved unwilling to yield the throne, the second sailed to Argos,
where Adrastos offered him the hand of his daughter, Argeia, and a promise to help him regain his
kingdom.

Or This appears to be the work which opened on 13 December 1674 (GB-Lpro). It was to have four revivals,
the last in 1690. Like Diocleziano, Eteocle was well attended and well received (GB-Lpro). A note
to the reader of the libretto terms Legrenzi's music incomparable for its beauty [vaghezza] and mentions
the contribution of Gio. Battista Lambranzi's scene to an overall sense of the masterful. Among the
singers was a certain Maddalena, who was hosted by the marquis Guido Rangoni in the Palazzo Bragadin
(parish of Santa Marina).'

 The success of this work must have been gratifying for the Vendramin (the owners of San Salvatore),
who had entertained thoughts of letting it for ten years to the impresario Francesco Bembo for the

Enea in Italia Music attributed to Carlo Pallavicino
[AENEAS IN ITALY]

A dramma per musica Text by Giacomo Francesco Bussani
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With a battle and balli SORTING DATE: 1675-12-04~

Dedicated to Filippo Giuliano Mazarin Mancini, Duke of Nevers

The Trojan prince Aeneas, the son of Venus and lover of the Latin maiden Lavinia, was confronted
by Camilla and a tribe of Amazons. After the prince's son, Ascanius, fell in love with Camilla, his
enchanted Sword of Beauty became the weapon of his own destruction. The production featured a dance
of the Cyclops and a chorus of Sirens.

Enea seems to be the only new opera for which Dolfin could have sent a libretto to Johann Friedrich
on 2 December 1675! and the only opera which could have been closing at SS. Giovanni e Paolo around
23 January 1676 (GB-Lpro).' Curiously, however, no new works seem to have opened at any Venetian
theater during the preceding January or February. Enea was also produced in Genoa (1676) and Naples
(1677). A like-named work by Minato (set by Draghi with contributions by Leopold I) was performed
in Vienna (Neustadt) in 1678.

Underworld. The libretto for La divisione was dedicated on 4 December 1675. The first performance
must have occurred almost immediately, because Adone in Cipro (1675/4) was in production by the
19th and probably opened sooner. The lack of documentation for an extensive run, in light of many
accounts of its lavish staging, gives the impression of a celebratory court spectacle, produced once,'
instead of a dramma per musica performed on successive evenings for several weeks. Its purpose in
that role would have been to inaugurate the newly redesigned theater. Whatever the number of
performances, the size of the audience was clearly stupendous, for reports are legion.

7-500) Reports of the staging of La divisione, Legrenzi's first opera for Venice in seven years, are legion. In
Saint- Didier's account, the Four Elements opened into the palaces of Love (Amore) and Discord, but
these were themselves transformed into the Temple of Mars, which was surrounded by weapons of
war. He regarded it as the most entertaining sight I ever saw upon astage." Rangoni had completely
renovated the theater.'"* Corradi praised the sweetness of Legrenzi's harmonious notes and said that
his music drama would impart a melody of Paradise. Bonlini said that the work was admired for the
pure breadth of conception of the machines and scenery.!"> Riccoboni still recalled the work and its
spectacular staging in 1738. Other distinctions of La divisione were its great number of arias (90'")
and its eight cori.

t) In a review in verse, members of the cast of La divisione were identified by nicknames. Fabbri has
decoded them as Maddalenina del Rospigliosi (Giunone); Catina Foresti (Apollo); Antonio Rivani
(Cicolino; Giove); Caterina Angiola Botteghi'"' from Florence (Venere); Ippolito Fusari (Pluto);
Francesco Lotti from Lucca (Amore); Pietro Paolo [Scandalibene?] from Cremona (Discordia); Antonio
Fontana (Formenti; Saturn); Lucrezia del Dolfin (Cintia); and Alessandro (Lissandro) Moscanera
(Marte). The impressions made by the singers are described in verse, scene-by-scene.'!

Adone in Cipro Music attributed to Giovanni Legrenzi
[ADONIS ON CYPRUS]

A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Matteo Giannini'
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Advent (Novena)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1675-12-19

Dedicated to Cesare and Alessandro Calimero!!

The text, based on Ovid's account of Venus and Adonis, departs from its model to concentrate on the
jealousy of the Cypriot princess Dorisbe. The work opened with a chorus of instrumentalists and
nymphs in the atrium of the palace of Amore, where a banquet was in progress. On the frontispiece
of the libretto, these figures were seated with four male figures on the left and four female figures on
the right. Books that appear to contain music lay open in the foreground. A sinfonia di stromenti followed
the song of two nymphs.

Adone was reportedly first performed in Venice on 19 December 1675 (Gb-Lpro).' All three versions
of the libretto were dedicated (by Francesco Nicolini) on the preceding day.' St. Stephen's openings
were necessarily avoided in 1675-1676 because of the papal jubilee, which kept the theaters closed
from 26 December until 8 January (GB-Lpro).

The libretto suggests that Giannini's text was originally composed for Vienna. In Venice it was at first
rejected by the censors.'* The present work included anonymous changes attributed without authority
to Giannini. The differences between US-LAu 215 and the other libretti cited here are substantial. This
version has a long and somewhat caustic dedicatory preface! plus an elaborate list of supernumerary
parts (for nymphs and shepherds, the Three Graces, attendants, warriors, soldiers, hunters, demons,
tritons who play instruments, and sirens who sing). It says that operas are not composed for those who
pluck feathers'** nor for idiots who row boats or weigh caviar.

Arias in I-MOe, Ne, Re, Rvat, Vqs
Listed as Galvani SSal 24; Bonlini 145; Groppo 148; Alm 206, 207, 215

" Dott. Giannini was from Modena; his involvements with opera were few. The Venetian Tebaldo Fattorini is credited with revising this libretto,
and Galvani (Zeatri, p. 89) maintains that little of Giannini's text survives.

Germanico sul Reno Music by Giovanni Legrenzi
[GERMANICUS ON THE RHINE]

A dramma per musica Text by Giulio Cesare Corradi
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli and a giuoco SORTING DATE: 1676-01-28

Dedicated to Luigi Grimaldi'?'

At the height of the military leadership of Germanicus, the Roman Empire had flourishing provinces
between the Elbe and Rhine Rivers, with capitals in Cologne (for the northern province) and Mainz
(for the southern). The story related here, adapted from Tacitus and concerned with the excessive brutality
of the Germanic tribal leaders Arminius and Segestes,'* took place in Cologne and culminated in the
coronation of Germanicus. (Arminius later ambushed several legions, and the Romans were forced
to withdraw to the left bank of the Rhine.)

Germanico was first performed on 28 January 1676 (Gb-Lpro).' The libretto had been dedicated the
preceding day. Germanico opened with an elaborate introduzione. A chorus of Hours, Days, Months,
and Years was assembled in the Palace of Time.'* Military Glory and Eternity flanked Time, which
was a globe of the Earth. Altogether there were eleven individual roles, nine choruses of mute
characters, and a specter of Orpheus. Among the incidental items were a ballo for [medieval] tribal
soldiers and a game (giuoco) for gladiators.

At its opening Germanico was received with full satisfaction.'*' Legrenzi was praised in the libretto
for providing unmatched variety and bizzarria. The agent reporting to the British resident in Venice
wrote that, The author [Corradi], having dedicated his work to the prince of Monaco, has been
generously recognized by him with a gold neck-chain of great value. (One week earlier the same agent
had written that the work would be sponsored by the Marquis Rangoni.) The cast included the soprano
Antonio Coresi and the tenor Giovanni Morselli.'* Between 1677 and 1680 Germanico was produced
in Milan, Reggio, Bologna, and Forli.

Score in I-MOe (probably from Modena, 1677); arias in B-Bc; I-MOe, Nc, Vqs

Listed as Galvani SSal 25; Bonlini 147; Groppo 150; Alm 211

Gallieno Music attributed to Carlo Pallavicino
[GALLIENUS]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1676-02-03~

Dedicated to Gio. Giacomo Farsetti, N.V.

The Roman emperor Gallienus [254-268 AD] fought battles on the Danube and the Rhine, where he
triumphed over the Goths. This account concerns his campaign in North Africa and shows his military
efforts to have been undermined by his susceptibility to amorous adventures. It was anticipated that
Gallieno would open by 31 January 1676 (Gb-Lpro), but since the 3 1st and 1 February were prohibited
