1676/3 Leonida in Tegea Music by Antonio Draghi; rev. attributed to M. A. Ziani'
[LEONIDAS IN TEGEA]
A dramma per musica Text by Nicold Minato
im Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1676-02-09~
@ Dedicated to Gio. Battista Strozzi'**
Oo The action here took place on the Peloponnesian peninsula, where Leonidas, a fifth-century king of

Sparta, and his wife Almira were unable to recognize one another because of the disguises they had
assumed. The libretto for the Venetian version of this work was dedicated on 9 February 1676. It had
been performed in Vienna (where Draghi was then the maestro of the chapel of Eleonora Gonzaga,
the empress) on 9 June 1670 for the birthday of Leopold I. An unusual feature of the music (probably
taken from the Viennese exemplar) was its scoring for six-part strings.'*

Oo Iocaste/Giocasta, the queen of Armenia, was secretly admired by Kyrenes/Cirene, the king of Assyria,
whose attempts to keep her captive failed. Disguised as a warrior, she escaped. Giocasta opened on
17 December 1676 (Gb-Lpro).' The original libretto (US-LAu 213) was dedicated on the preceding
day by Francesco Nicolini. A license to print it was issued on the 13th.'* The production seems to have
re-opened as soon as the papal jubilee (observed between 27 December and 10 January 1677) was
concluded (NV). An adaptation of the text by Stefano Benedetto Pallavicino (the composer's son)
provided the basis for J. H. Wilderer's score (Diisseldorf, 1696).' The work was considered by the
Mercure galant to have been a very great success and to have been full of accomplishments. The
scenery was superior, the machines admirable, the music perfect, and the performance
marvelous.'* One ballo was for painters.

1676/6 Giulio Cesare in Egitto Music by Antonio Sartorio'**

The conflict between Caesar's Rome and Cleopatra's Egypt in the first century BC provided the
background of this drama.'* Since Caesar led the Roman conquest into England, the choice ofan English
dedicatee here does not seem accidental.

XO) As the first opera of the season at San Salvatore, Giulio Cesare immediately preceded Antonino e
Pompeiano. A license to print the libretto was issued on 13 December 1676,'*' the libretto was dedicated
on the 17th, and an opening was anticipated by the 19th. However, the actual premiere was on the 26th
(NV), despite the fact that it fell on the cusp of the papal jubilee. The Aodit 1677 issue of Le Mercure
noted that the work was sung by the most excellent voices and that the production overall was no
less applauded than that of Antonino e Pompeiano by the same authors.'** Dolfin considered the work
superior and commended the performance of Margherita Pia (Rossina).'

1677/1 Elena rapita da Paride Music by Domenico Freschi'*
[HELEN ABDUCTED BY PARIS]
A dramma per musica Text provisionally attributed to Giacomo Fr. Bussani'
mM Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without known incidental items SORTING DATE: 1677-01-11
a Dedicated to Count Naimiro Conti'
 The abduction of Helen of Troy by Paris precipitated the Trojan War. This account highlighted Paris's

betrayal of the Trojan nymph Oenone/Enone and their infant son, who later became known as the
Shepherd of Mt. Ida.'* Elena rapita was the inaugural work for the Teatro di Sant' Angelo. Although
the theater's opening was said on 21 November 1676 to be imminent,' a license to print the libretto
was not issued until 27 December, by which time theaters and gambling houses were closed through
10 January for a universal jubilee (I-MOas A, NV). Four theaters (re)opened on the 11th.' This total
must have included Sant' Angelo.' Therefore 11 January 1677 appears to have been both the opening
date for the work and the inaugurul date for the theater.

 @&<*  Elenawas noted in the Mercure of the following August' for the magnificence of its sets. The beauty
of the voices of the very able musicians' who appeared in it responded perfectly to the profound
understanding of the excellent Sig. Domenico Freschi. The text was enormously popular, and the work
enjoyed settings over the next few years in Bergamo, Lucca, Milan, Modena, Verona, and Vienna as
well as Hanover before being revived in Venice (1687/2). The work was also translated into Dutch
and revised by Antonio Fiocco (Amsterdam, 1681).

1677/3 Il Nicomede in Bitinia Music by Carlo Grossi!
[NICOMEDES IN BITHYNIA]
A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Matteo Giannini
im Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)

& Dedicated to the Empress, Eleonora Gonzaga
oO Following Pierre Corneille's Nicomede (1651), Nicomedes, the king of Bithynia [northern Turkey],

was overpowered by Mithridates, the king of Pontos who was secretly supported by the Romans.
Nicomede had opened by the 6 February 1677 (I-MOas A); its libretto was dedicated on the 4th. In
the August 1677 issue of Le Mercure galant, Nicomede in Bitinia was rated most excellent, partly
on account of its delicate taste. Grossi's skills as an opera composer were said to be among the best
of that science.'* According to the libretto, the composer had studied every form of delight and
would give new attestations of his harmonic intelligence to the world with his new and bizarre
inventions. A prologue for Venus and Mars was added in the second version (US-LAu 224).

Antonino e Pompeiano Music by Antonio Sartorio
[ANTONINUS AND POMPEIANUS]

A dramma per musica Text by Giacomo Francesco Bussani
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1677-02-10

Dedicated to Johann Friedrich and Benedetta Henrichetta, the Duke and Duchess of Brunswick!

In Roman history of late second century, the degenerate tyrant Antoninus lusted after Julia, the wife
of Pompeianus, and schemed to imprison his rival. Pompeianus was saved by Publius Helvius Pertinax.
Antonino opened as the second opera on 10 February 1677 (GB-Lpro, I-MOas A). The dedicatees
had arrived by 23 January (NV) and Bassani thanked Johann Friedrich for accepting the dedication
on 12 February.'* The production was applauded in every respect by the British resident (GB-Lpro)
and found to be admirable in all respects in the Mercure galant, which reported that the proof of its
success was in the large audience that it drew.'*' Bussani's text was later set by C. F. Pollarolo (Brescia,
1689), Francesco Ballarotti (Genoa, 1695), and anonymously (Wolfenbiittel, 1709).'*? Antonino employed
the same cast as Giulio Cesare (1676/6). The balli were for Moors and heroic lovers.

Score in D-HVI; arias in I-Nc, Vqs
Listed as Galvani SSal 27; Bonlini 155; Groppo 158; Alm 225

[ARSINOE]

With balli SORTING DATE: 1677-11-29

The subject (perhaps suggested by Corneille) concerned amorous intrigues at the court of Arsinoe, the
queen of Cyprus. Although the libretto bears the dedication date of the 30th, Arsinoe opened on 29
November 1677 (GB-Lpro, I-NV).'* The work had opened in Bologna at the Teatro Formigliare on
26 December 1676.'*' With various revisions it was later performed in Innsbruck (1686) and London
(1705, 1707).

Oo The tyrant Anacreon usurped the throne of Cyprus, precipitating a series of conflicts between good

and evil which are recounted in this drama. Anacreonte opened on 2 December 1677 (GB-Lpro, I-MOas

 Sartorio mentioned in a note that the cast of Anacreonte included a Neapolitan mezzo soprano named

Francesco Grossi].' Pietro Dolfin reported that the landgrave of Hesse was occupying the box of the

of Jan Sobieski, the king of Poland) and an entourage of 150 as he traveled to Rome, where he was
to take up the post of Polish ambassador to the Holy See.

1677/7 Scipione africano' Music by Fr. Cavalli, rev. Gio. Bonaventura Viviani'
[ScIPIO AFRICANUS]
A dramma per musica Text by Nicold Minato, rev. Tebaldo Fattorini
MM Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Advent (Novena)
With balli and cori SORTING DATE: 1677-12-19~
& Dedicated to Ferdinando della Torre [Torriano], Baron of Taxis!

In Roman history, the courageous Scipio Africanus entered Africa and established a Roman province
there. This account emphasizes his relations with the conquered Carthaginians, whose leader, Hasdrubal,
was defeated by Scipio's forces. In addition to ten named characters and three anonymous ones (a sybil,
a cadaver, and a soldier), Scipione also called for ten cori, including one of singers and instrumentalists
and one of gladiators.

Or This resetting of Scipione, which had won great acclaim in Cavalli's setting of 1664, went into production
on or shortly after 19 December 1677 (GB-Lpro; I-MOas A, NV 'TM). The title-page was dated 1678.
Silvani's text for Sofonisba (1708/8) was indebted to that of Scipione. In the original production, and
apparently in this one, trumpets and violins played to prepare the audience for the amphitheater full
of spectators they would see when the curtain went up. The cast in 1677-78 may have included Giuseppe

1678/1 Medea in Atene' Music attributed to Antonio Giannettini!
[MEDEA IN ATHENS]
A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli
im Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With prologue and balli SORTING DATE: 1678-01-05~
& Dedicated to Gerolamo Fierenze Galenti'

This revival of 1675/3 was introduced by a prologue for five gods (including Pluto, Neptune, and Jupiter).
It retained the seven original roles, the part for a speaking cadaver, and the five cori.

 The libretto' was dedicated by the composer on 30 December 1677. The intended opening may have
been impeded by misadventure. On 5 January 1678 the noblemen Pietro Bembo and Girolamo Cornaro
were required to appear before the Maggior Consiglio to explain why masked, armed soldiers, allegedly
in their employ, had stopped an instrumentalist from entering Sant' Angelo and thus had prevented the
performance of an opera. This suggests 4 January 1678 as the intended opening date and 5 January
as the actual opening date. The run appears to have continued until 22 February, the last night of Carnival,
when a private ball was given in the Cappello palace (NV).?"!

i) Vespasiano was the inaugural work for the Teatro di San Giovanni Grisostomo, the phoenix of theaters,
according to its libretto, which was dedicated on 20 January 1678.2" The opening date was 24 January

Ow The production attracted a stupendous crowd on successive evenings and was found to be as beautiful
as it could possibly be (sommamente bella). The work involved six machines (including one of Apollo
on Mt. Parnassus), eight cori (including one of courtesans), three balli (including one of gamblers),
and several scenes of mock violence, including a rape and a fire. Trumpets were used in the sinfonia
of Act Two. The festa di ballo which took place on Shrove Tuesday attracted an overflow crowd (I-MOas
A).? The run concluded on 22 February 1678." Between 1680 and 1695, // Vespasiano had at least

1678/5 L' Aurora in Atene Music by Antonio Giannettini
[AURORA IN ATHENS]
A dramma per musica Text by Girolamo Frisari
1" Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1678-02-10~
e Dedicated to Antonio Grimani, N.V.
 In Greek mythology Aurora personified the dawn. She first noticed the hunter Kephalos/Cefalo, the

prince of Athens, shortly after his marriage to Procris. After he rejected her advances, she pronounced
a curse on him which was fulfilled years later when his javelin pierced his own wife as she, intent on
learning the identity of his secret love, pursued him through the woods. Only too late did she learn that
his secret love was for the morning breeze. The libretto for L Aurora was dedicated on 10 February
1678. The date is probably new-style because in 1678 a run could have lasted until the 22nd, while
in 1679 it would have had to end by the 14th. The audience (in 1678) is likely to have included the
duke of Mantua and the prince of Baden-Durlach, then the general of the imperial army (NV).

Sesto TarquinioTM Music by Giovanni Battista Tomasi!
[SEXTUS TARQUINIUS]

A dramma per musica Text by Camillo Badovaro
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1678-12-09

Dedicated to Ferdinand Carlo Gonzaga, Duke of Mantua

This account of the deeds of Sextus Tarquinius (compare to 1678/4) emphasized the brutality of his
military exploits. Sesto opened on 9 December 1678 and ran until c. 20 January 1679 (I-MOas A).
The libretto was dedicated on 5 December. A license to print il drama intitolato il Tarquinio was
issued to Francesco Nicolini, the impresario, on 6 December 1678.

As staged, the work contained singing roles for eight Romans and six Tuscans. It also employed some
twenty-three groups of princes, soldiers, and pages to represent the relative importance of each of the
major figures. One ballo was in the Armenian style. On 24 December Legrenzi wrote to Ippolito
Bentivoglio that the work lacked an enthusiastic response and that people spoke ill of both the poetry
and the music. At this point, he went on, it had had more than one performance for which only 30
or 40 tickets were sold. The cast was not bad, he added, but they did not sing up to the standard of
Cortona [Domenico Cecchi], who really sings well. For their appearances in two productions (this
one and J due tiranni al soglio, 1679/2}) at San Salvatore, Cecchi and Margarita Pio each received 400
gold pistoles, while Giulia Romana received 250, according to the Mercure. When the dedicatee left
Venice on 5 January 1679, he took Pio with him to Mantua.

 Sardanapalos, the last king of the Assyrians,* was dissolute in the extreme. After he abducted the
princess Armisia, his subjects, led by Armisia's beloved Arbakes, rose up against him. According
to the libretto for the first version, soldiers lighted pipes of tobacco from an on-stage lantern in one
of the baili. In the second version, the bal/i were eliminated and a prologue for Venus, Ceres, and Bacchus
was introduced. Sardanapalo opened on 10 December 1678. Publicity was in circulation by the 3rd
(I-MOas A). A license to print the libretto had been issued on 25 November. It was in print by 19
December, when Sartorio sent copies of it and the libretto from Sesto Tarquinio to Johann Friedrich.

1678/8 Il Nerone' Music by Carlo Pallavicino
[NERO]
A dramma per musica Text by Giulio Cesare Corradi
MM Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With concerti SORTING DATE: 1678-12-31
& Dedicated to Isabella Clara, Duchess of Mantua?*

The reign of the emperor Nero [54-68 AD], whose tyranny and self-indulgence had made him unpopular,
marked the end of the dynasty founded by Augustus. Nero had been instructed in music and art by Seneca,
who was later imprisoned. After the celebrated fire of Rome in the year 64, Nero built himself an
extravagant palace, the Domus Aurea on the Esquiline Hill. After having both his mother and his wife
murdered, he committed suicide. His reign was followed by civil war.

Ove One of Pallavicino's most celebrated works, // Nerone opened on 31 December 1678 (CO; I-MOas
A; NV).7 It had revivals in Genoa in 1681 and Naples in 1686. The cast included Giuseppe Maria
Donati (Giuseppino di Bavaria) in the title role, with Gio. Francesco Grossi (Siface) as Tiridates,
and Francesco de Castris (Lepido) in his operatic debut.?* Each singer was paid 1000 pistoles d'or

for the season. The staging involved 200 extras used as soldiers, two elephants to pull Nero's chariot,
and a horse for Tiridates.

 ws An extended commentary in the Avril 1679 issue of Le Mercure galant praised the sumptuousness
of the symphony, musicians, decorations, and machines and included one aria. To emphsize the
emperor's legendary love of music, the work opened with a concert of numerous instruments. Nerone's
depiction of an accademia di strumenti (including recorders, trumpets, drums, and members of the viol
and violin families) became an often cited but misleading proof of the lavish instrumentation of
Venetian operas. What it actually documents is opulent staging rather than customary orchestration.

According to the Mercure, Nero presented a superb feast in a grotto covered with clouds. Instrumentalists
played from all the recesses of the grotto....In the middle of the feast, Nero's palace was besieged....A
huge battle, lasting half an hour, took place. Nero ordered that a symphony be given immediately. It
was presented on a rotating machine which emerged from the entrance to the palace and appeared to
become larger as it approached [the audience]. As the clouds cleared, recorders, trumpets, timpani,
viols, and violins were revealed. They were joined by the regular orchestra to produce the most beautiful
and melodious [performance] one has ever heard.TM"' Other entertainments within the accademia included
the singing of Nero and the staging of a comedy (Act III, Scenes 2-7).* Pallavicino was praised in
the Mercure for a manner [of composing] that was as galant as it was spiritual.
St. Didier's account is also engaging. He says that Nero presented Tiridates with a Roman circus. The
triumphal chariot of the emperor and empress was pulled by an elephant. The movements ofits head,
trunk, and eyes convinced the Armenian that it was alive, but no sooner had the pair stepped down than
skin segments of the elephant were transformed into the shields of emerging gladiators.

The subject, possibly following Racine, was from Persian history. A fter conquering Persia, Alexander
the Great turned his attention to Sidon and Tyre, two cities on the coast of Phoenicia, just as the young
king Eumenes was attracted to the learned but lascivious Taide (much praised by the poet Menander).

Alessandro Magno opened on 7 January 1679, when it was described as most beautiful (I-MOas A).
Ziani's work was restaged as La Virti sublimata dal Grande in Naples (6 November 1679) and Venice
(1683/8). The Mercure commented on superb decorations and on the use of live horses which pulled
carriages in one scene and were mounted by cavaliers in another. Apollo and the nine muses descended
from Heaven in a machine which took up the full width (toute la face) of the stage and, taking a cue
from J] Nerone, offered an admirable symphony. The first bal/o was danced to this sinfonia. In the
second interlude, gladiators fought with two lions which had escaped from the serraglio.

I due tiranni al soglio Music attributed to Antonio Sartori
[Two TYRANTS ON THE THRONE]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1679-01-21

Dedicated to Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor

The western emperor Valentinian II [d. 392] sought an alliance with the eastern emperor Theodosios
I (subsequently his brother-in-law) in order to strengthen his hand against the Parthian Osroes, the brother
of the king of Persia. This alliance produced the monster with two heads to which the title alludes.
(The symbolism also resonates with the Hapsburg coat-of-arms, which featured a two-headed eagle.)
I due tiranni opened on 21 January 1679 (I-MOas A). The libretto was dedicated on the 15th. Legrenzi's
letter of 24 December (1678) indicated that the producers had high aspirations for the work.? The work
was produced in Palermo in 1686.

According to Le Mercure, Sartorio was one of the most adventurous composers in Italy. The performers
were the best one could find anywhere. This work made use of numerous machines, one of which
provided a firmament of stars in the manner of a palace of the gods. People peered at them from
balconies. The correspondent estimated that this machine alone could not have been constructed for
less than 2,000 ecus. Cortona [Domenico Cecchi] and Margherita Pio were each paid 400 pistoles
for two months of performances. Giulia Romana received 250 pistoles.*!

Listed as Galvani SSal 31; Bonlini 169; Groppo 172; Alm 243

Oo InGreek legend, the sorceress Circe possessed a potion that could turn men into swine. The concentration

on her powers of enchantment may have been welcomed after the emphasis on Roman history in
Sant' Angelo's previous production, Tullia superba (1678/4). This work established sorcery as a signature
theme at Sant' Angelo. La Circe opened soon after 21 January 1679 (I-MOas A) but not before the 23rd
(the date of dedication of the libretto), which was the opening date of Carnival. Reports of a 1682
revival cannot be substantiated.* The Venetian production was preceded by such lavish praise for
a prior performance in Vienna that this production could not have failed to disappoint its audience.

1679/4 Le amazzoni nelle isole fortunate Music by Carlo Pallavicino
[THE AMAZONS ON THE FORTUNATE ISLANDS]
A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Maria Piccioli?*
= Performed at the Villa Contarini (Piazzola*') SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With a prologue, cori, and balli SORTING DATE: 1679-11-11
ia Dedicated to Marco Contarini?**
 The Amazons of Thermodon, led by their princess, Pulcheria [Beauty], went to the Fortunate Islands

in order to subjugate Sultan, the king of Ethiopia. Sultan's captain, Anapiet, imprisoned Pulcheria.
Her cohort attempted to free her. The inaugural work for Contarini's private theater in his villa on the
River Brenta was performed on 11 November 1679, just before the nobility returned from villeggiatura
to the city. The libretto was dedicated on the same day; a license to print it had been issued on 24 October.
The work had had three performances by the 18th. Many nobles who had come to Piazzola for the
premiere remained for these and later performances (I-MOas A), perhaps because they were required
to operate machines in the production.

Ow The libretto gives an elaborate account of the work. It contained a prologue for Ingenuity (mounted
onan eagle), Difficulty (on a ostrich), and Fear (on a peacock). There were four female roles (Florinda,
Auralba, Jocasta, and Cilene) besides that of Pulcheria, plus the male roles of Sultan and Anapiet. The
goddess Juno appeared on a machine. There were crowd scenes (cori) for 100 Amazons (on foot), 100
Moors, 50 Amazons mounted on horseback, and miscellaneous pages, guards, and servants. One of
the most notable scenes (Act Two) featured an exhibition of military instruments. The duke of Mantua,
who attended the opening, is reported to have commented on the use of many theatrical machines of

1679/5 Ermelinda Music attributed to Carlo Fedeli?
[HERMELINDE]
A dramma per musica Text by Marco Morosini, N.V.2
MM Performed at the Teatro di Cannaregio SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
Without known incidental items SORTING DATE: 1679-11-23~
& Dedicated to Marco Contarini, N.V.?*
 The modesty of Hermelinde, the beautiful Anglo-Saxon wife of the young Lombard king Cunibert,

who reigned in the late seventh century, enabled her to regain the fidelity of her husband after he
dallied with her lady-in-waiting, Theodata. All of the action in this account hinged on a bath scene
involving Hermelinde and Theodata, whose beauty the queen later described to her husband.* The
inaugural opera for this small theater, Ermelinda opened shortly before 25 November 1679 (I-MOas
A). A license to print the libretto had been issued on the 10th. The work met with such a poor reception
that its poet  nicknamed the old Rooster (Galeno Antico)  became the subject of satirical verses.?*

262 Marco Contarini, the dedicatee, was the son of the sitting doge, Alvise Contarini. To judge from Saint-Didier's account of 1680, the doge's

of San Marco. The 183 opera scores that the Contarini collected for the library at their villa formed the Contarini Codices. In 1843 they were
bequeathed to the Marciana (National) Library in Venice by Pietro Canal, the last descendant of a daughter of Alvise Contarini.

?6 Carlo Fedeli (often called Sajon or Saggione) was an eminent player of the violone and violoncino. He had various ties with the Contarini
villa at Piazzola (where a version of Ermelinda by Piccioli and Freschi was produced two years later) up to his death (1685). His five sons
were all active musicians who traveled widely and worked, at various times, in England, France, the northern provinces of Germany, and Poland.

In Greek legend, Candaules was so eager to show off the beauty of his wife that he arranged for his

Oo Candaule opened between 25 November and 9 December 1679 (I-MOas A), when it was found to be
admirable, although a poor attendance was anticipated on account of the quarantine in effect at the
borders of the Republic (NV).?' It was the first music-drama to be given at San Cassiano since 1666.
Both versions of the libretto carry the title-page date 1680, but bibliographers group it with the autumn
season of 1679. Advent began on December 3. Morselli's text was set by Francesco Provenzale for
almost simultaneous performance (the libretto was dedicated on 21 December 1679) in Naples. It was
reset by Sarri for performance there in 1716.

1679/7 L'Alcibiade' Music by Marc' Antonio Ziani

Alcibiades was an Athenian statesman whose endeavors were considered to illustrate the dangers of
ambition. A follower of Socrates, he was assassinated in 404 BC. The work contained a substantial
pastoral element. The sculptor Praxiteles and his followers also figured in the plot.

Ow Alcibiade opened on the unlikely date of 21 December 1679 and enjoyed great attendance (I-Moas A).
On 30 December Francesco de Castris wrote that he had thus far performed four times in the production.?
The duke of Mantua undoubtedly attended a performance, for when he left Venice on 6 January he
said he had seen all the operas that are being performed (I-MOas A).' The work may have been
related to the spoken play Amor non inteso given in Reggio Emilia in the spring of 1679 with a musical
prologue in which Maria Maddalena Musi sang as Amore. Ziani's was given in Modena on 6 March
1685.7

i) The lascivious Valeria Messalina, although married to the emperor Claudius in the first century AD,

made a spectacle of her infidelities and ultimately committed suicide. Another of Pallavicino's celebrated
works, Messalina was first performed on 30 December 1679,* when it was found to be admirable.*!
The first version of the libretto, which had balli for pages and gypsies, was dedicated on 28 December
1679. The second version, dedicated on 8 February 1679 [M.V.], was somewhat more regal. It began
with a prologue for Eternity and Poetry and had three new balli, one of which was for the Rays of Apollo.
In both cases the title-page was dated 1680.7

 Messalina offers one of the best documented cases of rapid work alteration within the context ofa single
production. Two versions of the libretti, the intact score, and different sets of preserved arias suggest
continuous revision, even though the work is known to have had only this one production.

The 1680s: An Overview

n many ways, the 1680s represented a golden
ok decade for Venetian opera. The recent opening of

San Giovanni Grisostomo and Sant' Angelo greatly
increased the number of works produced. The increased
frequency of new productions brought seasonal definition
to the opera calendar and dramaturgical distinction to the
identity of each theater. It heightened competition. It
introduced a large number of young noblemen and women
to the phenomenon of opera. It brought increased status to
stars from nearby courts and new levels of competition
between theater owners for their services. Stage scenery was
described in respectful detail in many memoirs.

Much of this increase in activity was indirectly prompted
by the rise of the Holy League  a political alliance
supported by the papacy to redress the Ottoman penetration
of the Hungarian plains. The necessity of tactical planning
brought together representatives from many states and the
leaders of many ground troops (1683). The defense of
Krakow and Vienna against the Turks and paganism
(1684) raised the historical profile of Central and Eastern
Europe and the political power of the Polish ruler Jan
Sobieski. It placed Venice in the exalted position of coordi-
nator of military affairs, or so the Venetians believed. While
all official acts of alliance involved the Ducal Palace, many
of the most critical discussions took place in theater boxes
and at private entertainments.

In the first years of the decade, the Grimani tried to keep
the older SS. Giovanni e Paolo and the new San Giovanni
Grisostomo on an equal footing. Both theaters were host to
numerous works which portrayed the triumphs of military
leaders of antiquity by staging mock battles, by bringing
heroes and heroines onto the stage in carriages pulled by
prisoners of war, and by portraying palaces and their grounds
in exquisite detail. Many began or ended with coronation
scenes. Both theaters courted dignitaries from Saxony and
the Holy Roman Empire. Though new, humble Sant' Angelo
was, by contrast, a theater drawn to depictions of sorcery
and magic and to naval battles. The latter were drawn from
fictional elaborations of Greek mythology involving boats
bobbing on rough seas, shipwrecks, and pirates. Sant' Angelo
was, in short, a theater emphasizing the world-view of the

Venetian sailor. It was the most active theater of the decade
(Figure 21).

The Venetians made financial commitments to the
international cause that would be heart-stopping by today's
standards. A chief vehicle for replenishing its coffers was
to sell titles of nobility. New nobles, many of whom hed
grown rich through trade, were less accustomed to the
legends of antiquity than they were attuned to the exploration
of new territory. This affected the literature on which new
operas were based. Roman history remained fertile ground
at the Grimani theaters, as did Greek mythology at
Sant'Angelo. The subjects treated in other venues were
generally more frivolous. New currents stirred. Among the
most important were subjects from antiquity mediated by
recent French tragedy, on the one hand, and topics fashioned
from Teutonic, Slavic, and other Northern European
histories, on the other.

The 1680s saw the culmination of the careers of
Pallavicino and Legrenzi. There was a fundamental differ-
ence in the sources of their moral support: Pallavicino
divided his time between Venice and Dresden. He cemented
important links between the two musical establishments that
dated back to the long tenure of Heinrich Schiitz and his
contacts with Monteverdi. Legrenzi was heavily patronized
by the French and by Italian dukes with French sympathies.
Yet neither of these sets of involvements represented the core
alliances of the moment  with commanders, generals, and
field marshals who were primarily from German-speaking
lands. In terms of the music itself, it was generally San
Salvatore (whose patrons leaned to the French side of this
dichotomy) whose singers merited the highest praise. The
Grimani theaters scurried to recruit singers from the courts
whose leaders it sought to attract. It excelled at spectacle.

The increase in the number of productions brought great-
er formality to the collective profile of productions. The four
major theaters went head to head with openings immediately
after Christmas. They presented roughly comparable numbers
of works. As competition escalated, the more marginal
theaters spread out into earlier and later periods of the
theatrical year, with openings in late November and the
end of Carnival.

1680/1 L'Odoacre* Music by Giovanni Varischino!
[ODOVACAR]
A dramma per musica Text by Novello Bonis?
rT Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1680-01-04~
a Dedicated to Leonida Zarabella, Noble of Padua

OOo In the annals of Roman decline, the Ostrogothic chief Odovacar, king of the Heruls/Eruli, deposed the
last indigenous emperor in 476. He then made a pact with the Eastern emperor Xenon/Zeno. Odovacar
conquered Dalmatia, which by 1680 had long been a territory of the Venetian Republic. This account
stressed his Roman encounters and the subsequent opposition of Theodoric, the Gothic king of Italy.

' Varischino was Legrenzi's nephew.
? Bonis was a Venetian dramatist.

Groppo (MS, p. 95) points out that a third version of the libretto lacked mention of the theater and was dedicated to Pietro Pisani and Pietro
Contarini (on this, see the note for Tomiri, 1680/4).

The events related are similar to those recounted in Genserico (1669). Prior to the invasion of Italy, the Heruli and the Goths both held territory
north of the Black Sea.

Sabine opened on 17 January 1680 (CO; I-MOas A). It had been greatly anticipated (CO) but the

engaging another composer to set the third act.' The duke of Mantua remained in Venice after the
departure of his family in order to see the premiere (I-Rvat A, NV).

presented twelve Roman abductors, whose deeds are suggested in an incision in the libretto. The first
few performances were well received because of the work's marvelous machines, beautiful scenery
and costumes, and the participation of the best musicians that exist (CO), but on balance the work
was not a success. // ratto was replaced by a revival of J/ Vespasiano (1680/3; I-MOas A).

son in the line of succession if she would marry him. She responded by promising to marry the most
ferocious of her captains. This proved to be Nicomedes.

of the colossal Baroque mentality in Venetian opera. It featured twenty cori, 100 damsels, 100 attacking

soldiers, 100 mounted men, 40 footmen, six mounted trumpeters, six drummers, six standard-bearers,
six herald trumpeters, six players of flauti grandi, twelve young girls (cittelle) playing Turkish
instruments, five others playing in a concerto di flautini (recorder consort), six more playing harpsichords,
six pages, three sergeants, twelve hunters, twelve stable boys, seven coachmen for the victory scene,
and six others positioned along the thoroughfare.

The production involved two lions, led by two little Turks (turchetti), two elephants, led by two more
little Turks, four horses to pull Berenice's victory chariot, twelve horses to pull the six carts of prisoners
and spoils as well as six chariots in the general milieu (corso). A wild boar was pursued in a hunt in
Act One. At the end of Act Three, a globe opened into a machine to introduce Rapparini's patriotic
operetta, called II cittadino amante della patria overo il Tello, which consisted of a prologue and three
acts, all very short. (See Illustrations 8-11.)

The Mercure, which devoted much attention to Piazzola, noted that Berenice was performed from
six until eleven.* In comparison to Le amazzoni, which had been given in the preceding year, the
Mercure reported, Berenice surpassed it greatly for the magnificence of the entrees and for the richness
of the costumes.... Everything in this opera was different from what was used for the opening of Le
amazzoni. Thus there were new costumes, new scenery, and new musicians.?! On account of its
incomparable quality, the new production drew the majority ofnobles from Venice and many other
places (I-Rvat A). It continued in production, after feste di dame on the 9th and 10th, for approximately
two weeks.

 As originally envisioned by Marco Contarini, his cycle of festini would last for eight days. He offered
each attendee a room in his huge palace for 400 /ire for the duration of the cycle.*> During the week
ending on the 23rd, when the work was now termed famous, the production came to an abrupt halt
when an overhead storage room for the horse-drawn carriages collapsed. This destroyed the carriages
and frightened the horses (I-MOas A).TM It also damaged the theater (I-Rvat A). By its instant fame,
however, Berenice completely eclipsed the autumn theater season in Venice.

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1680-89) 145

The text for this revival of 1679/4 was undedicated. The heroic image of Amazon warriors was
continuously growing, perhaps partly in response to the original production. This performance of Le
amazzoni marked the first anniverary of Contarini's private theater. The scale on which it was produced
was again colossal, although the performance, at three and one-half hours, was much shorter than that
of Berenice (1680/6). Its participants were described as 300 actors  100 Amazon women, 100 men
disguised as Moors, and 50 mounted men, with the balance made up of other extras. At its conclusion
acarriage entirely covered with gold embroidery was pulled onto the stage by six of the most beautiful
horses ever seen. The performance was universally applauded.

This revival of 1671/4 is likely to have opened during early December. In the previous decade openings
at SS. Giovanni e Paolo had generally preceded those at San Salvatore by a few days. The libretto's
designation as an autumn work would preclude an opening after Christmas.

Irene e Costantino' Music attributed to Antonio Giannettini
[IRENE AND CONSTANTINE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Andrea Rossini*
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1680-12-13

Dedicated to Giovanni Battista Mora, N.V.

Constantine VI ruled the Eastern Roman Empire under the regency of his mother, Irene, from 776 until
1790, after which she was deposed. She was recalled as joint ruler in 1792, but Constantine won great
disfavor for his ruthlessness, divorce, and remarriage (795), whereupon Irene reclaimed the throne.
Constantine's dissolute life and misdeeds are portrayed here. Jrene was reported to have opened
admirably on the 12th (I-Rvat NV) or 13th of December 1680 (I-MOas A). The title-page of the libretto
is dated 1681. A ballo in Act I featured women at their bath, offering one example of the provocative
nature of the operas performed during this year.

Listed as Galvani SSal 33; Bonlini 183; Groppo 186; Alm 263, 264

gentlewomen dressed as Amazons (I-MOas A, Busta 5273 [olim 118], entry of 21 February 1682).

Pompeo Magno in Cilicia Music by Domenico Freschi
[POMPEY THE GREAT IN CILICIA]

A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1681-02-08

Dedicated to Francesco Vendramin, N.V.

The victories of Pompey brought Roman rule to lands previously governed by Greece. Pompey passed
through Cilicia (part of the present Turkish mainland north of Cyprus) en route to Antioch, where he
established Syria as a Roman province in 64 BC, and Judaea, which became a Roman dependency.
In contrast to Minato's text for Cavalli (1666/8), Pompey's defeat of the corsairs was emphasized.
Pompeo Magno was in progress by 8 February 1681 (I-MOas A) and may have opened earlier, since
its libretto had been dedicated on 22 January 1681. Aureli's dedication praised the marvelous and
singular music of Don Domenico Freschi and the skill of the impresario, Francesco Santurini. One
innovation in Pompeo was the use of a ballo to accompany the raising of the curtain. The opening scene
depicted slaves of various nationalities in the harem of Selinunte, the extrovert Greek ruler of Sicily.

1681/5 L'Olimpia vendicata Music by Domenico Freschi
[OLYMPIA VINDICATED]
A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli
rd Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1681-11-28
& Dedicated to Anton Ulrich, Duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbiittel!
 In this fanciful libretto (based on Ariosto's Orlando furioso), the Dutch princess Olympia fell in love

with the Irish king Obert. The ballo in Act I involved four ibernesi and concluded with a debate between
two boatmen and two boat-builders. The ballo in Act II featured six fishermen smoking pipes on the
shore of a lake. This production opened on 28 November 1681. The libretto for Olimpia had been
dedicated on the 20th. The duke had arrived during the week ending 8 November and was feted by
the Venetian government on the 24th. The last performance was on 3 January 1682 (I-MOas A).

OF The Florentine agent Matteo di Teglia, informing the Medici court of activities in Venice during Carnival,
singled out this work for its great attendance (gran concorso) and for the presence of the dukes of Mantua,
Wolfenbiittel, and Brunswick. In a report of the 29th the same correspondent labeled exorbitant
the expense of making musicians and singers of the first rank come here, not to mention the sumptuous
costumes and scenery that the owners of the theaters provide to compete with each other. Scarlatti's
setting of the same text had its premiere in Naples on 23 December 1685. When it was given there,
first at the Royal Palace and then at the Teatro di San Bartolomeo, this work was described as famous
and cited for the great exquisiteness of the performers and...the beauty of the scenery.

1681/6 Flavio Cuniberto" Music attributed to Gian Domenico Partenio
[FLAVIUS CUNIBERT]
A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
im Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1681-11-29
& Dedicated to Carlo Vicenzo Iovanelli'

The tyrant Flavius Cunibert, the Lombard king of Italy in the late seventh century, fell in love with
Theodata, the daughter of his councillor Hugo. He despised his virtuous wife, Hermelinde, whom he
eventually murdered. Much of this drama hinged on the affairs of his councillor Lothar, who was stabbed
by an unknown agent later shown to be the son of Hugo.

Ooo Flavio Cuniberto opened on 29 November 1681 (I-MOas A). The final performance was on 6 January
1682. Initially it was received with complete satisfaction (I-MOas A). The original cast featured
Domenico Cecchi (I] Cortona) in the title role, with Lugretia Fichiboni (Ermelinda), Giuseppe Canavese
(Lotario), Antonio Fontana (Formenti; Ugone), Margarita Salicola (Emilia), Clarice Gigli (Teodata),
Francesco de Castris (Guido), Tomaso Boni (Bleso), and Paolo [Pietro Paolo Scandalibeni?] (Vitige).

OR At the end of one performance (apparently that of 21 December), the final curtain was dropped before
all the performers had left the stage. The wooden beam from which it was suspended fell, injuring the
famous singer Domenico Cecchi (Il Cortona) on the head, and apparently caused a concussion. It
also injured an unidentified cantatrice on the shoulder. Cecchi was unable to continue in the title role.
Clemente Hader (Clementino), an English singer who had recently left Venice for an engagement
in Vienna, was summoned to return as a replacement. Upon his arrival in Venice he was refused
permission to perform ona public stage (I-Rvat NV). After giving private recitals for the duke of Mantua
and the prince of Brunswick, he set off once more for Vienna. Someone originally cast in a lesser role
took Cecchi's part. Cecchi was still recuperating on 3 January [1682].

- A revised version of the text set by Scarlatti was performed in Naples on 13 November 16887! and at
Pratolino (Florence) on 6 September 1702. The text for Handel's setting (Flavio, re di Longobardi;
HWV 16) of 1723 diverged from Mancia's Roman setting of 1696.

Il PausaniaTM Music by Giovanni Legrenzi
[PAUSANIAS]

A dramma per musica Text by Girolamo Frisari
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
Without known incidental items SORTING DATE: 1681-12-06

Dedicated to Giovanni Battista Mora, N.V.

The fifth-century Spartan ruler Pausanias, commanding the fleet ofan allied Hellenic League, captured
Byzantium. Although disliked for his boastful nature, he escaped punishment several times and eventually
become the object of a hero-worship cult. Although this account showed his weakness to be his love
for Erinda (daughter of the king of Argos, who had been promised to Pausanias's brother, Eumenes),
its visual representation emphasized power (Illustration 13).

The libretto dedicated on 8 December 1681 (US-LAu) may have been a revised version, since the first
performance is reported to have occurred on the 6th (I-MOas A). The production was suspended from
28 December through at least 3 January [1682] because of the fever and laryngitis of the prima donna
Margaritina' (I-MOas A; Rvat NV); the cast is otherwise unknown. When the work was produced
in Parma in 1692, the singers included Giuseppe Scaccia (Pausania), Fr. Antonio Pistocchi (Eumene),
Carlice Beni (Erinda), Elena Garofalo (/drena), and Diamante Scarabelli (Rosaura).

Ina season of productions dominated by images of power, Pausania marked the high-water line. The
hero, undoubtedly intended to represent the might of the Venetian Republic, was drawn to gigantic
proportions in the frontispiece of the libretto.

Arias in B-Be; D-B; I-Rvat, Tn (prima opera...1682), Vnm, Vqs

Listed as Galvani SSal 34; Bonlini 190; Groppo 193; Alm 271

Bassiano Music attributed to Carlo Pallavicino

ovvero II] maggior impossibile possibile*
[BASSIANUS, OR THE MOST IMPOSSIBLE THING MADE POSSIBLE]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
Without known incidental items SORTING DATE: 1681-12-08

Dedicated to Prince Josef Karl Lubomirski*!

Septimius Bassianus was the original name of Caracalla, the co-emperor of Rome (with his brother
Geta) from 198 to 211; he ruled solo from 211 until 217. The glory and military might of ancient Rome
were proclaimed here. The work opened in the salon of a Roman academy. The contrast between Greek
power as portrayed in Pausania and Roman power as portrayed in Bassiano could not be more striking.
Bassiano opened on 8 December 1681 (I-MOas A). At the end of November it had been reported that
Prince Lubomirski wished to remain in Venice for Carnival, but his mother (the queen of Poland) refused
to make available the funds he considered necessary for the purpose (I-Rvat NV). This may have
contributed to the appearance that the staging of this opera in his honor failed to achieve its intended

letters in I-Fas, [6 and 20 Dicembre 1681], from Alessandro Guasconi to the Florentine Luca degli Albizzi). Legrenzi, who was said to be
busy putting on the commedia at San Luca [i.e., the opera at San Salvatore], was expected to have grand pretentions (and thus higher salary
requests) if approached about setting an opera for Pratolino. Guasconi had been instructed to offer such a commission.

1682/1 Antioco il Grande Music by Giovanni Legrenzi
[ANTIOCHOS THE GREAT]
A dramma per musica Text by Girolamo Frisari

Antiochos Epiphanes [280-261 BC] consolidated the Seleukid empire but failed to incorporate Egypt
into it. He allowed the worship of Yahweh to continue in Jerusalem. In this work Ptolemy, seeking
peace with Antiochos, offers his sister Cleopatra in marriage. The cast included the now recuperated
Domenico Cecchi (II Cortona), Tomaso Boni, and Francesco de Castris.

 The opening of Antioco was anticipated on 3 January 1682 (I-MOas A), but Flavio did not close until
the 6th; the libretto had been dedicated on 17 December 1681. Antioco closed before 20 January,
possibly because de Castris was appearing both here and at SS. Giovanni e Paolo in what were more
or less simultaneous runs (see 1682/2).

This abbreviated revival of the work set by Draghi for performance in Vienna (1670) had been repeated
at the Teatro ai Saloni, Venice, in 1671 (Suppl. 7). According to Ovid, Ligdos, as he set off for battle,
instructed his pregnant wife Telethusia to give birth to a son. To hide her shame for producing a daughter,
Telethusia raised Iphis as a male. His/her actual gender was discovered when, having reached maturity,
he/she was betrothed to Ianthe, who was also fancied by an army general. The work was set in Candia.*!

1682/5 Carlo, re d'Italia Music attributed to Carlo Pallavicino
[CHARLES, KING OF ITALY]
A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
im Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1682-01-20
a Dedication to [the goddess] Fortune

In this largely fictional account, Carlo III [879-888] was called The Fat because of the four crowns
bestowed on him which he lacked the intelligence to manage. The work opened in a tomb, where Cyrene
was trying to bring to life a cadaver through magic incantations. The cast featured twelve singers, eleven
Roman gods, the cadaver, and thirteen groups of mimes. In the final scene of the work, the four alchemical
elements  Earth, Air, Fire, and Water  were depicted.

@ Carlo opened on 20 (I-MOas A) or 21 (NV) January 1682, with the princes of Brunswick and Mirandola,
and Lubomirski in attendance (I-Rvat A). The performance was generally applauded (I-Rvat NV).
Domenico Cecchi (Il Cortona) sang in the title role with Francesco de Castris (Rodaspe). Other
members of the cast were the same as for Flavio Cuniberto, with the addition of Anna Maria Manarini
(Cirene) and two unnamed singers.

 The battle between the Macedonians and Persians seems here to have been modeled on the Venetian guerra de' pugni, in which teams from

that over the neutral Rio San Barnaba) in a mock battle often staged at the behest of a notable visitor.

Temistocle in bando Music by Antonio Giannettini
[THEMISTOCLES BANISHED]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Adriano Morselli
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
Without known incidental items SORTING DATE: 1682-12-04

Dedicated to Ferdinand Carlo Gonzaga, Duke of Mantua!

Themistocles, an Athenian general of the fifth century BC, disguised himself as Emirenus of Egypt
before engaging Xerxes of Persia in a battle which resulted in his seeking asylum in Persia. The work
opened at the Hellespont. Temistocle was first performed on 4 December 1682 (M). The title-page of
the libretto is dated 1683. The libretto praised Giannettini's many arias enlivened by his singular virtue,
though in its continuation after Christmas Temistocle found little favor. Its run continued, however,
until 22 January 1683 (M). It appears that the singer Vittoria Tomi was promised 120 doppie to appear
at San Cassiano in 1682[-83]. As of 10 July 1684 she had still not been paid for her participation.'*!
The text was adapted by Giovanni Bononcini for the Teatro Capranica, Rome, in 1698. The later work
was widely circulated.

Appio Claudio* Music attributed to Giovanni Marco Martini!
[ApPIus CLAUDIUS]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Adriano Morselli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1682-12-15

Dedicated to Michel Amelot, Marquis of Gournay'

The popular consul Appius Claudius was one of the Roman decemvirate elected to draw up a code of
laws in the early years of the Roman Republic. In this tale from Livy, the ruler's lascivious interest
in Virginia led her father to kill him. Appio Claudio was first performed on 15 December 1682 (M),
when it was well received. The title-page of the libretto is dated 1683.

Bassianus Caracalla and Geta, the sons of the Roman Emperor Septimius Severus (193-211), shared
power for several years. This script concentrated on Bassianus's usurpation of the throne and violation
of the English princess Leucippe.' The opening of J due Cesari was announced for 20 December
1682. It was reported to have opened on the 19th (M), when it was found to be absolutely marvelous."
The title-page of the libretto was dated 1683. J due Cesari was revived in Milan in January 1688.'

 The performance was said to be replete with beautiful voices, and the decorations were des plus

 The work itself was criticized for improprieties and for its length (which is not considered pleasant
here). The first fault was considered incorrigible but efforts were made to remedy the second. The
production was temporarily suspended so that three singers  [Gio. Battista] Muzzi (Speroni),
[Clemente] Hader, and Ferdinando [Chiaravalle?]  could rest their voices for the Christmas Eve service
at San Marco. To perform at it was regarded as a much coveted honor among the virtuosi who sing
in the theaters here.""

 During the troubled rule of the emperor Tiberius [700-704], Flavius Liutbert [700-702] inherited the

throne of Italy as a child. His reign was manipulated by his tutor. The interests of France, Greece, and
Britain were represented here by other characters whom the librettist collectively described as those
both historical and added to history." Allegorical roles for Venus and the Roman spirit were added
in the revised version. JI re infante had its premiere on 10 January 1683 (M). The opening, originally
planned to occur immediately after Christmas, was delayed on account of the death, shortly before 19
December, of the countess [Ginevra] Manin, the wife of Gio. Carlo Grimani, a co-owner of the theater.'

participation of these singers.

1683/4 L'innocenza risorta, ovvero Ezio Music attributed to Pietr' Andrea Ziani
[INNOCENCE REGAINED OR AETIUS]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Adriano Morselli
im Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1683-02-06
& Dedicated to Alessandro Farnese, Prince of Parma'

In Roman history the captain Aetius/Ezio, who conquered Attila in France, was as emperor to be wrongly
accused of treachery against Valentinian [III]. After Valentinian's murder [454 AD], Maximus seized
control and married Valentinian's widow, Eudoxa/Eudossa.

CO L'innocenza opened during the week following 30 January 1683 (M), probably on 6 February, which
was the first day of Carnival. Le Mercure galant commented only on its scenery.'TM Its reception was
more enthusiastic than had been that of San Cassiano's previous offering, Temistocle (1682/7). One
of the singers had been brought by the dedicatee from Brussels and installed in a palace near San Lorenzo
(I-Rvat A). On 13 February the addition of the cantatrice from Reggio,'*> who was no less
accomplished in acting (fatezza) than virtuous in music, was noted (M). The work was produced in
Reggio Emilia (spring? 1683) under the title // talamo preservato della fedelta di Eudossa. Margarita
Salicola, who is likely to have been the cantatrice praised for her appearance in the Venetian production,
portrayed the widow. The cast also included Francesco Sarti Cottini (Valentiniano) and C. A. Riccardi
(Ezio).'* As retold in later works (e.g., 1698/4 and 1747/2) the story was based on different texts.

1683/5 Silla Music by Domenico Freschi
[SULLA]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Andrea Rossini
Vd Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1683-02-06

OOo Lucius Cornelius Sulla, a Roman military leader of the first century BC who was removed from command

in the conflict with Mithridates Eupator, incited a civil war in Rome. He was regarded by his opponents
as a dictator. Amorous involvements were emphasized in this account.'* Silla was first performed by
6 February 1683 (M). The libretto had been dedicated by the impresario Francesco Santurini on 4
February. Both Silla and Appio Claudio were received with beaucoup d'approbation.'* Both works
featured trumpet fanfares and the singing of Filanin, who in the arias with trumpet obbligato matched
his voice in an admirable manner."*! Silla, which was better received than Sant' Angelo's most recent
work, Appio Claudio (1682/9) (M), had a revival in Udine in 1699.

A No musical sources known

1683/6 Il Giustino Music attributed to Giovanni Legrenzi
[JUSTIN]
A dramma per musica'* Text attributed to Nicold Beregan'
I Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a balloTM and a battaglia SORTING DATE: 1683-02-07
i) Dedicated to Alessandro Farnese, Prince of Parma!*

Born a peasant, the Byzantine Justin rose through military ranks to a position of power during the reign
of the emperor Anastasios [491-518 AD]. This work opened with the wedding of the elderly Anastasios
to Ariadne, the widow of the late emperor Xenon. Upon Anastasios's death, Justin was proclaimed
the new emperor by the army.' A clever statesman, he was able to reinvigorate the ties between the
Eastern and Western Empires. Justin and his nephew Justinian'' were accused of killing the popular
Gothic consul Vitalian, whose ghost appeared in this work.

L'Orontea Music attributed to Antonio Cesti

This revival of the work, previously given in 1649, 1656, and 1666 (1666/2),'* was in rehearsal by

Falaride, tiranno di Agrigento Music by Giovanni Battista Bassani!*
[PHALARIS, THE TYRANT OF AGRIGENTO]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Adriano Morselli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Andrew's)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1683-11-29

Dedicated to Alessandro Contarini, N.V.'*

The argonaut Phalaris, who ruled Sicily for sixteen years [sixth century BC] was noted for his brutality.
In this plot it was matched by his sexual prowess. His ministers (among them the Moorish eunuch
Lenos/Leno) were called upon to execute his malevolent wishes. In the opening scene a female singer
exhorted Phalaris to enjoy himself. The closing scene took place in the harem (serraglio) to which his
concubines were confined.'

Falaride was first performed on 29 November 1683 (I-MOas A) with satisfaction (M). The title-page
is dated 1684. According to Antonio Predieri, the apparent impresario for this production, the dress
rehearsal (prova generale) on the 23rd caused great envy, as a consequence of which the text was held
to be too lascivious. A few words were then changed as a token gesture to the censors.' On December
4th Predieri reported that the work had been considered good enough (assai bene) at its opening,
while on the 12th he admitted that everyone spoke ill of it. However, he said that this did not hurt
attendance. On the 18th he reported that the newly opened Licinio (1683/11) was more lascivious than
Falaride. He expressed resentment towards San Giovanni Grisostomo (the large fish that eats the small
one).'! He also reported that La Romanina,' a member of his cast, was ill.

No musical sources known
Listed as Galvani SAng 14; Bonlini 213; Groppo 216; Alm 300, 301

In this medieval tale, the emperor Ludwig/Lodovico I [816-840, with interruptions] was deceived by

Lothar [820], who repeatedly attempted to impose himself as emperor.

Legrenzi's correspondence of the preceding spring indicates that the availability of the singers Giuseppe

declined. It must be on this account that the libretto was revised.'' By the 17th the audience had dwindled

L'incoronazione di Dario
[THE CORONATION OF DARIUS]

Music attributed to Domenico Freschi

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Adriano Morselli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without known incidental items SORTING DATE: 1684-01-04~

Dedicated to Lucio della Torre [Torriano], Count of Valsassina!

The death of King Cyrus of Persia left as contenders for the throne Darius, who claimed noble birth;
Orontes, who had a popular following; and Hargapos/Argapo, who enjoyed the support of the army.
Overcoming various plots and deceptions, Darius prevailed and won the hand of Stateira, the daughter
of Cyrus. Darius's coronation [522 BC] coincided with the beginning of Persia's great war with Greece.

This work was first performed on c. 4 January 1684 (M). The duke of Mantua gave permission on c.
18 December 1683 for a young trumpeter (putello trombetta) to go to Venice to perform in the second
work at Sant' Angelo. Once there, he was accepted into the service of the Malipiero family with many
obligations and was praised for his virtue. The singer nicknamed La Romanina remained ill, and
Predieri feared for her health.'' L incoronazione was to be revived at Sant' Angelo as Dario (1685/2).
Perti set the text for Bologna (1686) and Aldrovandini for Naples (1705). A revised version of the text
was reset in 1717 by Vivaldi (1707/3; RV 719) for Sant' Angelo.

Score in I-Vnm
Listed as Galvani SAng 15; Bonlini 217; Groppo 220; Alm 305

Ricimero, re de' vandali Music attributed to Carlo Pallavicino
[RICIMER, KING OF THE VANDALS]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1684-01-22~

Dedicated to Moritz Wilhelm, Duke of Saxony-Zeitz'

As the Roman Empire fell, the Vandals sacked much of Europe. Ricimer, a Roman general of Swebe
descent,' was raised to the rank of patrician in recognition of his successful defeat of the Vandals in
458. At the start of the reign of Libius Severus [461], Ricimer fell in love with the daughter of Valerian
III [425-455 AD]. Power eventually went to his head, and in 465 he murdered Libius. Ricimero is one
ofa series of works attempting to mine the history of the declining Roman empire for the purpose of
highlighting the contributions of German leaders to Italian survival. Among them, this was the first
work dedicated to a German. The parallel was prominent in the mind of librettists as the Holy League
crafted its strategy against the Turks.

During the autumn of 1683 a lot of publicity about the upcoming opera season was circulated. Many
singers were coming from Germany and, it was hinted, this would raise the quality of performance
significantly. As they began to arrive, it was also noted that the costs to the theaters would be greater
than in the past. The duke of Saxony arrived in Venice on 8 January 1684.'* An opening around the
middle of the month would have been likely but for the fact that the doge died on the 15th. The ducal
succession eclipsed carnival entertainments and the publicity that would normally have attended the
opening of a work by Pallavicino, who was the duke's Kapellmeister. The cast included two of the
duke's favorite singers  Margarita Salicola and Domenico Cecchi (Il Cortona), but the singer in
the title role has not been identified.'*!

No musical sources known'?
Listed as Galvani SGG 11; Bonlini 218; Groppo 221; Alm 306

Publio Elio Pertinace Music by Giovanni Legrenzi
[PUBLIUS HELVIUS PERTINAX]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro d' Averara'
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1684-01-22

Dedicated to Ferdinand Carlo Gonzaga, Duke of Mantua

By some interpretations, the demise of the Roman Empire began with the fall of Publius Helvius Pertinax.
He served briefly as emperor in 193 AD before being murdered by one of his Praetorian guards, who
then attempted to put the Empire up for sale. The focus here was on Publius's ascension by acclamation
after the murder of Lucius Commodus.

"8 Moritz Wilhelm served as a commander in the upcoming campaign against the Turks.

' The Swebes were a Germanic tribe of the early middle ages. The word was derived from the Middle High German verb to swim.

of people had succumbed to a fever. Only after the 29th, when the new doge, MarcAntonio Giustinian, was duly elected and inaugurated,
can there have been any significant activity in the theaters. The fact that this work's opening is not mentioned suggests that it was obscured
by these many other occurrences.

'! Other members of the cast corresponded to those in Licinio. See Caffi's notes (Joc. cit.) and in Saunders, Repertoire, p. 452.

This production was to open on 22 January 1684 (M), when a good reception was anticipated. The

still owed by the impresario Gasparo Torelli for the playing he had done for the rehearsals and
performances of two operas (this and 1683/10) during the preceding year at San Salvatore. The rate
of pay was high for an instrumentalist and suggests that Fedeli was the concertmaster at the theater.'**

L'amante fortunato per forza Music by Giovanni Varischino
[THE LOVER WHO WAS NECESSARILY LUCKY]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro d'Averara
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1684-11-29

Dedicated to Giulia Rangoni, Marchioness Ariberti'

Eumenes, the king of Pergamum, allied himself in the second century BC with Rome in its battle against
the common enemy Antiochos. Pergamum reached its cultural peak under Eumenes' rule. While not
hiding his disgust with the text, d' Averara reminded his audience of Varischino's much appreciated
score for Odoacre [1680/1].

L'amante fortunato is reported to have opened on 29 November 1684 (I-MOas A, NV), even though
the dedication of surviving libretti is dated 1' ultimo [30] Novembre 1684. Suspended for the Novena
of Christmas, the production resumed after Christmas and continued into the new year (M). In a note
to the discreet reader, d' Averara said his work was based on a French drama but suffered from both
translation to the Italian and adaptation to a musical setting. He said that in such an adaptation the
musicians want to have more songs (canzoni) than words and that not only the quantity but also the
character of the personalities is prescribed. Therefore, he concluded, he had to alter the invention,
intrigues, and almost all the episodes.

No musical sources known
Listed as Galvani SAng 16; Bonlini 219; Groppo 222; Alm 307

from Mantua; Ascanio Belli, Carlo Andrea Clerici, and Pietro Cesti from Parma).

Ariberto e Flavio,

regi de' Longobardi' Music by Carlo Ambrogio Lonati'TM*
[ARIBERT AND FLAVIUS, RULERS OF THE LOMBARDS]
A dramma per musica Text by Rinaldo Cialli'
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1684-12-26

Dedicated to Arnold [Aernout] Druyvesteyn, Secretary of Haarlem'

In Lombard history of the early eighth century, Flavius Aribertus II (here called Ariberto) cut off the
ears of the wife and daughter and pulled out the eyes of the son of his enemy, Flavius Ausprandus (here
called Flavio). Later realizing that he owed his life to this enemy, Aribert restored these members
and the rule of Ausprandus.'!

Ariberto was first performed on 26 December 1684 (M), despite its autumn designation.' The libretto
had been dedicated on 9 December 1685. The title-page gives the year as M.DC.LXXXV at the top
and M.DCL.XXXIV as a printer's date at the bottom. Cialli said of Lonati, a noted violinist, that
with the bow ofa musical instrument he has excited the soul ofan entire world. The production elicited
universal satisfaction as much for the exquisite voices as for the composition and. ..perfect operations.
The elector of Saxony was so impressed with the singing of Domenico Cecchi (Il Cortona)' that
he took him into his service, granting him a title of honor and a huge stipend (I-MOas A).

Massimo PuppienoTM Music by Carlo Pallavicino
[MAXIMUS PUPPIENUS]

A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1685-01-04~

Dedicated to the Empress Mother, Eleonora Gonzaga'TM

The Roman soldier Maximinus ascended briefly to the position of emperor [235 AD]. Vilified for his
brutality, he was removed in favor of Gordian, then consul in Africa. Gordian was killed within five
months, which paved the way for the ascent of Maximus Puppienus [236-238 AD]. The original work
included roles for Happiness and the Ghost of Gordian, while a revised version included allegorical
roles for Rome and Africa. Massimo Puppieno opened shortly before'** 6 January 1685 (M), probably
on the 4th (the theaters were closed on the Ist, 2nd, and 3rd), when it elicited universal satisfaction.

'8 Lonati was currently serving as a virtuoso to the duchess of Mantua.

had thus far refused to grant a permit to open the work despite the forceful entreaties (vive istanze) of the principals. On the 16th it gave the
impression that the work must have opened before the theaters closed for the Novena. Yet the report of the 30th tends to converge with that
of (M) in suggesting that the work opened after Christmas. Any pre-Novena performances may have been officially considered rehearsals.

Rodoaldo, re d'Italia Music by Domenico Gabrielli!
[RODEWALD, KING OF ITALY]

A dramma per musica Text by Tomaso Stanzani
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without known incidental items SORTING DATE: 1685-01-10

Dedicated to Ferdinand Carlo Gonzaga, Duke of Mantua

Rodewald, a mythical king of Italy, wished to marry his daughter to a potential successor. His choice,
an apparent peasant, surprised but suited Rodewald's subjects. This was the first fully staged opera
to be given at the newly restored Teatro Zane since 1677; puppet operas had been given between
1680 and 1682 (see Suppl. Sc). The libretto was dedicated on 10 January 1685. The production was
in progress by the 13th but did not satisfy anyone (M).'*

Penelope la casta Music attributed to Carlo Pallavicino
[PENELOPE THE CHASTE]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a prologue SORTING DATE: 1685-01-28

Dedicated to Georg Ludwig (Prince) and Ernst August (Duke) of Brunswick'

'%6 Griffin Doc. 82, entry of 28 Decembre 1685. Scarlatti's setting, also given at Leghorn in 1697, was published in a moder edition by Colin
Slim (The Operas of Alessandro Scarlatti, vy; Cambridge and London, 1979).

87 Domenico Gabrielli, an enormously inventive composer (1651-90) from Bologna, was a cellist and a pupil of Franceschini.

' Georg Ludwig (1660-1727) was the first-born son of Ernst August and eventual king (from 1714) of England. The Houses of Brunswick
and Hanover were supplying one-third of the troops used in the current Holy League campaign in Greece, which was designed to divert the
Turks from their assault on Hungary (Hanlon, Twilight, p. 164). The dukes of Saxony were officially received by the doge on 3 and 9 February
1684 [M.V.], the first date coincident with the opening of Carnival. Johann Georg III, the elector of Saxony (1680-91), spent all or most of
February in Venice. Fiirstenau (Geschichte der Musik, p. 277) dates the duke's visit from 15 January to 28 February. One report (M) indicates
that he was expected on the 29th but did not arrive until the 31st; avvisi place his arrival later (see 1685/5). One (I-MOas A) relates that he
arrived during the week ending 10 February and left on 10 March for Piazzola. He set off from there for Saxony within a few days.

168 A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

In Greek mythology Penelope, the wife who waited twenty years for the return of her husband Ulysses,
was considered a paragon of virtue for resisting the marriage proposals of numerous suitors. In the style
of courtly opera, Penelope's personal virtues were here highlighted in such allegorical roles as those
of Merit, Constancy, Valor, Glory, and Truth. There were also roles for Doubt, Suspicion, Fame,
Necessity, Politics, Suspicion, Arrogance, Forgetfulness, Earth, War, Imagination, and other attributes.
There were three editions of the libretto.

XO) Penelope opened on 28 January 1685, when it was universally applauded."' A revival with the music
of Chelleri at Sant' Angelo (1716/9) was a pale reflection of the original work and not well received.
Giuseppe Canavese sang as Ulysses. The roles of Elvida and Ariene were taken by Antonia Marzari
and Clarice Gigli respectively. Other male singers were Antonio Fontana (Formenti; Osimante),
Venturin (Lutetio), Domenico Milchiori (Gismondo), and Tomaso Boni (Gildo).

 The performance of Margarita Salicola in the title role was still remembered thirty years later, partly
on account of the events which followed. The elector of Saxony was so captivated by her singing that
he forthwith took her into his service with a title of honor and a huge stipend. Her travel was staged
as a kidnapping because she anticipated disapproval. She left Venice clandestinely, via Murano (with
the help of the Venetian nobleman Giovanni Molin), by boat to Piazzola, where festivities on 11 March
celebrated her future position with a performance. From there she traveled by coach to Dresden in the
company of the Mantuan agent Carlo Maria Vialardi (I-MOas A).?

The elector also reassumed Pallavicino into his service. The composer, in turn, recruited the sopranos
Domenico Cecchi and Giuseppe Milanese for the Saxon court. Not content merely with musicians
to establish a beachhead of Venetian culture in their midst, the Saxons also offered enormous stipends
to some gondola-makers to go to Dresden to introduce the use of these boats, particularly in the summer
on the Elbe.

- Scarlatti's setting of the same text was given in Naples around 13 February 1696 and continued until
the 27th. Starring Giuseppe Canavese, it enjoyed praise which exceeded that of all the other theaters
of Italy.5 The performance given at the Casa Corsini in Florence on 22 November 1705 could have
involved Pallavicino's music; it featured Margarita Salicola in the title role. The music is usually credited
to Scarlatti. Meanwhile, Perti had also set the text in 1696 for performance in Rome. Chelleri reset the
text for Sant' Angelo in 1716, but the work had a catastrophic production. Nonetheless, the long shadow
cast by the text reached into the nineteenth century through the operas of such composers as Cimarosa
(Naples, 26 December 1794, with later performances extending to St. Petersburg, 1817).

1685/5 Teseo tra le rivali Music by Domenico Freschi
[THESEUS AMONG HIS RIVALS]
A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli
im Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1685-02-04~
a Dedicated to Johann Georg III, Elector of Saxony

In Greek mythology, Phaedra/Fedra, the daughter of Minos, king of Crete, was given in marriage to
Theseus, who was already married to the Amazon queen Antiope.* Phaedra bore him two children.
Here four additional women were Phaedra's rivals for the love of Theseus. The work included a dance
for children in the temple of Minerva and other balli for pilgrims and for figures representing Phaedra.

 A revised version of the libretto was dedicated on 7 February 1685. The elector, expected on the 29th,
arrived on 31 January, and more Saxon royals arrived within the next few days (M). Aureli commented
in his note to readers on the fact that he was involved in two productions simultaneously. He noted
that he had accommodated this work to the needs of Sant' Angelo and called attention to the merits of
the scenery and the music of Freschi.

 While Tullius Hostilius, a legendary king of the Romans, was locked in battle with the Albans, his

daughter Marcia was abducted by Silvius and subsequently conceived Celius. Circumstantial evidence,
particularly from musical sources, points strongly to an opening shortly after 3 February 1685. Many
dignitaries were massing in Venice for military and political discussions. Duke Maximilian II Emanuel
of Bavaria was expected during the week following 3 February (M, Rvat A). The new French ambassador
arrived on the 8th (A). The Polish count could have traveled with the Saxon delegation (see 1685/5).

Gli amori d'Alidaura Music by Domenico Freschi
[THE LOVES OF ALIDAURA]

A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Maria Piccioli
Performed at the Villa Contarini (Piazzola'!*) SEASON: Summer (Assumption)
With cori SORTING DATE: 1685-08-05

Given in honor of Ernst August?!'

Alidaura, the daughter of the cavalier Arneste, wanted to become a vestal virgin until she fell in love
with Rosmondo, the son of the nobleman Brunoro, whereupon Rosmondo broke his engagement to
Celinda. Gli amori appears to have been the main work ina series of entertainments performed between
the 5th?' and the 10th of August 1685 (M).! The opening scene of Gli amori, an accademia di musica
featuring an ensemble of diverse instruments (coro di vari stromenti), was strongly reminiscent of the
centerpiece of Pallavicino's // Nerone. Instruments were woven into the action in several scenes, and
many couplets spoke of music or employed musical analogies. Alidaura herself played the spinet. Celinda
was accompanied by a chorus of young girls (fanciulle). The concourse of noble men and women in
attendance was said on the 11 th to have been incredible (M).?'* When he left Piazzola the following
week, the duke left a gift of 500 zecchini to all the singers in this group of works (NV).

This revival of 1681/4 involved the accompaniment of wind, string, and keyboard instruments. It was
performed on 7 August 1685 by the figlie of Piazzola's residential music school. A striking scene was
that in which the Queen of Fate descended almost to the proscenium on a machine connected to five
other machines which contained a total of 60 torches. Although the work was undoubtedly abridged,
the performance lasted for two hours.

Clearco in Negroponte' Music by Domenico Gabrielli
[KLEARCHOS IN NEGROPONTE]

A dramma per musica Text by Antonio ArcoleoTM
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1685-12-28

Dedicated to Giorgio Cornaro, N.V2

Klearchos/Clearco was an unpopular Spartan military commander of the fifth century BC who lost an
important battle to Persian forces. Here, as king of Thebes, he was locked in combat with Eurymedes,
the king of Corinth. Several readings are arguably relevant to political affairs of the time.?** Clearco
was in progress by 31 December 1685; the production continued from 4 January 1686 (I-MOas A).
It was revived as 1686/6. Scarlatti's setting of the same text was reportedly given in Naples on 21

December 1686. An anonymous setting (which is likely to have been closely related to this work)
was given in Mantua in 1688. Domenico Gabrielli's setting was presented in Reggio Emilia in 1689.
The libretto offered apologies for the theater's necessary restraints and other impediments reflecting
the austerity of the time as well as for incidents which departed from historical truth. It urged viewers
at least to admire the music of Domenico Gabrielli, whose Rodoaldo [1685/3] was so well received.
A painters' academy was the subject of one of the work's balli.

Prague (9141) and Ferrara (9142).

2 Antonio Arcoleo, a Cretan with a university degree, was the author of three opera libretti, of which this was the first.

23 Cornaro, also a member of the nobility of Candia (although the family name is distinctly Venetian), made his public entry as a procurator
of San Marco on 2 February 1685 (I-MOas A). According to the libretto, he was a physicist of renown.

24 The stage venues lay close to current interests, for the Venetians, through their involvement in the Holy League, were newly involved in
the Aegean; in 1687 they were to capture 15,000 Turks in Attica and Thebes. The port of Negroponte on the large Aegean island of Euboea
had been one of their strongholds in earlier crusades. Thebes was famous at the time for its silk, and Venetian traders regularly provided it
to merchants in the city.

1685/10 La Didone delirante Music by Carlo Pallavicino
[DiDo DELIRIOUS]
A dramma per musica Text by Antonio Franceschi
im Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1685-12-26~
is) Dedicated to Franz Anton, Count of Berka'

OO Dido, the legendary founder of Carthage, was so distraught when her brother killed her husband that
she flung herself onto the funeral pyre. In the partially fictional episode recounted in Franceschi's
libretto, the infidelity of Aeneas/Enea was emphasized. La Didone was in progress by 31 December
1685 (I-MOas A). Scarlatti's setting of an adaptation of the text was given in Naples on 19 May 1696.7"
This was a major production featuring mythological gods, a celestial cortege, and dancing monkeys.
Franceschi praised the perfection of Pallavicino's music, which he contrasted to the bareness (nudita)
of his own text. Purcell's Dido and Aeneas, performed at an English girls' school in 1689, was unrelated.

overo Giugurta" Music attrib. to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
