Jugurtha ruled the western part of Numidia in the second century BC, but after attempting to seize power
in the eastern part, which was ruled by Adherbal, he was executed. Noris described the plot as a caprice
of dramatic fantasy and claimed that the work begins happily, becomes serious, and [finally] heroic.
The ballo was for ghosts.

Oe The first version of this work was in progress by 31 December 1685 (I-MOas A) and probably opened

an unnamed work which had opened at Sant' Angelo on the preceding Thursday [29 December], reported
many improprieties in the production but also cited the merit of some of the singers. Early in
January Venetian authorities caused the production to be terminated because of its scandalous offense
to the Catholic religion.**' On 11 January 1686 the revised version of the libretto, now entitled Giugurta,

lost Salicola and Cecchi as cast members, it may have been intent on creating new distractions for the
audience. The cast had strong Mantuan ties: Clarice Gigli took the role of Psyche, with Barbara Riccioni
as Venus and Angiola [Angela] Salicola (the sister of Margarita) as Juno. Other singers were Carl' Antonio
Rata (Amore), Antonio Borosini (Zeseo), Gio. Battista Galon (Ercole), Tomaso Boni (Lesbo), and
Signore Salvador (Mercurio).

The production included six balli, one of which was for twenty-four little Cupids (amori) who, in
two groups, formed interwoven patterns as they circulated with lighted torches.' The depiction of
a School of Fencing and Dancing was singular but later much imitated. The work was also full of allusions
to Venetian spectacles, including those associated with Giovedi Grasso. In one scene Hercules conquered
a lion and a dragon, in another Jupiter mounted an eagle, and in another the flight of Love was
represented. Venus and Juno arrived in a carriage filled with doves.

L'amazzone corsara Music by Carlo Pallavicino

owvero L'Alvilda, regina de' Goti
[THE AMAZON WHO WAS A CORSAIR, OR ALVILDA, QUEEN OF THE GOTHS]

A dramma per musica Text by Giulio Cesare Corradi
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1686-02-04~

Dedicated to Francesco Duodo and Loredana Tron, NN.VV.24

The beautiful and virtuous Alvilda, the queen of the Goths, had refused matrimony with Alf, the king
of the Danes. Becoming a warrior instead, she had many adventures before Alf finally conquered her
with scorn (the true weapon for winning an obstinate woman, according to Corradi). This may have
been the most beautiful opera mentioned by the Mantuan agent Lorenzo Zanchi, in his report of 9
February 1685 M.V., as having opened within the past week. An imprimatur on the final page of
the libretto is dated 1 February 1686, but an opening before the 4th is unlikely. A note to the reader
of the libretto says that the composer, having already produced a miracle in the theaters, had now
produced a miracle of miracles. L amazzone opened with a trumpet fanfare." Alessandro Scarlatti's
setting of this text was given in Naples on 6 November 1689.

In legend the Thracian king Lycurgus, who decorated his gates with the corpses of those he had murdered,

Le generose gare tra Cesare e Pompeo Music by Domenico Gabrielli
[THE RIVALRY BETWEEN CAESAR AND POMPEY]

A dramma per musica Text by Rinaldo Cialli
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without known incidental items SORTING DATE: 1686-02-09

Dedicated to Maximilian Wilhelm, Prince of Brunswick?>!

The rivalry between Caesar and the consul Pompey in the first century BC was hardly friendly. Although
this plot involved their wives (Junia and Cornelia), militarism and heroism were underscored, perhaps
in homage to the dedicatee, who was an increasingly important commander of troops sponsored by
the Holy League. An imprimatur on the final page of the libretto is dated 9 February 1685, which is
the more veneto date of opening given by the Mantuan agent Lorenzo Zanchi. The title-page is dated
1686. Cialli praised Gabrielli's virtuous, bizarre, and spirited notes, which, with the harmonic chords
of his, tie his name to fortune and glory.

Listed as Galvani SSal 43; Bonlini 236; Groppo 239; Alm 328

1686/7 Zenocrate, ambasciatore a' macedoni' Music attributed to Pietro Porfiri2"
[ZENOCRATES, AMBASSADOR TO THE MACEDONIANS]
A dramma per musica Text attributed Marc' Antonio Gasparini?
Mr Performed at San Moise SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1686-11-29~
& Dedicated to Alvise Morelli, N.V.2
Ow Zenocrates, a philosopher of upright character, was the Calcedonian ambassador to Macedonia when

it was ruled by Philip in the third century BC. The excesses of the Macedonian court were alien to
Zenocrates, whom Philip considered to be mad. This production re-opened on 28 December 1686 (I-MOas
A), indicating that the work's premiere would have been given before the Novena of Christmas and
perhaps before the start of Advent, thus in late November. Many scenes appealed to customs of the
established Venetian nobility (the dedicatee was newly raised to this status). Among these were the
academy of cavalry exercises (Act One), the gallery for pictures, sculpture, and antiques (Act Two),
and the hunt in the hills (Act Three).

A Arias in F-Pn
Listed as Galvani SMoi 28; Bonlini 241; Groppo 244; Alm 335

1686/8 Elmiro, re di Corinto* Music attributed to Carlo Pallavicino
[ELMER, KING OF CORINTH]
A melodramma in musica Text attributed to Vincenzo Grimani
11 Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With intrecci and a combattimento SORTING DATE: 1686-12-26
rs) Dedicated to Domenico Orsini, Duke of Gravina?

Corinth, which controlled the isthmus connecting mainland Greece to the Peloponnese, was of crucial
military importance both in antiquity and at the time this work was produced. Peisistratos, the Athenian
tyrant, sent his sons to try to outwit the young Corinthian king Elmer, who had caused offense by refusing
to offer the hand of his daughter Idalma in marriage.

O# Elmiro was first performed on 26 December 1686 (M; I-MOas A). The title-page bears the dates
M.DC.LXXXVII at the top and M.DC.LXXXVI at the bottom. Variant libretti were dedicated on 25
and 26 December 1686. The work was noted for its spectacular scenery, its acting and singing, and
its opening sinfonia (M). Particularly memorable were its intrecci (two in Act Two and one in Act Three),
cued in the libretto as bali. In the first, for Turks and Moors, the action took place on a machine carried
by twenty-four soldiers. In the second, the followers of Peace and the followers of War were disgorged

6! Porfiri (also Porferi) was a Venetian priest (c. 1640-after 1714). He served in numerous posts in and around Pesaro, and his five subsequent
operas were produced in that vicinity.

Michael Measey and John Greene. This suggests that Morelli was responsible for occasional stage sets of crystal (e.g., in Le muse in maschera,
Suppl. 6). The Venetian glass industry was being undermined at the time by a cheaper manufacturing process developed in France.

265 With revisions attributed to Girolamo Frisari. Caffi's notes incorrectly give Giuseppe Tosi as the composer.
266 The Orsini were a powerful Roman family that boasted three popes and numerous other dignitaries.

?67 Venetian bombs had exploded Turkish gunpowder stored in the Parthenon (an ancient temple built in honor of the goddess Athena) just
a few months before this work was given. Still more recently the Turks had been defeated at Nauplia (Roumania). Thus a work of this kind,
particularly when written by a super-patriot such as Vincenzo Grimani, could be read as a celebration of victory.

1686/9 Tl Maurizio" Music by Domenico Gabrielli
[MAURICE]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Adriano Morselli?'
M1 Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without known incidental items SORTING DATE: 1686-12-26
o Dedicated to Ranuccio II Farnese, Duke of Parma
 Tiberius conceded his crown as Eastern Roman Emperor to Maurice in 582. He also betrothed his

daughter Ormisda to his successor. The coronation and wedding of Maurice [Mauritius Tiberius] bring
this work to its conclusion. Maurizio was first performed on 26 (M) or 27 December 1686 (I-MOas
A), although the title-page is dated 1687. Variant libretti were both dedicated on 25 December 1686;

the imprimatur is dated 20 December 1686.

Qo The cast was given in Pallade veneta, where the work was reported to have been well sung and well

acted and in consequence to have been received with unusual applause (applauso non ordinario).
A dedicatory sonnet to one of the singers, Barbara Riccioni, and an arietta were included. Ina preface
to the libretto, Gasparo Torelli praised the singular music of Domenico Gabrielli, which on other
occasions has elicited greater applause than the scenery. A simplified version of Maurizio's aria
Venticelli che tacete, which constituted the pivotal scene of the work, was also included in Pallade
veneta. Contemplating the prospect of controlling the Byzantine empire, Maurizio implored the breezes
to assuage his sense of anxiety. In a production of the work given in 1689 in Modena, Venticelli became
an interrupted aria (i.e., recitative was inserted into it). An obbligato theorbo was used in the Modenese
production, and there is a good chance it was used in the Venetian production as well.' Revivals of
Maurizio, which were numerous and widespread, extended into the first years of the eighteenth century.

La Gierusalemme liberata Music by Carlo Pallavicino
[JERUSALEM LIBERATED]

A dramma per musica Text by Giulio Cesare Corradi
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a ballo and a combattimento SORTING DATE: 1686-12-28~

Dedicated to Charles Montagu, Earl of Manchester*

Based on Tasso's account of the First Crusade, the Christians, including Geoffrey/Goffredo and
Ronald/Rinaldo, are pitted against the Saracens, among whom are Clorinda and Armide, in the battle
for Jerusalem. The Crusaders' intention was to make the holy city the seat of Latin power in the East.
The theme was pervasive on the Italian (especially the Venetian) stage. According to one report (I-MOas
A), Gierusalemme opened on 28 December 1686. The imprimatur of the UCLA libretto is 3 January
1687. It presumably corresponds to the version reported first to have been performed on 4 January 1687
(M, A).

Gierusalemme opened with a pompous scene and a noble ballo. It was particularly noted for its battle
scene, which involved 80 participants and is vividly described in Pallade veneta. A visiting Roumanian
Shah found the singers enchanting and believed the soldiers to be real. He asked whether the musicians
could come to his home every evening. Upon being informed that their time was claimed by the theater,
and further that Venice maintained several such theaters, he exclaimed that he thought it unfair that
God should bestow all of his benefits on Christians.

A lavish production was given in Dresden on 2 February 1687. It featured Margarita Salicola in the
role of Armide. She cannot have sung in the Venetian production, for the one aria (Voglia per forza)
preserved in Pallade veneta lies in a substantially lower range than the same aria preserved in the Dresden
score. Although the work was sung in Italian, a German translation of Corradi's libretto, with a dedication
to Johann Georg III by Stefano Benedetto Pallavicino, was issued by the Saxon court press.
Scores in US-LAu (Venice); B-Br (modern copy); and D-DIb (Dresden); arias in PV;* F-Pn; I-Rvat
Listed as Galvani SSGP 77; Bonlini 240; Groppo 243; Alm 334

2 Pallade veneta, pp. 64-6. Although the work is not specifically identified, // vizio depresso was the only work of the season with a role

for Fulvia.

28 The sonnet is reproduced in Pallade veneta, illustration facing p. 224.

?8! Charles Montagu (1660-1721) was the fourth ear! and first duke of Manchester. Kimbolton Castle, his residence in Cambridgeshire, became
a great repository for Venetian painting in the early years of the eighteenth century.

2 Pallade veneta, p.145.

?8 The work was staged with the German translation of Fiedler in Bamberg in 1695.

284 Ed. Hermann Abert, DDT, Vol. 55 (Leipzig, 1916), pp. 70ff. The Dresden score is complemented by instrumental parts, some of which
are on Venetian paper. For particulars, see E. Selfridge-Field, Introduction to Pallavicino's Messalina (DMV, viii).

1687/4 L'inganno regnante Music by Marc' Antonio Ziani

ovvero L'Atanagilda, regina di Gottia
[THE DECEPTION THAT PREVAILED, OR ATHANAGILDE, QUEEN OF THE GOTHS]

A dramma per musica Text by Giulio Cesare Corradi
ry Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With sonate * SORTING DATE: 1687-12-26

Dedicated to Ernst August, Duke of Brunswick

OB

In this medieval Gothic tale, King Olderic, lacking male heirs, reluctantly signed a pact to relinquish
his throne to Rudolf. Later regretting his agreement, he raised his daughter Athanagilde as the mock
prince Gismond. The plot unraveled when the prince fell in love with his/her general Orontes. The
production of this work was in progress by 27 December 1687 (I-MOas A), suggesting that it opened
on the 26th (A). The title-page of the libretto, dated 1688, praised two prodigies  the composer
Ziani for his harmony and the set designer Gio. Battista Lambranzi for his beautiful colors.*

fi Arias in GB-Lbl, Ob; I-MOe, Rvat

OO In this wholly invented tale, the Damascan princess Irene was promised to the Armenian prince Alindo.
A series of potential threats failed to prevent the marriage. La fortuna, first performed on 19 January

1688 (A; I-MOas A), was noted for its scenery and dances, and for the singing of Bernardo da Rimini.*

ES Simulations of nature were emphasized in the staging, perhaps to acknowledge the respect in which
Savorgnano's own gardens in both Venice and Udine were held. Swans swam; stags were pursued by
hunters, archers, and dogs; fountains overflowed; artificial thunder was heard and lightning seen. The
leaves of trees and flowers fluttered in the breeze. Audiences were terrified by a tall giant who raised
the curtain (this gimmick was used in many other works). A ballo at the end of Act One was for
hunchbacks. The heathen ways of Zoroastrians were portrayed in Act Two. After genuflecting to the
Sun, they were shown celebrating the sacrifice of a victim.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Carlo il Grande Music by Domenico Gabrielli
[CHARLEMAGNE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Adriano Morselli
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli and cori SORTING DATE: 1688-02-14

Dedicated to Ferdinando III de' Medici, Grand Prince of Tuscany

This account of courtly intrigue in the age of Charlemagne, derived from Ariosto's Orlando furioso
(1510), featured the paladins Roland/Orlando and Ronald/Rinaldo. The battle scenes emphasized the
defense of Paris [which the Moors never attacked] and the defeat of the Moors. Monsters issued from
an underground passageway in the first badlo.

Carlo il Grande was first performed between 17 and 21 February 1688 (A, M). Its run would have been
short, since Shrove Tuesday fell on March 2. The production was a stellar one, replete with six cori
and thirteen roles. Giacomo Filippo Cabella sang in the title role, with Nicola Tricarico (Orlando), an
unnamed Servite priest (Rinaldo), Alessandro Girardini (Ruggiero), Laura Spada (Bradamante), Angiola
Gringher (Alcina), Faustin Marchesi (Medoro), Vittoria Tarquini (La Bombace, Angelica), Tomaso
Boni (Breno), the Polish bass (Atlante), and other unidentified singers.

Each act included five distinct sets of scenery. One page of the libretto was devoted to listing the machines
and special actions in each act  seven (including demons, monsters, and a stag hunt) in the first, ten
(including a bed that turned into a dragon, a cloud that became a chariot, a review of the French army,
and winds that were transformed into spirits) in the second, and four in the third act. Tessin described
the work's scenery in glowing terms. He was impressed by one change [in Act Three] from a splendid
chamber into a frightening grotto because of the impressive difference between them. The thing
he found absolutely surprising and inconceivable was the lowering of an entirely new scene which
included a box filled with people and live horses.?? This would have been the amphitheater in which
Roger/Ruggiero and Ronald were to fight their duel at the end of the work.

Accounts of Orlando furioso had a long history rooted in the commedia. In earlier Venetian opera, Pietro
Paolo Bissari's Bradamante (SS. Giovanni e Paolo, 1650**) was the one setting of a related story. In
it the ghost of Merlin appeared in a prologue. Its production was replete with balli featuring baboons
pursued by hunters (who, after catching them, imitated their antics), the delivery of Alcina by a flying
dragon, and a plethora of phantoms.

Score in I-MOe; arias in GB-Ob; I-MOe

Listed as Galvani SGG 17; Bonlini 253; Groppo 256; Alm 349

Il gran Tamerlano Music by Mare' Antonio Ziani
[TAMERLANE THE GREAT ]

A dramma per musica Text by Giulio Cesare Corradi
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1688-12-30

Dedicated to Ferdinando III de' Medici, Grand Prince of Tuscany'

Late in the fourteenth century, Tamerlane conquered much of the Ottoman Empire, took the Turkish
emir Bayezid prisoner, defeated the Golden Horde (of Mongols), and invaded Russia and India. The
subject was recast by Piovene (1711/4) and later reset as Bajazet (1742/6). In this account, non-historical
episodes were added. Zamerlano opened on 30 December 1688 (I-MOas A); its title-page is dated 1689.
The first ballo, for eight buffoons with Turkish instruments, suggests a janissary band. The cast, given
on the last page of the libretto, included Anna Maria Torri (Roselena), Elena Cavazzoni (Zelida),
Giuseppe Maria Segni (Finalino; Emireno), Pietro Paolo Scandalibeni (Baiazette), Giuseppe Scaccia
(Tamerlano), Lorenzo Sartini (Jalone), and Giovanni Rosetto (Ali).

Amulio e Numitore Music by Giuseppe Felice Tosi
[AMULIUS AND NUMITOR]

A dramma per musica Text by Adriano Morselli
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli and cori SORTING DATE: 1689-01-11

Dedicated to Georg, Landgrave of Hesse*

In Roman mythology, Amulius, king of the Albans, was the grandfather of Romulus and Remus. Numitor
was his brother.** The relationship described here between the brothers was fictional; gods intervened
with poetic fables. Morselli wryly remarked that he had written not a tragedy but a drama for the
Venetian stage. Amulio opened on 11 January 1689 (I-MOas A), the first day of Carnival. The dedicatee
had arrived in Venice during the week ending 1 January 1689 (M). Francesco de Grandis sang in the
title role, with Anton Francesco Carli (Numitor), Anna Maria Lisa (Silvia), Angiola Gringher (Martia),
and Tomaso Boni (Liso). One of the seven cori was for sea monsters. Tosi's incomparable music

and the singular virtue of the singers were praised in the libretto.

Rosaura, the widowed queen of Persia, was intent on resisting the advances of an army general in order

costumes already prepared.?*? The prologue was for Venus, Love, and Destiny, and one ballo was
for Truth and Trickery. La Rosaura opened on or shortly after 11 January 1689 (I-MOas A).>4

II trionfo d'Amor e di Marte Music by Antonio Lombardini**
[THE TRIUMPH OF LOVE AND WAR]

Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a giuoco and balli SORTING DATE: 1689-01-15

Dedicated to Adriana Tirabosco

The story was drawn from Persian history, with emphasis on Xerxes' siege of Thebes. Arsakes, the
king of Thebes, was to establish the Parthian dynasty in what is now Iran. In this work he fought to
regain his liberty from Xerxes' prison. The production of // trionfo was in progress on 15 January 1689
(I-MOas A). According to the report of Lorenzo Zanchi, San Moise had in // trionfo the most beautiful,

Il Pertinace Music attributed to Paolo Biego
[PERTINAX]

A dramma per musica Librettist unknown***
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1689-01-29~

Dedicated to Friedrich Augustus, Prince of Saxony*?

The demise of the Roman Empire began with the fall of Pertinax [193 AD], a figure in Legrenzi's Publio
Elio Pertinace (1684/3). This account, predating those events, concentrates on Pertinax's predecessor
Lucius Commodus [180-192], who tried to engage the interest of Marcia by donning a lion-skin and
carrying a club, in imitation of Hercules. She often dressed as an Amazon. The dedicatee of this work,
which is not directly cited, arrived at his palace near San Felice on 15 January 1689 and remained there
until 21 February (M). He enjoyed both operas and feste di ballo during his visit (M). This may have
been the unnamed work cited in the memoirs of the lute virtuoso Pietro Bertacchini as one after which
he gave a notable private performance. Pertinace was produced in Parma in 1699.*4!

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Le gare dell'Inganno e dell' Amore Music by Teofilo Orgiani
[THE CONTEST BETWEEN DECEPTION AND LOVE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Paolo Emilio Badi
Given at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1689-02-05~

Dedicated to Giovanni Battista Piatti

In this short work Solakes, a gentleman of Thebes, was to wed Corilda (see 1688/3), a lady of Thessaly.
Rosmene, the princess of Epiros, encountered Corilda disguised as Armindo, Rosmene's brother. This
provided the pretext for the gay scenes, happy accidents, and spirited canzonettes with which Badi
claimed to have constructed this operina in three nights. In the final scene, Deception and Love appeared
on a machine.

Le gare appears to have been given late in Carnival in 1689.>* It was the last work to be produced at
San Moise until 1692. The uncertain date seems to reflect a miserable reception in Venice. Badi wrote
that it fell to him to try to restore a theater which had been battered not because of disgrace but because
of ill-will. Orgiani was praised for his Roman mastery of the theatrical oddities expected in
Venice.*? The work was produced in Macerata in 1694.

No musical sources known

Listed as Galvani SMoi 32; Bonlini 258; Groppo 261; Alm 357

L'Argene. Cf. Suppl. 7.

3 The dating of this work is problematical. Considered in isolation, it would seem a likely candidate to have opened in early January 1689,
but if it opened then it cannot have run for long. // trionfo d'Amor was in progress by the 1 Sth and it would probably have run for three weeks.
Since Carnival was over by 22 February, the available time slot could have consisted of the second and third weeks of February. Given that
the libretto was allegedly written in two days and set to music in three nights, a short run would have been in proportion to the effort expended.
It is conceivable that it was given only on the last nights of Carnival.

The 1690s: An Overview

he ducal tenure of Francesco Morosini (1688-94)
LG coincided with a series of international confronta-
tions. His return to Venice in January 1690 was
greeted with victory celebrations, but the battle against the
Turks continued. Roused by a frenzy of ceremonies at home,
Morosini bravely set off again in May 1693. He died (of
illness, not injury) in Roumania the following winter. His
successor, Silvestro Valier (1694-1700), while bolstered by
the confidence that Morosini had earned, promoted ceremony
and ostentation at home. He reintroduced the custom
(abolished in 1645) of crowning the dogaressa (Suppl. 6).
He permitted Venetian noblewomen to wear their jewels and
finery in public, a previously prohibited custom. The height
of pomp was reached with the visit of Czar Peter the Great
in the autumn of 1698. The Peace of Carlowitz (Serbia),
officially ending the war initiated by the Holy League, was
concluded in January 1699. Austria retained Hungary,
Venice retained Dalmatia and the Peloponnese, and Poland
retained its border provinces.

The 1690s were in some ways less bold, in others more,
than the 1680s. The heady days of war planning passed.
Many of the military strategists who now assembled in
Venice were troop commanders or their surrogates, rather
than dukes and princes. The majority were from Germany
or the Empire. The execution of and recovery from war were
less exhilarating than anticipatory dreams of glory.

The most influential changes of the decade affecting
theaters concerned texts. First came the rise of a
dramaturgical reform movement (1695). There then arose
a divergence between its adherents (who represented anew
generation of noblemen) and the existing theatrical establish-
ment. The protagonists of change were the poets Apostolo
Zeno and Domenico David, as well as the architect Gerolamo
Frigimelica-Roberti. All of them were proponents of the
Arcadianism (emulation of bucolic innocence, praise of
nature) which emanated from the court of the exiled Swedish
queen, Christina, at Rome. Arcadia championed bucolic
settings and literary purity. For opera this meant the
suppression of comic scenes in tragic works, plus a return
to the Aristotelian unities (of time, place, and action) in
dramatic construction. Roles for nurses and servants

disappeared. Less celebrated is the search which the Arcad-
ians, particularly Zeno, made for new stimuli to the historical
imagination. Zeno himself acquired a growing library of
histories of parts of Europe  Spain, Scandinavia, and the
Slavic lands in Eastern Europe  which were remote from
Venice and its prior interests.

The Arcadian movement had an implicit allegiance to
the Holy Roman Empire. It flourished in the Grimani
theaters, particularly San Giovanni Grisostomo, which
enjoyed the patronage of an expanding circle of beneficiaries
of imperial power. Arcadian values were reinforced in the
academy run by Gio. Carlo Grimani at his palace on the
Campo Santa Maria Formosa (Suppl. 7). Arcadianism was
largely ignored in the other Venetian theaters, although
Sant' Angelo paid it lip service in later years. Arcadianism
had several flavors. Machines continued to impress by their
size and mechanical properties, particularly in works devised
by Frigimelica-Roberti, but bucolic settings were essential
to the elaborate intermedi of his works. Sets were more
carefully described than ever before, but prologues for the
gods were disappearing. Shepherds  by turns love-sick,
gay, or scheming  provided a backdrop for the discussion
of human foibles.

The most important new composer of the period was
Carlo Francesco Pollarolo, a commanding presence, an
unusually imaginative artist, and the preferred musical
interpreter of Arcadianism. Pollarolo brought with him from
Brescia an extensive knowledge of both voices and instru-
ments. He was an experimenter ready to try something new
in every work. He set the longest works ever produced in
Venice. They were based on the most elaborate of
Frigimelica-Roberti's tragedies, which ran to five acts.

While Pollarolo was rescuing San Giovanni Grisostomo
from obscurity, the dilettante violinist Tomaso Albinoni
brought new luster to San Cassiano, which had many ties
to Florentine theaters. Taste at San Salvatore was reoriented
through the theater's promotion of two young Venetian
composers, Marc' Antonio Ziani and Antonio Caldara. Both
developed ties to the Mantuan court and later went to Vienna,
where, serially, they dominated music at the Hapsburg court
for the first third of the eighteenth century. Mantua, for its

FIGURE 22. Productions by theater, 1680s vs. 1690s.

part, supplied many of the best voices heard in Venice in
the last two decades of the seventeenth century. Comparisons
of theatrical activity in the 1680s and 1690s are shown in
Figure 22.

The two theaters which presented the largest number
of works in the 1690s, San Salvatore and SS. Giovanni e
Paolo, were both destined to withdraw from opera production
at the end of the century. To avoid congestion after Christ-
mas, there was significant growth in the autumn season,
particularly in the St. Martin's period and especially when
an early Lent was imminent, but there was a corresponding
decline in winter operas, particularly in the St. Stephen's
period.

Almost as many operas (86) were produced in the 1690s
as in the preceding decade. The number of meta-operas-
declined in response to a reduction in state visits to Venice.
Only eighteen operas (20 per cent) from this decade are
survived by full scores. They exclusively represent the works
of Pollarolo, Giacomo Perti, and Giovanni Bononcini and
dedicatees of significance. Many works are survived by
miscellaneous arias. The news-sheets of choice are now the
Mercuri, the papal legate's records, and the Corriere
ordinario. Primary avvisi are in short supply. As the median
political rank of opera-goers slipped from its social peak in
the 1680s, digesters of weekly news-sheets began to ignore
works to which no important witness could be linked.

Pirro e Demetrio Music by Giuseppe Felice Tosi
[PYRRHOS AND DEMETRIOS]

A dramma per musica Text by Adriano Morselli
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli and a battle scene SORTING DATE: 1690-01-11~

Dedicated to Gasparo de Luca, N.V.

In the second century BC, Pyrrhos tried to liberate the state of Epiros from Macedonia, which was then
ruled by Demetrios. In this account the two rulers have become friends. Demetrios, who is in love with
the Ethiopian princess Klymene, encourages Pyrrhos to feign love for her in order to test her virtue.?
Morselli's dedication expressed the hope that the harmonious music of maestro Tosi and the sweet
song of the most famous singers of our century would compensate for the defects of the drama, which
he attributed to the short period of time available to write it.

Pirrois likely to have opened between 10 and 21 January 1690 and to have run until the end of Carnival
(7 February). On 11 February 1690 Gio. Carlo Grimani noted that Giovanni Buzzoleni [Demetrio] had
completed his appearance at San Giovanni with much applause and sought a contract for the following
year. Grimani was greatly impressed with the natural skill at ornamentation (maniere disinvolte) of
Dianina Testi [Climene] and also praised the singing of Anna Maria Beccarina.*

Both in casting and in its incidental entertainments, Pirro contained an odd mixture of allegorical,
mythological, historical, and modern-day figures. A ballo in Act One was for Persian and Ethiopian
children, while in Act Three a ballo in the form of a battle required four changes of scene and was to
be presented by cavallieri. To judge from the frontispiece of the libretto, the scenery may have
emphasized exotic dress and customs. Alessandro Scarlatti's setting of the same text was to open in
Naples on 28 January 1694. It attracted a great deal of interest when it was given in London in Owen
[Mac]Swiney's translation (1708). It was revived there in 1717.

The mythical Curtius, lured by the voice ofan oracle calling for one more noble citizen, made the ultimate

La Falsirena Music by Marc' Antonio Ziani
[FALSIRENA]

A dramma per musica Text by Rinaldo Cialli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1690-01-15~

In this story popularized by Marino, the mythical Adonis was captivated by Falsirena.* Like the three

Il gran Macedone Music by Giuseppe Boniventi?
[THE GREAT MACEDONIAN]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giulio Pancieri
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With balli' SORTING DATE: 1690-12-14

Dedicated to Ferdinand Carlo Gonzaga, Duke of Mantua

The plot focused on the conflict between Phoenicia and Macedonia in the time of Alexander, the great
Macedonian. It was embroidered with amorous intrigues. The first opera to be given at San Cassiano
since 1683, the work was expected to open on 19 or 20 November 1690. Though later said to have opened
on the 25th with universal satisfaction (I-MOas A),'! this date cannot have been correct. The opening
was postponed numerous times on account of the failure of one of the singers, Valeria Guidicelli, to
reach Venice. Once there, she contracted laryngitis. According to the mortified impresario, Gio. Francesco
Palazzi, permission to open the production was granted for 8 December, but the actual premiere did
not take place until the 14th.'? On account of its late start, it resumed on 29 December (I-MOas A).

1690/6 L'incoronazione di Serse Music by Giuseppe Felice Tosi
[THE CORONATION OF XERXES]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Adriano Morselli
"1 Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1690-12-26
o Dedicated to Sophie Charlotte, Electress of Brandenburg"?

Xerxes, the king of Persia in the fifth century BC, assumed the throne after the defeat of his father,
Darius, by the Greeks at the battle of Marathon. In this account, Darius returns to Persia to challenge
plans for his succession. Morselli derived his text, he said, from the beautiful tragedy of Corneille.'*

OL L'incoronazione opened on 26 December 1690 (I-MOas A), the date of dedication of the libretto.'
According to a letter from Gio. Carlo Grimani of the previous year, Giovanni Buzzoleni agreed to a
payment of 100 doppie for his appearance and 16 doppie to cover travel expenses.' Grimani had also
planned to procure the services of Dianina Testi, Anna Maria Beccarina, and Domenico Cecchi (Il
Cortona).' However, Beccarina had already been engaged by Sant' Angelo and Cecchi was committed
to appearing in Rome during the coming Carnival.'* In their places Grimani sought to engage [Rosa]
Mignata and Ferdinando [Chiaravalle]. He was soon in conflict with the first over her demands for a
wardrobe and with the second for wanting a stipend for his free time.'? Neither appeared in the work.
The title-role was taken by Francesco Antonio Pistocchi, with Diana Testi as Stateira.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Dedicated to Torrismondo della Torre [Torriano], Baron of Taxis

In Greek history of the fourth century BC, a measured defense against the advances of Philip of
Macedonia was launched by the heroes of this work, led by Xenocrates. This seems likely to have been
one of the works which opened on 26 December 1690 (M), perhaps with a preview performance before
the 15th. The title-page is dated 1691; the season is identified as autumn.

Arias in I-MOe, Rvat

Listed as Galvani SSGP 82; Bonlini 268; Groppo 271; Alm 367

Creonte" Music by Marc' Antonio Ziani
[CREON]

A dramma per musica Text by Rinaldo Cialli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1691-12-27

Dedicated to Pietro Zeno, N.V.!

Creon, a mythical king of Egypt, was repeatedly unfaithful to his wife, Hypsipyle, the mythical queen
of Lemnos, and was eventually conquered by Cyrus. Creonte officially opened on 27 December 1690
(I-MOas A). The title-page is dated 1691; the season of performance is defined (wishfully, it appears)
as autumn. The cast must have included Anna Maria Beccarina. The libretto praised the music of Ziani,
which in the past year has been acclaimed marvelous and this year has merited the crown of Apollo
on account of its harmonious notes. It noted that the scenery designer Tomaso Bezzi was working
for San Giovanni Grisostomo as well as Sant' Angelo.

Arias in F-Pn; GB-Cfim; I-Rvat

Listed as Galvani SAng 26; Bonlini 269; Groppo 272; Alm 368, 369

L'inganno scoperto per vendetta" Music by Giacomo Antonio Perti
[THE DECEPTION DISCOVERED FOR REVENGE]

A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Silvani
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1690-12-28

Dedicated to Sebastiano Soranzo, N.V.?

The Scythian prince Sydernes, who was believed to be the son of the Persian ruler Cyrus, was engaged
to marry Mandane but fell in love with Stateira, the beloved of Darius. L 'inganno opened on 28 December
1690 (I-MOas A). It was given in Genoa in 1691. Perti is praised by Silvani in the libretto as one of
the most celebrated composers of Italy. While the actual casting is unknown, it appears that Maddalena
Musi had rejected an offer of 200 doppie from San Salvatore for the 1690-91 season in favor of one
from the Grimani to sing at San Giovanni Grisostomo.**

and cultural news. [Della Torre is also sometimes given as Torriano.]

L'Almerinda Music by Giuseppe Boniventi
[ALMERINDE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giulio Pancieri
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without known incidental items SORTING DATE: 1691-01-20

Dedicated to Francesco Girolamo Gravena, Marquis of San Giorgio

Almerinde, the daughter of Albazar, king of Media, and wife of Belard, king of Persia, was the subject
of this fictionalized history. The title-page of the libretto is dated 1691; the dedication is dated 20 January
1690 [M.V.]. A note in the libretto says that the drama had been presented previously under a different
title and ina different format. The author maintained that the music of Boniventi and the performance
of virtuosi compensated for the dramaturgical defects of its present reduced form.

No musical sources known

Listed as Galvani SCas 27; Bonlini 271; Groppo 274; Alm 371

Marte delusa Music by Marc' Antonio Ziani
[MARS DELUDED]

A dramma per musica Text by Rinaldo Cialli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1691-01-21~

Dedicated to Johann Albert of Freschen

This revival of Falsirena (1690/4) had newly added balli. Mars was scorned by Venus with the usual
disdain of the beautiful sex, and Adonis was encouraged. The work opened in Roman catacombs. Marte
delusa should have opened in the latter half of January, probably between the 1 6th and the 27th. Three
instrumentalists (Antonio Caldara and his father, Iseppo, plus Francesco Venago) filed a notarial
complaint against the impresario Francesco Quintavalle. They sought 130 ducats for the 1691-92 season
at Sant' Angelo. They claimed to have spent more than one month in rehearsals and to have given more
than thirty performances.* No works are named, but since the complaint refers to the season as such,
it is likely that the figures account for both Creonte (1690/8) and Marte.

Listed as Galvani SAng 27; Bonlini 274; Groppo 277; Alm 374

 The Syrian king Seleukos [312-280 BC] murdered Berenice, the sister of the Egyptian king Ptolemy.

Peace was brought about by the Macedonian king Antiochos. La pace was mentioned as the forthcoming
second work at San Giovanni Grisostomo in a dispatch of 16 December 1690 (I-MOas A), by which
time its dedicatee had arrived in Venice. He remained until c. 23 February (A). The work should have
opened late in January, after the last performance of L 'incoronazione di Serse (1690/6). The title-page
is dated 1691.

 La pace was the first opera set by Pollarolo for San Giovanni Grisostomo. The librettist was dubious
about the reception, since instead of presenting the same scene which had been repeated hundreds
of times before on our stages, he had sought to create a new fantasy [based] on foreign poets. He
praised the marvelously adorned music of Pollarolo and the best swans of Italy [i.e., the singers].
Six singers, including Francesco Antonio Pistocchi (Antioco), were retained from Serse, but two 
Laura Spada (Seleuco) and Antonio Romolo Ferini (Arpago)**  were new. Spada's appearance
represents the earliest documented casting of a woman in a male role in Venetian opera.**

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1690-99) 199

Dedicated to Duke Camillo Gonzaga*

Albuin, who reigned in the later sixth century, was the king of the first Germanic tribe to invade
northeastern Italy. After crossing the Julian Alps, his forces overcame those of Byzantium in the northern
Adriatic. The nucleus of what was later to become the Venetian state was formed by those who took
refuge from his advances in the marshes near Grado. In this account Albuin's tyranny is treated almost
generically and is contrasted to the virtue of the Roman Empire.

The dedicatee appeared in Venice on 14 February 1691, which suggests an opening for Carnival proper.
The production could have begun from 27 January onward, though with only a month remaining until
the start of Lent, it is unlikely to have opened much later. Pollarolo had assumed the office of second
organist at San Marco the preceding August.

Dedicated to Luigi d'Este, Prince of Modena

Almira, the young queen of Castile, was lost in a shipwreck. Her infant son, raised anonymously by
the fisherman who rescued him, was eventually recognized as the heir to the throne. The balli were
respectively for eight Moors and eight Spaniards. L Almira opened on 22 November 1691 (also the
date of dedication of the libretto) with much applause (NV). The elector of Bavaria [Maximilian II
Emanuel] attended a performance in early December. The title-page does not indicate a season. According

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

In this work the love of Artaxerxes, the son of the Persian king Darius, for Berenice, the daughter of
Mazeos, the king of the Scythians, triumphed over the enmity between their countries.

The reputation of La Virti substantially preceded its official premiere. It was in preparation by 2 October
1691, when G. Boughton wrote to Henry Grey, the duke of Kent, enclosing some arias of the new
first Oppera. He commented that Cortini and the Romanina sings at St. Lukes [San Salvatore]
which is thought will be the best Oppera.'* The story was little changed when the Corriere ordinario
reported on 22 December that the elector of Bavaria [Maximilian II Emanuel], Prince Eugene of Savoy,
and many others had greatly enjoyed the opera rehearsal at San Luca one week earlier. When the
work finally had its premiere, on 26 December, it was praised for the exquisiteness of the voices,
the magnificence of the scenery, and the richness of the costumes (CO). Another report (NV) found
the production to be most sumptuous. In introducing his libretto Silvani praised the music, the singing,
the architecture (i.e., the sets), and the painting (of the scenery). The text was later used by B. Micheli,
A. Vivaldi, and N. Romaldo in the like-named work (RV 740) given at the Capranica (Rome, 1724).

L'Ibraim Sultano* Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[IBRAHIM THE SULTAN]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Adriano Morselli**
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1691-12-27

Dedicated to Johann Albrecht of Freschen**

Ibrahim, who feigned stupidity, was declared the emperor of the Turks. His brother, Bayezid, succeeded
to the throne.*' The subject is usually said to be derived from Racine's account, although recent
commentaries credit Georges de Scudery's Ibrahim, ou L 'Illustre Bassa (1643) as Morselli's main source.
The role of Akhmet /Acmat in Morselli's text provided the basis for Osmano in Goldoni's like-named
tragicomedia (1740; see Suppl. 3a), his last tragic work for San Samuele.

L'Ibraim opened on 27 December 1691 (CO). The elector of Bavaria [Maximilian II Emanuel] attended
arehearsal of this and other works in the days immediately preceding the Novena of Christmas (NV).
The work opened with a view of the serraglio ona canal that leads to the sea and ended with Bayezid's
coronation celebration. One ballo (Act I) featured eight Indians leading an elephant.** The production
was praised, together with that of La Virti trionfante (1691/7), for the exquisiteness of the voices,
the magnificence of the scenery, and the richness of the costumes (CO).

appointed governor of the Spanish Netherlands and a member of the Order of the Golden Fleece in the year of her death. In 1694 he married
the Polish princess Theresa Kunegunda Sobieska, who became an important, if invisible, patroness of Venetian instrumental music (to judge
from diplomatic dispatches in I-Rvat, AS, NV). He was to side with France in the War of the Spanish Succession. Losing with the French
side in the Battle of Blenheim (1704), he spent the last two decades of his life in exile in France.

[THE OPPRESSED RELIEVED]
A dramma per musica Librettist(s) unknown
i Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)

a Dedicated to Johann Georg IV, Duke of Brunswick
Soa

This renamed but unrevised revival of Leonida di Sparta (Turin, 1689) emphasized clemency. The text
was said to be based on Plutarch. The work left no imprint in existing documentation. It is likely to
have been provided to replace an unsuccessful work (Quesnda's La Gelidauria [1692/1] ), or perhaps
to have been given only for the last nights of Carnival (still two weeks away). The title page is dated
1692. The serenata at the end of Act Two included Sirens (Partenope, Ligia, and Leucasia) as well
as Nereids (glauchi) and Tritons. Arcadian reforms were not observed: the main text included a role
for a comic servant.

Rosalind and Leald were shipwrecked off the Barbary Coast. Although rescued, she was subsequently
enslaved by a pirate who presented her to Akhmet, the king of Tunisia. Marchi noted in the libretto
that, knowing how hard it is in these times to please all humors, he was reluctant to see this work
submitted to censors and produced on the stage. Rosalinda was first performed on 15 November 1692

Tole, regina di Napoli Music by Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[IOLE, QUEEN OF NAPLES]

A dramma per musica Text by Giulio Cesare Corradi
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1692-11-18

Dedicated to Johann Adolf, Prince Palatine

After a flood of the Nile, Iole, the princess of Cairo, was married to the second emperor of Rome and
given the title of Queen of Naples. Jole was first performed on 18 November 1692 (M). Corradi wrote
that Pollarolo had surpassed the believable in composing the music and urged those attending to listen
to it. The work contained balli for buffoons and courtesans as well as a game with arms for soldiers.
The production was praised (CO) for its music and for the sumptuousness of its presentation (comparse).

This treatment of the adultery of the emperor Zeno was pastoral. // trionfo opened on 26 December

Nerone fatto Cesare Music by Giacomo Antonio PertiTM
[NERO MADE EMPEROR]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris

Incontrast to Corradi's text of // Nerone (1678/8), this text gave equal attention to the emperor's second
wife, the lascivious Agrippina. The present work also contained a role for a Spanish ambassador, Guzman,
and, to further confuse its cultural message, a rigadoon.

Nerone had its first rehearsal in the Vendramin palace on the 15th (CO). It opened officially on 27
December 1692 (CO, NV). The run continued through at least 7 February 1693 (M). This and La forza
della virtit (1692/10) were received with great applause for the sumptuous scenes and musicians (M).
Noris cited the participation of the most celebrated singers of our century and said that Perti's music

* Lotti (1666-1740) was to be a giant of Venetian music from the 1690s through the 1730s. He was a singer (contralto, from 30 May 1689),
organist (second organist from 1692, first organist from 1704 to 1736), and maestro di cappella (1736-1740) at San Marco. He was widely
known as a composer of operas and other dramatic works. He was a prolific composer of sacred vocal music, much of which survives in Germany,
where he was in residence of three years (1717-19). Benedetto Marcello (1716) condemned the naive dissonance treatment in Lotti's Madrigali
(1705), which were dedicated to the emperor, Joseph I.

La forza della Virti" Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[THE POWER OF VIRTUE]

A dramma per musica Text by Domenico David
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1692-12-29

Dedicated to Giovanni Carlo Grimani, N.V.

The historical Roderic/Rodrigo, last king of the Visigoths, was celebrated in Spanish history for his
personal virtue. In this account, Clotilda, the wife of Fernando, the first king of Castile, was even more
virtuous. It was she who befriended the ambitious Anagilda, her husband's mistress, and thereby disarmed
her, enabling marital virtue to prevail. The story was set in Seville.

La forza, having been delayed by the indisposition of one of its singers, opened with pomp and
magnificence not seen for a long time on 29 December 1692 (CO). It had been in rehearsal since before
the 15th. On 3 January it was said to be enjoying great applause (M).8 On the 23rd it was still enjoying
great attendance. The production continued through 7 February (M), the last Saturday of Carnival.
David noted that he had attempted to move the affetti in the breasts of the hearers with such efficacy
that they will delight those who are not emotionally stupid or spiritually obtuse in [comprehending]
the sentiments of the passions. Some of the most striking expression in the work comes from Pollarolo's
imaginative music. Anagilda's unaccompanied vanity aria, in which she sings of her allure, is an
apt example. Her role was taken by Domenica Pini, with Vittoria Tarquini (Clotilda), Antonio Romolo
Ferini (Rodrigo), Giovanni Buzzoleni (Fernando), and Pietro Moggi (Sancio).* Il Corriere ordinario
reported that the opening performance was characterized by more pomp and magnificence than Venetian
opera [had] provided for a long time.*!

The tale of Rodrigo and Anagilda had a long tenure on the Venetian stage. Pollarolo had composed
the music for a text (attributed to G. B. Bottalino) called L'Anagilda over Il Rodrigo, which was
performed in Reggio Emilia in the spring of 1685 (possibly also in Treviso in 1687); it featured Barbara
Riccioni (Anagilde), with B. Donatelli (Rodrigo) and C. Frangiossi (Sancio). David's text was set,
possibly by G. A. Perti, for performance in Florence (1702). It was adapted by Heidegger as a pastiche
for performance in London (Clotilda; 1709), and it was indirectly a model for Handel's Flavio (HWV
16; London, 1723).* Later treatments of the story included those of Paisiello (// gran Cid, 1775) and
Massenet (1885) and continued into the early twentieth century.

 David credits the fifth volume of Rogatis's Storie di Spagna (1648) for the particulars. He is more forthright than most librettists in hinting
at allegorical relationships between modern affairs and those of the times recounted. Pierre Corneille's Le Cid (1637) had treated similar material
but from a different perspective. The subject of Roderic was also a popular one for comedies in Spanish-speaking lands. The performance
ofa new comedy on this subject was noted in Naples, for example, in December 1702 (see Griffin, Gazzetta, Doc. 148, entry of 26 December).
The treatment here is very much in line with Arcadian reform.

The Sauromates were a tribe of Iranian nomads in which women and men played relatively equal roles
as warriors. In the second and third centuries (the period of time suggested by this text) they came into
conflict with roaming German tribes in central Asia. Amage, having for a husband the decadent Ulderic,
was forced to administer justice and to instruct the troops herself. The first ballo depicted a baccanale,
suggesting the lasciviousness of works commissioned for newlyweds.** Despite the title-page date of

Oo The argomento relates that the emperor Otto posed as his own ambassador at the court of the Byzantine

1694/2 Ottone Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[OTTO]
A tragedia per musica (5) Text by Girolamo Frigimelica-Roberti
ry Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With intramezzi containing balli SORTING DATE: 1694-01-14
& Dedicated to Ernst August, Duke of BrunswickTM

When Mary of Aragon, the wife of the Emperor Otto III [996-1002], was attracted to a young count,
her jealous husband had him decapitated. The count's wife now sought revenge. In this version of the
story, the count was a son of Otto but was believed to be the son of Lucretia, a widow with whom Otto
had fallen in love. In a typically high-flown introduction, Frigimelica-Roberti stated that tragedy is
a mysterious panegyric of public liberty...the most noble delight that one can provide for universal
recreation on the stage. He allowed, however, that Venetian taste might be different from that of Greece,
Rome, or Paris.

* A-Wn, CO; also I-Rvat, AS, Fondo Awvisi, N. 56, entry of 14 Novembre 1693, f. lv, and N. 57, entry of 16 January 1694, f. Ir.
 Stieger, Opernlexikon, iv, 72.
*! Duke of Sabbionetta and a Spanish Grandee. The Spinola family served the Spanish throne in Genoa.

 CO; I-Rvat, AS, Fondo Awvisi, N. 57, entry of 16 Gennaro 1694, f. Ir. No works were performed between 26 December 1693 and 9 January
1694 because of a jubilee (/oc. cit.).

 Count Frigimelica-Roberti, from Padua, was principally an architect and structural engineer. The libretti he created for the Venetian stage
over the next years marked the apex of grandiose staging, investing in their exemplars of classical dramaturgy opportunities to maximize
dramatic effects through elaborate presentations. Frigimelica-Roberti was also an ardent patron of anti-Turkish espionage networks.

* In 1692 the emperor created the special title of Elector of Brunswick-Liineburg for Ernst August. The plot can be read as a gloss on the
elector's personal affairs (see also 1696/7). In the winter of 1693-94 the elector was amalgamating military forces in Venice. The count of
Oxestam (a German) and Count Bielch (a Swede) were among those who had arrived in the autumn (I-Rvat, AS, Fondo Awvisi, N. 57, entries
of 31 Ottobre, 5 Dicembre 1693). His own retinue included various members of his family, some of whom began to leave Venice at the end
of January 1694 (Joc. cit., entry of 30 Gennaro 1694), Others remained through May.

S The time frame was described by the librettist as the days of Pietro Orseolo, the celebrated doge [991-1008] who first started to expand
the Republic of Venice down the eastern shores of the Adriatic [999].

OOn Ottone opened on 14 January 1694 (M, CO), the date of dedication of the libretto. Francesco Ballarini,
who had not sung at San Giovanni Grisostomo for ten years, took the title role. The production was
noted for its most superb machines (CO). A revised version with anonymous music was given with
the title / prodigi dell 'innocenza (Florence, 1707). The original version was revived in Venice as 1716/5.

o-39 The staging, which was conceived on a grand scale, became a model for later settings of Frigimelica-
Roberti's texts. Each act featured one elaborate intramezzo. The depictions represented Love, Innocence,
Virtue, the Underworld, and Chaos. The scenery for them collectively hinted at a contest between Virtue
and Vice. The infernal scene in Act Four was full of furies, shadows, and spirits. In the intramezzo
called a spettacolo (Act Five) the stage was divided between an amphitheater full of people and Chaos,
which was being put in order.

1694/3 Alfonso primo Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[ALFONSO I]
A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
im Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1694-01-24
[cal Dedicated to Juan Antonio Moles?'TM

In this story derived from medieval Spanish history, the Visigoth Alfonso, who served as the first king
of Asturias [739-757], had a sister (Gelinda) who fell in love with and seduced a married vassal.'"!

 2  Alfonso opened on 24 January 1694.' The curtain was opened at the start of the work by the Winds
to reveal a woods of great oak trees. Scene Two was introduced by a sinfonia of harps, violins, and
theorboes, which accompanied the dance of amorini in a misty salon of Alfonso's palace called the
Heaven of Venus. Behind this scene a third curtain was raised to show a sea on which boats could be
seen in the distance. These opening scenes were supposed to symbolize thoughts of love, amorous sin,
and royal treachery respectively. A series of other palace rooms with celestial themes followed in order:
the Heaven of Mars (showing a comet), of Lucina (showing a full moon), of Jupiter (showing his star''),
and of the Sun, and of Mercury. The production was very well received, ostensibly for its beautiful
scenery, machines, and general appearance.!TM Atypically, there were two balli in each act.

 According to the Mercure of the 16th, only San Salvatore and San Giovanni Grisostomo were then open. The Vatican avviso for the same
date indicates, however, that Sant' Angelo had also re-opened and that comedies were in production, from the 11th, at San Cassiano, San Samuele,
and Cannaregio.

dedicatee were one and the same. Further on Moles, cf. 1696/4.

L'Amore, figlio del Merito Music attributed to Marc' Antonio Ziani
[LOVE, THE SON OF MERIT]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1694-02-06~

Dedicated to Friedrich August, Duke of Saxony!

Prince Lydios, the son of Midas, the mythical king of Phrygia, loved Sulpicia, the daughter of the nature-
spirit Silenus. Some elements of the work (the presence of the princess Theodelinda, the ballo for gypsies)
were external to the mythological context.

L'amore opened during the week ending 13 February 1694, which was shortly before the departure
of its dedicate.' It was doubly ill-fated in that word of the death of Doge Morosini in Roumania was
received in Venice on the 13th. Although the theaters were permitted to remain open, masking was
suspended. All festivities on the piazza were closed, and plans for a festive Giovedi Grasso, which fell
on the 18th, were rescinded. Morosini's funeral occurred on the 21st, and his successor, Silvestro Valier,
was elected the following day. Festivities on Valier's behalf took place on the 25th, 26th, and 27th.'

Zenobia, regina de' palmireni Music by Tomaso Albinoni"
[ZENOBIA, QUEEN OF THE PALMYRANS]

A dramma per musica Text by Antonio Marchi

The city of Palmyra, which stood at the intersection of roads leading to Syria and Babylonia, was ruled
in the third century first by Zenobia's husband, Septimius Odaenathus, and, after his murder, by her
[269-272]. Zenobia was first performed on 13 November 1694 (M). The production continued after
Christmas. The production of Albinoni's first opera, which contained fifteen scene changes, was
considered good enough (assai bene) and was well attended (M). Marchi, who hoped for the same
success as he had enjoyed with Rosalinda, praised the virtuous and delightful music of Sig. Tomaso
Albinoni, who...has reached the level of the leading professors.

converted to Catholicism, paving the way to his appointment as king of Poland the following year. He was later known as August the Strong.

The libretto was based on the chivalrous tale of Friedrich/Frederic/Federico, the Staufen king of Sicily
[1198-1250],''? who fell in love with the slave Ginevra. She was rescued by her original lover, Amerigo,

Irene' Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[IRENE]

A tragedia per musica (5) Text by Girolamo Frigimelica-Roberti''*
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With intramezzi in the form of giuochi and balli SORTING DATE: 1694-12-26

Dedicated to (Cardinal) Pietro Ottoboni, N.V.

The Eastern ruler Mehmet, depicted in this libretto as a man with a curious mix of vices and virtues,
was learned in languages, sciences, and letters. He first noticed Irene,''' the niece of Constantine, when
she was a slave and he was about to undertake a campaign in Hungary. The work opened in the imperial
palace in Constantinople and closes on a field in Hungary.''

Frigimelica-Roberti intended the libretto to be a sequel to his Ottone (1694/2). Ina lengthy note to the
readers he offered a short treatise on dramaturgical aesthetics. Poetry, he said, is the most delicate of
the arts because it is judged both by fantasy and by intellect. Those who do not like verisimilitude must
not like the truth to which it is akin. Human actions are the truths that poetry imitates. Art exposes
perfect ideas as models. In the present case he seeks to write a work which will please an audience in
Venice. The work is very simple, for Irene's tragedy is starker than that of Otho. One will find less
action, fewer characters, and more concentration on passion. However, a happy ending is maintained.
Irene opened on 26 December 1694 (M). Diamante Maria Scarabelli, a later favorite of this theater,
made her debut as Irene's sister Deianeira. Antonia Marzari sang in the title role."' The first of the
four intramezzi featured court mutes and story-telling Turks, while the second was for Moorish and
Turkish eunuchs with tambourines and Turkish-style instruments. ... Moors were featured in the third

Laodicea e Berenice' Music by Giacomo Antonio Perti
[LAODIKEIA AND BERENICE]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1694-12-26

Dedicated to Tarquinia Colonna Ottoboni'

Laodikeia and Berenice were the successive wives of the Syrian ruler Antiochos II in the third century
BC; he divorced the first to marry the second. Perhaps responding to Frigimelica-Roberti's declaration
of purpose, Noris noted in his preface his long experience with works for this stage, his modesty, the
purity of his expression, the necessity of each role he created, and his avoidance of superfluity. The
work was first performed on 26 (M) or 27 (CO) December 1694. It was revised around 22 January 1695
(CO). The libretto assured readers that the most exquisite voices of Italy were employed in it and
in Irene (1694/7). The singers are not identified. Scarlatti's setting of the text was performed in Naples
in April 1701. The work influenced L 'inganno trionfante in amore (1725/6; 1735/6).

future husband either Prince Rodolfo of Portugal or Prince Luis of Castile. Their true heritages were
discovered through their opposition to one another.' /] prencipe opened on 12 January 1695 (CO);
its libretto had been dedicated on the 10th, and Carnival had opened on the 11th.

212 A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

rT Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With intramezzi SORTING DATE: 1695-01-22
& Dedicated to Karl Philipp, Margrave of Brandenburg'?

This works gives an elaborate account of the conversion of the nymph Daphne (Antonia Marzari), who
resisted the advances of Apollo (Valentino Urbani), into a laurel tree.'4 She was thereby concealed
from her pursuer. Ina further installment of the discourse on drama which was serialized in the prefaces
to his libretti, Frigimelica-Roberti defended his combination of pastoral subject matter with the tragic
genre. He cited Aristotle and Homer for examples in defense of the character of his new work,'* but
the story's essential elements link it to a long tradition of Italian poetry, notably through Petrarch's
Laura and the many crowns of laurel that pervade it.

Oo The secondo drama...at which one sees a great concourse was first performed on 22 January 1695,
when it was found to be very good (M). A week later universal applause was reported (CO). The
dedicatee had arrived in Venice before the first of the year and left during the week ending 12 February
(M). He was esteemed for having donated a substantial sum to the allied cause in 1694.'" I! pastore
had reprises in Brunswick (1697) and Wolfenbiittel (c. 1703) as well as Venice (1704/4).

 The staging involved six machines, seven choruses, and twenty-four allegorical parts  including Time,
the Century, the Year, the Month, the Day, the Twelve Diurnal Hours, the Four Seasons, Dawn, Dusk,
and Daylight  perhaps in anticipation of the end of the century. Many of these appeared only in the
elaborate intramezzi, which concluded each act. The opening of the work showed what must have been
a spectacular forest scene, with Daphne's father, the lucid River Peneos, singing to her. In the first
intramezzo nymphs played instruments, sang, and danced in praise of the huntress Diana. Satyrs and
hunters did the same in the second. Zephyrs came with Dawn in the third; nymphs and shepherds frolicked
in the fourth. Dreams and phantoms arrived with Night as Apollo departed at the end of the work.

&S The descent of Apollo's palace at the start of the last act was the subject of an often-quoted account
by Luigi Riccoboni. The palace was ...formed entirely of chrystals of different colours, which turned
about perpetually...while lights showed through them into the eyes of the audience.' This spectacle
gave the work a legendary status that is still echoed in many studies.

A Score in CS-K; arias in F-Pn; I-Rvat
Listed as Galvani SGG 27; Bonlini 302; Groppo 306; Alm 415, 416

Oov Groppo attached a quotation from the later anonymous Considerazioni sopra il Demofonte dell Abb.
Metastasio (1735, Suppl. 3b) concerning Zeno's contribution to the reform of opera libretti. It states
that the dramatist was certainly the first to raise our theater to nobility. To start with, he rid it of the
ridiculous and ended the abuse of buffoonery, which had been introduced in the dramas of previous
years. A fter that, he selected subjects to represent which were drawn from the most illustrious and most
famous works of Greek and Roman antiquity. Finally, he brought order and decorum to dramas which
had become corrupted in our theaters.'* The reform movement was apparently not welcomed so
enthusiastically elsewhere. Alessandro Scarlatti's setting of the same text (under the title Agarista)
was given in Naples, with added comic scenes, on 6 November 1699 and was repeated in Florence in
1705. A setting by Buini was given in Venice (1722/7) and Florence (also 1722).

Rosimonda Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[ROSAMOND]

A tragedia per musica Text by Girolamo Frigimelica-Roberti
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With cori SORTING DATE: 1696-01-09

Dedicated to Alessandro Molin, N.V.'*

The Lombard invader Albuin, after killing his rival Cunimond, had compelled the latter's daughter
Rosamond to marry him. The chalice he had fashioned from the skull of her late father was regularly
used ceremonially to symbolize his power. Albuin gradually established his rule across Lombardy [568-
573].'8 Rosamond conspired with one of the newly conquered princes to murder her husband; then
she married the murderer. The Lombards refused to accept their new king, which caused Rosamond
to abscond with their treasures and settle in Ravenna. Both husband and wife were murdered there.
The work opened in Pavia, where a royal banquet was in progress. The banquet hall became a funeral
parlor after Albuin is murdered.

In contrast to his other recent tragedies, Frigimelica-Roberti here intended a tragedy with an unhappy
outcome, he wrote. He strove to offer frequent incidents of a sentimental nature, the expression of
vehement passions, and robust elocution. In his introduction to the libretto he commented at length
on the expression of the passions and the debts of the dramatic concept to Aristotle. Wrath was the
dominating passion in this work, he said, and he wondered, therefore, whether it could please an audience
in Venice. He speculated that if it were well performed it should be well received, because the taste
there was no less delicate, no less pure than that of [ancient] Athens.

Rosimonda opened on or about 9 January 1696 (CO). The theaters had been closed for all of Advent
in 1695 (CO). There were few entertainments between Christmas and this time because of the death
of the imperial ambassador, Count [della Torre] (CO), in mid-December and the illness of the doge
in early January.

4 Dorothea Sophia, the princess of Neuburg and the daughter of the Elector Palatine, was to be married to her brother-in-law, Francesco [Famese]
I, Duke of Parma, on 9 July 1696. The marriage had been arranged the preceding November through the intervention of the marquis Pagano
(I-Rvat, AS, NV, N. 143, f. 499v). Thus, if the year is correct, she was a future (rather than a current) duchess.

'45 Noris claimed to have written in a new style, neither ancient nor modern, in creating a story of jealousy with fine intrigues and a narrative
designed to pique the curiosity of the audience.

46 T-MAas, AG, Carteggio da Venezia, Busta 1583/2, letter of Angelo Robetani dated 28 Gennaro [16]95 [M.V.].

47 Alessandro Molin was named General of the Morea in 1695 (M). He was dispatched on a mission in late August and could have commissioned
this text (or have been solicited for a dedication) prior to his departure.

'88 Alboin's Lombardy included many locales (Treviso, Vicenza, Verona) which were currently part of the Venetian Republic.

OR Rosimonda, which included individual roles for eighteen characters (several of them mythical or pastoral)

Sigismund, the king of Hungary [1410-1437] who staunchly resisted Ottoman advances, died without
male heirs. The Houses of Austria and Hungary were subsequently combined. This plot recounted events
of 1435, when Sigismund went to Rome to be crowned emperor. In an irrelevant subplot, his minister
fell in love with a married noblewoman from Siena.'*

O@E Sigismondo opened on 11 January 1696 (CO). During the week ending the 21st the dedicatee was said
to be planning a lavish public entry (as imperial ambassador) for the last days of Carnival, but the event
did not occur until 29 April.'** By the end of the month, Sigismondo was attracting only a small
audience.'* In 1701 Gabriele Marcello wrote to the duke of Mantua stating that debts for which Moles
was responsible  because he had made [Sigismondo] be recited  were still unpaid. He expressed

1696/6 Eraclea Music attributed to Bernardo Sabadini!
(HERACLEA]
A tragicomedia per musica (5) Text by Giulio Cesare Godi
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With cori and ballo SORTING DATE: 1696-02-08
& Dedicated to Ferdinando III de' Medici, Grand Prince of Tuscany

Hieron/Arrenione, the king of Sicily, was the uncle of the cruel Girolamo and the father of a married
daughter, Heraclea/Eraclea. Her husband, on a mission to Egypt, decided not to return to his homeland,
leaving Sicily prey to the rule of Carthage. In a series of invented incidents, virtue prevailed and, as
the title of a later opera maintained, treachery tricked itself.

ics) Eraclea had its first performance on 8 February 1696 (CO). The Grand Prince had arrived ten days
earlier with a following of more than 40 persons. Separate libretti had been dedicated on 5 and 6 February
1696.' Carnival had opened on the 4th, and he was said to be enjoying it greatly during the following
week (M). He was feted by the Venetian government on the 6th. Gifts in his honor (wild beasts, fish,
wine, candies and confections, crystal) were so numerous that four boats were required to convey them.'*!

 Godi explains that he had assumed the mask of the poet and opted to write a tragedy only in order
to obey the command of a great person, presumably the Grand Prince to whom he was dedicating the
work and whose sojourn in Venice was also noted. Godi says he spent three months writing the text,
making Eraclea a notable exception to the numerous libretti which were written in haste.' This was
the first of only two five-act works produced at San Salvatore (the second was Zeno's Tirsi, 1696/10).

'' Friedrich III (shortly to be Friedrich I of Prussia) inherited from his father Friedrich Wilhelm (the Great; 1640-88) the mantle of leadership
of German Protestantism. He supported William of Orange in his efforts to recapture the English throne (1688) and opposed Louis XIV. He
was imprisoned in 1697, but in 1701 the emperor, eager for his military support, granted him the title of King of Prussia.

Ercole in Cielo Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[HERCULES IN HEAVEN]

A tragedia per musica (5) Text by Girolamo Frigimelica-Roberti
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With cori SORTING DATE: 1696-02-11

Dedicated to Georg Friedrich, Margrave of Brandenburg

After completing his Labors, Hercules married the beautiful Deianeira/Dejanira, who accidentally
poisoned him. This account moves from Hercules' bravery in rescuing Deianeira from the Centaur and
other heroic deeds to the misunderstanding which led to his death. Ercole included five elaborately
choreographed cori. Ercole opened on 11 February 1696 (CO). Members of the House of Brandenburg
had arrived in Venice during the week ending 28 January 1696 and remained into Lent, leaving during
the week ending 17 March (M). The Corriere's short summary of the work said that it opened in Hell
and ended in Heaven.

Continuing his discourse on modes of tragedy from earlier libretti, Frigimelica-Roberti traces the four
modes defined by Aristotle. Of those with tragic endings, his recently well-received Rosimonda (1696/3)
illustrated the situation in which the culminating horrible event was intended. In this work, in contrast,
the culminating horrible event was accidental. He notes that he has followed the models of Sophocles
and Seneca in order to introduce a different kind of pleasure appropriate to the second part of Carnival.
These accommodations lean towards the model of Sophocles and include combining the vague with
the well-defined, acchieving a certain style and color in the poetry, and encouraging the use of
scenery which was similarly varied in its hues and designs. He says that although this explanation of
his goals in attempting to create a new species of tragedy for the musical stage might be insufficient
in other places, for the audience in Venice it provides an adequate rationale. In its grandeur and sense
of power, the portrayal of Hercules' mighty physique on the frontispiece of the libretto (Illustration
14) is suggestive of a mentality somewhat different from that described by Frigimelica-Roberti.
Following the example of Frigimelica-Roberti's previous tragedies, this one employed eleven mythical
figures, four heavenly gods, and seven cori. Signora [Maria] Landini was given the role of Deianeira,
in preference to Diana Turinese, who sang as Iole. A Mantuan agent informs us that this caused the
exchange of disparaging glances between the husbands of these two singers.' The role of Hercules
was taken by Francesco Ballarini. A newcomer to the San Giovanni Grisostomo cast was Nicola Paris
(Hillo).'*

Arias in I-Rvat

Listed as Galvani SGG 29; Bonlini 311; Groppo 315; Alm 427

220 A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA
Dedicated to Lorenzo Verzusio Beretti-Landi'
Alaric II, the king of the Visigoths [485-507], was killed in battle by Clovis, the king of France. His
son Amalaric feigned peace with Clovis and sought the hand of Clovis's daughter Clotilda, who, however,
was promised to Lothar, the king of Aquitaine. Clovis now debated which union would be more politically
advantageous. The work opens in the palace of Lothar, who is about to marry Clotilda. Clotilde was
first performed on 18 February 1696 (CO). The dedicatee was in Mantua on c. 31 January 1696 as part
of the receiving party for the bride of Rinaldo d'Este, the duke of Modena, which may have delayed
the opening of the work.'

Ov Neri maintained that the outline of the plot lent itself to tragedy, but that it was impossible to present
one in San Cassiano, which he called a theater of dilettantes. He recommended some of the stage
incidents as well as the marvelous music of Ruggieri, the appearance of celebrated professors among
the dilettantes, and enchanting sets as items which would conceal the deficiencies of this libretto. The
work was later revived at San Moise under the title Amor per vendetta (1702/7). It cannot be established
whether the work on this text given at the Cocomero in Florence (Carnival 1706) used Ruggieri's music,
but it did employ Neri's text. The Florentine cast featured Margarita Salicola in the title role, with the
comic singer Antonio Maria Ristorini as Sancio.'*

1696/9 L'Asmiro, re di Corinto Music by Pietro Romolo Pignatta
[AsmiRos, KING OF CORINTH]
A dramma musicale Text by Pietro Romolo Pignatta
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1696-02-18
mao Dedicated to Johann Seyfried, Prince of Eggenberg'

First given under the title // vanto d'amore at the prince's palace in 1689,' L 'Asmiro focused on the
aftermath of the siege of Corinth. In Pignatta's original version, Thomyris/Tomiri and her infant brother
Erippos were concealed in an underground passage by their uncle, Ergestes. Because they grew up
with assumed identities, the mature Erippos sought unwittingly to marry his sister. The goddess Amore,
who led them to safety, was visible only to Thomyris. In this version, Asmiros, the king of Corinth,
had fallen in love with Thomyris and sought to liberate her from the prison of Kleisthenes/Clistene,
the king of Alexandria.

'6 Serving at the time as secretary to the duke of Mantua, Beretti-Landi (1661-1725) was a virtuoso of diplomacy if not also of intrigue. After
the break-up of the duchy of Mantua (1702), he became attached to the canton of Lucerne (where in 1704 he started the Summer Nights
music festival, which continues to the present day), served as a Swiss Guard, represented Spanish interests (1703-1716), and eventually became
Spanish ambassador to Holland (1716-1721). The possibility that he was already serving Spanish interests during his years of Mantuan service
is tantalizing, for, having been involved in the procurement of musical performers there, he could also have been a conduit for Spanish comedians,
both to Mantua and to Venice.

' The prince (1644-1713), who was also the duke of Krumlov/Cromau (Bohemia; now the Czech Republic), lived in Gradisco, near Gorizia,
where several officials of the Holy Roman Empire had summer residences. He was to be elected to the Order of the Golden Fleece in 1697.
Pignatta had been in his service since 1688 or earlier. The prince visited Venice during Carnival 1693 (arriving on 11 January, according to
CO), and it is therefore possible that Pignatta had also been present. Cesky Krumlov, on the Vitava [Moldau] River, was on the main trading
route between Bavaria and Italy. Its palace housed an impressive theater (currently awaiting restoration) of intricate seventeenth-century design.
Many Italian operas (particularly by Pallavicino and Pollarolo) were staged in it. From 1728, Eggenberg's palace near Graz hosted operas.

1696/12 Zenone, imperatore d'Oriente Music attributed to Tomaso Albinoni
[XENON, EMPEROR OF THE EAST]
A dramma per musica Text by Antonio Marchi
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1696-11-14~
4 Dedicated to Jan Casimir Bochum'

Xenon/Zeno was the ruler of the Eastern Roman Empire in 476, when Rome was sacked and the Western
Empire collapsed. Although briefly deposed, his rule was re-established and he served until he was
murdered in 490. In the tense climate of the time his wife, Belisante,' was falsely suspected of
treachery. A number of fictional elements were added to this account. Marchi's libretto notes that the
work was written for current audiences, not for long-term storage [in a] prestigious library.

oo Zenone had opened by 17 November 1696 (M). The libretto was dedicated on the 12th. This was
Albinoni's first opera for San Cassiano, which was to be his chief sphere of theatrical activity in Venice.'
The work opened ina labyrinth within a horrid cave. Several other scenes of horror were interspersed
with pastoral and ceremonial scenes.
