In this pastoral treatment of Greco-Roman history from the first century AD, the beauty of Miriam,
the wife of Herod, the king of Judaea, aroused the jealousy of her sister-in-law, Salome.'* Several
episodes of the plot, which was situated in Jerusalem, were freely invented. The libretto called attention
to ways in which the text could be abbreviated. La Mariamme is most likely to have opened during
the latter half of November 1696. The dedicatee was in Venice from the start of October through 24
January 1697 to negotiate troop allocations and finances on behalf of the imperial ambassador (M).
He was feted around the first of the new year.'TM The title-page says autumn.

Amor' e dover" Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[LovE AND DuTY]

A dramma per musica Text by Domenico David
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a danza SORTING DATE: 1696-12-26

Dedicated to Ferdinando III de' Medici, Grand Prince of Tuscany

Matilda, the daughter of Beatrice d'Este and a Tuscan count in the eleventh century, was instructed
by her mother, newly remarried mother to a cousin, Geoffrey of Lorraine, to marry Geoffrey's crippled
son (Geoffrey the Hunchback). In encouraging the union, Beatrice was torn between her love for the
prince and her royal duty, Matilda by love for her mother and personal disinterest. A confrontation over
feudal lands with Henry IV of Germany was brewing.'** The action was set in Ferrara.

This work was first officially performed on 26 December 1696 (CO); its rehearsal on 21 December
attracted a large audience (M). The title-page is dated 1697. The work was criticized (M) for the fact
that the sets [did] not correspond to the music,' although the Corriere ordinario reported that the
drama, the music, and the voices were universally praised.'* Maria Domenica Pini sang as Matilda,
with Matteo Sassani (Goffredo). Michel Angelo Gasparini appeared as the councillor Silvio.'*

L'Erifile opened on 27 December 1696 (CO). A license to print its libretto had been issued on the 17th

The Assyrian prince Eumenes was not permitted to rule until he was twenty-two years old. When his

although he was secretly enchanted by Roxane's beauty. / regi equivoci opened on 12 January 1697

Il Tigrane, re d'Armenia Music by Tomaso Albinoni
[TIGRANES, KING OF ARMENIA]

A dramma per musica Text by Giulio Cesare Corradi
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1697-01-19

Dedicated to Felipe Antonio Spinola Colonna, Duke of Sesto!

After acceding to the throne of Armenia, the ambitious Tigranes sought to marry Oronta, the daughter
of his predecessor. An Athenian rebellion interfered with his plans. Tigrane opened on 19 January 1697
(CO). On the 26th it was said to be much applauded (M). It was still in production on 9 February,
when it was said to include some exquisite voices (M). A license to print the libretto had been issued
on 9 January 1696 M.V. Corradi praised the virtue of Albinoni, saying that music of such accomplishment
rendered the label dilettante an understatement of his skill.

I rivali generosi Music attributed to Marc' Antonio Ziani
[THE GENEROUS RIVALS]

A dramma per musica Text by Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1697-01-21~

Dedicated to Franz Heinrich, Count of Mansfeld!

The text treats the triumphs of Justinian's general Belisarius over the Visigoths in the sixth century.
Amorous interests revolved on Elpidia, the princess of Puglia, who was admired by both a Greek prince
and the king of the Goths. In a subplot another Greek prince fell in love with a Gothic princess. The
action took place in Ravenna, which, after being besieged in 538, was to be the second most important
city of the Italian peninsula for the next five centuries.'

A license to print the libretto was issued on 2 January 1696 M.V. The production opened between 19
and 26 January 1696 M.V., probably nearer the first date, since the count, who was feted by the Republic
on the 12th, left Venice on the 24th (M). The work was still running on 9 February 1696 M.V., when
the production (Ja composizione dell opera) was praised (M). The Corriere (9 February), amplifying
a report from the Mercurio of 26 January, reported that the work was extraordinarily applauded.
One of the singers, Matteo Sassani (II Matteucci) accepted an invitation by the French ambassador
to give a private concert on 2 January. It took place in a palace on the Grand Canal with doors wide
open, so that the sound accidentally attracted a water-borne audience. The concert lasted until 3:30
O.V. Sassani sang with great alertness (veglia) and was very well received by an indoor audience
consisting of the ambassador, the papal legate, the receiver of Malta, their respective courts, and various
other dignitaries.'"' Another singer and a Bolognese priest who played the viola (both unidentified)
also participated.'*

T rivali was given in Florence during Carnevale 1698. The text of J rivali was reset for Naples in
1700.'? On 12 March 1701 Zeno wrote to Lodovico Antonio Muratori in Modena that his text was
to be given again, now in a setting by Giannettini.2 A pastiche version was given in Reggio in the
spring of 1710.7" Segments of the original work were combined by Handel with arias from later Venetian
operas to create the pastiche Elpidia (HWV 1A; King's Theatre, London, 1725).

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

The consul Titus Manlius Torquatus was the subject of Roman legends extolling both mercy anda stern
sense of justice. In the third century BC, he subdued Latin rebellions. In this account he sent his like-
named son, Manlius, to suppress such rebellions. Tito Manlio is reported to have opened on 31 January
1697 (CO), a normally prohibited date for theatrical activity. Its opening was already anticipated on
the 19th (M). It had been given at Pratolino, the summer residence of the Grand Duke of Tuscany, on
20 September 1696, and was to be repeated in Venice at the end of the year as 1697/9. It was given
in Giannettini's setting in Reggio (spring 1701).

The Corriere (2 February) commented enthusiastically on the final scene, in which a machine representing
the Tiber dazzled the audience, and noted on the 9th that the work was extraordinarily applauded.
The Mercurio related that, unlike Amor' e dover (1696/14), Tito was well received. On the same date
it was praised in the Mercurio for its music but not for its sets or singers. The librettist acknowledged
that the order of some scenes had been changed, arias added, and the overall length significantly reduced,
but that the work's heroic character had not been diminished. Antonio Francesco Carli took the role
of Tito, with Matteo Sassani as Manlio. Michel Angelo Gasparini held down two roles  those of Decio,
captain of the Phalanges, and Germinio, captain of the Latins. The famous virtuosa who was given
1200 doppie in jewels and coins from Baron Martini was probably Maria Domenica Pini (Servilia)
rather than Angiola Gringher (Vitelia). Both were in their first season at the theater.

Score (Pratolino): D-SW1; arias in B-Be; I-Ne

Listed as Galvani SGG 31; Bonlini 322; Groppo 326; Alm 440, 441

In this tale of ancient Sparta, Hermione, the daughter of Menelaus, was promised in marriage to Orestes.
Unaware of this arrangement, her father offered her hand to Achilles. Conflicting dates are given for
the opening. The Mercurio (19 January) reports that the second work of the season in this theater opened
on 14 January, while the Corriere (9 February) cites the opening by title on 7 February, by which date,
according to the Mercurio, attendance had dwindled. The anonymous librettist noted that the work had
been written ina few days, suggesting that the preceding work [La Mariamme] had had a poor reception.
The production was prepared (M) by an unidentified Prince Colonna.

1697/6 Primislao, primo re di Boemia Music attributed to Tomaso Albinoni
[PREMYSL, THE FIRST KING OF BOHEMIA]
A dramma per musica Text by Giulio Cesare Corradi
M1 Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1697-11-09
a Dedicated to Giacomo Riccardi, Venetian Sergeant-General in the Levant?
we The peasant Premys| founded Prague. Pfemysl's high-born wife, LibuSe, was widely known for her

learning. From the Piemyslid dynasty which was established in the eighth century the later entity of
Bohemia emerged. The first of the work's four balli was for the Four Elements (Earth, Air, Fire, and
Water) and the second for the four parts of the world. The second featured a globe which opens
up into the four parts of the world and shows all its peoples.

OOn Primislao opened on 9 November 1697 (CO, M), the date of the dedication of the libretto. A good
attendance was reported on the 16th (M). Smetana's Libuse (Prague, 1881) was centered on the same
two principal roles (LibuSe and Pfemysl). Josef Wenzig's German text (1866), which portrayed Libu8e
as wise and Premysl as lucky (for having been selected to be her husband), took on Czech nationalistic
overtones in the later nineteenth century. An element of Bohemian nationalism is already expressed
in the Corradi text.

A No musical sources known
Listed as Galvani SCas 32; Groppo 331; Bonlini 327; Alm 448

1697/7 Eumene Music attributed to Marc' Antonio Ziani
[EUMENES]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Apostolo Zeno
i Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SorTING DATE: 1697-11-12
& Without dedication
 As he lay dying, Aristarchos, the king of Cappadocia, left the care of his infant daughter Artemis to

his sister Laodikeia, who tried to manoeuver herself onto the throne. After preliminary success, she
fell in love with the Macedonian captain Eumenes. He, in turn, fell in love with Artemis. Zeno claimed
to have taken the story from Plutarch." In preparation by 26 October (M), Eumene opened on 12
November 1697 (CO, NV) and enjoyed universal applause (I-Rvat A). It was revived at San Moise
as 1722/11. Albinoni set a different version of the story (1717/9) between these productions.

A No musical sources known
Listed as Galvani SAng 38; Bonlini 329; Groppo 333; Alm 450

?7 Several important naval battles were fought in the eastern Mediterranean between June and October 1697. The results favored the Venetians.
Riccardi was probably returning from one of these. Meanwhile, the son of Baron Taxis, en route from Bohemia to Naples, stopped in Venice
around the time this work opened, providing a tie-in between the plot and one possible attendee; Taxis left c. 15 November (NV).

208

The staging is reminiscent of that in one of Corradi's earliest libretti, La divisione del mondo (music by Legrenzi, 1675/2). Alchemy had
been a prominent interest of some courts in Central Europe (especially that of Rudolf II in Prague), and, in common with other physical sciences,
it was attracting new interest through the writings and assemblies devoted to the work of Vincenzo Coronelli and other investigators. Coronelli
(1650-1718) was one of the most enterprising of Venetian academicians. In contrast to the literary interests of the Arcadians, who were bent
on reform, Coronelli and his Argonauts were intent on expanding knowledge of geography, navigation, astronomy, and the other sciences
rooted in the physical world. They produced thirteen volumes of the At/ante veneto and other books in the 1690s.

20 Another work with Bohemian associations is 1696/9.

210 Personal details are largely lacking in Plutarch's account. Aristarchos is given as Aristarfo in the libretto, although Aristarco must have
been intended.

The sorceress Circe, who changed Ulysses' men into pigs, failed to control the voyager, who resisted
her spells by taking a special herb. After living with her for a year, he and his men set sail for the
Underworld. In this account, Polydoros, the prince of Troy, arrived at Circe's island ahead of Ulysses,
thereby changing the story.

Oo@ Although announced for the 11th (NV), Circe opened on 13 November 1697 and enjoyed universal
applause (CO, I-Rvat A); the libretto had been dedicated on the 12th. On the 16th, all three currently
operating theaters were reported to be enjoying robust attendance (gran gente), and on the 23rd the
applause and concourse, especially of foreigners was again noted.' The appearance of a French
virutosa had been announced on 26 October (M). Aureli commented wryly in the libretto that although
Circe had been abandoned by Ulysses, she could enjoy the attention of the secretary of state to the duke
of Mantua [the dedicate].

A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Silvani'
rl Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)

a Dedicated to Franz Ferdinand, Count of Salbourg!

The fanciful plot was loosely based on Merovingian history. It mainly concerned the fortunes of Alaric,
who had been taken from Germany to Norway as a 3-year-old by Vandals fleeing the campaign of his
father, Ernst. Now grown, Alaric had himself been proclaimed king of the Vandals but had made the
error of falling in love with Ginevra, the wife of one of his generals. In a subplot Briinnhilde, the widow
of Ernst, was protected by Aistolf. Silvani asked the reader to forgive him for liberties he had taken
with facts and to concentrate instead on the music.

Cec L'ingratitudine opened on 17 January 1698 (NV), the date of dedication of the libretto [17 January
1697 M.V.]. The title-page is dated 1698. The Venetian production may have been poorly attended,
since there were heavy snows in late January and early February (M); Lent began on 19 February. A
musical work on the same text which was given in Florence during Carnival 1701 bore the title Alarico,
re de' Vandali. The present work had a revival at San Cassiano (1702/4); the Florentine cast performed
the work again in Palermo (1705).

218 Montagu, who would make his public entrance as special ambassador on 3 February 1698, had arrived on 21 December 1697. He was sent

prince to the English throne was not recognized by the papacy, to whom this missive was directed, since William replaced the deposed Catholic

of British merchants by Venetian commanders in the Levant and to settle long-standing debts of Venetian merchants.

a Dedicated to Marc' Antonio Borghese, Prince of RossanoTM*
Camilla, the virgin daughter of the late king and queen of the Volscians, was living as the shepherdess
Dorinda. She was an accomplished huntress. Many episodes involving the Volscians and their enemies,
the Latins, were elaborated in this plot, probably to suit the prince's Arcadian sympathies.

 When the Venetian production opened on 6 October 1698 (PV), it elicited universal satisfaction (NV).
Two explanations exist for the unusually early date of opening. According to one report (CO), it was
prompted by an exceptionally wet autumn, which roused the nobility from villeggiatura. Meanwhile,
the state visit of Czar Peter the Great, who had arrived on 29 July, could have called for special
entertainments. He was accompanied by two palaces of attendants and was seeking the help of the
Venetians in repulsing the Turks.
Camilla ran continuously until at least 30 November (M). It was apparently revived after L 'innocenza
giustificata (1698/9), for it was in the midst of a run on 16 January 1699 (BG). Venetian attendees at
the original production must have been few: BG (contradicting CO) indicated (16 October 1698) that
the other theaters would delay their openings until the nobility returned from villeggiatura.

O0 The production of Camilla was quite exceptional with respect to the ticket price of one-quarter ducat,
an unusually high price which caused considerable comment (M). An already famous work, Camilla
had had its premiere in Naples on 27 December 1696 and was given in Rome in January 1698, in
Florence during Carnival 1698, and in Mantua on an undetermined date in the same year. In all, Camilla
enjoyed at least 38 productions through 1765; most used the music of Bononcini. Among the early ones,
the translation by Owen MacSwiney (later called Swiney) attracted significant attention to Italian opera
in Bononcini's setting (London, 1706), which enjoyed more than 100 performances through 1728.78
Nicole Minato's text, La regina de' Volsci, which was set by Antonio Draghi (with ballets by Schmelzer)
for the Empress Eleonora Maddalena on 6 January 1690, may have been inspired this work.

The central character in this work was not the powerful Cypriot king AigisthosTM" but rather the humble
Helphenike/Elfenice, a gentlewoman of Thebes who was without resources and served Aigisthos's
daughter Doriclea.* Aigisthos's son Kleitarchos fell in love with Helphenike. To avoid marriage to
a suitor selected by the king, Helphenike consecrated herself to the Vestal Virgins.

OO ws A license to print the libretto was issued on 30 October 1698, and it was in rehearsal by 1 November.
Although two reports claim that it was scheduled to open on 17 November (PV, A), NV says that it
opened on the 8th. The opening curtain was to rise in the middle of the sinfonia and reveal Alidoros
(the king's preferred suitor for his daughter) and Helphenice moving from a loge into a small garden.
In the ballo at the end of Act 1, vases of flowers were transmuted into a group of young women
(damigelle). One of the balli in Act 2 was for the courtesans of all nations. Some of the scenery 
including the Hall of Mirrors in Act 2 and the Temple of Cynthia in Act 3  was relatively unusual.
An appeal to French taste can be inferred from these traits."

Silvani's text was concerned with the division of Charlemagne's empire in the ninth century. His son,
Ludwig the Pious, had three sons  Lothar, Pepin, and Ludwig  from his first marriage. After the
death of his first wife, Ludwig the Elder married Judith, the daughter of the duke of Bavaria, and she
produced a fourth son  Charles. The division of the father's property [c. 843] caused much conflict
among the brothers, with the result (in this account) that Lothar waged war on the other three and accused
his step-mother of adultery with a Spanish duke in order to gain the empire. Repercussions of this
division carried through German and French political history into modern times.

CO L'innocenza opened on 26 December 1698 (NV). Its title-page is dated 1699; its libretto was dedicated
on 24 December 1698. The production included balli in this work for Spanish and French cavaliers
and for German rockets (incendiari). Silvani praised the fertile bizzaria of Vinaccesi's ideas.
Nonetheless, Camilla (1698/5) was revived after this run terminated. Silvani's text hada long life, both
in direct derivations and in tropes on its various strands. The text was reset by Chelleri as 1722/4.

Faramondo* Music by Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[FARAMOND]

A dramma per musica Text by Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1698-12-27

Dedicated to Ferdinando III de' Medici, Grand Prince of Tuscany

King Gustav of Bohemia had three children  Sven/Sueno, Adolph, and Rosamond. When he refused
to give the hand of his daughter to the king of the Swedes, war ensued. Faramond, the legendary king
of Franconia, played a decisive role in the final battle. Faramondo opened on 27 December 1698
(NV), the date of dedication of one version of the libretto.' Francesco Antonio Pistocchi sang in the
title role, with Anton Francesco Carli (Gustavo) and [Maria] Domenica Pini (Rosimonda).?**
Faramondo seems to have cemented relations between Zeno and the Florentine court. Apart from the
frequent presence of the Grand Prince in Venice, Zeno was in regular correspondence with Antonio
Magliabecchi in Florence from June 1698 onward concerning the dramatic initiatives of the Arcadians
and related matters. On 27 December he sent Magliabecchi a copy of this work with the comment, The
intrigues of the drama, which should have its first performance tonight, do not permit me to enjoy them
all by myself.** The text remained in use for the next half century. Handel's work of the same title
(HWV 39; 1738) was based on a 1720 revision of Zeno's text.

Score in A-Wn; arias in B-Bc

Listed as Galvani SGG 34; Bonlini 339; Groppo 343; Alm 461

Gl'amori tra gl'odi, Music by Mare' Antonio Ziani

ossia Ramiro in Norvegia
[Love IN THE MIDST OF HATRED, OR RAMIR IN NORWAY]

A dramma per musica Text by Marc' Antonio Remena!
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1699-01-10~
Without dedication

Against the background of the animosity between Ramir, the king of Denmark, and Effro, the king
of Sweden, intrigues involving Lamberta and Irene (disguised as Ardea) thaw royal animosities. Since
San Cassiano did not respond to the Arcadian mandate for reform, it is not surprising that G/'amori
contained a generic role for a comic servant (Nesso).

Despite the absence ofa dedication, the subject suggests that G/ amori (in which the names are fictional)
was intended for the visit of the prince of Denmark, who arrived in Venice on c. 7 January 1699. The
introduction to the libretto indicates that this production was arranged hastily from a text which had
been written at an earlier time for a performance which was deferred. As now constituted, the work
lacked its original merit and was beholden to the limitations of the site. Some arias were omitted
in the interests of brevity. Ziani's skills as a composer, in distinction to the restrictions of the situation,
were second to none.

Dedicated to Joseph Leopold?

The daughter of Claudius and Messalina, Octavia was married to Nero, who divorced her to marry
Poppea, the wife of the emperor Otho/Ottone. Octavia was falsely found guilty of treason and executed.
As the libretto depicts him, the reckless Nero was a student of playing the lyre, a dilettante of music,
[and] a friend of song, fantasy, vanity, and lasciviousness. The work opened with the coronation of
Tiridates, a pretender to the Armenian throne.

This second opera was first performed on 13 February 1699 (CO, NV). It was variously reported
to have been received with great applause (NV) and with maximum applause for the great machines
(M). Maria Domenica Pini sang in the title role, with Francesco Antonio Pistocchi (Nerone), Anna
Maria Torri (Poppea), and Gio. Battista Franceschini (Ottone).?

La fortezza al cimento Music by Giuseppe Aldrovandini?
[FORTITUDE AT RISK]

A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Silvani
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1699-02-14

Dedicated to Eugene, Prince of Savoy

In this treatment of history, Nero defeated Mithridates and imprisoned his wife and daughter but then
was killed. La fortezza opened on 14 February 1699 (CO, M), which was also the date of dedication
of its libretto. It may have been one of the newly opened operas which was receiving universal
applause with a great concourse on the 21st (NV). A setting of the same text, possibly Aldrovandini's,
was performed with an added comic role, in Florence during Carnival 1703. Another setting, by Francesco
Mancini, was given in Naples in 1721.

Teodosio Music attributed to Mare' Antonio Ziani
[THEODOsIUS]

A dramma per musica Text (mis)attributed to Vincenzo Grimani?
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1699-02-14
Without dedicatee

This plot depicted the rivalry between the (Eastern) Roman and Persian empires. After the Roman
Arcadius was killed in battle, the victor, Isdegard, cunningly offered to look after his orphaned children,
Theodosius and Pulcheria. The offer was deceitful and confrontations continued. Teodosio apparently
opened on 14 February 1698 (CO). Although there is no dedicatee, it seems likely that the work was
intended for performance during the visit of the queen of Poland, who arrived on 18 January 1699 (M).
A public reception for her was held almost immediately. She was expected to remain for only two weeks
but may have stayed longer; she did not reach her next stop, Bologna, until 1 March.

Milziade Music by Giovanni Maria Ruggieri
[MILTIADES]

A dramma per musica Text by Lotto Lotti
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (Fat Week)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1699-02-25

Dedicated to Giovanni Battista, Count of Castelbarco

Miltiades, the Athenian general who defeated Darius at the battle of Marathon, here posed as a slave
who was ultimately betrothed to Darius's daughter, Roxane. The action took place in Persepolis. Milziade,
the last work to be produced within a regular sequence at SS. Giovanni e Paolo, can only have been
performed near the end of Carnival, since the libretto was dedicated on 24 February, two days before
Giovedi Grasso. The dedicatee, an envoy of the emperor to the duke of Mantua, had arrived in Venice
by the 7th (NV). Lotti explained in the dedication that this was not the work he intended as the second
of Carnival and he apologized for its deficiencies. He hoped that the music of Ruggieri, one of the
most accredited of his profession, would offset the work's defects.

Dedicated to the Ladies of the Veneto

The establishment of Moorish rule in Spain upset the balance of power involving such other lands as
Arabia and Tunisia. This plot played on these new conflicts. It hinged on portraying Egilda, who was
really the daughter of Roderic/Rodrigo, the last king of the Goths, as the daughter of a North African

army commander. The work, situated in Cordova, had been given in Vienna on 30 June 1697.2

Although an opening had been announced for 3 November, this work actually had its premiere on

7 November 1699 (CO, M). A license to print the libretto had been issued on 29 October. Anna Maria
Battaglia, a Bolognese singer in the employ of the duke of Mantua, took the role of Egilda. Other members
of the cast named in the libretto were Oliviero Matraia (in the service of the viceroy of Sicily), Margherita
Raimondi (Merisbe) and Filippo Sandri (Arideno) from Verona, Carlo Campelli (Cratero) from Milan,
and Paolo Teodorovich (Consalvo), who was in the service of Cardinal Pallavicino.?

Rossane, imperatrice degli Assiri Music by multiple composers?
[ROXANE, EMPRESS OF THE ASSYRIANS]

A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With a ballo and cori SORTING DATE: 1699-11-22~

Dedicated to Ferdinand Carlo Gonzaga, Duke of Mantua

The orphaned Assyrian princess Roxane was courted by the Persian king Artabanos, who falsely
represented himselfas a widower. His wife, Argene, upon discovering his treachery, schemed for Roxane
to wed the Armenian prince Arsakes. The action took place in Babylonia.

Given that it was for the autumn season, Rossane is likely to have opened during the St. Martin's period
(11-28 November), following Sant' Angelo's example in recent years. The publisher's date on the title-
page is MDXIC. Bonlini noted that the libretto printed in 1700 (see 1700/6) was a reprint,' suggesting
a continuation of this production after Christmas.

Rossane had ten roles, an unusually large number at the time. Four allegorical figures (Venus, Love,
Delight, and Happiness) were also required. The staging was somewhat exotic in its calls for a royal
peacock and military instruments for a royal cavalcade (for which the dedicatee had a great enthusiasm;
see Suppl. Se). In the final scene a machine was pulled by an elephant.

Dedicated to Anzolo Maria Priuli, N.V.

The Roman military leader Paulus Aemilius captured Crete and governed Macedonia in the first century
AD. Alexander, the son of Perseus, the king of Macedonia, spied on the Romans by pretending to be

Lucio Vero" Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[Lucius VERUS]

A dramma per musica Text derived from Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1699-12-26

Dedicated to Felipe Antonio Spinola Colonna, Duke of Sesto

Lucius Verus of Ephesos, where this work is situated, served as co-emperor with and later succeeded
Marcus Aurelius of Rome. The political relationship was solidified by Lucius's marriage to his
collaborator's daughter, Lucilla. Before the marriage was concluded, however, the Parthians waged
war on Rome. Lucius defeated their leader, Vologeses [191-208 AD], and fell in love with his widow
Berenice. A councillor for Marcus Aurelius demanded that Lucius choose between his promise to Lucilla
and his infatuation with Berenice.

A license to print the libretto was issued on 14 December 1699. Some libretti*' were dedicated on 26
December 1699, which was also the date of the first performance (M). The title-page was dated 1700.
Lucio was received with applause. Francesco de Grandis sang in the title role, with Maria Domenica
Pini (Berenice) and Filippo Scandalibene (Volgeso)."*

The text had been performed in an anonymous musical setting at Pratolino in September. It was billed
there as a commedia and given before Cardinal Francesco de' Medici.* The same text was the basis
for the production of // trionfo della costanza at the Cocomero (1709). In various permutations it was
extremely long-lived. Albinoni and Gasparini set it for other venues in 1713 and 1719 respectively.
Araya set it for Sant' Angelo as 1735/1. Revised towards mid-century by G. E. Luccarelli as Vologeso,
the text found new representations in the settings of Galuppi (1748), Sarti (1754), Bertoni (1757), Sacchini
(1764), Traetta (1774), and Martin y Soler (1783). Another derivative was Mattio Verazzi's Vologeso,
set by Jommelli (1766).

Il duello d'amore e di vendetta' Music attributed to Mare' Antonio Ziani
[THE DUEL OF LOVE AND REVENGE]

A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Silvani
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1699-12-27

Dedicated to Luis della Cerda y Aragona, Viceroy of Naples**

This fanciful treatment of Iberian history concerns the end of the Visigoths' reign but contrasts sharply
with David's text, set by Pollarolo as 1692/10. Roderic/Rodrigo, the last Gothic king to rule Spain,
seduced the young noblewoman Florinda with the promise of marriage. Upon the death of the ruler
Wittiza/Vitige, Roderic succeeded to the Spanish throne [710-711]. The future of Spain was thought
to depend upon the son to whom Florinda gave birth.** The action took place in Seville.

11 duello must have opened prior to 31 December 1699 because a report of 2 January 1700 said that
it was enjoying applause (M). The libretto had been dedicated on 26 December. On 16 January 1699
M.V. (M), it was said to be the best-attended work of the season. The cast-list given in the libretto
indicates the dominance of singers from the Mantuan court  Maria Landini (Elisena), Anna [Maria]
Battaglia (Climene), Margherita Raimondi (Florinda), and Filippo Sandri (Giuliano). The role of Rodrigo
was taken by Nicola Grimaldi (from the vice-regal chapel at Naples), who was appearing in his Venetian
debut. That of the son of Wittiza (Evanco) was sung by Oliviero Matraia from the vice-regal chapel
in Sicily. Paolo Teodorovich appeared in a minor role.

Ziani's work was given in Mantua in the spring of 1701. Silvani's text was adapted for Handel's first
Italian opera, now known as Rodrigo but first given with the title Vincer se stesso e la maggior vittoria
(HWV 5) for the Accademia degl'Infuocati, which met in the civic theater on the Via del Cocomero
(Florence) late in 1707. It was set as Li sdegni cangiati per amore (San Moise, 1725/4).

The 1700s: An Overview

he years 1700-1703 brought profound changes to
Ne northern Italy and adjacent parts of Europe, as the
War of Spanish Succession began. Initially, the
dispute involved only France and Austria, but eventually it
consumed most of the Continent and the British Isles. The
Venetian Republic maintained official neutrality, but several
early battles took place in the neighboring duchies of Mantua
and Modena. The Mantuan court took refuge in Monferrato.
The duke of Mantua, who sided with the French, became
an exile in Venice, where he died in 1708. Hostilities did
not cease until 1713.

The realities of war caused a purge of all theatrical
activities in Venice. The division between patrons sympa-
thetic to the French and those attuned to the Empire became
conspicuous as the war progressed. Performers could be
waylaid, sometimes for years, by the precarious nature of
travel. In compensation, Venetian opera was imitated in
ahost of venues. Even as that happened, the Great Northern
War, involving Sweden and Czarist Russia under Peter the
Great, served as a new stimulus to the theatrical imagination.
Librettists plumbed unfamiliar histories in search of new
subjects. To entertain audiences with fewer performers, the
staging of opera began to change. Prologues, cloud machines,
and the gods to populate them disappeared. Battle scenes
became passe except at San Giovanni Grisostomo. A new
theater, San Fantin, featured very young performers in low-
budget productions. It survived for the first twenty years of
the new century.

In this hobbled economy, the Grimani, on behalf of their
comedy house, San Samuele, contracted with the Vendramin,
who owned San Salvatore, to share resources and avoid direct
competition. One result was that San Salvatore ceased to
present operas, but so too did the Grimani's older opera-
house, SS. Giovanni e Paolo. Ina series of contracts written
between 1703 and 1708, prose comedies were back-handedly
prohibited at San Cassiano and Sant' Angelo over the next
twenty-five years! While Sant' Angelo had never presented
comedies, San Cassiano had alternated between modes of
entertainment. It was currently an opera house. San Moise,
which also had a history of alternation, was currently closed.

San Cassiano and Sant'Angelo promptly took their
revenge by introducing comic intermezzi into their operas

(1706). Comic roles in drammi per musica, which had been
in intermittent use for decades, were discouraged by the
Arcadian reformers promoted by the Grimani. San Giovanni
Grisostomo shunned this undignified innovation, but in the
remaining theaters, the familiar discourse of monarchs and
generals was now periodically interrupted by the petit-
bourgeois conversations of merchants and maids. San
Cassiano flourished.

Fewer libretti bore formal dedications. Dedicatees were
distinctly less eminent. Audiences became more anonymous.
Theater managers shifted their attention from pleasing a few
personaggi with large retinues to drawing audiences one by
one from a random population of visitors. In combination,
an influx of inexperienced impresari, a decline in the
presence of generous princes, and the recruitment of veteran
performers to venues elsewhere caused chaos. Annual
contracts remained in effect only in the larger houses. In the
smaller theaters, pay was dependent on the number of
performances. Aspects of productions thought to be pleasing
to female audiences  lavish costumes and elaborate balli
replaced those considered appropriate for male audiences
awe-inspiring sets and vigorous battle scenes. (Some male
commentators expressed disgust at this perceived
feminization of the genre.) Table 23 gives only the faintest
notion of how different opera in the first decade of the new
century was from that of the 1690s.

With adaptations, the successes of the Grimani at San
Giovanni Grisostomo culminated during this decade. The
political career of Vincenzo, who was the co-owner of the
theater and the effective manager of San Samuele, was
capped by his appointment (1708) as viceroy of Naples.
(Service to a foreign monarch also resulted in his exclusion
from the Venetian nobility.) Grimani's contacts with
Neapolitan performers led to an invitation to Alessandro
Scarlatti for Carnival 1706-07 and may have paved the way
for Handel's presence at San Giovanni in 1709-10. Pollarolo
and Lotti were San Giovanni's main composers. Ambassa-
dors from the Empire and its allies as well as from the Papal
States were instrumental in procuring the services of many
new singers. The glory years began to fade after Grimani's
death in 1710. San Giovanni's decline was accelerated by
the death of Gio. Carlo Grimani in 1714.

TABLE 23. Productions by theater, 1690s vs. 1700s.

The changing mix of theatrical venues, musicians, and
audiences conspired to spread opera over most of the autumn.
There was now significant growth in the St. Luke's period
at the expense of the St. Stephen's. The number of operas
given during the formal Carnival period remained steady.
A few works were given exclusively for the last days of
Carnival. Sant' Angelo and San Cassiano, which were the
most active theaters of the decade, operated in both the
autumn and winter periods. San Fantin functioned sporadi-
cally from the margins of autumn through Carnival.

Theaters hosted an increasingly diverse mixture of
Bolognese singers, Florentine patrons, and figures of stature
in the Empire. Allegiances between specific duchies and
houses came apart as the duchies themselves collapsed. King
Frederick IV of Denmark (1708-09), the most prestigious
visitor of the decade, spread his largesse over the three
principal houses and the Gran Ridotto.

@ Other

Gasparini and Albinoni, who were the among the most
active composers of the decade, worked mainly at San
Cassiano. Compared to the 1690s, the number of operas (92)
increased, but this reflected increased turnover. Embassies
increasingly presented private entertainments to insulate
themselves from the problems of public theaters. Source
survival dropped precipitously: only a dozen operas of the
decade are fully preserved.

War was a strong stimulus to the circulation of news,
but it frequently disrupted their delivery. The mercuri and
the legate's records remain valuable sources, but each has
some lapses. Records for 1701 are missing for the first.
Relevant information is skimpy for 1706 in the second.
Scribes were consumed by reporting battlefield hostilities
for long stretches of the decade. The upheavals of comedy
troupes are well documented in voluminous correspondence
preserved in Mantua.

1700/2 Il colore fa la regina Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[HER COLOR IDENTIFIES THE QUEEN]
A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
i Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1700-01-30
& Dedicated to Georg Friedrich, Margrave of Brandenburg

The axis of mistaken identity has shifted here from gender to ethnicity and race; the plot is fictitious.
The title seems to have been an afterthought; the libretto was originally published without a title.

 I colore was first performed on 30 January 1700 (CO, M, NV). A license to print the libretto had been
issued on 25 January 1700. Among the attendees were Alexander and Constantine Sobieski.

y-39 The work overflows with elements of exoticism. It carefully delineates different beliefs in China, where
astrology flourished, and India, where elephants roamed at will and a king could change the skin-color
of his subjects from black to white. It featured a monster twice the size of an ordinary elephant,
as well as fabulous costumes and jewels, a plain filled with silver columns, and a palace with a golden
vine. To proclaim it a scenic fantasy was not an exaggeration. The opening scene took place in
Cambodia [sic], where the sun was rising over the River Ganges.'

> Apparently Landgrave Karl (1654-1730) of Hesse-Kassel, who was married to Marie Anne de Courlande (1653-1711). The third of their
fourteen children was Prince Karl (1680-1702). An unnamed Hessian prince had arrived around the start of the year; a second arrived on the
6th (NV). The dedicatee was in town until the 25th (M).

> Perhaps loosely based on Baltic and North Sea history of c. 1000 AD. Of the four Boleslavs who ruled in the eleventh century, Boleslav
1(The Intrepid, 992-1025) is the most probable subject for this story. Sven I of Denmark [1000-1014] was concurrently King Swein of England
during the final year of his second reign (his widow's real name was Sigrid). The mixture of nationalities would have suited the rulers of Hesse-
Kassel, whose own family-tree was more mixed than most.

* Silvani's libretto indicates that as performed in Venice, the work was an abridged version of one given the previous summer for the duke
of Mantua.

* Durastante would have been only fourteen years old in 1700 (Kirkendale, Handel with Ruspoli, p. 304).
 See Besutti, La corte, p. 83, citing -MAas, AG, Mandati, Busta 61, vol. 112/2, f. 21.

7 The absence ofa single cultural tradition suggests a possible, if tenuous, link between // colore and an anonymous Scenario del moro della
bianca fe, which formed the basis ofa comedy given during Carnival 1694 in the Seminario Romano, Rome. The Roman performance included
a prologue and two intermedi involving balli. As well as a master of balli, a master of salto a cavallo was also engaged (Sartori 21115).

5 It is cited under the title // color fa la regina etiopica in CO.

 Sunrise over the Ganges was a trope in the Italian secular vocal repertory. Examples include Sigismondo dall' India's madrigal Nasce dal
Gange and Benedetto Marcello's cantata Sorge dall' Gange.

RO During the opening performance, the lead singer Francesco de Grandis (Cecchino) injured his leg
when he fell into a hole in the set. He was carried on a chair for the remainder of the evening. The opera
was not repeated, as originally envisioned, on the 31st; it reopened on Tuesday, the 2nd of February
(M). Despite the initial disruption, the work enjoyed an incredible attendance with great applause
in the following week, when the dedicatee presented the theater with a diamond worth 112 ongarid'oro
(M). Audiences were enthusiastic about the subject, the most beautiful scenery, and the extravagant
machines (CO). De Grandis's performance (as Adelasio) was greatly applauded during the week of
13-20 February (M). The cast also featured Nicola Tricarico (Tassilo), Stefano Romani (Vitegio), and
Anna Maria Torri (Gelida).'

 1700a Il giudicio di Paride sul monte Ida. Cf. Suppl. 7a.
1700/3 La pace generosa Music attributed to Marc' Antonio Ziani
[THE GENEROUS PEACE]
A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Silvani
i Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1700-02-10
& Dedicated to Charles Henri of Lorraine"

Revisiting the Roman occupation of the Rhineland in the first century AD, Germanicus (see Germanico
sul Reno, 1676/1), the adopted son of his uncle Tiberius, rescued Segestes from the German prince
Arminius.' In this account some of the interest was invested in the role of Ismene, the wife of Arminius
and daughter of Segestes.

 The libretto for La pace was dedicated on 10 February 1700, the date of the premiere (CO, M). A license
to print the libretto had been issued on 30 January 1700. At its premiere, which was attended by the
duke of Mantua, the performance of Nicola Grimaldi (Nicolino, singing as Arminio) was greatly
applauded (M). The work itself had mixed reviews, ranging from its having brought satisfaction (CO)
to its having received little applause (NV). Four of the singers were from the Mantuan court, although
Grimaldi was from the Chapel Royal. Oliviero Matraia (Germanico) was from the vice-regal court in
Naples.

"' Charles Henri de Lorraine-Vaudemont (1642-1723), a knight of the Order of the Golden Fleece (1675), was now the governor-general of

& Dedicated to Antonio Ottoboni, Nob. Ven."?

In Roman history of the second century BC, the dictator Sulla persuaded Bocchus, the king of Numidia,
to hand the Roman prince Jugurtha over to Marius, resulting in the execution of Jugurtha. In this account,
ostensibly based on Plutarch, the Roman courtesan Nicopole plays a decisive role.'*

O@ This first work to be fully produced at the teatro domestico San Fantin had its premiere between 23
and 30 October 1700 (M).' The production was cited for two excellent voices  one a woman's and
one a castrato's (due buonissime voci d'una donna et d'un castrato). The theater became known
for its low-priced tickets.' The libretto itself called attention to the youth of the singers, the straitened
circumstances of the production, and the fact that it was being given in a private house. Apparently,
this was an experimental venture with little forethought given to the establishment of a permanent theater.

1700/5 L'Aristeo Music by Antonio Pollarolo''
[ARISTAIOS]
A dramma per musica Text by Giulio Cesare Corradi
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1700-11-12~
& Dedicated to Felipe [Antonio] Spinola Colonna'*

In Greek mythology, Aristaios, a Thracian prince, was associated with hunting and divination. In this
account, he wanted to determine whether Doriclea, the Theban princess whom his father wished him
to marry, was as beautiful and virtuous as she was said to be. While en route with a letter of introduction,
he was accosted by bandits (masnadieri) whose leader presented himself in Thebes as the intended
of Doriclea.

oo L'Aristeo was first performed in public between 6 and 13 November 1700. On the 13th it was reported
(M) that the opening occurred in addition to many performances given for a low admission fee in
different houses of this city.' Three of the singers in the San Cassiano performance (including Antonio
Giustachini, who sang in the title role) were from the Mantuan court. One was from Florence and another
from the court of Brunswick. Antonio Ristorini, who was later to become a celebrated interpreter of
comic intermezzi at this theater, sang in the role of Doriclea's father, Evander.

II delirio comune Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo

per l'incostanza dei geni"
[DELIRIUM SHARED ON ACCOUNT OF FICKLE SPIRITS]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1700-12-11
Without dedicatee

The characters of // delirio were derived loosely from Greek mythology, although the concept of genius
(here defined as an inborn spirit that keeps persons and groups alive) was said to be Roman. // delirio
was first performed on 11 December 1700 (BG). The title-page is dated 1701; the libretto is signed
December 1700. The work's reception, noted by mere applause, was unenthusiastic. Gio. Battista
Barbaretti (Erostrato), Gio. Battista Roberti (Leonida), and Viena Mellini (Drosilla) were newcomers
to San Giovanni Grisostomo, but the other singers (de Grandis, Ballarini, Scarabelli, and Cabella) were
all veterans of its stage.

The first battles of the War of the Spanish Succession had begun in November. Although Venice was
officially neutral, it responded carefully to the growing sense of danger from all sides. Vincenzo Grimani,
the co-owner of San Giovanni Grisostomo, was one of three appointees (on 12 December) to the newly
formed (but unrelated) post of Inquisitor for the Peloponnese. The libretto offers evidence of the
financial difficulties of the times: unadorned type is substituted for the customary graphic design of
the title-page. In the absence ofa dedication, a short essay on intentions is given. The title and elements
of the depiction of the May Dance shown on the frontispiece seem to have been drawn by hand.
No musical sources known

 In Greek mythology, Hercules fed the wicked Thracian king Diomedes to his man-eating mares. This

anterior account concentrates on how Diomedes' capture of the Spartan princess Harpalike/Arpalice
thwarted her intended meeting with her husband, Evander. Diomede was first performed on 12 December
1700 (BG). The production was apparently revived late in January, when it was seen by Joseph Addison.

?5 Alcide (Alcides, Alkides) was a patronymic for Hercules or one of his descendants. Although the name Alcide is used in this title, the
corresponding role in the opera was assigned to Ercole [Hercules].

6 The libretto asserts that she was Spartan, but she is more commonly described as Thracian.

of 1724 (Selfridge-Field, Addison, p. 191). Addison may have been with a delegation of severall English Gentlemen. (plus the countess

1701/1 Griselda Music attributed to Antonio Pollarolo
[GRISELDA]
A dramma per musica Text by Apostolo Zeno
r1 Given at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1701-01-04
x Dedicated to Antonio Ballarini

The dedication traces the lineage of this pastoral story  in which the Sicilian baron Walter/Gualtiero
fell in love the shepherdess Griselda  to Boccaccio, Petrarch, Iacopo Filippo Foresti, Paolo Mazzi,
Ascanio Massimo, and Carlo Maria Maggi." The librettist claims to have constructed his characters
to be of middling virtue (mezzana virtit).

<7) Griselda opened on 4 January 1701 (CO), when it was received with much satisfaction (BG). One
libretto, Sartori 12515, also carries the printer's date 1701.? The Venetian production would have
coincided with the start of the blockade of Mantua, where there was soon a health crisis. The paucity
of openings in both 1701 and 1702 attests to the growing number of unfavorable circumstances.
In the previous absence of a definitive date for this work, an unusually long trail of vague indicators
has generated many speculations about its performance. The only confirmation of the existence of a
Venetian version of Griselda was for a long time that found ina letter of 1703 from its librettist, Apostolo
Zeno. Dated 24 February 1702 M.V., the letter expressed Zeno's infinite delight over the comic scenes
added by Girolamo Gigli for the Florentine production then in progress. A manuscript note ina libretto
from that production said that the work (by Albinoni and Zeno) had been given at San Cassiano in Venice
in 1702.4 Several of the singers in the Florentine production were later active in Venice.*>

o Zeno's text offered the basis of numerous productions through the 1730s, and it generated a long trail
of settings up to the end of century. Albinoni's setting was also given in Palermo and Verona. Other

and Michelangelo Pomelli) were uomini.

1701/2 Il Pericle in Samo Music by multiple composers
[PERIKLES IN SAMOS]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Rossi
Performed at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1701-01-08~
a Dedicated to Lorenzo Verzusio Beretti-Landi*
o The Athenian general Perikles, a champion of democracy, defended his city against the Spartans in

the Peloponnesian wars (fourth century BC). This account concentrates on his personal life: two legitimate
sons died in a plague, but a son (also Pericles) born to his mistress Aspasia (who in this account had
been raped by the wicked prince Doralbos of Samos; in others she was a prostitute) survived. The action
depicted here was said to take place in Algeria. Pericle was written for the [still private] teatro domestico
of San Fantin and may have opened around the start of Carnival (8 January). The publisher's date on
the lower title-page is given as 1701. M.V. In this case the designation M.V. appears to be in
error, since Addison, who visited Venice in 1701, attended a performance.** Addison criticized the
acting for its lack of conviction but said nothing about the music.

A No musical sources known
Listed as Bonlini 359; Groppo 363; Wiel 6; Alm 483

1701/3 Catone uticense Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[CATO OF UTICA]
A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1701-01-13
& Dedicated to Gaetano Cesarini

The librettist says he set out to weigh the worlds of joy and sorrow against one another. His subject,
Marcus Porcius Cato (Francesco Ballarini), who was noted for his high principles, committed suicide
rather than accept a pardon from Julius Caesar (Francesco de Grandis). Caesar married Cato's daughter,
Flaminia (Diamante Maria Scarabelli). For its time, Catone included a large number of allegorical figures
 Fortune, Fate, Glory, War, the Spirit (Genio) of Rome, and Mercury.

> Then secretary and councillor to the duke of Mantua. The occupation of the duchy (November 1700) drove a wedge between the duke, who
sided with the French, and Beretti-Landi, who sided with the Spanish. Beretti-Landi (sometimes called simply Beretti) was given a pension
of 300 doppie and the title of Count of Calatrava by 29 July 1702. By 1704 he was serving the Spanish throne in the Swiss cantons, where
he allied himself with Charles Henri of Lorraine. He is specifically acknowledged in the libretto as the mecenate di questo drama. It was
hoped that the work would temper his misfortunes. In 1711 the Princess of Santo Buono (wife of the Spanish ambassador) said that Beretti-Landi
would not return to Venice (I-Vas, RC, Busta 592, Fasc. Cremona 1711, letter of 23 Octobre 1711). He ended his career (1716-21) as Spain's
ambassador to the Netherlands.

> The seasonal designation at the top says that the work was for I'anno 1701. According to the Mercurio, nothing new had opened through
the 28th, but the time-frame may refer only to the currently closing week, since the statement is clearly in error for a longer retrospective period.

** It is hard to imagine that M.V. was given erroneously, but easy to imagine that the intention was to write 1700 M.V. Addison's
correspondence established the year of his visit. However, the 1700-01 season marked a low ebb in opera productions. lit is not inconceivable
that some of this season's failures were replayed in 1701-02. Similar apparent contradictions of date pertain to Catone uticense (1701/3).

@ _&  Addison's impressions of Catone were published in his travel diary (1705) and were reprinted

Caesar, it opened to reveal the three continents and their riches  gold, jewels, and metals of all

describes, the participants were disguised as shepherds and wore garlands of poppies around their necks.

Oor In this tale from the eighth-century Arabic invasion of the Iberian peninsula, Roderic, the young Gothic

king of Granada, disguised himself as a woman to evade Algerian sailors. He was nonetheless captured
and taken to King Amurat, who fell in love with his alter ego. Queen Fatima, detecting his true gender,
fell in love with him. He in turn fell in love with their daughter, the princess Clymene. A license to
print the libretto was issued on 12 January 1701, and it was dedicated on the 16th. An opening on the
17th was anticipated (CO). Although L 'inganno was revived in Vicenza in 1717 and at San Cassiano
as 1725/10, it cannot have been a success in 1701 because Diomede (1700/8) was soon reinstated.

250 A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

& Dedicated to Massimiliano Godi*'

L'Orfeo portrayed Orpheus and Eurydice as happy earthlings, Orion pursuing Diana, Aristaios longing
for Eurydice, and Cupid and Pluto trying to influence Fate. The first two acts featured a garden and
the wooded bank of a stream, while the third featured a hunt. At the end of the work all the nymphs
and shepherds became stars, while the goddess Diana was transformed into the moon. The author said
his intent was to imitate the simple language of shepherds in this short pastoral work, which had
previously been given in Rovigo as Le finezze d'amore (1698); under this title it was revived in Venice
as 1703/7.

OGLE Evidence from notary's records suggests that Orfeo was in production by 29 November 1701. Apparently
the sole offering of San Fantin throughout the 1701-02 season, it was still running on 11 February 1702,
when it was enjoying a great concourse (BG). The librettist praised the sweetness of harmony and
the beautiful execution [manieri'] of the performers. This work was more ambitious than most at
San Fantin but was still relatively short. A reference to the doge's having prohibited performances at
San Fantin in November 1701*? may only reflect the enforcement of a closure during Advent, which
would have been lifted after Christmas.* However, lack of underwriting for the troupe of performers
may have been the main motive for the prohibition.*!

A No musical sources known
Listed as Bonlini 364; Groppo 368; Wiel 10; Alm 490

 1702a Pastoral for Epiphany. Cf. Suppl. 9.
 1702b Elpino. Cf. Suppl. 7.

1702/1 L'arte in gara con l'arte Music attributed to Tomaso Albinoni
[ONE DECEPTION IN CONFLICT WITH ANOTHER]
A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Silvani
im Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1702-02-04
& Without dedicateeTM

Like so many other Venetian opera plots of the time, this one involved concealed identities. The historical
Manfred, an illegitimate son of the half-German, half-Sicilian Frederick II, continued Staufen rule in
Sicily after his father's death in 1250. At first the lineage was continued by Manfred's son Conradin.
It was terminated by his death (1266) and by that of his own son, Frederick Conradin (1268). In this
account Manfred believed Ruggiero to be his son, but Manfred's actual son was disguised as William,
the gardener.

*7 A nobleman from Vicenza.
* Its dedicatee there had been the duke of Mantua.

* A petition signed on 6 Novembre 1710 by Pietro Taneschi [Ianeschi] (I-Vas, Sezione Notarile, Atti Attilio Centon, Busta 3903) reiterated
one of 29 Novembre 1701, in which the doge did not permit in teatro alcuno e particolarmente in quello di S. Fantino la recita de drami per
sostenire la parte con troppa proclive fide. ... An extensive list of plaintiffs, all apparent parties involved in the earlier production, was headed
by P. Nicola Giglio come coratador e come compositore della Musica, Francesco Rossi come coratador [ = impresario], [and] Carlo Platti

Tiberio, imperatore d'Oriente Music by Francesco Gasparini
[TIBERIUS, EMPEROR OF THE EAST]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Gio. Domenico Pallavicini
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Fat Week)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1702-02-19

Without dedicatee

When Tiberius II, a Thracian, was Eastern Emperor [578-582], Ravenna and Carthage figured prominently
among his domains. In this prelude to his story, Sophia, the widow of his predecessor Justin II [565-578],
had her hopes for the adoption of Justin's nephew, Justinian, disappointed.

Tiberio was first performed agreeably on 19 February 1702 (PV). A printer's note in the libretto
praised the virtue of Sig. Francesco Gasparini, the honored maestro of the donzelle who sing in the
choir of the Pieta, and the suavity of his harmonious notes enriched with various caprices.... Scarlatti's
setting of the same text was given in Naples in May 1702. Tiberio was revived at San Fantin as Le vicende
d'amor e di fortuna (1710/2). On the evening of 24 February an adolescent member of the Marcello
family (which co-owned the theater with the Cappello family) was involved in a fight which caused

L'odio e l'amorTM Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo and others
[HATRED AND LOVE]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1702-12-27
Without dedicatee

The text, which is based on Persian history of the fifth century BC, concerns the relationship of Thomyris,
the widowed queen of the Massagetes, to the Persian king Cyrus. When Cyrus's plan to woo the widow
failed, he attacked her territory and captured her son. She avenged his misdeeds with a massacre of
his troops [530 BC], which was held to be one of the most savage of the era chronicled by Herodotus.
The text appears to have inspired that of Paolo Rolli for Giovanni Bononcini (London, 1721; Brunswick
and Wolfenbiittel, both 1724).

L odio was first performed on 27 December 1702 (M, PV).' The title-page of the libretto is dated 1703.
Noris promised in the libretto to fashion a new doctrine of drama which would feature more
fantasy...[and] elocution more elevated, noble, clear, and poetic than before. These changes, he hoped,
would suit San Giovanni Grisostomo, the theater of stupors and musical Campidoglio, which catered
to the glory of royalty and imperialism. In contrast to many works of the time, this was a notably
long work; its libretto ran to 79 pages. The work was praised in Pallade veneta for the equal virtues
of the poet and the composer and in the Mercurio for the composition and the voices.? The
appearances of Francesco de Grandis (Cecchino) as Arbace, Nicola Grimaldi (Nicolino) as Ciro,
and Diamante Scarabelli (Diamantina) as Jomiri drew special notice (PV). The virtuosity of the
singers, the majesty of the sets, and the splendor of the costumes were said to complement each other
(PV).

Arias: GB-Lbl (Naples, 1704); I-Ne

Listed as Bonlini 370; Groppo 374; Wiel 16; Alm 496

Gli amanti generosi Music by Benedetto Vinaccesi
[THE GENEROUS LOVERS]

A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Pietro Candi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1703-01-05

Dedicated to the Venetian nobility

The text is derived from the life of Artaxerxes (fourth century BC). The libretto professed to focus on
its protagonist's character: his qualities of being singularly prudent and learned while at the same time
concealing his vices. As portrayed here, Artaxerxes was envious of the amorous and military successes
of his brother Darius. In later revisions the contention between Hydaspes (disguised here as Acrone)
and Artaxerxes for the hand of Berenice was highlighted.

 Usually fully attributed to Pollarolo, but eight arias are also attributed to Aldrovandini in a Neapolitan manuscript.

7 Although the libretto was not dedicated, Prince Eugene could have been the intended patron. General of the Imperial Armies, he attended
a performance at San Giovanni Grisostomo on the 30th (BG).

 Or, alternatively, the 26th (BG).
 Pallade veneta, p. 249.

* The full cast is given in Saunders, Repertoire, p. 459. See also Pallade veneta, p. 248.

TM Little is known about the Candi (Gio. Pietro and Gio. Battista).

*5 Despite the anonymity of the subjects, dedications of this kind could be just as flattering as those addressed to single individuals. Here, for
example, the dedicatees were praised collectively for their beautiful spirits, heroic and pure.

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1700-09) 255

Oo Gli amanti was first performed on 5 January 1703 (PV). A license to print the libretto had been issued
on the 2nd. The work was called a curious entertainment... .in which the women became [progressively]
more superb and less beautiful (PV). The dedication suggests that the composer was a somewhat
unwilling party to this enterprise and that the arias would satisfy common taste better than they would
express his genius. Candi praised the spirited notes of Cav. Vinaccesi and the singular ability
of the virtuosi. Nonetheless, the text was revised for a resetting by Francesco Mancini for performance
in Naples (1705) and was later given in London under the title L Idaspe fedele. Broschi's setting (as
Idaspe) was given in Venice in 1730.

A No musical sources known
Listed as Bonlini 371; Groppo 375; Wiel 24; Alm 497

1703/2 L'onor al cimento Music by Teofilo Orgiani
[HONOR ON TRIAL]
An opera musicale Text by Girolamo Colatelli
Given at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival?)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1703-01-15~
wz Dedicated to Benedetto Rigogli
mac) L'onor al cimento was based on a conventional tale from Tasso's Gerusalemme liberata in which Rinaldo

was first the enemy of and then the lover captivated by Armide. The work opened with a triumphal
scene in which Armide's chariot was pulled onto the stage by two lions. It ended happily in Jerusalem.
L'onor had been performed under such titles as Li amori e incanti d'Armida con Rinaldo in Rovigo
(1694), Treviso (1698), and Udine (1698). The bulk of this run would have occurred in the winter of
1703 (the title-page date), although its premiere could have occurred in advance of Advent 1702.

Bonlini 373; Groppo 377; Wiel 19; Alm 499.

1703/4 Venceslao Music by Carlo Francesco PollaroloTM
[WENCESLAS]
A dramma [tragicomedia] (5) Text by Apostolo Zeno
im Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1703-02-07~
& Dedicated to Marquis Filippo Rangoni*

The historical Wenceslas IV reigned over Bohemia [1283-1305] and Poland [1302-1305]. In this account
his sons Casimir and Alexander were both in love with the princess Eirenike/Erenice but, reflecting
their contrasting personalities, the second had honorable intentions, while the first did not. The action
was set in Krakow, and one ballo was for Polish sculptors.

i) The dedicatee was present in Venice in early February 1703 and held a sumptuous festa di ballo on
the 14th (M). Zeno had written to Antonio Magliabecchi in Florence on 13 January that he had started
and finished, during a stay of more than a month in Conegliano, a drama to be recited in San Giovanni
Grisostomo during the present Carnival.*

 In a letter to Muratori in Modena on 24 February, Zeno reported that Venceslao enjoyed a singular
attendance and applause superior to its merit. He enclosed two copies of the libretto.** Giovanni
Buzzoleni sang in the title role, with Grimaldi as Casimir, Pietro Moggi as Alexander, Francesco de
Grandis as the general Ernando, Caterina Azzolini as Eirenike, and Diamante Scarabelli as Lucinda,
the queen of Lithuania.

applause than it deserved in Venice. The text was reset by Perti for Bologna (as II fratricida innocente,
1708; 1722) and by Mancini for Naples (1714). It was also given in a pastiche version by Porta, A.
Pollarolo, and Capelli (San Moise, 1723/3; San Giovanni Grisostomo, 1722/5; 1735/8), and in a new
setting by Pampani (San Cassiano, 1752/1). Caldara used it as a name-day entertainment for Charles

1703/5 L'Almansore in Alimena Music by Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[ALMANSOR IN ALIMENA]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giovanni Matteo Giannini
" Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Fat Week?)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1703-02-10~
sy Dedicated to Prince Filippo Ercolani!

During the course of his formal engagement to Seripha, the princess of Fez, Almansor, the Saracen
king of Granada, fell in love with a woman in his own court. By promising to donate royal lands in
compensation, Almansor enlisted his lunatic brother Alindar to stand in as groom for him.

Oo The Roman princes Altieri and Ottoboni were in Venice on 17 February 1703, perhaps to witness
Ercolani's public entry. The Mercurio states that a large number of persons from Bologna, Ferrara,
and other cities of Romagna were in town towards the end of Carnival. Baron Martini had been present
since late January (NV). The gathering of this constellation of dignitaries suggests a sufficient cause
for the opening of an opera late in the season. It would help to explain the involvement of Pollarolo,
who was much favored by leaders of the Empire, at Sant' Angelo, which lacked the prestige of San
Giovanni Grisostomo. Since Carnival ended on the 20th, this opening should have occurred by the 13th.
Almansore had been given in Bologna in 1690 and in Reggio Emilia in the spring of 1696. Giovanni
Orsato, who was active in many places in northern Italy, signed the dedication.

A No musical sources known
Listed as Bonlini 374; Groppo 378; Wiel 23; Alm 500

 La forza treats the life of the emperor Caligula [37-41 AD], the precocious son of Germanicus, who

was well received at first but came to be severely disliked for his autocracy. According to Minelli, this

*' Prince Ercolani, who was from Bologna, took up the post of imperial ambassador to Venice in February 1703. In 1711 an envoy to Venice
from Lorraine, the Count of Armoises, was to complain to the Austrian authorities that Count Ercolani's absorption in opere, balli, e feste
di corte rendered his behavior as an ambassador irregular (I-Vas, IS, RC [Riferte dei Confidenti], Busta 592, fasc. Cremona 1711, entry
of 27 Febraro 1711).

* Although the libretto is unclear on this point, one possible reading of the title of the work is that the donated lands were in Sicily. The town
so called was founded in 1628 through a grant made by King Philip IV. Thus the Almansor in the title would have been the false Almansor.

 The duke of Mantua addressed letters (I-MAas, Busta 1584) to both on 17 February 1702-3. A note from the printer, Girolamo Albrizzi,
in the libretto began by saying that the work should appear in 1703 (Alamansore in Alimena deve comparire quest'an. 1703). This was a
rare statement that suggests some uncertainty.

* Fabbri and Verti (Due secoli, p. 47) give an informative account of the performance in Reggio. C. F. Pollarolo sat at the first harpsichord,
with his son Antonio at the second. The other instruments used were a violone, theorbo, two violoncelli (apparently one for continuo and one
for the accompaniment of solos), four violins, four violas, and a trumpet. Several of the performers were from Modena. The singers are not
named.

1703/8 Il miglior d'ogni amore Music by Francesco Gasparini
per il peggiore d'ogni odio
[THE BEST OF EVERY LOVE FOR THE WORST OF EVERY HATE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Silvani
i Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)

Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1703-11-07
&o Dedicated to Joseph, Prince of Lorraine'

In this unusual plot, Sancho I, the king of Aragon (1063-1094), loved his horse so much that he kept
the animal in his bedchamber. The intrigues that developed from the care of this creature during his
absence form the basis of the somewhat whimsical plot. The portrayal of Spaniards could have been
prompted by the continuing War of the Spanish Succession, which had already had major effects on
northern Italy, extending to the dedicatee's homeland.'!

 This work was first performed on 7 November 1703 (M), when it received great applause. The libretto
had been dedicated on the 6th.

chronological position is tellingly apposite. In March 1703 the Grimani family, in a contract with San
Salvatore, had attempted to regulate comedy performances so as to exclude San Cassiano and Sant' Angelo

Farnace Music by Antonio Caldara
[PHARNAKES]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Lorenzo Morari
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1703-11-19

Dedicated to Francesco Maria Pico!

The historical Pharnakes was ruler of Pontos in the second century BC. Much of the fictional story
related here revolved around the deeds of Thomyris, the warrior queen of the Scythians. Farnace was
first performed, with great applause, on the 19 November 1703 (M). The libretto had been dedicated
on the 15th. It was still in production (at least theoretically; see below) on 1 February. Gio. Battista
Carboni (from Mantua) sang in the title role, with Catterina Galerati (from the Tuscan court) as Thomyris.
Lucrezia d' Andre, who later left town without permission (see 1704/2), appeared as Cyrene. Before
the curtain was raised, there was a raucous concerto of trumpets, timpani, and other warlike instruments.
The text formed the basis of Giovanni Bononcini's Farnace (London, 1723).'%

Il giorno di notte Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[Day INTO NIGHT]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1703-12-26~

Without dedicatee

The text was based loosely on Roman history, but the emphasis was clearly on spectacle. The Emperor
Elagabalus was noted for his effeminate taste and extravagant indulgences (cf. 1667/6). He said he wished
to turn day into night, and this text projected a tongue-in-cheek realization of that wish.

This was apparently the work whose opening was anticipated on 27 October 1703 (M), but taking into
account its title-page date of 1704, it is unlikely to have opened sooner than late December. The work
opened with a low-pitched symphony (profonda sinfonia), which underscored the darkness of the
stage. Many specters of night  crawling creatures, ghosts, shimmering stars  appeared as Night
crept over a field of sunflowers. Four later balli featured shepherds and shepherdesses, nations, peasants,

To end tyranny, the people of Macedonia recruited Cassander to teach the heir apparent, Pyrrhos,

OL While there is no firm date for the opening of Pirro, there is an obvious hole in Sant' Angelo's calendar

La vendetta disarmata dall'amore Music by Girolamo Polani'!
[REVENGE DISARMED BY LOVE]

A dramma [pastorale] per musica Text attributed to Francesco Passarini'

Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1704-11-02~

Dedicated to Domenico Delai'

Although the text was said to come from the shores of Spain, the story took place in England. Its
cast included King Everhard and his sister Rosicleria, Prince Henry and Princess Stella of Salver, and
the general Lewis. The general had been in love with Rosicleria prior to his retirement from court, but
it is Henry who now could save her life.

Intended for performance during both the autumn and winter seasons, this short work opened after 2
November 1704.' It had been given with applause'?> in Rovigo in October 1703 as La costanza
nell'onore. The text was reset by Buini (Bologna, 1724). Francesco Rossi, as impresario of the theater,
filed a notarial complaint (stragiudiziale) in November against Antonio Pollo, whom he claimed was
to have secured the services ofa singer whose name is given only as Pietro. The singer had been absent
for twenty days, leaving both the rehearsal schedule and the actual production in a state of chaos.'

More than most plots of the time, this was a morality play in which the philosophy of the tutor Aletes
was intended to protect the virtue of Eriphyle, the daughter of the recently deceased king of Sicily. The
work's theme is derived from the proverb Love and ambition are the two rocks on which the ship of
innocence most easily founders. Quite unusually, La maschera opened with a soliloquy.

Or  La maschera levata was first performed on 4 November 1704 (M). Libretti were dedicated on the 2nd
and the 4th.'8 Buini's setting of the same work was staged in Bologna both under its original title (Teatro
Marsigli Rossi, 1730) and as // filosofo ipocrita (Teatro Formigliari, 1735). The Mantuan minister

uplifting (it provided poca levatura''). Thus, it was not much appreciated in Venice. Only three singers

1704/7 Virginio console Music attributed to Antonio Giannettini

M Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1704-11-10
& Without dedicatee

Lucius Virginius Rufus served as consul three times in the first century but refused to become emperor
after the death of Nero [68 AD]. Here amorous intrigues involve Valeria, the daughter of Virginius.

o Virginio console was first performed on 10 November 1704 (M, PV). Antonio Giannettini, formerly
engaged in Mantua, had assumed the role of impresario at Sant' Angelo in July. He was appalled by
conditions there and ordered many improvements.'* In a report of 1 November, the Mantuan agent
Galvani had said that all the singers in this work would be new to the Venetian stage. Two weeks later
he reported that the work met with mediocre applause, despite beautiful scenes and bizarre costumes.
The tenor from Parma who sang in the title role was applauded, and the women were rather good,
but the other singers were poorly received.'*!

 A correspondent for Pallade veneta who attended the opening was more generous. He said the work
was greeted with universal applause and that the machine of delight swings [like a pendulum] between
the poles of Nicolin [Nicola] Paris and Signora [Caterina] Volsechi. Members of the cast are not
otherwise identified but probably corresponded to those in Artaserse (1705/3).

La fortuna per dote Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[GOoD FORTUNE FOR A DowRY]

A tragicomedia (5) Text attributed to Girolamo Frigimelica-Roberti
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With cori d'intermezzo with balli SORTING DATE: 1704-11-29
Without dedicatee

The emperor Theodosius (Luigi Alberelli) had five sisters. One of them, Flacilla (Viena Mellini), who
was to succeed her brother, was courted by the somewhat rustic Marzianus (Anton Francesco Carli).
In its entirety the work was a paean to extending political power through advantageous marriages. In
its emphasis on spectacle, this tragicomedia was an unintended parody of heroic opera.

Lafortuna per dote was first performed, with magnificent scenery, on 29 (PV) or 30 November 1704.'*
According to the Mercurio, the work received universal applause. The five-act structure gave scope
to five elaborate choruses serving, on the model of // pastore d'Anfriso, as intermedi. All five involved
choral singing and the accompaniment of various consorts of instruments. In the first, warriors and
Amazons battled while trumpets and other military instruments played. The second, featuring sailors
and fishermen, involved diverse instruments; Cadmus and Amore looked on. In the third, followers
of Bacchus played harpsichords (cembali) as their leader was transported in a carriage drawn by tigers.'**
According to the libretto this was done using license, which permits the mixing of an element of joy
into the most serious spectacles. ..to celebrate the coronation of Theodosius. Nymphs and shepherds
celebrated the coronation of Flora in the fourth number, while cavaliers and gentlewomen celebrated
three weddings in the final number.

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 389; Groppo 393; Wiel 35; Alm 515

La Fredegonda Music by Francesco Gasparini
[FREDEGONDE]

A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Silvani
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1705-01-10

Dedicated to Lorenzo Versuzio Beretti-Landi'TM*

The text, derived from the history of the Visigoths on the Iberian peninsula, alludes to Spanish-French
relations through the king Athanagilde and his Frankish son-in-law Chilperic. Fredegonde, whose
behavior was often vicious, was Chilperic's third wife.'*> The librettist and the dedicatee were both
previously associated with the duke of Mantua, whose duchy was subject to continuing conflict between
modern France and Spain (via the Empire). La Fredegonda was first performed on about 10 January
1705. It closed during the week of January 24 to 31 (M). Its libretto had been dedicated on December
26, 1704.'* Margherita Salicola Suini sang in the title role with Antonio Ristorini (Chilperico), Maria
Domenica Pini (Atanagildo), and Domenico Tempesti (Ermengildo).

Oo This short pastoral work featured three Arcadian figures  Eurilla, Filli, and Tirsi as well as a satyr

and a wild beast. Eurilla is the assumed name of the shepherdess Orinda, who is half-wild. She disappears
shortly before her wedding. L enigma, which had been given for the spring fiera of 1698 in Reggio
Emilia,' opened at San Fantin shortly after 12 January 1704 [M.V.], the date of dedication of its libretto.
A license to print the libretto had been issued on 30 September 1700 [sic]. The title-page is dated 1704
M.V. For a work of modest expectations, L enigma had a substantial career. It was revived as Gl'amici
rivali at San Fantin (1715/3), and Antonio Bononcini adapted Pollarolo's music for an autumn production
in Modena in 1716.'* It also circulated, under various titles, in the Veneto.

complications in the royal line of succession. The story was set in Susa.'*
