perfunctory, since Carnival did not actually open until the 19th.'* Francesco Guicciardi sang in the

'57 Neri (d. 1726) was a secretary to the new imperial ambassador to Venice, Prince Filippo Ercolani.

'8 The Alberti were added to the Venetian nobility in 1658. They lived on the fondamento running along the Rio San Barnaba. The Alberti

1705/4 Il Dafni Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[DAPHNIS]
A tragedia satirica (5) Text attributed to Girolamo Frigimelica-Roberti
M1 Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With cori da intramezzi including balli SORTING DATE: 1705-01-30
& Without dedicatee
SS In classical mythology, Daphnis (Luigi Alberelli) , who was raised by the nymphs, had a very genial

disposition and a great love of music. The nymph Nomia" blinded him after he was unfaithful to her,
after which his songs became sad. In this satirical treatment, much of the meaning was conveyed through
the interludes. They included a chorus of witches who played, sang, and danced under a trellis of flowers,
achorus of two-faced nymphs, and a chorus of gods (Neptune, Sybil, Pluto, and Jove) who also played,
sang, and danced. Like all of Frigimelica-Roberti's texts, this one was purposely modeled on an ancient
exemplar  in this case on the tragedia satirica of Horace.'*

OOR 11 Dafni was first performed, with applause, on 30 January 1705 (M). Describing the work as a pastoral,
the Mantuan agent Galvani remarked that the voices were highly varied and the scenery sumptuous."
NV said it was received with satisfaction. Gio. Carlo Grimani had attempted to secure permission
from the Florentine court for the Neapolitan singer Matteo Sassani (Il Matteuccio) to perform during
Carnival, but he was deemed too ill to travel to Venice.'*

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Dedicated to Zorzi Melli'

In Iberian history of the eleventh century, Fernando, the count of Castile, a previous enemy of Sancho,
the late king of Navarre, decided to marry the Navarrese princess Sancha.'*' Sancho's son and successor
Garcia did not approve the union and attempted to subvert it.' A fictional role for Elvira, a sister of
Fernando who fights in male costume, has been added.

The libretto for La fede ne' tradimenti was dedicated on 30 October 1705, but the production seems
to have opened after Antioco (said to be the first work in the new season). Gigli's text had first been
set by Giuseppe Fabbrini (Siena, 1689). Pollarolo took it up quickly (Bologna, 1690), and it was
apparently his work which was revived in Mantua in 1697. However, his earlier Anagilda, on arelated
subject, had been staged in Reggio Emilia in 1685 (see 1692/10). A pastiche version of La fede was
given in Pesaro (1717). A setting by Predieri was presented during the first season of productions at
the new Teatro alla Pergola in Florence (September, 1718). Buini reset it for the Accademia de' Remoti
in Faenza in 1723. Under the title Anagilda it was set by Caldara (1711) and Sarti (1758). Grua set Gigli's
text for Sant' Angelo (1721/8), while Pampani's Anagilda (San Cassiano, 1735/2) was based on a different
account. Anonymous music was used in 1749/3 (San Moise).

Score (pastiche, Pesaro, 1717): GB-En
Listed as Bonlini 396; Groppo 400; Wiel 44; Alm 523

Flavio Bertarido, Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo

re de' longobardi
[FLAVIUS BERTARIDE, KING OF THE LOMBARDS]

A dramma per musica Text by Stefano Ghisi
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With balli' SORTING DATE: 1705-12-01

Dedicated to Cardinal Vincenzo Grimani

The Lombard king who is the subject of this text reigned in the latter half of the seventh century. After
the death of his father Aribert [661; cf. 1684/5], the kingdom was divided between Flavius Bertaride
and his younger brother Godebert. The latter, with the assistance of Duke Grimaldi of Benevento,
attempted to conquer the lands of Bertaride by offering to marry Grimaldi's daughter. Numerous fictional
elements are added to the plot, which was loosely derived from Corneille's Le Cid. Flavio appears to
be the greatly applauded work which opened on 1 December 1705, with a cast including Matteo Sassani
(Matteuccio) (NV) as well as Anton Francesco Carli (Flavio Grimoaldo), Stefano Romani (the captain
Oronte), and Gio. Battista Carboni (Onulfo). The run continued after Christmas.'

1705/9 Creso tolto a le fiamme Music attributed to Girolamo Polani
[CROESUS SPARED FROM THE FLAMES]
A dramma per musica Text by Aurelio Aureli'
mM Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With intermezzi and balli SORTING DATE: 1705-12-12~
& Dedicated to Andrea Navagiero, Overseer of Palma!
OO The enormously wealthy Croesus, king of Lydia, was defeated by the Persian Cyrus the Great. The

libretto for Creso related a fable about Croesus thinking himself the happiest man alive because of his
wealth and then repenting his hedonism after he was imprisoned by Cyrus. In a fictional overlay,
Croesus's wife Clymenides, disguised as a shepherdess, stole into Cyrus's camp to see her husband.
Creso opened during the week ending on 12 December 1705.' The libretto (US-LAu 524) was dedicated
on the 4th.' The two baili in this work are for phantoms of sleep and followers of caprice. Both
are suggestive of instrumental pieces of an impressionistic nature later composed by the Venetian
violinists Giorgio Gentili and Antonio Vivaldi.'

Listed as Bonlini 397; Groppo 401; Wiel 42; Alm 524, 525

This tale from the Gothic middle ages bears little resemblance to Shakespeare's Hamlet, although it

the wicked tyrant Fengon.' Nicola Grimaldi sang in the title role, with Maria Domenica Pini (La
Tilla') as Veremonda, and Lorenzo Santorini as Fengone.

OOo This treatment of the early life of Semiramis, the Babylonian queen, was different from both earlier

1706/3 Statira Music attributed to Francesco Gasparini
[STATEIRA]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Pietro Pariati
mM Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Florinetta e Frappalone' SORTING DATE: 1706-02-03
&o Dedicated to Giovanna Caraccioli, Princess of Santo Buono!
 The text is loosely derived from Persian history. Stateira, the daughter of the late Artaxerxes, was destined

to marry Arsakes, one of the captains of the army. Barsina, the daughter of King Cyrus, was also in
love with Arsakes. The consequences of this conflict led to a civil war. Statira was first performed on
3 February 1706,'** when it was received with satisfaction (M). The libretto had been dedicated on
2 February 1705. A revised version was given (Florence, Cocomero) for the Carnival of 1708.'*
 This is the earliest San Cassiano opera with a surviving text for comic intermezzi. It is therefore
noteworthy that the dedicatee was the Neapolitan consort of the Spanish ambassador. According to
the dedication, she was also worthy of inclusion in the Arcadian colony. While the dramma per musica
was by Zeno, who was staunchly opposed to the inclusion of comic characters in such dramas, the
revisions were by Pariati.

Listed as Bonlini 402; Groppo 406; Wiel 38; Alm 534

1706/5 Paride in Ida Music adapted from Luigi Mancia by Ag. Bon. Colletti!
[PARIS ON MT. IDA]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Mazzari'

Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's?)

With balli'' and the intermezzi Lesbina e Milo SORTING DATE: 1706-11-15~
& Without dedicatee

While pregnant, Hecuba, the wife of King Priam, had a dream which was interpreted to mean that the
child to whom she would give birth would destroy Troy. Asa child, her son Paris was therefore exiled
to the countryside, where, as he grew to maturity, he grew accustomed to cavorting with nymphs.

Oo Paride was first produced in 1687 in Hanover, where Mancia worked briefly as a singer. Colletti's
revisions were originally made for a performance given in Parma in 1696.' The title-page of the libretto
identifies the period of performance as autumn 1706. It is likely to have opened in mid-November,
following the customary practice of this theater. It was produced in 1719 in both Padua and Bologna.

 On October 15 the Mantuan agent Muzio Francesco Cremona summoned the virtuose Margarita Farnetti
and Teresa Frigieri to leave Mantua for the next production at Sant' Angelo. This summons is the only
clue to the cast, since no names appear in the libretto or score.' The balli are unusual in that they seem
to be for soloists  in one case for a young shepherd (representing Paride?) and in the other for a young
Moorish woman (representing Nerina) who dances in many styles.

ad Argene, the queen of Cyprus, was so crushed by the death of her husband, Morastos, that she vowed

1707/1 L'Ifigenia Music by Agostino Bonaventura Colletti
[IPHIGENEIA]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Aurelio Aureli, Pietro Riva'
M Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1707-01-04
& Without dedicatee

In Greek mythology, Iphigeneia was the first-born daughter of Agamemnon. To placate the goddess
Diana, who was angry about the killing of a hart, her people prepared to offer Iphigeneia in sacrifice.
This account involves messages from an oracle requesting the presence of one hundred virgins. The
action takes place on the day of the intended sacrifice.

Oo@ While /figenia is said to have opened on 3 January 1707 (M, NV), it is more likely to have opened on
the 4th. The libretto carefully delineated the character of each of the figures. Agamemnon was a father
tender to the point of extremity regarding his oldest daughter. Achilles was a fiery, impetuous, and
passionate man. Diomedes (the name given to Achilles' friend Patroclos in order to suit the music)
was of a sweet and faithful nature, while Iphigeneia is magnanimous and constant, Eriphyle
ferocious and resolute, while Deidamia was suave and amorous.

With Lisetta e Astrobolo;' balli SORTING DATE: 1707-01-04

[ay Without dedicatee
The rules of succession in a polygamous kingdom were at issue in this libretto. The king of China had
seven wives, one of whom was the official empress and producer of legitimate successors, while the
other six were mere queens. He also had numerous mistresses. Taikang is said to have been the son
of the newly deceased emperor Vamblie and the empress Gemira, who was herself foreign-born. A
subplot explored the relationship between China's two nobilities  one of letters and one of arms.
The outlines of the text were said to rest on the writings of the Portuguese historian Samedio.

o Taican was first performed on 4 January 1707 (M, NV). Francesca Vanini Boschi sang in the title role,
with Santa Stella as Gemira, Maria Domenica Pini as the Moghul princess Elmirena, Francesco de Grandis
as King Zeliano of Japan, Nicola Pasini as a man-of-letters (Mitrane), and Domenico Tollini as a man-at-
arms (Sunone). Giuseppe Maria Boschi, a soon-to-be popular bass, debuted as Ruteno.!

BO Chinese motifs formed part of the visual spectacle, starting with the pagoda-like palace shown on the
frontispiece. Gemira's chamber in Act I was adorned with Chinese pictures; the Great Wall was featured
in Act Two, and golden dragons were featured in the fifth act. The work was situated in Peking. The
dances, choreographed by Monsieur l'Eveque of Mantua, were for Indian Moors, for temple priests,
and for the Chinese nobles at Taikang's coronation. The printer added a note to the text stating that
in order to allow time for the ridiculous intermezzi, all the lines of text with marginal markings will
be omitted. He refers to the already well established use of vergole (quotation marks) in printed libretti
to indicate passages which the poet provided for the drama but which would be omitted in performance.
Such omissions more commonly affected recitatives than arias.

[MITHRIDATES EUPATOR]

' See the comments on China and Gnagnaro in Suppl. 4a.

20 The name Taikang belonged to a legendary king of the Xia Dynasty (c. 1700 B.C.), an emperor of the Jin Dynasty (280-89), and an administrator
(1074-82) under Tao Tsung. Other possible transliterations of Taican include the names Taizong (belonging to seven emperors of various
dynasties) and Taichang (held by three emperors). Polygamy was widely practiced among Chinese rulers over much of recorded history. Two
nobilities was a topical issue in diverse chapters of the histories of Russian, India, Japan, and China as well as ancient Europe. In sum, the
name Taican may not relate to any precise historical figure. If it does, the Jin Dynasty figure is a likely candidate. Note, however, that another
opera ostensibly based on Chinese history, Teuzzone (1707/15), concerns the eleventh century.

Mithridates Evergetes, king of Pontos, was assassinated in a plot involving his wife, Stratonica, and
her lover, Pharnakes. He was succeeded by his son Mithridates Eupator,? whose reputation for violence
was legendary. In this account Pharnakes is spared but Stratonica is murdered. The work contained
two dances featuring Egyptian women. A compulsive essayist, Frigimelica-Roberti adorned his
commentary here with quotations from Petrarch and Ariosto. He claimed that the situation of Mithridates,
Stratonica, and Pharnakes would be recognized as a disguised version of that of Orestes, Clytemnestra,
and Aigisthos. Who knows, he pondered, whether the perfection of opera can be equal to the perfection
of thought?

A license to print the libretto was issued on 30 November 1706. Mitridate was first performed on 5
January 1707 (M, NV). A pastiche based on Frigimelica-Roberti's text was given in Reggio in 1723.
This and the two preceding works suited their audiences (among which there were said to be many
cavalieri oltramontani), to perfection in their opening performances. Regarding the preparations for
the work, a plea on behalf of the damas venezianas was made during the previous May by the prince
of Santo Buono through the offices of the Mantuan resident, Count Cremona, to have el Virtuoso Nicola
Grimaldi sing at San Juan Chrisostom.* Extensive negotiations were also required for the
participation of Diamante Scarabelli and the oboist Monsieur de Noie, both in the employ of the prince
of Vaudemont. These negotiations may account for the long gap between the issuance of a license
to print the libretto and the first performance.

La fede tra gl'inganni Music attributed to Tomaso Albinoni?
[FIDELITY BETRAYED AND VINDICATED]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Silvani
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1707-01-29

Dedicated to John Austen and Crew Offley?"*

The plot framed the conflict between Pontos and Mycenae as the amorous betrayal of Flerida, a princess
of Pontos who was disguised as Attalos, by Pheraspes/Feraspe, a prince of Mycenae."

La fede opened on 29 January 1707 (NV). We are informed that cavalieri oltramontani*"* arrived in
Venice on 15 January 1706 M.V. and that the official opening of Carnival occurred on the 26th (M).
Running until 8 March, this Carnival period was the longest since 1666, which suggests why there was
time for two printings of the libretto,! a practice which had become rare. Perhaps demonstrating its
origins as a work intended for performance in Rovigo, the first version was quite short"* and requires
only five characters. The absence of incidental items indicates that this was a low-budget production.
The second version was apparently intended to augment its stature.

Marino Rossetti's preface to the first libretto extols the virtues of English patrons. He praises the military
and civil virtues of the nation, the riches and illustrious actions of the citizens, and the perfection of
their studies and travels. The printer's note explains that the libretto was written during the youth of
its author and that it was given in Rovigo for the entertainment of the nobility, which is usually
accommodated there for a few days in the autumn. Although the author is now at a distant location,
the composer has prepared the work for the current Carnival. Of course he had to think of its preparation
not for the restraints of the situation in Rovigo but for the vastness of the audience in Venice.

Listed as Bonlini 411; Groppo 415; Wiel 64; Alm 544

Il trionfo della liberta Music by Alessandro Scarlatti
[THE TRIUMPH OF FREEDOM]

A tragedia per musica (5) Text by Girolamo Frigimelica-Roberti
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1707-02-05
Without dedicatee

Tarquinius Superbus was the last king of Rome. Junius Brutus, the son of Marcus Junius, was falsely
considered to be mad and was left to languish for twenty-five years. The plot concerns the conflict which
evolved between the three sons of the first and the two of the second, which extended to members of
successive generations. The Romans were ultimately to gain their liberty from monarchy at the cost
of irreversible damage to these relations. Frigimelica-Roberti's libretto contains a substantial rationale,
citing numerous variations and refinements of the plot as well as a poetic notice which carefully
underscores the elements within the story which contribute most to its merits as a tragedy. As in previous

Conoscenza, p. 120).

Achille placato Music by Antonio Lotti
[ACHLLES PLACATED]

A tragedia per musica (5) Text attributed to Urbano Rizzi
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Melissa,* Dragontana e Policrone, balli SORTING DATE: 1707-02-05
Without dedicatee

Although the wrath of Achilles was legendary, he made peace with Agamemnon in the tenth year of
the Trojan War. As this work opened, smoke rose from the ashes of Troy. According to the libretto
it was the poet's intention not to distract the audience with alien events in the principal action. He
emphasized elements in the character of each role (e.g., the weakness of Menelaus in pardoning Helen)
as highlights of the drama. He particularly noted how after her death, Helen was transformed into the
vapors of the borasco blowing over the sea and notes that in later Greek legends it was these winds
which protected the Greek army in its exploits in Asia.

Achille opened on 5 February 1707 (BG) as the third opera at San Cassiano. Its opening performance
was attended by the duke of Mantua and by Jacques-Vincent Languet, the count de Gergy, who was
a French envoy at the time. The entourage appears also to have included some of the duke's Elboeuf
in-laws. The work produced universal satisfaction (M). The size and distinction of the cast were notable.
There were nine singing roles and two mute ones in addition to the two roles of the intermezzi. Giuseppe
Maria Boschi sang as Agamemnon, with G. B. Roberti as Menelaus, Francesco de Grandis as Ulysses,
and Santa Stella as Helen. The intermezzi called The Ruins of Troy [or Dragontana e Policrone] obviously
suited the work well. A note in the libretto indicates that in order to provide time for these ridiculous

intermezzi, it was necessary to eliminate all lines of text preceded by quotation marks.

1707/8 Vindice la pazzia della vendetta Music attributed to Girolamo Polani
[Madness VINDICATED BY REVENGE]

mM Performed at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival)

The primary emphasis of this short pastoral was on the magical properties of Arcadian poppies and
the love affairs of the mad Clopeus. Its other characters were stocks of the pastoral trade  Clori,
Mirtillo, Fileno, Silvio, Amarilli, and Laurilla. The librettist emphasized the need to adapt the work
toasmall theater. Unusually for San Fantin, the cast members were identified. They included Giuseppe
Bassani (C/opeo) and Diana Vico (Mirtillo), who were relatively well known.

 Licenses to print libretti for this work?* were issued on both 31 January 1707 (the date on which the
dedicatee's exile from Mantua formally commenced) and 27 January 1708. The exiled duke had settled
in Padua (with 150 of his best horses) by 12 Febuary 1707 (BG). The correct year of first performance
has to have been 1707 because La virtit trionfante was authorized for production at San Fantin at virtually
the same time in 1708. This leaves the second license without any clear rationale, apart from the
possibility that La virtu was poorly received and by way of replacement, a revised version of Vindice
la pazzia was considered.

1707/9 Armida abbandonata Music by Giovanni Maria Ruggieri
[ARMIDE ABANDONED]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Silvani
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With intermezzi SORTING DATE: 1707-11-10

& Dedicated to Nicole Cornaro and Francesca Soranzo, NN.VV.2

While these tales of Armide from the First Crusade were derived from Tasso's Gerusalemme liberata,
the emphasis here was disproportionately on magic, enchantment, and visual distortion. Gothic staging
would become a hallmark of Sant' Angelo's productions in the years ahead. A haunted palace was
substituted for the isole fortunate, Erminia appeared as an Amazon. The religious orientation of the
final scene seems to have been intended to placate censors wary of tales of magic. The work opened
in a grotto under a river bed, where Philomachus clandestinely cast his spells. The librettist claimed
that this was the first entirely amorous opera to be seen in the past twenty years, which had been marked
by heroic works.

Il selvaggio eroe Music by Antonio Caldara
[THE HEROIC SAVAGE]

A tragicommedia eroica-pastorale (5) Libretto attrib. to Girolamo Frigimelica-Roberti
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1707-11-20
Without dedicatee

Although it exhibited his usual careful intentions, this text was something of departure for Frigimelica-
Roberti. Itmixed comic and tragic roles as well as pastoral and heroic ones because, he observed, people
are always looking for something new. The principal figures were Gargore, an Andalusian prince, his
daughter Gelinda (who was erroneously believed to be unmarried), and her son Abydos/Abide, who,
believed to be illegitimate, was raised in the wild by hunters. Alarda became his beloved.

II selvaggio was first performed on 20 November 1707, when it was enjoyed by Theresa Kunegunda
Sobieska, the electress of Bavaria ( M), and Ferdinand Carlo Gonzaga, the duke of Mantua (NV). Anton
Francesco Carli sang as Gargore, with Santa Stella (Gelinda), Diamante Maria Scarabelli (Alarda),
and Nicola Grimaldi as Abydos/Abide, (the savage hero of the title). The doge had intervened to
secure Grimaldi's services for San Giovanni Grisostomo (M) after the singer was recruited to appear
in England.

The work opens with a royal hunt and proceeds with a series of outdoor scenes. Each act contains a
ballo. The dancers depict by turns wild beasts of the forest, various nations in the service of the king,
and courtesans who dance with savages to celebrate the wedding of Abydos with the princess Alarda.
Arias in D-MUs; GB-Lbl, Lkc, Lpr (prima), Ob

Listed as Bonlini 418; Groppo 422; Wiel 57; Alm 551

L'amor generoso Music by Francesco Gasparini
[GENEROUS LOVE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With Melissa schernita e vendicata SORTING DATE: 1707-12-01

Dedicated to Girolamo Delfin, N.V.*

Aldan, a Danish prince and brother of king Frealaf/Frilevo, was raised anonymously in the Norwegian
court. As a young man he fell in love with the Danish princess Girita but was required by duty to marry
Alvilda, the newly ascendant queen of Norway. Alvilda, a former warrior, recognizing the true reasons
for the union, imprisoned Frealaf and installed Aldan on the Danish throne. Portions of the text were
reused in La fede in cimento (1730/2).

L'amor generoso was first performed on 1 December 1707, when it was enjoyed by Theresa Kunegunda
Sobieska (M) and numerous imperial and Hessian officers (NV). This text was set the following year
by Giuseppe Orlandini and Rocco Cerruti for performance at the Cocomero (Florence) in October. Zeno
wrote on 9 December that L amor had already opened with public sympathy, even though it was
the product of only a few days' work. The principal roles were taken by Antonio Tosi (Aldano),
Giuseppe Maria Boschi (Frilevo), Francesca Vanini Boschi (A/vilda), and Maria Domenica Pini
(Girita)?

La Partenope' Music attributed to Antonio Caldara?

[PARTHENOPE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Silvio Stampiglia**
mM Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)

With balli SORTING DATE: 1707-12-26

Without dedicatee

Princess Parthenope left her native island of Negroponte [Crete], an island in the Eastern Mediterranean
often visited by Venetian sailors and sometimes held under Venetian rule. Following the path of a white
dove, she founded a great settlement where it landed, on a beach of the Tyrrhenian Sea. The name of
the new city, first called Partenope, was later changed to Naples [neo polis]. This account highlights
an amorous square formed by Parthenope, who loved Arsakes (prince of Corinth), who in turn loved
Rosmira (princess of Cyprus), who loved Armindos (prince of Rhodes), who loved Parthenope. To
lessen Parthenope's interest in Arsakes, Rosmira posed as the Armenian prince Eurymenes and courted
Parthenope.

oo The Venetian production was announced in the Gazzetta di Napoli of 24 December 17077! and opened
on the 26th (NV, BG), when it pleased its audience to perfection (M). Title-pages dated both 1707
and 1708 survive. A license to print the libretto had been issued to Stampiglia on 27 September 1698.
Diamante Scarabelli sang in the title role with Santa Stella (Rosmira) and Nicola Grimaldi (Arsace).
The work opened with an impending sacrifice to Apollo, whose statue was being approached by eagles
and swans. The balli were unusually eclectic and featured courtesans and savages (perhaps recycled

from // selvaggio eroe), as well as gentlewomen and men, cicisbei,'* and peasants.

o Stampiglia's text, first set by an unknown composer for performance in Naples and Rovigo in 1699
and given in Florence in November 1701, formed the basis for Handel's Partenope (HWV 27), which
opened in London on 24 February 1730. Predieri's setting, made for the opening of the Teatro Marsigli
Rossi (Bologna) in 1710, was given in Florence in 1718 and in Bologna in 1719. One variant text called
Rosmira fedele was set by Vinci for San Giovanni Grisostomo (1725/3), and another, simply called

musical masquerade (mascherata) called La sirena Partenope had been a major event in the life of the Neapolitan aristocracy on 5 February
1696 (see Griffin, Gazzetta, Doc. 85, for 7 Febraro). The hostess of the 1696 event seems to have been Aurora Sansverino (see La gloria trionfante
d'amore [1712] and La fede ne' tradimenti [1721]). The final performance of La Partenope (27 January) was attended by Charles Montagu,
who was accompanied by General [James] Stanhope, who had just arrived from Barcelona and left for London as soon as the performance
was concluded (BG). Stanhope was to win the important battles of Almenara and Zaragosa in 1710, only to be defeated at Brihuega a few

> In Sartori Nos. 17817 and 17818.

28 Cicisbei (literally whisperers) were noblemen who were official escorts of noblewomen in Venice. Cicisbei were unmarried (roughly
40 per cent of Venetian noblemen were unmarried in the middle of the eighteenth century). No extramarital adventures were implied by such
arrangements; they were sanctioned in wedding contracts. A cicisbeo's presence was expected at theatrical performances, church services,
and other occasions on which his charge circulated in society. It was intended to discourage flirtations and dalliances.

1707/15  TeuzzoneTM Music by Antonio Lotti
[TAO TsUNG]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With Catulla e Lardone; Melissa vendicata; balli SORTING DATE: 1707-12-27
& Without dedicatee

The plot focuses on rights of succession through this tale from medieval Chinese history. Zidiana, a
commoner, was married to the emperor Troncone a few days before he was killed in a war with the
Tartars. Although prince Tao Tsung was his legitimate heir, Zidiana claimed that she was named
as Troncone's successor in his will. Meanwhile the captive Tartar princess Zelinda had fallen in love
with Tao Tsung and argued on his behalf. Just as Tao Tsung was to be executed, the will produced
by Zidiana was shown to be false. The action took place in Nanking.

CO Teuzzone was first performed (as the third drama) on 27 December 1707 (BG), when, like Partenope,
it suited its audience to perfection (M). The title-page is dated 1708, and the work is identified in
the libretto as the third of the season. It had been announced in the Gazzetta di Napoli of 24 December
1707. The text was set by Orlandini without change of title (Bologna, 1711; Ferrara and Genoa, 1712),
and, with the title La costanza fra gl'inganni, for performance at the Cocomero in Florence in January
1712.48 Teuzzone was probably one of the two works for which Zeno sent libretti to Magliabecchi on
11 February 1707 M.V. with the comment that both were received this year with applause. Domenico
Cecchi sang in the title role. Don Nicola Pasini, who sang in the ducal chapel, was cast as the Emperor
of China. Vivaldi set it under the original title (RV 736) for Mantua in 1719. Other composers who
set the text included Fiore (Turin, 1716),?* Feo (Naples, 1720), and Ariosti (London, 1727).

This character-oriented elaboration of a tale derived from Tasso's Gerusalemme liberata portrays a

1708/2 Alessandro in Susa Music attributed to Luigi Mancia?
[ALEXANDER IN SUSA]
A tragicomedia (5) Text attributed to Girolamo Frigimelica-Roberti
mM Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli?*' SORTING DATE: 1708-01-28
& Dedicated to Karl Alexander, Duke of Wittenberg**

This account of the campaign of Alexander the Great in Susa was based, according to the librettist,
on the historical and philosophical writings of Plutarch, Diodorus, Seneca, and other ancient authors
as well as works more directly related to the theater by Euripides, Aristotle, and Terence. Frigimelica-
Roberti refrained from his usual habit of writing a long-winded treatise on the dramatic genre employed,
but the structure of the work is similar to that of its predecessors insofar as it has five acts, each concluded
by an elaborate spectacle. Albrizzi published an anonymous poetic discourse on this work in 1708.7

OO & Alessandro was first performed as San Giovanni's third work on 28 January 1708 (M, NV, BG).
General Stanhope, a special envoy of the queen of England, attended the premiere. The work ran
through the end of Carnival.*' Nicola Grimaldi, now a cavalier, sang in the title role, with Santa Stella
as Stateira and Diamante Maria Scarabelli as Candaspe. A novice, Francesco Bravo (Apelle), appears
to have been the singer killed at a festa di ballo near the traghetto San Felice on 12 February 1707
[M.V.], for he never appeared in later works. The work included dances for Persians, Indians, for
satyrs, and for courtesans at the wedding of Alexander and Stateira. A ballo for gardeners in Act Four

Flavio Anicio Olibrio Music by Francesco Gasparini
[FLAVIUS ANICIUS OLYBRIUS]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Pietro Pariati
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Melissa contenta; Pollastrella e Parpagnacco > SORTING DATE: 1708-01-30~

Dedicated to Charles Montagu'>

While in Rome to liberate his sister Theodelinda from prison, Ricimer (Giuseppe Boschi), the king
of the Goths, fell in love with Placidia (Maria Domenica Pini), the daughter of the late emperor
Valentinian III. The Roman general Flavius Anicius Olybrius (Domenico Cecchi) professed love for
her in public but was privately attracted to Theodelinda (Francesca Vanini Boschi).

The performance of Flavio started around 28 January 1708, when many foreign gentlemen were arriving
in Venice (M). The title-page date was given as Carnovale dell'anno 1707. A license to print the
libretto had been issued on 12 January 1708 for 1707. It must have been one of the two works for
which Zeno sent libretti to Magliabecchi on 11 February 1707 M.V. with the comment that both were
received this year with applause. Later settings of the text, which reassumed several characters who
were highly profiled in the 1680s, included those of Porpora (Naples, 1711, as // trionfo di Flavio Anicio
Olibrio), Vinci (Naples, 1728, as Ricimero), and Bernasconi (Vienna, 1738, as La tirannide debellata).
No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 424; Groppo 428; Wiel 54; Alm 557

La virti trionfante d'amore vendicativoTM Music by Girolamo Polani
[VIRTUE TRIUMPHANT AND LOVE VINDICATED]

A favola pastorale Text by Bartolomeo Pedoni
Performed at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1708-02-05~

Dedicated to Gaetano Sessi?*

This fable [favola] featured Apollo and Amore, with Mars, Vulcan, Endymion, and other gods who
disported themselves in gardens and woods, and on hills. The librettist asked that readers appreciate
the constraints imposed on the drama by its performance in a small theater. Licences to print the libretto
were issued on 31 January 1707 and 1 February 1707 M.V., but it would not have opened until after
the feast of Santa Maria Formosa on 2 February.

Astarto Music by Tomaso Albinoni
[ASTARTOS]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Pietro Pariati
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With Vespetta e Pimpinone; Catulla e Lardone? SORTING DATE: 1708-11-11

Dedicated to (Prince) Filippo Ercolani?

In this tale of a prince raised with a false identity, Astartos was believed to be the son of Phoeniceos,
who was secretly hostile to the reign of Elissa, queen of Tyre, with whom Astartos was in love. The
subject, which focuses on the early history of the Phoenician city of Tyre, was derived from Greek history
of the tenth century BC, mediated by the tragedies Astarto and Amalasunta of Quinault.

Astarto was first performed on 11 November 1708 (M, NV, BG). Giovanna Albertini (La Reggiana)
made her Venetian debut in the title role with a cast including Santa Stella (Elisa), Domenico Cecchi
(Fenicio), and Antonio Ristorini (Geronzio) in the main work. Gio. Battista Cavanna sang as Pimpinone
in the debut performance of Albinoni's later well-known intermezzi. Paolo Rolli's adaptation of the
text was set by Giovanni Bononcini (Rome: Capranica, 1715; London: King's Theatre, 1721).
Arias in D-MUs, SWI; GB-Ob

Listed as Bonlini 428; Groppo 432; Wiel 69; Alm 562

Sofonisba Music by Antonio Caldara
[SOPHONISBA]

A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Silvani
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1708-11-24

Dedicated to Francesco Girolamo Gravena

The ancient Numidians were divided into two camps, one headed by Syphax and the other by Massanissa.
While the Carthaginians under Hasdrubal were gaining power in Spain, Syphax and Massanissa were
both attracted to Hasdrubal's daughter, Sophonisba. Each saw the possibility of expanding his own
empire by forming an alliance with her father. Sophonisba poisoned herself to avoid becoming a prisoner
of Scipio Africanus the Elder.*!

Sofonisba was first performed on 24 (M) or 25 November 1708 (BG).* The libretto had been dedicated
on the 22nd. Diamante Scarabelli, now a virtuosa in the service of Vincenzo Grimani, viceroy of Naples,
sang in the title role of this militaristic work. It included balli for Amazons and Indians as well as that

27 Groppo MS, p. 161. Bonlini MS cites only [Vespetta e] Pimpinone.

La pace fra Pompeiani Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo

e Cesariani
[THE TREATY BETWEEN THE POMPEIANS AND THE CAESARIANS]

A dramma in musica' Text attributed to Aurelio Aureli
Performed at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Grilletta e Demo** SORTING DATE: 1709-01-05~

Dedicated to the Venetian nobility

The Roman populace, divided in their loyalties between Caesar and Pompey, was reunited by the death
of the latter and the intervention of Ptolemy. The characters represented in this work  the middle-aged
Caesarinus Drusus and his three children, plus the young Lentulus and his sister  were drawn from
the ranks of lesser Roman nobles. There was also a role for the hump-backed servant Bleso.

A stragiudizial of 2 January 1708 [M.V.] complained that the costumes for the second workat San
Fantin fell below expectation, both in quantity and in quality, that therefore the payment of 10 ducats
for them to Andrea Bona was reasonable (in relation to the 30 ducats which had been paid for costumes
for the autumn work), and that remedies were to be provided within three days.* This leads to the
conclusion that a scheduled opening was imminent. The singer Angela Pace (Pasi) filed a separate

stragiudizial against Francesco Rossi, the impresario. She acknowledged having been late for
performances after Rossi fell behind in their contractual agreement to pay her 9 Jire per performance.
She said she had grown weary of performing without recompense and complained that performing
intermezzi had not been in her contract.

Despite these acrimonious relations, the intended production may have been the most ambitious one
attempted by San Fantin. Pollarolo was by now highly esteemed, the subject was more serious than
most, and the scenery more ambitious: Peace descended in a machine (an uncommon occurrence at
San Fantin) at the end of the work. The undated dedication was signed by Rocco Commelati.

Il falso Tiberino' Music by Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[THE FALSE TIBERINUS]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Pietro Pariati
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Vespetta e Pimpinone' SORTING DATE: 1709-01-12

Dedicated to Benedetta, Duchess of Brunswick?

In this episode from early Roman history, Tiberinus was the cruel king of the Albans. His designated
successor was the Etruscan chieftain Mezentius/Masentio, who was in the event upstaged by Agrippa,
the son of the Alban leader Tyrrhenus/Tirreno. Agrippa took advantage of his physical resemblance
to the king to pose as him after the accidental drowning of Tiberinus.

Il falso Tiberino appears to have opened on 12 January 1709 (BG). The king of Denmark had been
taken to a rehearsal at San Cassiano on the 2nd (M). Licenses to print libretti had been issued on 29
December 1708 and 4 January 1708 [M.V.]. This work and // vincitor generoso received universal
applause, both for the musicians and for every other aspect of the production (M). The cast was an
outstanding one which included Giovanna Albertini (La Reggiana; here Agrippa), Santa Stella
(Lavinia), Maria Anna Garberini (Albina), Domenico Cecchi (Tirreno), and Francesco Bernardi
(Ascanius), as well as Antonio Ristorini (Fausto) and Andrea Pacini (Mezenio).

[To LOVE MORE THAN IS BELIEVED POSSIBLE]

The lovelorn shepherdess Locrine commits herself to the cult of Diana in Ephesos. Mirtillo comes there
in pursuit but falls in love with another shepherdess. Diana punishes all of Arcadia with a plague. In
this pastoral the Arcadians try to win back the favor of Diana. The poet offered this work for a happy
diversion during these few [remaining] days of autumn and promised a heroic work for Carnival. He
believed that the air of villeggiatura which hung over the present dictated the need for a pastoral work.

C8 In this pastoral, the handsome Endymion has been carried to Heaven by Jove. A contest between Jove

(representing Comedy) and Juno (representing Tragedy) ensues. As the work opens, Endymion is
descending from Heaven. A license to print the libretto was issued on 29 November 1709, and Endimione
is likely to have opened soon after.* The librettist complained that the scenery should have been

between Night and Day, and between bucolic tranquility and tempestuous storms  as well as Comedy
and Tragedy. A setting by Buini was given at the Teatro Formigliari, Bologna, in 1729.

Soothsayers of Astyages, the king of Media, maliciously instructed the king to give his daughter Mandane

The 1710s: An Overview

he Peace of Utrecht (1713) brought little relief to
E the declining fortunes of the Most Serene Repub-

lic. A year later a new war erupted in the Balkans.
Venetian holdings on the fringes of these lands were threat-
ened. Within six months the Turks had invaded the Venetian-
held Peloponnese. Under Field-Marshal Schulenburg, the
Venetians held Corfu in 1716. On the Hungarian plains, the
Empire gained ground under Eugene of Savoy. Belgrade fell
in 1717. The treaty signed at Passarowitz in 1718, which
expanded the Holy Roman Empire and assigned Sicily to
Savoy, also concretized the Republic's losses in the Aegean.

Overall, these back-to-back wars redefined the balance
of power between maritime and land-based empires. Except
for access to the Black Sea via the Danube, Austria had been
aland-locked country. As soldiers charted unfamiliar river
valleys and plains in Bohemia, Poland, the Balkans, and
Ukraine, they were impressed by novelties of geography and
topography, flora and fauna, languages and cultures. New
awareness gave rise to better maps of the sprawling interior
of the Continent, overland extensions in transportation and
communication, the rapid growth of market towns at major
crossroads, and the opening of untaxed ports. Notable among
these was Trieste, which sat directly across the Adriatic from
Venice. By 1720 the foundations of the Venetian economy
were challenged from every direction.

Librettists from the nobility found themselves distracted
by new political agendas. Apostolo Zeno abandoned his
dramaturgical pursuits to Pietro Pariati when he launched
the bimonthly Giornale de' letterati d'Italia (1710). Eight
years later he moved to Vienna as court poet. Girolamo
Frigimelica-Roberti, a pillar of dramaturgical reform in the
1690s, occupied himself with clandestine schemes for inter-
European canals and the management of espionage networks
in the Balkans. Agostino Piovene expressed his anti-Turkish
hostility in plots such as that of Zamerlano, set by Gasparini
as 1711/3. Inthe same year the government, every supersti-
tious about a lack of piety in politically delicate times,
prohibited the holding of banquets in theaters.

Peace enable distinguished visitors once again to visit
the city. The elector of Bavaria (1716) and the electoral
prince of Poland and Saxony (1712, 1716-17) were among
those most feted. In general, however, audiences became

more anonymous. A blanket induction of new nobles in 1716
paralleled the increasing tendency of librettists to dedicate
their works collectively to the ladies and gentlemen of
Venice, or simply to ladies collectively.

Impoverished by war, divested of its patrons and its
trade, the government in 1715 sanctioned more frequent
public lotto drawings. In 1717 it began to sell off the salons
of the Procuratie Nuove on the Piazza San Marco. (One
became Florian's Caffe, which still survives.) Economic
collapse led to the wholesale departure of singers, instrumen-
talists, and scene-painters for other climes, particularly
London. German princes offered positions to the Italian
performers they particularly favored. Venice continued to
produce an enormous quantity of indigenous musical talent,
but much of it was siphoned off as quickly as it was devel-
oped. The stellar example is that of Faustina Bordoni, who
made her debut in a Venetian serenata (1716) but within ten
years became a celebrity in London and Paris.

The most decisive events in theatrical life were the
deaths of Vincenzo (1710) and Gio. Carlo Grimani (1714).
In Vincenzo's absence, San Samuele began to present operas,
albeit infrequently. At San Giovanni Grisostomo, reorienta-
tion took several years. Sant'Angelo became the most
consistently active theater (Figure 24). Its vicissitudes were
bound up with the involvements of Antonio Vivaldi as
violinist and sometime impresario. Although conditions were
often chaotic, Sant' Angelo's stagecraft seems to have been
moderately well received. Despite the official reservations
of the State Inquisitors, scenes of magic and enchantment
had wide appeal. Audiences saw depictions of palaces and
gardens, storms and shipwrecks designed by Marco Ricci
as well as Bernardo Canal and his sons. Activity at San
Cassiano fell sharply with Gasparini's move to Rome. San
Moise re-emerged as an opera house at mid-decade through
its engagement of the Denzio troupe, many of whose
members were later drawn to Graz, Brno, and Prague.

Among composers, Pollarolo's activities at San Giovan-
ni Grisostomo declined. Gasparini was recruited to Rome
in 1713, Lotti to Dresden in 1717. Vivaldi was called to
Mantua at the end of the same year. Albinoni was the most
experienced composer who stayed behind. He found
supplementary work in private palaces and in the provinces.

FIGURE 24. Comparison of works per theater in the 1700s and 1710s.

Sant' Angelo's repertory became a parade of works by little-
known, sometimes foreign composers.

The absorption of displaced singers from failed duchies,
in coincidence with the arrival of new audiences from distant
principalities, posed profound obstacles to textual under-
standing. Opera productions were forced to appeal to a
polyglot audience in textless ways. Dramaturgical messages
lost some of their cultural meaning. Virtuosity flourished.
Instrumental cadenzas and fantasies proliferated. Gifted
musicians, among them the Saxons Heinichen and Pisendel,
came to Venice to study. They also contributed to new
musical fashions, especially in matters of musical articula-
tion. Arguments about taste became rampant.

Productions during Advent were avoided entirely,
reflecting the strictness of government control. The number
of works given during the winter increased significantly. The
level of private activity at palaces and embassies was little
changed from that of the preceding decade. The rate of score
survival (18 works or 20%) is marginally improved. Polla-
rolo, Vivaldi, and Lotti are the beneficiaries.

The legate's records provide the one stable stream of
news reports of the time. Avvisi and Pallade veneta
manuscripts are preserved only for politically sensitive
periods. Owing to a temporary increase in British patronage,
the State Papers begin again to mention theatrical affairs in
parallel with an expansion of trade interests.

In the third century BC, the historical Aratos opposed Macedonian influence in the Peloponnese and
freed Athens. In this fanciful account Leonidas, the king of Sparta, wished to see his daughter Almira
well-married. Hericlene/Ericlene, in pursuit of her beloved Aratos (who has assumed the name of
Rimedes), was shipwrecked off the coast of Sparta, where she discovered her husband negotiating with
Leonidas for the hand of Almira.

OOE Arato in Sparta was first performed between 4 and 9 January 1710 (M); the 4th is most probable. A
license to print the libretto was issued on 2 January 1710 for Carnevale 1709. All theaters were closed
from 26 January to 8 February by papal order.' Audiences heard Antonio Bernacchi in the title role.
Maria Angelica Bracci (Ericlene) and other singers protested to the Council of Ten on 1 March 1711
that they had not yet been paid by the impresario, Giovanni Orsato. One of the plaintiffs was Girolamo
Polani, suggesting that it was he who was the composer.*

The subject of this work was Zoe, the Eastern Empress who married the Roman chancellor Argirus.
The mother of one son, Constantine, she was persuaded by her politically ambitious husband to adopt
another, Isaac. The resulting tensions made her marriage a microcosm ofa contentious political terrain.
The work opens with Zoe's coronation.

Or Il comando was first performed on 8 February 1710 (M). The libretto had been dedicated on the 6th.
A setting of the text by Francesco Gasparini was given at the Cocomero (Florence, music lost) in
November 1715. Settings given in Naples and Genoa (1713) are of unknown authorship. The cast included
Margherita Durastante (Zoe) and Diamante Maria Scarabelli (Jeodora). The balli depicted gypsies,
mad people, and genies. The audience may have included Livio Odescalchi, the duke of Bracciano,
who had just arrived in Venice to enjoy Carnival (CO).

Sesostri, re d'Egitto Music by Francesco Gasparini
[SESOSTRIS, KING OF EGYPT]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Pietro Pariati
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Bertolda e Volpone'*; Galantina e Tulipano SORTING DATE: 1710-02-09

Dedicated to Fulvia Visconti'

The life of Sesostris, who reigned in Egypt in the twelfth dynasty [1970-1936 BC], was spared in
childhood, when the rest of his family was massacred by the tyrant Amasis, through the help of the
faithful satrap Phanes/Fanete. Raised as Amasis's natural son, Sesostris organized a serious resistance
to the brutal rule of Amasis.' Sesostri was first performed (as the third work of the season) on 9
February 1710 (M).'' The opera was later produced in Rome, Florence, Genoa, and Turin. This and
the preceding work were received with universal satisfaction. The cast included Stefano Romani
(Sesostri), Gio. Battista Carboni (Amasi), and Giovanni Paita (Fanete). Gio. Battista Calvi (Gambino)
performed in both the main work (as Canoppo) and in the intermezzi.

Sesostri is one of the few works for which there is proof of a /ater performance without music. Riccoboni
revised it as a dramma representativo in 1715 (supplement 3a), apparently for performance during his
last season at San Salvatore before moving to Paris.' A setting by Francesco Conti, with balli by Nicold
Matteis, was given in Vienna in 1729.

Berengario, re d'Italia Music attributed to Girolamo Polani
[BERENGAR, KING OF ITALY]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1710-02-15~

Dedicated to Giovanni Battista Durino?

Louis, the king of Gaul, sent to Arnoulf, the earl of Flanders [Germany], portraits of his two eligible
daughters, Matilda and Leonora. Jealousies between the sisters provided the basis for a series of incidents
involving marriage and deception after the death of Louis and the ascension of Charles [879-888]. Upon
Charles's death, Berengar [888-889] began the first of his two reigns.'* Berengario was first performed
between 15 and 22 February 1710 (M). The subject was related to that of 1682/8.

1710/6 L'amor tirannico Music attributed to Francesco Gasparini

A dramma per musica (5) Text by Domenico Lalli'

Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1710-11-08
wz Dedicated to Marquis Filippo Rangoni, Count of Monza

Tiridates, the wicked king of Armenia, was married to Polyxena but had fallen in love with Zenobia,
who was married to Rhadamisthos, here described as a prince of Thrace. Wounded in the defense of
her city and taken for dead, Zenobia was thrown into a river, from which she was rescued by Tiridates'
soldiers and then imprisoned. Much of the plot hinges on Rhadamisthos's efforts to save her.'
OO L'amor was first performed on 8 November 1710 (PV), when it was received with common satisfaction
(NV). It was still running on the 22nd (M). Pallade veneta noted that Gasparini had sweetened [a text
which applauded tyranny] with his musical ideas.'' The text had been set under the title Radamisto
by Albinoni (1698/7), and an adaptation of the libretto was to be used as the basis for Handel's Radamisto
(1720; HWV 12). Gasparini's own setting may have been the one given at the Teatro Cocomero, Florence,
in January 1712."* A pastiche version by Chelleri and Porta was given ten years after that (1722/6).

Inasarcastic note, the correspondent for Pallade veneta noted that this was an entertainment for those
who have a slender purse...since the music is accompanied by little clinking of coins.! The libretto
symbolized a style of presentation which was the antithesis of the lavish practices of San Giovanni
Grisostomo. The plot summary and the note to the reader consist entirely of short couplets.

Isacio tiranno Music attributed to Antonio Lotti
[ISAAC THE TYRANT]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris, rev. Francesco Briani
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With danze SORTING DATE: 1710-11-24

Dedicated to John (Johann), Duke of Marlborough?

The subject here was the Cypriot tyrant Isaac, who had come to power with false credentials in the reign
of the Eastern emperor Andronicus. Many atrocities were committed in his war against the king of Sicily,
which he would have won had it not been for the intervention of a fleet of English ships which had
been blown off-course into the Limassol harbor. One ship carried Constance, the wife of the English
king Richard, who demanded revenge for her mistreatment by the Cypriots.

Isacio was first performed with grand applause on 24 November 1710 (M, A, PV). Paolo Rolli was
to adapt the text, based on English history, for Handel's Riccardo primo, re d'Inghilterra (1727; HWV
23). According to NV, the production elicited applause and satisfaction equal to that received by L amor
tirannico. Anton Francesco Carli sang in the title role with Francesco de Grandis (Riccardo), Diamante
Maria Scarabelli (Costanza), and Margherita Durastante (the tyrant's daughter, Pulcheria).

L'ingannator ingannato Music attributed to Giovanni Maria Ruggieri
[THE DECEIVER DECEIVED]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Antonio Marchi
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1710-11-29
Without dedicatee

The plot's Roman setting concerns the reign of Domitian [81-96 AD]. The first opera to be performed
at San Samuele, L 'ingannator opened on 29 November 1710 (A, M, NV, PV), when it met with general
pleasure and applause. Marchi cited the virtues of the new theater and the selection of [unnamed]
singers in the work, while beseeching viewers to overlook the restraints imposed by time. The staging
was carefully contrived. While the outer acts provided the customary chambers, piazzas, and courtyards
expected of a Roman setting, the two sets for the second act depicted a gallery of musical instruments
(as in Nerone, 1678/8, the second work given at San Giovanni Grisostomo) and a garden of rose-covered
trellises and cedars.

Suleyman, the Shah of Algeria, banished his infants to the custody of his brother Mehmet, but en route
to their new home they were seized and killed by Turkish sailors. A different set of children was given
over to the care of the uninformed brother. Only after the proxy children were grown and contemplating
marriage was Suleyman made aware of the deception. Non son Quella was first performed on 29
November (A, M, NV) or | December 1710 (PV). The libretto was dedicated by Zan [Giovanni] Battista
Zuccato on the earlier date.

t According to Pallade veneta, the bizarre title was symptomatic ofa curious production. Anna Vicenza
Dobbi, an apparent member of the cast, filed a notarial complaint (stragiudizialey' on 19 January 1711.
In it she expressed dismay over not having received the first installment (of three) of the 2,000 /ire [de

same date stating that he had not yet received the first installment (of two) of the 1,000 lire de piccioli
offered him the preceding August to cover his travel expenses, maintenance, and honorarium. Falier
may have been the impresario.

La morte d'Adone. Cf. Suppl. 5a.

La costanza fortunata in amore' Music anonymousTM
[CONSTANCY FORTUNATE IN LOVE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Maria Piccioli
Performed at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1711-01-10

Dedicated to the Venetian nobility

In this revised version of Ermelinda (Piazzola, 1681/4 and 1685/8) Aristaios, wishing to protect his
daughter from the ravages of love, decided to live in a rural village of Phoenicia. Hermelinde's lover,
the prince Ormond, in order to seek her out, disguised himself as a beggar and then, not wanting to
alarm her father, pretended to madness. The work's Arcadian scenes depicted the sites past which
Aristaios led Hermelinde: a grove of cedars, a solitary house in the countryside, and other rural settings.
This short work was first performed between 10 and 17 January 1711 (PV). The title-page of its libretto
is dated 1710 M.V. The impresario Antonio Bonomo, on 27 January 1711 M.V., acknowledged many
grievous problems. He admitted that debts were owed to singers and to the costume-maker Andrea
di Bona. The problems were caused, he claimed, by unforeseen expenses and aggravated by the
cancellation of some performances. The document was signed by singers and instrumentalists, who
committed themselves to performing in another work when it was ready.*

Il tradimento, traditor di se stesso Music attributed to Antonio Lotti
[TREACHERY, TRAITOR TO ITSELF]

A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Silvani
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli and a divertimento giocoso SORTING DATE: 1711-01-17

Dedicated to Princess Isabella Cesi Ruspoli*

Cyrus, the second son of Darius, revolted against his older brother, Artaxerxes, and was killed by him
in battle. Artaxerxes' oldest son, also called Darius, when given adult responsibilities, fell in love with
his father's wife, Aspasia, and the doting parent renounced his own marriage to permit the union.
Ultimately, however, Artaxerxes' son Ocho (here called Ariarate) ascended to the throne.

II tradimento, a relatively short work for San Giovanni Grisostomo, was first performed on 17 January
1711 (M, A, PV), the date of dedication of its libretto. // tradimento was produced in Fano in February
1718 for the exiled English court, then resident in Urbino. A resetting by Francesco Mancini ran in
Naples (as Artaserse, re di Persia) in 1713.

* Nicola Giglio (who is otherwise unknown) is named in notarial papers (note 35) as both the composer and librettist, but it is more likely

oo Designed not as a history...but as a tragedy, according to Piovene, Jamerlano opened in Prusa, the

capital of Bithynia, the first city conquered by Tamerlane after the defeat of the Turks. His command
over tribal forces enabled him to defeat Bayezid/Bajazet. This third work of the season opened on
24 January 1711 (NV). The title-page of the libretto is dated 1710. Much applause was anticipated
because the librettist (autore) had contributed his fee for the work to improve the scenery. Tamerlano
brought delight both for its poetry and for the exquisiteness of its music. It and the preceding work
were by other accounts (A, M) received with universal satisfaction. Giovanni Paita sang as Bayezid,
with Gio. Battista Carboni (Zamerlano) and Santa Stella (Asteria).

OOo When Berenice was proclaimed the queen of Egypt, Mithridates was the king of Pontos and Sulla ruled
Rome. Each male ruler feared that the beautiful Berenice, who was noted in particular for her hair, might
marry a pawn of the other. Fortunately for both, she married Alexander, through whom both sides were
united. The action takes place in Alexandria. Le gare is reported to have opened both by 31 January
(M, A) and during recent days preceding 7 February 1711 (PV). Its libretto was dedicated on 28
January. Pallade veneta, moralizing about the text's message that prudence conquers every passion,
termed the drama delicious.* The librettist apologized for the constrained space afforded by San
Samuele. Perti's setting of the text had been staged at Pratolino in September 1709.%

1711/5 Circe delusa Music attributed to Giuseppe Boniventi
[CIRCE DELUDED]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giorgio Antonio Falier
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1711-02-05
& Dedicated to Richard (Lord Viscount) Lonsdale**

These episodes from the encounter of Circe and Ulysses emphasized the sorceress's ability to change
one form of life into another. She changed Picus, the king of the Latins, into a wild boar. When he rejected
her love, she changed him into a woodpecker. The shipwrecked, demented Ulysses believed her to be
Penelope, his wife. The work began and ended with Circe's soliloquies. At the start she invoked the
horrible spirits, while at the end, as she watched Ulysses depart, she longed for death.

O@ Although some sources (M, A) suggest that Circe opened shortly before 31 January 1711,' its first
performance took place on 5 February 1711, when the work was found to be agreeable. A license
to print its libretto had been issued on 13 January. Perhaps to please his English patron, the librettist
interleaved numerous Latin quotations from ancient sources into his account of the life of Circe.

BE The manner of staging was Arcadian, with its woods and fountains, gardens and herbs. Yet the
transformations brought about by Circe's magic must have made a greater impression on audiences
than the underlying idyll. In Act One Ulysses' men were turned into monsters and then restored to their
human appearance. In Act Two Circe was changed into a peasant and then converted back to herself.
In Act Three Scylla was changed into a monster (according to the legend, with twelve feet and six heads).
Each scene was introduced by the trembling of a mountain. The cooperation of the cast apparently
faltered, for on 8 February the Council of Ten ordered Giovanni Castellini to perform and demanded
his court appearance the following Wednesday (11 February).

Pasqualigo's text by Orlandini (1725/1) and of Vitturi's by Galuppi (1741/1; also reset for Sant' Angelo in 1759), both held by some to have
been influenced by Racine's Berenice.

1711/6 Armida in Damasco Music by Giacomo RampiniTM
[ARMIDE IN DAMASCUS]
A dramma per musica Text by Grazio Braccioli*
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1711-10-17

& Dedicated to Silvio Antonio Marsigli Rossi

In the First Crusade (eleventh century), according to Tasso's epic Gerusalemme liberata (1579), the
Saracen sorceress Armide was lured to the Holy Land to deceive the Christian crusaders. Among her
intended victims was their leader Tancred. Rinaldo, who succeeded in liberating his imprisoned allies,
fell under Armide's spell but persuaded the sorceress to convert to Christianity. A Ferrarese member
of the Arcadian colony of Rome, Braccioli sought here to balance prescribed reforms with the vivacity
of earlier literary traditions.** This was his first libretto for the Venetian stage.

 The libretto was dedicated on 17 October 1711, the date of the first performance. The attendance was
expected to be good because few people had gone away for villeggiatura. The work was said still
to be running on 14 November (M), although one ballerina who appeared in the work was paid for only
two performances. The relatively early opening date and the dedicatee's presence may have been related
to the investiture of the new papal legate [Girolamo Mattei].

Ow The principal roles were taken by Margherita Gualandi (La Campioli; here Armida) and Giuseppe
Dini (Rinaldo), with Francesco Maria Venturini cast both as Hydraot/Idraote, the king of Damascus,
and as Pluto. The scenery was painted by Bernardo Canal, in what appears to have been his first theatrical
commission. Among the more interesting scenes were Pluto's inferno (end of Act One) and a garden
with four statues representing the four seasons (end of Act Two).

 The Council of Ten, on 29 February 1712, ruled in favor of Nicola Pini (Rosmondo) and other singers,
who had appealed for assistance in collecting overdue pay. The complaint cited contracts made with
the impresario Cristofolo [Cristoforo] Fuggieri [Frigeri?] on 17 June 1711 for the whole of the new

Costantino Music by Francesco Gasparini
[CONSTANTINE]

A dramma per musica (5) Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Pietro Pariati
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1711-11-11

Dedicated to Francis, Prince of Lorraine

The story, derived from Corneille's Maximien, concerns the relations between the imperial general
(later Roman emperor) Licinius and the Eastern emperor Constantine.TM Licinius consolidated his own
position by defeating Maximianus/Massimiano, Constantine's father-in-law, and marrying Constantine's
sister Flavia. Costantino was first performed on 11 November 1711 (M, NV).* Stefano Romani (II
Pignattino) sang in the title role. The role of his wife (Fausta) was taken by a French singer, Marie
de Chateauneuf. Francesco Maria Cignoni, from the Tuscan court, took the part of Maximianus, with
Pietro Casati as Licinius. The text was recycled in Orlandini's Massimiano (see 1731/2).

La forza del sangue Music attributed to Antonio Lotti
[THE POWER OF BLOOD]

A dramma per musica Text by Francesco Silvani
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1711-11-14

Dedicated to Almore Pisani and Isabella Cornara

by his mother, Zoe, to the care of Romanus [archbishop of Ravenna, 878-c. 888] under the assumed
name Heraclius. This plan was designed to foil Zoe's enemy, the general Phocas/Foca, who believed
Heraclius to be his own son. The plot appears to be a sequel to // comando non inteso et ubbidito,

Elisa Music attributed to Giovanni Maria Ruggieri
[ELisa]

A commedia [in musica] Text by Domenico Lalli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1711-11-25

Dedicated to Nicole Berlendi

In the text of this comedy, Elisa had been promised in marriage to Ricciardo, the son of the elderly
Florentine merchant Fabrizio. After the untimely death of her father, she was sold to a merchant in
Constantinople, where she remained for seven years. Upon her escape and return to Florence, she
discovers that Ricciardo has found another love. Disguised as Fabio, she takes a job in his father's shop.
Eventually her full identity is discovered and the marriage finally takes place. Elisa was said by Bonlini
and Groppo to have been the first comic opera given in Venice.' A few earlier works (e.g., Silvani's
Il miglior d'ogni amore per il peggiore d'ogni odio, 1703/8) had significant comic content, although
their libretti did not declare them to be comedies. Here one might cite the intrusion of a Neapolitan
librettist which shifted the emphasis, although in earlier instances the connections were often Florentine.
Lalli's preface to Elisa assumed an Arcadian posture in noting that comedy was an instrument of ancient
Athenian rule. He cited models from Greek and Roman drama as well as many from recent centuries
(by Trissino, Guarini, Ariosto et al.) based on them.

A license to print the libretto was issued on 25 November 1711. Elisa had a total of nine performances,
the final one not later than 28 December. (Ortolani deduces from this that the work was not well
received.)

Despite lofty discussion of literary prototypes, the roles showed pronounced influence from the commedia
dell'arte. A pedant, two servants, and a captain complement those noted above. As in comedy, the
performers were not identified. Two other distinguishing elements of this plot were its modern context
and its clear refutation of the typical progression of events in an opera seria, for here love is fickle rather
than unwavering. Although Sant' Angelo had been discouraged by the Grimani from competing for
the use of comedy troupes (Song and Season, Ch. 8.1), with Vincenzo Grimani dead and with San
Samuele now producing operas, the time for genre experimentation had come.

Merope (Maria Landini*') was the widow of Cresphontes, the late king of Messenia, which was now
threatened by the tyrant Polyphontes (G. B. Carboni). A lengthy introduction to the libretto philosophized
about the nature of tragedy. The plot was inspired by Guarini's // pastor fido.

Europe throughout the century. Later settings for Venice included those by Giacomelli (San Giovanni
Grisostomo, 1734/5), Vivaldi (as L oracolo in Messenia, Sant' Angelo, 1737/10), Jommelli (San Giovanni
Grisostomo, 1741/6), Perez (the same theater, 1750/8), Gassmann (San Moise, 1757), Latilla (San

Publio Cornelio Scipione' Music attributed to Carlo Fr. Pollarolo
[PUBLIUS CORNELIUS SCIPIUS]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Agostino Piovene
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1712-01-09

Dedicated to the Venetian nobility

After defeating Antiochos, the king of Syria, Publius Cornelius Scipio took his enemy's son hostage,
thus providing the historical foundation of this work. Francesco Vitali took the lead role, with Santa
Stella (Anagilda) and Diamante Scarabelli (Erifile).

This must be the other work which, with Merope, opened between 9 and 16 January 1712 (M).TM
Pollarolo's work was produced with a different cast and the intermezzi Dorilla e Brenno in the salon
of the Signori Capranica in Rome during the Carnival of 1713. Handel treated the subject in a like-named
work (HWV 20; 1726). Rolli's model was ostensibly based on Salvi's text (set anonymously in 1704
for the Teatro di San Sebastiano in Leghorn). The libretto for it followed the Venetian exemplar in noting
that Handel had created a work of maximum expression and harmony within the space of three weeks.
Scipione il giovane (1731/12) also had minor debts to this work.

Arsinoe vendicata Music by Giovanni Maria Ruggieri
[ARSINOE VINDICATED]

A dramma per musica Text by Grazio Braccioli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a combattimento SORTING DATE: 1712-02-02

Dedicated to Giovanni Battista Labia

Ptolemy (Nicola Tricarico) deluded his sister Arsinoe (Margherita Gualandi; La Campioli), the widow
of the first king of Macedonia, causing her to kill two of her own sons. Her effort was aided by the
military leader Belgius (Francesco Maria Venturini). Arsinoe opened on 2 February; its final performance
was on the 8th. Its libretto had been dedicated on the 1st.

A dispute between the cast and the impresario, Gio. Battista Zucatto, about overdue pay came to ahead
when Lent began (17 February). On the 11th, an agent of the Council of Ten recorded a week's worth
of receipts which he had personally monitored. He was charged with seeing that the singers did not
confiscate the costumes! Gualandi claimed that her costume was her personal property.** The numbers
of tickets sold for each night were recorded as 147 (February 2nd), 109 (3rd), 115 (4th), 87 (5th), 82

to provide an intermezzo, although none is associated with this work). The orchestra members (sonadori)
were collectively paid  [/ire] 53:18 for each night except the last, when they received only 39:9.
Partial payments to singers began to materialize after a further complaint to the Council of Ten on 30
June 1712.!

1712/5 L'infedelta punita Music attributed to C. F. Pollarolo, Antonio Lotti
[INFIDELITY PUNISHED]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Silvani
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1712-11-15
& Dedicated to Pietro Zanardi'
Oo@ In a contest for the Gothic throne, Luitmere bested Vittigis. Having only one daughter, Gundeberg,

Luitmere was unable to secure the succession for his line. Thus Vittigis's only son, Ricimer, laid claim
to it upon his father's death and imprisoned Gundeberg's fiance, Indimer, the king of Norway. The
work was situated in Uppsala. L 'infedelta was first performed, with reported levels of approval ranging
from satisfaction (NV) to much applause (M), on 15 November 1712. A license to print the libretto
had been issued on 3 October 1712, while the libretto was dedicated on 12 November. The cast included
Margherita Durastante (Gundeberga) and Bartolomeo Bortoli (Ricimero). The ballo of Act Two featured
court buffoons.

1712/6 La gloria trionfante d'amore Music by Giacomo Rampini
[GLORY TRIUMPHANT OVER LOVE]
A dramma per musica Text by Grazio Braccioli
im Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With Salpina e Barillotto; balli SORTING DATE: 1712-11-22
& Dedicated to Aurora Sanseverino
o@ Ostensibly based on the life of Dido and the founding of Carthage as described in Virgil's Aeneid, this

tale by Braccioli featured Juno and Venus and the benevolent genius of Iarbas, who, like Aeneas,
was in love with Dido. The action took place in Carthage, which was, according to legend, built on
land donated by Iarbas. The librettist justified his changes to the story as satisfying the theater's need
for variety. The libretto was dedicated on 16 November. The opening was announced for 22 November
1712 (M).' This production was the first given during Antonio Vivaldi's tenure as impresario at
Sant' Angelo. Vivaldi may have been assisted by his father, Giovanni Battista.'' The cast, of little renown,
included Elena Croce Viviani (Didone), Angelica Rapparini (Giunone), Orsola Astori Sticotti (Venere),
and Giuseppe Ignazio Ferrari (Jarba).

&S An incision in the libretto showing Antonio Mauro's design for the Elysian fields (Act Two) is one
of the earliest surviving testimonies to scenography at Sant' Angelo. A description of this scene in the
libretto relates that on a cart pulled by Immortal Virtue, the Throne of Glory appeared on a golden seat
(carried by a phoenix) with Fate atop a starry globe (carried by an eagle) alongside. The work otherwise

provided by Zanardi are also noted. The same name belonged to a new nobleman (1653-after 1734) who was a merchant living near the
Do Mori. A Mantuan count who may have been related (Antonio Maria Zanardi Landi) was the eventual husband of Vivaldi's prima donna

Arcadian.

Spurio Postumio Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[SPURIUS POSTHUMIUS]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Agostino Piovene
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1712-12-26

Without dedicatee'

In the late second century BC the Roman consul Spurius Posthumius suffered military reversals after
leaving his troops in the care of his brother Aulus. He was eventually convicted by a tribunal, represented
in this work by disembodied Voices of the Tribunes and of the People. The account is derived from
Livy. Spurio Postumio was first performed on 26 December 1712 with universal satisfaction (M).
The title role, although male and without motive for disguise, was taken by Margherita Durastante,
with Diamante Scarabelli as his fiancee Placilla. One ballo was for Roman hostages.

No musical sources known
Listed as Bonlini 471; Groppo 475; Wiel 111; Alm 608, 609

I veri amici' Music attributed to Andrea Paulati'TM
[THE TRUE FRIENDS]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Silvani, rev. Domenico Lalli
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1712-12-26

Dedicated to Marchioness Daria Marsigli'

After murdering the pharoah Apries, Amasis tyrannized the Egyptian people. His effort to have Apries's
infant son, Evergetes, killed failed because the widowed Queen Candace concealed three male infants
 her son (Evergetes), Amasis's son (Lagides), and the son (Auletes) of a deceased friend. The body
of Auletes (believed to be that of Evergetes) was carried to Amasis by the minister Tilames, who was
the true friend of Candace.' The action was set in Memphis (later called Cairo).

I veri amici opened on 26 December 1712 and was received with universal satisfaction (M). Vienna
Mellini took the role of Candace, with Gio. Battista Carboni (Amasi) and Francesco Maria Cignoni
(Tilame). It is likely that all the theaters were closed from | through 17 January, for in addition to the
usual three-day closing at the new year a two-week indulgence (to pray for relief from a cattle plague
throughout the Veneto) was authorized by Patriarch Barbarigo on the 4th (CO).

The work had numerous further productions, including one at the Cocomero (Florence) opening on
27 December 1714. The text was reset by Albinoni for performance in Munich in 1722, and it was his
version which was given in Venice as 1723/2. Lalli revised the text as Candace (Lampugnani, 1740/6)
and it was reset as Evergete (Gibelli, 1748/8).

was added in 1713. Antonio Mauro was married to Vivaldi's sister, Cecilia.

Le passioni per troppo amore Music by Johann David Heinichen'
[A PASSION FOR TOO MUCH LOVE]

A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Lisetta e Asdrobalo'TM SORTING DATE: 1713-01-28
Without dedicatee

This story of uxorial love so great that it became tyrannical was not derived, according to Noris, from
any pre-existing source, although it was held to be partly historical. The loving spouse was Gelinda;
the beloved husband was Helvitius/Elvezio, here styled king of the Indies.

Le passioni was apparently the work first performed on 28 January 1713 (M). Given the haste with
which it was succeeded by Calfurnia, Le passioni cannot have been well received. The surviving score
cannot easily shed light on the details of the work because, like much of the rest of Heinichen's music
preserved in Dresden, the manuscript is badly deteriorated. One early number in Act I (the bellicose
Sonate, amigeri) is sufficiently visible to establish that rich instrumentation was employed. The string
ensemble is here supplemented by two oboes, with trumpets and timpani added in selected passages.
The performance may have included allegorical roles not indicated in the libretto. A stage direction
in the final scene of Act Two cites Constancy and Fidelity, who are absent from the cast list but could
have appeared on a machine. Fetis, who inferred that Calfurnia (1713/3) was given before Le passioni,
reports that the impresario [Vivaldi] wanted to cancel the production after its second performance but
that the public demanded its continuation. Being dissatisfied, Vivaldi withheld the 200 ducats he
had promised Heinichen for the two works (1713/1, 1713/3). The composer went to Rome while litigation
was pursued in Venice, but he later returned to collect the money due him.'

Score in D-Dlb (aut.)
Listed as Bonlini 473; Groppo 477; Wiel 123; Alm 611

Porsena' Music attributed to Antonio Lotti
[PORSENNA]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Agostino Piovene
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1713-02-04
Without dedicatee

Porsenna, a legendary Tuscan king who ruled at the dawn of the Roman Republic, was camping on
the Janiculum in preparation for combat against the Roman consul Valerius as this work opened. In
the fictionalized overlay, his fiancee, the Alban princess Camilla, was imprisoned by the Romans as
she was being conducted to her wedding. Porsena was first performed on 4 February 1713 (M)." It
was greeted with universal applause (M). The production included Giovanni Paita (Porsena), Gaetano
Mossi (Valerio), and Giovanna Albertini (La Reggiana) as Camilla. According to the libretto, lighted
coals were seen in the temple of Apollo depicted in the third act.
