1713/3 Calfurnia Music by Johann David Heinichen
[CALPHURNIAS]
A dramma per musica Text by Grazio Braccioli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Lisetta e Batto SORTING DATE: 1713-02-07~
sy Dedicated to Count Pietro Zanardi
ov Calphurnias, the daughter of the consul Marius and his wife Julia, was engaged to Trebonius, who in

turn was the object of the affections of Alvida, the daughter of Jugurtha." The action took place both
within the city and outside the walls of Rome. In contrast to libretti ofan earlier era, Braccioli promised
not to bore the reader with an account of the many adventures in his plot but appealed instead, in an
opening paragraph in Latin, to the authority of Plutarch's account of Calphurnias. Heinichen's work
was produced in Hamburg in 1716 as Calpurnia, oder Die remische Grossmut. Braccioli's libretto was
revised by Nicholas Haym for Giovanni Bononcini's setting (London: King's Theatre, 1724).

@ Calfurnia, the libretto for which was dedicated on 26 January 1713, was first performed between 4
and 11 February 1713 (M). The opening probably took place before the 7th, when the impresari Gabriel
Faglia and Giovanni [Zuane] Orsato gave depositions concerning their inability to start the opening
performance until 3.30 [O.V.], owing to the fact that the instrumentalists did not appear until 3.''? The
year, reported by Wiel as 1714, is further confirmed as 1713 in the records of the Council of Ten,'
which, on 22 February (the last day of Carnival), ordered Heinichen to turn over the originale of the
work to its representative according to a prior agreement.'"4

@ Elena Croce Viviani took the role of Calphurnias. In the opening scene the Roman phalanges advanced
to the sound of trumpets and drums (famburi). Members of the orchestra seeking payment for their
performance in Calfurnia in 1713 were Giovanni Canciani, Giovanni Meneghin [violin], Antonio
Gabbiato [violin], Gio. Battista Moschini, Nadolin Bonamizi [Buonamici; cello], Iseppo who played
second keyboard, Ignazio [Siber] who played oboe, and Francesco Mazzoni.''S The musical skills of
enough members of this group are known to suggest the overall composition of three violins, viola,
cello, and violone with keyboard and obbligato oboe.'!

314 A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

a Dedicated to Domenico Grillo, Nob. Gen.
By his two marriages the Bithynian king Prusias had two sons  Nicomedes, who became an archenemy
of the Romans, and Atalos, who became an ally. Before his death Prusias arranged for the eventual
marriage of Atalos, his designated successor, with the Armenian princess Laodikeia. Atalos later fell
in love with the Assyrian princess Arsinoe, who was imprisoned by Laodikeia's father as she traveled
to her own wedding. In the battle that followed Nicomedes recovered the throne, thus restoring the
true line of succession.'"

OO The dedicatee had arrived in Venice by 21 January 1713 (NV). A license to print the libretto was issued
on 5 February 1712. Its dedication was dated 7 February 1713. Nicola Grimaldi took the role of Atalos,
with Maria Eleonora de Scio (La Todeschina) as Laodiceia, Vienna Mellini as Arsinoe, and Stefano
Romani (II Pignattino) as Nicomedes. Roberto Clerici, a pupil of Francesco Bibiena, designed and
painted the scenery. This was Gasparini's last opera for Venice before moving to Rome.

1713/5 Orlando furioso Music by Giovanni Alberto Ristori'*
[ROLAND IN A RAGE]
A dramma per musica Text by Grazio Braccioli
M1 Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With a danza SORTING DATE: 1713-11-09
a Dedicated to Scipione dal Sale'

Courtly life in the time of Charlemagne (eighth century) had been absent from the Venetian stage since
Carlo il Grande (1688/7). Braccioli's account contrasted two kinds of madness  Roland's crazed
love for Angelica and Ruggiero's spell-induced infatuation with the sorceress Alcina.' Orlando furioso
was rife with scenes related to the general theme of enchantment, which may have been stimulated
by the enthusiastic reception of Circe delusa (1711/5). Braccioli said in the libretto that he had tried
to steer an even course between delighting the ear with the story and the eye with visual interest. He
emphasized his fidelity to the Aristotelian unities of place and time, said that he was trying to restore
the importance of the actress in the title role, and wished to emphasize the transforming power of
passion and sentiment.

OOe Orlando furioso was first performed on 9 November 1713 (M); the libretto had been dedicated on the
7th.'?! Braccioli later claimed, in the libretto of Rodomonte sdegnato, that there had been more than
40 performances of Orlando furioso, and indeed the work was still in production on 13 January 1714
(NV). It is not clear who Braccioli's ideal actress was. The role of Angelica was sung by Anna Maria
Giusti (La Romanina), with the little-known Elisabetta Denzio as Bradamante, and Margherita Faccioli

"7 Silvani relates in a note to the reader that this work had been written eight years earlier for the same theater but then had been modified
to restrict the number of scene changes and adapt it to the activities of the virtuosi. Thus much had been added and much else cut. He credits
as earlier models of the verisimilitude he sought, particularly for Arsinoe's remorse, an old drama called Amore veleno e medicina
dell intelletto, a heroic work called Un pazzo guarisce I altro, and Seneca' s Ercole furiente. See also Laodicea in Egitto (Suppl. 3a, 1715).

"8 Ristori (c. 1692-1753) was the son of an actor (Tomaso) whose troupe spent many years at the court in Dresden. G. A. Ristori moved in

" Dal Sale (also del Sale) was a Neapolitan count and may have been a patron of Domenico Scarlatti.

as Alcina. Anton Francesco Carli sang in the title role. Orlando could well have helped to shape Vivaldi's
two treatments of the same subject (Orlando finto pazzo, 1714/4, and Orlando furioso, 1727/10).

 On 18 November the Vivaldis were cited by Giovanni Gallo, the impresario of the Teatro di Verona,
who said they had blockaded his season by signing up the singer Gio. Battista Minelli' for the role
of Ruggiero in the Orlando production. This culminated a week of sparring between notaries in Venice
and Verona, where Minelli had been engaged in August to perform with Gallo as impresario. Gallo
attempted to file suit on the 8th via Antonio Costanzi in Verona, then filed another claim on the 10th
in Venice. The Vivaldis responded on the 11th.' Minelli remained in the Venetian cast.

1713/6 Irene augusta Music by Antonio Lotti
[IRENE THE AUGUST]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Silvani
MM Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1713-11-22
rai Without dedicatee
eX) The Byzantine emperor Leo [457-474], in concluding a war with the Bulgarians, arranged for the

Bulgarian princess Eudoxa to marry his only son, Constantine. After Leo's death, the Greek prince
Nikephoros, as a regent to the young imperial prince, attempted to wrest control of the regime. He
persuaded him to renounce his vow to Eudoxa, much to the consternation of his widowed mother, Irene.
Irene was first performed, with applause, on 22 November 1713 (M, NV). Santa Stella sang in the
title role, with Giuseppe Maria Boschi as Nicephoros and Francesco Bernardi (II Senesino) as
Constantine. As the work opens, Constantine is being entertained in the royal apartment of Theodate,
in whom Nikephoros has encouraged him to take an amorous interest. Instrumentalists and singers perform
on two conch shells.

1714/1 Semiramide' Music by Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[SEMIRAMIS]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Silvani
im Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1714-01-06

Semiramis, the wife of Memnon and the queen of Babylonia in the ninth century BC, became a heroine
when she captured and imprisoned Zoroaster, the king of Bactria.'* Ninus, the king of the Assyrians,
paid her great respect but the ultimate consequences were tragic.

Semiramide is said to have opened on 6 January 1714 (M),' although since the 6th was the feast of
Epiphany, the Sth or 7th is more probable. Few foreigners attended because the transalpine passes were
blocked. A license to print the libretto had been issued on 30 December 1714 [sic]. The title-page was
dated 1713. Santa Stella appeared in the title role, with Francesco Bernardi (II Senesino) as Ninus/Nino
and Giovanni Paita as Zoroaster. On the 13th the work was said to be attracting a larger audience than
the work [Orlando furioso] at Sant' Angelo.'? A scene showing the temple of the Sun (a staple
representation of Zoroastrianism) occurred in Act Two. Silvani's text provided what came to be an
inordinately popular subject in the eighteenth century and beyond. It had been preceded by Moniglia's
very different account for P. A. Ziani (1670/4).

La Merope. Cf. Suppl. 3a.

Rodomonte sdegnatoTM Music by Michel Angelo Gasparini
[RODOMONTE DISDAINED]

A dramma per musica Text by Grazio Braccioli
Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1714-01-20

Dedicated to Giuseppe Maria Gonzaga'

Turning again to Ariosto for his model, Braccioli's subject is a group of murderous women who band
together. Rhadamanthys/Rodomonte, the king of Sparta, married Aleria, the queen of this group. As
in Orlando furioso (1713/5), magic was an important ingredient of the work. The action took place
in Alexandria, where a siege was in progress as the work opened. Unlike many of his predecessors,
Braccioli seemed to take pride in writing a text expressly for a dramma per musica rather than a tragedy
per se, although he advertised his adherence to Aristotelian precepts. He noted the ability of the dramma
per musica to reinvigorate good taste and commented on how much greater he found the pleasure
of actually hearing and seeing his works performed than he had in reading their texts.

The libretto was dedicated by the impresario (Vivaldi) on 20 January 1714, which was the date on which
the work opened (CO, M, NV). A license to print the libretto was issued on 15 January 1713 (M.V.).
The writer of NV hoped the work would enjoy applause because of the special nature of the music
but admitted that bad weather was driving foreigners out of Venice and that San Giovanni Grisostomo
was attracting most of the crowds with Semiramide. Anton Francesco Carli sang in the title role.

With balli and cori SORTING DATE: 1714-01-27
Dedicated to the Ladies and Gentlemen of Venice!

Part of ancient Arcadia was consecrated to the goddess Persephone/Proserpina, but the shepherds of
this work, being unaware of this history, dedicated it to the goddess Pallas. This infuriated the Infernal
Goddess, but after being touched by the branch ofa magic olive tree, her vengeful wishes were rendered
mute, and Pallas prevailed. A license to print this short libretto was issued on 27 January 1713 [M.V.]
for Carn. 1714.'3 The work had been given the preceding summer in Padua at the Teatro Obizzi,
with the Vicentine singer Laura Soranzo in the roles of both Pallas and Persephone.'TM*

 Although it is not possible to say with certainty what the relationship of Pallade trionfante in Arcadia
was to the pastoral called // trionfo di Pallade in Arcadia,'* it seems likely that II trionfo (San Samuele,
autumn 1713; cf. Suppl. 3a) was not fully set to music.'* The winter work had as actors two shepherds
(Nicandro and Aminta), three shepherdesses (Lisa, Leucia, and Dorina), the two goddesses, and three
choruses (of nymphs, of shepherds, and of Furies). Tomaso Ristori, the composer's father and the leader
ofacomedy troupe resident chiefly in Dresden, wrote the dedication of both works; Gio. Alberto Ristori
is cited as a composer only in the libretto for the winter production.

[ROLAND PRETENDING TO BE MAD]

The enchantress Ersilla'* had imprisoned numerous cavallieri in her castle. Roland's magic sword
made him invulnerable to her powers. She created havoc by tricking his friend Brandimarte into believing
he was Roland.'* Roland went mad, entered the temple of Hecate, killed his guard, and stole the statue
of Merlin which had been the source of Alcina's power. The spell of Alcina was broken by Brandimarte
when he slipped on a magic ring. Margherita Gualandi sang in the role of Ersilla, with Elisabetta Denzio
as Tigrinda. As in 1713/5, Anton Francesco Carli took the title role.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

The libretto was dedicated on 10 November 1714'* and the work is likely to have opened soon afterward.
Braccioli's text had been the basis for Ristori's setting (Orlando furioso; 1713/5). Despite its portrayal
of pastoral features, this version of Orlando gives equal emphasis to the lugubrious. A chorus of priests
of Hecate and ministers from the temple of Pluto appear in the opening scene. Nymphs and fauns are
featured in the stage action of later portions of the work. The third act is rich in images, with crystal
sets in Ersilla's magic grotto, which is ringed by instrumentalists.

Orlando furioso Music attributed to Gio. Alberto Ristori,
[ROLAND IN A RAGE] rev. Antonio Vivaldi!
A dramma per musica Text by Grazio Braccioli
Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a danza SORTING DATE: 1714-12-26~

Dedicated to Angelo and Annibale Marsigli Rossi!

This revision of 1713/5 probably opened after Christmas. The libretto was dedicated on 1 December
1714." As described in the libretto, the staging was now to be lighter, brighter, more sumptuous, and
perhaps more subtle in its interpretation than in Ristori's original. The work opened in Alcina's enchanted
palace, where two fountains had the power to ignite or extinguish love. The second act, which culminated
in the wedding of Angelica and Medoro, emphasized woods, mountains, flowers, and breezes. The
temple of Hecate, which revealed a statue of the famous magician Merlin and an urn containing his
ashes, was featured in the third act.

This must be the work which J. F. A. von Uffenbach, a nobleman from Frankfurt who arrived in Venice
on 2 February 1715, reported on the 4th to have seen at Sant' Angelo.'* He declared the performance
of [Anna Maria] Fabbri (Alcina) to have been incomparable." As in 1713/5, Carli and Denzio took
the roles of Orlando and Bradamante. Margherita Gualandi succeeded Anna Maria Giusti as Angelica,
and three other substitutions were made to the cast.'* His greatest praise was for the incidental violin
music of Vivaldi. Uffenbach related that towards the end Vivaldi played a splendid solo which absolutely
amazed me, because there has never been (nor could one image there ever being) such a manner of
playing: he made his fingers jump to within a hair's breadth of the bridge, leaving virtually no space
for the bow, on all four strings with imitations [between them], at incredible speed."*

Score (Acts 1, 2) in I-Tn; aria in D-Dlb

Listed as Bonlini 484; Groppo 488; Wiel 125; Alm 626; RV Anh. 84

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1710-19) 319

Marsia deluso Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[MARSYAS DELUDED]

A favola pastorale (5) Text attributed to Agostino Piovene
Performed at SS. Giovanni e Paolo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1714-12-26~
Without dedicatee

In this pastoral fable, Piovene combined two myths  that of Daphne, a nymph from Thessaly, and
Marsyas, a Phrygian satyr. Disguised as a shepherd, Apollo, who is in love with Daphne, kills a serpent
to save her from harm. Gio. Battista Cavana took the role of Marsyas, with Anna Ambrevil (in her debut)
as Daphne and Pietro Casati as Apollo. Three other singers  Agata Landi, Gio. Battista Minelli, and
Pietro Ramponi  had made their debuts in Ristori's Orlando furioso (1713/5).

Bonlini and Groppo' point out that SS. Giovanni e Paolo was reopened in the winter of 1714-15 in
substitution for San Giovanni Grisostomo, which was closed in mourning for Gio. Carlo Grimani.'?
Marsia appears to have preceded the only other work (Polidoro) given during the brief reopening of
the theater. The title-page refers to the carnovale dell'Anno 1714, which in isolation could refer to
the preceding year. Taking 1715, when San Giovanni Grisostomo did not open until after Christmas
(see 1715/8) as model, a likely date of opening for Marsia would have been just after Christmas 1714.'*!
Owing to long periods of quarantine, 1714-15 was a lackluster season, with sparse attendance at Carnival,
in any event.

The use of music by Pollarolo suggests a hasty arrangement made by Grimani's heirs to employ the
well-regarded house composer of San Giovanni Grisostomo. Francesco Bernardi (II Senesino), who
appeared in the title role, and Giuseppe Boschi (Darete) had both performed in Semiramide, a popular
work which played at San Giovanni Grisostomo through the heart of Carnival in 1714. Marsyas was
credited with the invention of the double flute, but there is no evidence here of the use of a flute.
Arias in D-Dlb (prima)

Listed as Bonlini 485; Groppo 489; Wiel 130; Alm 627

GI' amici rivali' Music attributed to Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[THE FRIENDS WHO WERE RIVALS]

A favola pastorale Text attributed to Giovanni Battista Neri
Performed at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With danze SORTING DATE: 1714-12-29~

Dedicated to Faustino Avogardo!*

The libretto for Gl amici, which was a thinly disguised remake of L enigma disciolto (1705/2),' was
dedicated by the impresario Giovanni Orsato in December 1714. It appears to have preceded L amante
impazzito (1715/3). The production was probably chaotic. Of the five singers in the cast, three cannot
be associated with any other work given in Venice. A fourth, Anna Maria Armida (La Mantovana),
who took the role of Eurilla, is otherwise known only from notarial records. On 7 February 1715 she
was accused by Orsato of having failed to appear on time, of having thrown temper tantrums (gravi
capricci) both at rehearsals and at performances, and of not having been adequately prepared for the
opening.'**

Lucio Papirio Music by Luca Antonio Predieri'
[Lucius PaPIRIUS]

A dramma per musica Text by Antonio Salvi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1715-01-12~

Dedicated to Karl Josef Novohradski, Count of Kollororath'

The dictator Lucius Papirius was opposed by the cavalry general Quintus Fabius, who defeated him
in battle. Lucius threatened violent forms of retaliation, but Quintus Fabius was saved by his father
Marcus. Anton Francesco Carli sang in the title role, with Andrea Pacini (Quinto Fabio), and Florido
Matteucci (Marco Fabio). Elisabetta Denzio sang as the tribune (Appio).

The winter of 1714-15 coincides not only with a low ebb in theatrical activity in Venice (owing to the
recent death of Gio. Carlo Grimani) but also with a hiatus in news sources. Only circumstantial evidence
of dating is available. The impresario for this production was Antonio Vivaldi, who wrote an undated
dedication. An anonymous note to the reader says that for two years I have served your pleasure in
the theater. This represents three years of service, if one counts from the formalized contract made
in the summer of 1712.'' Elisabetta Denzio first worked at Sant' Angelo in 1713-14. Andrea Pacini
sang at Sant' Angelo only in 1714-15; he went to San Giovanni Grisostomo in 1715-16.

The text of Lucio, which was known from performances in Florence and Rome 1714, survived in various
guises until the end of the eighteenth century. Roughly half of its numerous productions were in Florence
or neighboring locales.

Arias (Florence, 1714) in GB-Lbl

In Euripides' account, Priam asked his youngest son, Polydoros, to carry gold to the kingdom of Thrace

gold. Here the librettist has modified the story to include Andromache's flight from Pyrrhos, the son

'SS The Bolognese composer L. A. Predieri (1688-1767) was evidently adaptable. He was known as a violinist and violist early in his career.
He was elected to the Accademia Filarmonica in 1716 and was to serve as its prince in 1723. He was well regarded in church and theater circles
in Bologna. From 1737 to 1751 he served the imperial court at Vienna, first as vice Kapellmeister and, from 1741, as full Kapellmeister. A
number of his operas involved texts from Spanish history. The presence of a Slavic patron here lends credibility to rumors that Predieri went
to Russia, which could be a generic term for Eastern Europe.

ad

This pastoral work, which was based on quasi-historical themes, concerns the heroic love of Alkiades,

the brother of Admetos, the king of Thessaly, for Clodomira.' It had been given under the titles

L'Alciade (Bergamo, 1709) and La violenza d'amore (Dolo, 1711). According to Groppo, booksellers

had cut the frontispieces from the libretti of those works in order to recycle the texts.'

OL The absence of other productions at San Fantin allows that L'amante impazzito could have had
performances in the autumn of 1714, but circumstantial evidence suggests that it followed the production
of Glamici rivali (1714/7). In fact, it could have opened near 4 February, when Carnival was officially
opened, but in that case it would have run for only a few days. In a stragiudiziale filed on 7 February
1714 M.V. the impresario Giovanni Orsato complained that the singer Anna Maria Armida (La
Mantovanina), who was obligated to participate in numerous rehearsals and performances, had fled
the city, depriving him, as impresario, of the expected return on his investment in her and in the
production.' The only other Venetian production in which Armida is known to have sung was that
of Gl'amici rivali (1714/7), which therefore must have preceded this work.

 This pastiche was based on Noris's text as set by Perti (1692/8). A note to the reader says, hyperbolically,

that the work has been modernized to accommodate the current taste for one of the happiest of dramatic
ideas. A license to print the libretto was issued on 12 February 1714 (M.V.).' The work may not
have opened until the 19th. It was given in Brescia the following year. Uffenbach heard this work
(Agrippina) performed on the 19th, the 26th, and 4 March. He related that Vivaldi (the composer
of twelve of the arias) played long violin solos on the third occasion, which would have been on the
evening preceding Shrove Tuesday. On the second occasion he played only one aria.'' Margherita
Gualandi sang as Agrippina with Anna Maria Fabbri (Nerone) and Anton Francesco Carli (Seneca).
Uffenbach found the costumes a significant distraction. He said that Fabbri was in French garb, with
the others variously in Spanish and Persian dress. It was the first work in which Fabbri was cast in a
male role. By the 1730s the practice was prevalent at Sant' Angelo.'

 According to the author of this fanciful plot, Alexander the Great wished to be taken for a son of Jupiter.

The librettist apologized for the anachronisms that flowed from creating a unity of action. In his account
Talestri, the queen of the Amazons,'* was in love with the great military conqueror. Alessandro opened
on 27 October 1715 with not a little applause.! A license to print the libretto had been issued on

November, quarantine prevented it until early January 1716 (NV).'*

The historical Phocas murdered Maurice in 602 to gain control of the Eastern Roman Empire. He ruled
until 610. Perhaps to suit a German dedicatee, this account was tangled with anachronistic tales of Otto
the Great, his son Otto, and Otto's beloved Honoria. The action took place in Calabria. A license to
print the libretto was issued on 13 December 1715. The dedication date of the libretto, 26 December
1715, was the date of the first performance (A, NV). The title-page was dated 1716. The work was
performed with specially chosen singers and enjoyed full applause.'' Stefano Romano (Otto) sang
with Vienna Mellini (Onoria). Two of the remaining singers  Annibale and Anna Maria Fabbri 
were in the employ of the dedicatee.

The last male heir of the Brescian Martinengo family died in 1682. This led to numerous disputes about heredity which peaked in 1746, when
the dedicatee of this work died. Although originally from Bergamo, the Colleone owned a palazzo near Santa Maria della Pace in Brescia.
Inc. 1670 it became the Oratory of San Filippo Neri and passed to the administration of Santa Maria della Pace, a church with which Vivaldi
had contacts. Some members of the Venetian Colleone family lived on the island of Murano. According to Groppo (MS, p. 178), one version
of the libretto had no dedicatee.

M.V.'TM The libretto itself was dedicated on 18 January 1715 M.V. The singular virtue of Vivaldi,
maestro de' concerti at the Ospedale della Pieta, was praised in a note to the reader. Antonio Denzio
sang as Artabanos with Filippo Piccoli as Tigranes.

 Daily attendance figures through the 25th were reported on the 27th. Ticket sales per day had totaled
305, 287, 285, 269, 310, 200, and 80. While the proceeds of rentals of scagni are given, numbers are
not. They increased the proceeds by nearly 50 per cent on the first two nights but fell off thereafter.
The total taken in from seven performances was 2841 grossi,10 lire, against expenses of 745 lire (roughly
150 ducats a night). The net proceeds were 2096 grossi,10 lire.'*> Vio computed the average cost of
aticket (across four price categories) as having been 5 lire, 25 soldi.' The highest sales were on Tuesday
the 20th, the lowest on Sunday the 25th. It was mandated at the start of the run that singers and
instrumentalists had to be paid before income could be directed in any other way.' On the 29th Denzio
renounced the practice of allowing singers and instrumentalists to rent boxes on credit.'** In May 1716
Carl' Antonio Mazza (Olderico) filed suit against the impresari Pietro Denzio and Giovanni Orsato
for lack of reimbursement for the theater-box he had sublet to King George I of England.'

- Obviously a popular work at its inception, La costanza was reworked many times, starting with its revival
at San Moise as Artabano, re de' Parti (RV 701; 1719/2). The exiled English court at Urbino went
en masse to Fano to see the work staged in February 1718. James III wrote to the duke of Lorraine in
March 1718 that the opera at Fano was much better than the one at Paris.? It was given as Artabano
(Mantua, 1725) and as a pastiche called Doriclea (RV 708; Prague, 1732). Some arias from La costanza
were also used by Antonio Denzio in a pastiche called La tirannia gastigata (RV Anh. 55; Prague,
1726), which was in the main based on Silvani's libretto for La fortezza in cimento. It was produced
at San Moise as L 'odio vinto dalla costanza (1731/5).

26 Porta (c. 1675-1755) is believed to have been Venetian by birth and to have trained with Francesco Gasparini. After Gasparini's departure

The text concerned Barsina (Elisabetta Denzio), the daughter of Artabanos, and her stature as the

second wife of Alexander the Great, whose original union was with Stateira (Anna Maria Giusti, La

Romanina). The action took place in Babylonia. The text had earlier been set under the title Amori

ministri della fortuna for a production in Milan in 1694. It was revived in Prague in 1728. Later progeny

included Galeazzi's II trionfo della costanza (1731/1) and Paganelli's Barsina (1742/7).

OR La costanza was first performed on 17 October 1716, the date of dedication of the libretto. (An earlier

production continued through 26 November, when it was abruptly halted owing to the sudden death
of the 21-year-old Denzio.

1716/7 Arsilda, regina di Ponto Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[ARSILDA, THE QUEEN OF PONTOS]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Domenico Lalli
Tr Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With Grilletta e Fanfarone SORTING DATE: 1716-10-27
w Dedicated to Giacomo Brivio"

The royal twins Tamese and Lisea lost their father before Tamese was old enough for his voice to
have changed. As they grew into adulthood, each was courted by suitors from other nations. After
Tamese was falsely believed to be dead, Lisea, disguising herself as her brother, courted Arsilda, the
queen of Pontos. Lalli emphasized his conformance to the Aristotelian unities of place, time, and action
by devoting an entire page of the libretto to describing them as such. The place was Sicily, the time
was the annual day on which government figures took public oaths, and the actions (somewhat in contrast
to Aristotelian precepts) consisted of the intrigues to which false identities and infidelities lent themselves.

ice) Arsilda was first performed on 27 (A, NV) or 28 October 1716 (PV). It was still running on 21 November
(A). A license to print the libretto had been issued on 18 October 1716. Arsilda was revived in January
1717 after the failure of Penelope (1716/9).

&o Dedicated to Karl Philipp of Neuburg, Imperial Elector?!
i) In this text, ostensibly derived from Ariosto's Orlando furioso, the foreign knight Ariodante fell in

love with the Scottish princess Guinevere/Ginevra, but he was opposed by the scheming Polynexos,
duke of Albania.'* Guinevere was betrayed by her lady-in-waiting, Dalinda, who hoped to win Polynexos
for herself. The story was set in Edinburgh. Ariodante was first performed, with maximum applause,
on 14 November 1716 (A). A license to print the Venetian libretto had been issued on 5 November
1716. Venetian theaters were closed from 29 November for Advent in 1716. Ariodante reopened after
Christmas (CO), when it may have been attended by ten English lords and other foreign dignitaries.

Oe Faustina Bordoni made her operatic debut as Guinevere in this production."! Her appearance may have
been prompted by her recent success in the serenata Fede, Valore, Gloria, e Fama (Suppl. 5a). Bordoni
came to be known for her accuracy of pitch, unlabored facility at ornamentation, impressive musical
memory, plasticity of expression, fluidity of movement, and for her particular skill in conveying pathos.
It was noted in the libretto that the music was by the celebrated master Carlo Francesco Pollarolo.
Romoaldo Mauro is likely to have been the scenographer for this work, for he was given a box at San
Giovanni Grisostomo almost contemporaneously with the production.??

but, as he noted in this libretto, the work had now been truncated and altered in numerous ways, and
the number of characters had been changed. These days in Italy, he said, anyone [can] change
anything, including the title ofa work, at will. Such changes did not dampen the enthusiasm of audiences.
The total work was revived as 1718/7. The text was also recycled by Sellitti (1733/5, as Ginevra) and

1716/9 Penelope la casta" Music by Fortunato Chelleri
[PENELOPE THE CHASTE]
A dramma per musica Text by Matteo Noris
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1716-12-28
& Dedicated to Domenico Grillo, Nob. Gen.

This resetting of a text given with Pallavicino's music at San Giovanni Grisostomo (1685/4) to rave
reviews could not have met a more unlikely reception than that at Sant' Angelo in 1716. The revival
may have been intended to appeal to the many Saxons who spent the 1716-17 Carnival period in Venice,
but in contrast to the legendary performance of Margarita Salicola, recruited on its basis to the Saxon
court, that of Anna [Vicenza] Dotti (La Bombace) engendered prompt hostility.

8@ This second opera had opened by 28 December 1716 and was probably terminated on the 30th. A
license to print the libretto had been issued on the 7th. The work's poor reception was the subject of
asatirical poem. According toa report of 8 January 1716 M.V., the composer had been stabbed during
the preceding week as he was handing the Bombace to her boat. The report's author, Alexander
Cunningham, speculated that it was some of the [y*] Opera men in St. Angelo [who committed the
crime], because his Opera did not take, and was damned the 2d and 3d night.

 The performers were not paid in a timely manner, despite the requirement that deposits be made before
the production opened. Three singers  Angelo Zanoni (Ulisse), Lugrezio Borzari (Gildo), and Anna
Fabris (Ariene)  were ordered by an official of the Council of Ten on the 31st to continue in the
production, but it is not evident that there were further performances. A miscalculation in the number
of tickets issued for that performance is mentioned in a stragiudiziale brought against the composer.
Ramponi was ordered to return the originali to Chelleri on 5 January (1717), indicating that the production
had already ceased. A revival of Arsilda (1716/7) was in progress by 16 January (CO).

M1 Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1717-01-04~
a Dedicated to Honophrius Peyer?

This text, which had been set by C. F. Pollarolo as La forza della virti (1692/7), concerns Spanish,
Austrian, and French interrelations in the early medieval period. The work has been abridged and some
of the characters have been renamed; no cast list is given.

O@E A license to print the libretto was issued on 28 December 1716.2*? The production, which should have
opened almost immediately, was reported to be in progress on the 16 (CO) and on 28 January 1716.
Records of the Council of Ten gives some sense of the (dis)organization of San Moise. As the maestro
di musica and leader of the orchestra, Giovanni Porta was supposed to provide performing materials
(originali) every evening. As impresario, Giovanni (Zuane) Orsato was supposed to provide nightly
pay for the orchestra and lighting in the theater.** Nicola Tricarico, then officially employed in Mantua,
was ordered by the Council on 28 January to be prepared to sing every night at San Moise, as he was
contracted to do, and to learn the music for the work or appear before the tribunal the following morning
to explain why he could not.* Pietro Balbi was responsible for the box- and folding-chair rentals in
the theater.> Overall, the monies earned from the rental of boxes and chairs, the sale of tickets, and
other miscellaneous charges were to be put into an escrow account administered by a representative
elected by the musicians for the good of the creditors (scenery designers, tailors, et al.). The creditors
were to be recompensed only after the singers and instrumentalists had been paid.

1717/2 Alessandro Severo' Music by Antonio Lotti
[ALEXANDER SEVERUS]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Apostolo Zeno
ry Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1717-01-17
i) Dedicated to Charles Mordaunt, Earl of Peterborough'?

Alexander Severus became emperor of Rome [222-235] at the age of thirteen. He was the second of
two Syrians to ascend to this position (the first was his cousin, Elagabalus). His mother initially served
as his regent. His marriage to the patrician Sallustia was arranged a few years later. His genuine love
for his wife led to her appointment as empress, a title which alienated his mother.

parts of Swabia.

2 Lord Peterborough (1658-1735), noted for his short stature and frenetic activity, spent the carnivals of 1712, 1715, 1716, and 1717 in Venice.

in Bologna under false charges of seeking to assassinate the exiled James III, who was in Urbino (Corp, Origin, p. 19). In 1722 he took as
his second wife the singer Anastasia (Mrs.) Robinson (1695-1755).

1717/3 L'incoronazione di Dario' Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[THE CORONATION OF Darius]
A dramma per musica Text by Adriano Morselli
im Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1717-01-23
& Dedicated to Antonio Ferdinando Gonzaga
-

Morselli's text on the great Persian king had been set as 1684/1 by Freschi. It was noted in the 1717
libretto that the arias and the characters were altered to suit the modern use of the theater. This account
highlights Darius's ascension, after defeating two other claimants, and his union with Stateira, the
daughter of his predecessor Cyrus. Apart from some differences in the order of entries, however, the
changes are more those of emphasis than of substance. Roles for Apollo and a peasant have been
eliminated and an oracle has been introduced.

 @E This third opera was first performed on 23 January 1717 (A, PV); the title-page is dated 1716. A
license to print the libretto was issued on 15 January 1716 for 1716 [M.V.]. Although the work opened
amidst lingering financial difficulties which had begun with Penelope la casa, Pallade veneta praised
its magnificence. Annibale Pio Fabbri sang in the title role, with Anna Dotti (Statira), Carlo Cristini
(Oronte), and Antonia Pellizzari (Arpago). Vivaldi was identified as a celebrated composer. The
scenery was by Bernardo Canal and his sons. Lodovico Madonis, who was head of the second violins
in the orchestra, was also a financier of the work. He complained to the Council of Ten about the
receipts for the third night.

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1710-19) 333

Chi la fa Vaspetta Music attributed to Girolamo Polani
[HE WHO DOES IT EXPECT IT]

A dramma-comico in musica Text attributed to Francesco Passarini
Performed at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1717-01-25~
Without dedicatee

The basic five-character scheme generally used at San Fantin was in force here, with a Venetian artisan
and his daughter Eurilla, who was being pursued by both Mingone and the gondolier Nico. The final
scene was to resemble a Venetian neighborhood. This is the first known instance (outside intermezzi)
in which Venice itself was portrayed on the Venetian stage.

A license to print the libretto was issued on 25 January 1717. The work can have run only for a short
time, since L ambizione castigata (1707/5) opened on 6 February. The year is likely to be new-style
because two different productions are confirmed for the winter of 1718. Since the theater had been
inactive over the preceding two years, a work with roots in commedia dell'arte could have provided
a transitional path to new productions.

Anticipating Goldoni (who used the same title for a work of his), Eurilla, her father, and the gondolier
all sing their lines in Venetian dialect. In the earlier Neapolitan commedia called Chi la fa, l'aspetti,"
the heroine was Isabella, the pursuers Camillo and Filino. Among the eleven roles in Goldoni's later
work of the same title, there were two for merchants  one with a young daughter and the other with
a young son. The story was long known in Neapolitan commedia.**!

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 507; Groppo 511; Wiel 158; Alm 653

L'ambizione castigataTM Music anonymous
[AMBITION PUNISHED]

A comi-drama in musica Text attributed to Francesco Mazzari
Performed at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1717-02-06
Without dedicatee

The roles in this short work anticipated those of many intermezzi and early comic operas. They include
a widow who is in love with a mock prince, a chambermaid, a gondolier (barcariolo), and a general.
The work opens with the widow admiring her hair in a mirror. L ambizione was first performed on 6
February 1717, when it enjoyed slight applause (PV). Its run would have been short, for Lent began
on the 17th. Licenses to print the libretto had been issued on | and 3 January 1717, in the latter case
for 1716.

oo]) Lothar, a ninth-century king of Astrasia, wished to renounce his wife, Teutberg, in order to marry his
secret love, Waldred. Other amorous liaisons and political ambitions complicated the plot. All of the
actions occurred on the wedding anniversary of the royal couple. Tieteberga was first performed on

conspicuous, and we are told that they received grand applause.*** The composer was styled the
ever-celebrated don Antonio Vivaldi.

1717/11 Arsace' Music by Michel Angelo Gasparini
[ARSAKES]
A dramma per musica Text by Antonio Salvi
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a ballo, a giuoco, and a trattenimento giocoso *" SORTING DATE: 1717-12-26~
wz Dedicated to Charles Douglas, Duke of Queensbury and Dover*

The hero of this work was only nominally related to the ancient Arsakids of Parthia, for the story was
a thinly veiled account of the Count (Ear!) of Essex, a lover of Elizabeth I who betrayed the queen for
one of her ladies-in-waiting and was eventually beheaded. The story had been transmitted over the past
century both in French drama and in Spanish and Neapolitan improvised comedies.?

ic) A license to print the libretto was issued on 12 December 1717, suggesting performance immediately
after Christmas; the title-page was dated 1718. The opening was anticipated in a letter of 24 December
1717 by Alexander Cunningham, who noted that the text was based on ye [the] Tragedie of ye Earle
of Essex under ye name of Arsace. Corneille's drama was credited in the libretto, while pleasing the
Ttalian theater was given as the reason for changing the venue from England to Persia. The textual
tradition eventually led to Donizetti's Roberto Devereux (1837).

 This production seems to have had only two performances in the first instance, but it had a brief revival
(not separately listed) after Astianatte (1719/1). Cunningham referred to its poor reception in a letter
of 18 February 1718, in which he reported that this town is much devided in their judgement about
ye last Opera at St. Giovanni Chrysostomo...tis condemned without being heard ye third time, and
most of ye Compagnie has left that house; alsoe Sigr. Nicolini [ = Nicola Grimaldi] with several other
actors are ingadgeing [engaging] themselves for the next year to sing at Naples, if the Spaniards doe
not disturb them.?

26 4 nobleman from Genoa. The surname Lomellini is well-known to music historians because the composer Alessandro Stradella (b. 1642)
was stabbed to death in Genoa in 1682 for his alleged love affair with Maria Caterina Lomellini, the wife of Gio. Maria Garibaldi. The surname
also belonged to the Genovese Grand Prior (1685-92) of the Order of Malta in Venice (Fra Stefano Lomellini).

27 Orsato was defended by another Roman singer, Maria Maddalena Tibaldi, in November 1717 (Gastone Vio, unpublished research).In one
of his dealings of the same period, he promised the composer Giovanni Vandi 50 ducats for the score of L odio abbattuto dalla costanza, which
he expected to produce at Sant' Angelo. It appears that Orsato was reluctant to stage works (including this one) which did not have a dedicatee.
Giusti later performed with traveling troupes, including that of Antonio Denzio (Prague, 1724-35).

21! Although San Giovanni Grisostomo prided itself on not providing comic intermezzi, this trattenimento giocoso di familiari di corte appears
to have used the pretense of representing court jesters in a play-within-a-play.

the Royal Academy of Music, London, in 1728 (Gibson, Royal Academy, p. 31).

the scenario in Cotticelli et al., Commedia, 473ff.

24 In Corneille's Le Comte d'Essex (1678), which served as Salvi's model, Stateira (representing Queen Elizabeth) was rumored to have had
a love affair with Robert Devereux, the count of Essex. Strohm, Dramma, p. 305, also defines the differences of intellectual context in Britten's
Gloriana (1943).

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1710-19) 337

Despite such reactions, the text for Arsace was all but immortal: it was in use through 1768 and variant
versions survived until 1789 (e.g., at San Benedetto). Gasparini's music had a long lifetime as well,
for it was in use through 1733. Further settings were made by Giacomelli, Lampugnani, and Feo. The
best known alternative version based on Salvi's text was by Orlandini (with arias by Amadei). Called
Amore e Maesta, it was first performed at the Cocomero (Florence, summer 1715) and revived by Paolo
Rolli (London, 1721).? Airs from Orlandini's setting were published in England in the same year,
and the full work (with various revisions) was given at least six times between 1725 and 1739 in London,
Hamburg, and various venues in northern Italy.

Meleagr oO Music attributed to Tomaso Albinoni
[MELEAGER]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Pietro Antonio Bernardoni?
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1717-12-27~

Without dedicatee

In Greek mythology Meleager, the king of Caledonia, was a champion boar-hunter who wished to court
the huntress Atalanta. Since Atalanta, the queen of Arcadia, had said she would only marry someone
who could beat her in a contest, he gave her a boar-hide as a sign of his love. Ovid's tale as presented
here enables Meleager (Domenico Tollini) to marry the princess Elisa (Camilla Zoboli) so that Atalanta
(Teresa Muzzi) can wed the prince with whom she was originally in love.

It can be deduced from the overall pattern of activities at Sant' Angelo that Meleagro should have opened
onor about 27 December 1717. The title-page is dated 1718. The text had first been set by Marc' Antonio
Ziani for performance at the Viennese court in August 1706.

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 517; Groppo 521; Wiel 164; Alm 665

A dramma tragicomico Text attributed to Francesco Passarini
Performed at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1718-01-11~

Without dedicatee

This short tragicomedia featured Albuin, the king of the Lombards, and three other members of his
court plus Berthold, a villain well-known from children's stories (see 1749/1). The setting was Verona.
A license to print the libretto was issued on 24 December 1717; the title-page was dated 1717. Bertoldo
is likely to have opened by the time Carnival began (11 January).

Farnace Music by Carlo Francesco Pollarolo
[PHARNAKES]

A dramma per musica Text by Domenico Lalli
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1718-01-11~

Dedicated to Wilhelm Friedrich (Prince), Margrave of Brandenburg!

As in Morari's text on the same subject (1703/9), history and mythology are entangled in this work.
Some of the names have been changed. Cunningham indicates that this work was running on 14 January
1718 (a Friday) and implies that it may have opened the preceding Monday or Tuesday.*? Tuesday,
the 11th, is likely to be correct, since it was the opening day of Carnival. The cast included Gaetano
Borghi in the role of Pakoros, king of the Parthians, with Diana Vico as his second wife, Stateira.*
This is the first libretto to give credit to the choreographer  Susanna Dentis, who was to be a mainstay
of the profession. The composer was honored with his own box on account of his being a celebrated
maestro.** Although Lalli's text was set again by Leo (Naples, 1736), it was A. M. Lucchini's account
which found a broad reception all over Europe in the last quarter of the eighteenth century.*

Cleomene Music by Tomaso Albinoni
[CLEOMENES]

A dramma per musica Text by Vincenzo Cassani
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Alcea e Gillo,** balli, and a combattimento SORTING DATE: 1718-01-22

Dedicated to the patrons of the theater

Before his death Otaros, the childless king of Corinth, instructed his wife, Theodelinda, that after a
year of widowhood she should marry the most valorous prince of the realm. Cleomenes, the prince
of Macedonia, who was to help in the quest, declared himself to be in love with her.

Performance of Cleomene was authorized by the Council of Ten on 22 January 1718. A request to open
on the 20th had been denied.*' Teresa Muzzi took the role of Theodelinda, with Domenico Tollini as
Cleomenes. Because the production was closely monitored by the Council of Ten, highly informative
payment records exist. They show that by way of instrumental resources, the production involved two
cembali, twelve string players, and an oboist (Domenico Mahaeni). The three most highly paid string
players  Paolo Sabadin (principal violinist), Giovan Pettinati (violone), and Carlo Bianchi (violoncello)
 were brought in from outside the Veneto. So too was the viola-player Antonio Meani. One of the

28! Margrave Wilhelm Friedrich (1686-1723) was from the Ansbach line of the family.

locals played a small theorbo (siorbina),** and seven played bowed strings. Domenico Magini was

engaged to tune the harpsichords and to manage the other instruments.* Giovanni Gallo was engaged
to provide the balli and combattimento (which are not mentioned in the libretto).?
Performances given on 22, 23, and 25 January, which are documented in detail, were not well received.
Folding-chair rentals totaled 109 for the first night; ticket sales are curiously absent from the report.
For the second performance 214 tickets were sold and 36 scagni were rented. By the third performance
only 49 tickets were sold and 5 scagni rented. It appears that the production was then terminated.!
Albinoni is not named as the composer in the libretto, but he is identified in payment records, which
also indicate that he conducted the orchestra. As maestro di musica Albinoni was paid 186 lire, a
sum which represented 30 zecchini for the opening night and 13 zecchini for each subsequent
performance.

&S Bernardo Canal was paid 15 zecchini for the scenery used on the opening night and 5 zecchini for each
subsequent night, for a total of 80 zecchini. This suggests a total of fourteen performances in all, while
Albinoni's pay indicates a total of thirteen. Canal seems also to have been responsible for lighting the
inside of the theater and operating the machinery, for which he was paid separately.

1718/4 La virti tra nemici Music attributed to Giuseppe Boniventi'
[VIRTUE AMONG ENEMIES]

A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Battista Abbati?*

ml Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)

Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1718-01-24~

Dedicated to Francesco Bembo*

The plot did not follow a particular historical script. The widow Amages was content to lead a reclusive
life in Sarmaria when her king (Olderic) was attacked by Scythians. Her captain and emissary (Ormontes)
was unable to negotiate a peace. The invader set his amorous sights on Ormontes' daughter Berenice,
but she was eventually married to her first love, Silvio. The cast included Francesco Braganti (Olderico),
Costanza Maccari (Amage), Rosa Venturini (Berenice), and Antonia Merighi (Silvio).

 La virti, ostensibly given in the winter of 1718, is a difficult work to date precisely. A number of Venetian
battleships, returning from Corfu and its environs, arrived at the Lazzaretto for quarantine on Christmas
and the early days of 1717 (BG). The occupants would have been released in the later half of January.
Although Carnival officially opened on the 11th, the onset of heavy snows around the 20th, followed
by exceptional cold, froze the waters and led to a food shortage which continued a month (NV). By
the time the situation eased, few revelers remained. The remainder of the season was thus impaired.

> The nightly cost of hiring Gallo and his forces was 55:12 lire; the orchestra forestiera cost 54 lire a night (including lodging expenses);

1718/5 Il vecchio deluso' Music anonymous
[THE OLD MAN WHO WAS DELUDED]
A dramma comico Text attributed to Francesco Passarini
im Performed at San Fantin SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1718-02-16~
& Without dedicatee
 This was a bizarre tale, intended to include incorrect elocution. Elements of other recent works

at San Fantin seem to have been woven into it. It included roles for the young Florinda, courted by the
boatman Nico, for Florinda's friend Silvia, for an old man (Balilo), and for a bizarre youth (Aurindo).?
It was unrelated to the intermezzi (Fiammetta e Pancrazio; Suppl. 4a) sometimes called by the same
title. A license to print the libretto was issued on 16 February 1717 [M.V.]. The title-page is dated 1718.
Although the work had only two weeks in which to run, a contingent of French travelers from the House
of Bourbon arrived only on the 24th to enjoy the rest of Carnival.

1718/6 Antigona' Music by Giuseppe Orlandini?*
[ANTIGONE]
A tragedia da cantarsi (5) Text attributed to Benedetto Pasqualigo'
im Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Serpilla e Bacocco and balli SORTING DATE: 1718-02-13
& Dedicated to G. A. G3

In this account of Sophocles' tragedy, Antigone (the only surviving offspring of Oedipus) had a daughter,
Jocasta, by Osmenes, the son of her tyrannical husband Creon. Here Jocasta is believed to be the daughter
of the shepherd Ormindo.

oo Antigona was first performed on 13 February 1718 (A). It was the last work to be given at San Cassiano
until November 1724. Diana Vico sang in the title role, with Antonia Cavazzi (Giocasta), Gaetano Borghi
(Creonte), Valentino Urbani (Osmene), and Antinoro Claudi (Ormindo). The tragedy was conceived
in a grand style and presented as such. Antigone was described as ferocious and vindictive, Creon
as politically motivated and cruel, and Osmenes as pious and faithful. Susanna Dentis was the
choreographer. The libretto was obviously intended to be read, for each act is introduced by an eight-line
stanza. A concert performance is implied.

associated with the Aria del Granduca. As someone who worked mainly in Florence, Orlandini would have had many uses for

Armida al campo d'Egitto Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[ARMIDE IN THE CAMP OF THE EGYPTIANS]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giovanni Palazzi'
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1718-02-15

Dedicated to Friedrich Hieronymus, Baron of Witzendorff

This libretto, derived from Tasso's account of the First Crusade, had been set twice previously. The
setting was Gaza. A license to print the libretto was issued on the dedication date, 12 January 1718
[M.V.]. Armida was first performed on 15 February 1718 (A), a week before Shrove Tuesday. The
cast included Annibale Imperatori as Caliph, king of Egypt, with Antonia Merighi (Armida), Costanza
Maccari (Adrasto), and Chiara Orlandi (another Mantoanina) as Erminia.

Both Armida's opening and its spring run (RV 699b) were cited in the Gazzetta di Mantova of 29 April
1718, at which time its Mantuan performance' was expected to continue through May. It was revived
in Vicenza (as Gli inganni per vendetta, 1720; RV 720/699c), Ravenna (1726), and Venice (Santa
Margherita, 1731/4; Sant' Angelo, 1738/4). The sinfonia was reused in Vivaldi's Ercole sul Termodonte
(Rome, 1723).

Vivaldi on La verita in cimento (1720/7).

Carnevale, et essendosi mutato nel teatro 4 San Cassano il dramma in musica, vi ando lunedi sera per la prima volta quello intitolato L 'Antigona,
et in quello 4 San Moise vi ando martedi sera per la prima volta l'altro intitolato Armida in Campo d'Eggitto. The description of the activities
of the duke of Guastalla resembles those of a year later. Preceding material gives an account of recent naval affairs in the Adriatic which likens

1718/8 L'amor di figlia Music by Giovanni Porta
[THE MOTHER WHO WAS SUSTAINED BY HER DAUGHTER]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Gio. Andrea Moniglia by Domenico Lalli*
ry Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With Lisetta e Delfo *TM SORTING DATE: 1718-10-29
& Dedicated to Antonio Rambaldo*

This not too serious, not too comic, but rather galant story is derived from Boccaccio. Lalli considered
it appropriate for the annual opening of Sant' Angelo and the autumn season. It is based

on the story of a Roman noblewoman who, although held in prison without food, was sustained by the
milk of her daughter, Sabina. The extraneous episodes woven into this story, including that of the jealous
husband, Martius, who disguised himself as Sabina's sister in order to accompany her on her visits
to the prison, were created by Lalli.

OO ww L'amor di figlia was first performed on 29 October 1718 (A, NV). Margarita Caterina Zani sang as
the devoted daughter. Vittoria Tesi made her Venetian debut in the unusual role of Claudio, who fell
in love with Marzia, the female impersonated by Marzio.** Another voice new to Venice was that
of Pietro Paolo Laurenti, a cellist, composer, and prince of the Accademia Filarmonica in Bologna.
The scenography was by Marco Ricci. As it was his first theatrical commission, he was offered a
box in the theater

1718/11 Amalasunta' Music by Fortunato Chelleri
[AMALASUNTA]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giacomo Gabrieli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With Serpilla e Bacocco; Madama Dulcinea e il Cuoco* SORTING DATE: 1718-12-27
i) Dedicated to Johann Mattheus, Count of Schulenburg*'

Amalasunta, the daughter of the sixth-century Ostrogothic ruler Theodoric, was not permitted to assume
the throne because of her gender. To produce an heir, she was forced to marry her cousin Theodatus.
In this account Amalasunta was deeply in love with Theodatus, who was pursued by Doriclea but married
Amalasunta in order to gain the Ostrogothic throne in Italy.

OO & Although anticipated for the winter of 1716 [see 1716/1], Amalasunta was first performed on 27

December 1718 (A, NV). A license to print the libretto had been issued on 17 December 1718 for 1719.
The libretto was dedicated on 24 December 1718; the title-page was dated 1719. Margarita Catterina
Zani took the lead role, with Antonia Merighi as Doriclea, Vittoria Tesi as Doriclea's brother Clodesillus,
and Giammaria Morosi as Theodatus. The scenography was probably by Marco Ricci.

3'5 Cuzzoni, from Parma, was in the service of Princess Violante Beatrice at Florence from 1717 until 1722, when she went to London.

Erranti in Brescia, while he himself was involved with the Collegio in Parma.

317 The 1718-19 season was the last in which libretti regularly contained descriptive incisions on the frontispiece. San Giovanni Grisostomo

1719/1 Astianatte' Music by Antonio Maria Bononcini*"*
[ASTYANAX]
A dramma per musica Text by Antonio Salvi?!
1 Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1719-01-04~
& Dedicated to Rodrigo Annes de Saa*'

In Greek mythology Astyanax, the son of Hector and Andromache, was marked for death as a child.
Mythological accounts vary as to his ultimate fate. In this account, based on Racine's Andromaque,
he was saved by Pyrrhos, who was then wounded by Orestes.

o A license to print the libretto was issued on 17 December 1718. The production would have had to open
after J] Lamano (1718/8) closed, thus early in January. Despite the appearance of Marianna Benti
Bulgarelli (Andromaca) and Nicola Grimaldi (Pirro), Astianatte's run lasted for only two nights, after
which two performances of Arsace (1717/11) were given.*! Ifigenia (1719/3) opened on 21 January
1719. All theatrical works in progress at around 3 a.m. [O.V.] on 7 January were suspended because
of an earthquake. According to one report, it lasted the length of a Credo and caused audiences and
performers alike to exit the theaters.

Lalli declined to give a synopsis of the plot, saying that it would be clear from the opening scene what
the work was about, but this was hardly the case. More than most works of its time, it can be termed
a historical pastiche. Lalli noted that some of the roles would deviate from dramatic traditions to satisfy
the need of a theater in which continual variety in the incidents [accidenti] is required. In the opening
scene, Aldaric (credited with a fiery, lascivious, but in the end generous character) has assumed the
throne of Sparta. The idiosyncracies of temperament of each of the other characters are carefully noted
and the chemistry between them probed.

Il pentimento opened on 4 Feburary 1719 (A, NV). A license to print the libretto was issued on 9
January 1718 [M.V.] for Carn. 1719. The libretto states that it was the udtim opera del Carnevale
1719 (at Sant' Angelo). Giuliano Albertini sang as Aldaric, with Vittoria Tesi as the Tunisian prince
Cario and Valentino Urbani as the African king Almansor. The scenography was by Marco Ricci.

Gelon, a Sicilian tyrant preceding Hieron (1708/6), made a claim to the Egyptian throne then held by
Orontes. After a fierce naval battle in which Orontes was almost killed, he triumphed to gain both the
throne and the hand of Gelon's intended, the princess Elissa of Carthage.*** Rossi said that because
his text was weak, it would serve only as an introduction to the more serious Carnival recitations
at Sant' Angelo. La caduta was first performed on 11 (A) or 12 (NV) November 1719. The principal
roles were taken by Matteo Lucchini (Gelone), Cecilia Bellisani (Elisa), and Domenico Borghi, who
made his debut as Orontes.** One ballo was rustic, the other heroic. The sets and scenery were
by Cristoforo Canal. Francesco Rossi, who was serving as impresario, made the unusual arrangement
of compensating the virtuosa Francesca Miniati (Florinda) with rents from particular boxes in lieu of
pay.

The 1720s: An Overview

he decade of the 1720s placed the past under a rosy
Si A generation of Europeans, impeded by war

since the turn of the century, now came to Venice
expecting to find the legendary splendors of earlier times.
Instead they encountered an escalation of ceremony and its
symbols. Among these symbols were the Ascension Fair and,
to advertise it, a new bucintoro  the golden galley on
which the doge sailed to the Lido to mark the annual
Wedding of Venice to the Adriatic.

So strong was the promotion of Ascension that a short
spurt of operas was regularly scheduled from 1722, inrough
coincidence with the mercantile fair held on the Piazza in
front of San Marco. The authorization was motivated by an
interest in generating more tax revenues from the fair itself,
not by any interest in promoting operas per se. (Comedies
were not given during the Ascension period.) Ascension
opera soon became categorically different from autumn and
winter opera. The audience for spring opera was largely a
transient one. Subjects were often pastoral or comic. The
works were usually shorter than those given at other times
of year. Since the number of performances was relatively
few, it was extremely difficult for theaters to realize a profit
from Ascension productions unless the works were staged
simply. Since few concessions were made to staging,
Ascension opera generally increased the debt load of the
three participating theaters.

Summary numbers for the decade (Figure 25) fail to
delineate the ways in which spring opera, however modest
it was in character, changed the comparative profiles of
theaters and theatrical periods. For San Samuele, which
initiated the practice, opera itself was a departure from its
near monopoly on comedy, which it continued to provide
in the autumn and winter. Rising (after its fashion) to the
occasion, Sant'Angelo managed to operate steadily in all
three seasons. San Moise, which offered more operas than
any other theater during this decade, participated in spring
opera by employing the troupe model of production. The
benefit to San Moise was short-lived, because troupes such
as that of Antonio Denzio developed their own new markets
in Ljubljana, Graz, Prague, and elsewhere.

Sant'Angelo and San Giovanni Grisostomo ranked
closely behind San Moise in the number of works they gave.

At San Giovanni, which eschewed spring opera, the increase
resulted from a vigorous winter schedule. San Giovanni often
presented two works between St. Stephen's and Shrove
Tuesday, and they were usually based on new texts. After
almost thirty years of vigorous activity, San Cassiano began
to recede to the sidelines. San Fantin ceased operations in
1720. Numbers mask the increasingly speckled successes
of San Giovanni Grisostomo, which now had to contend with
the financial consequences of the Peace of Passarowitz.
Rising prosperity in many other parts of Europe left
Venetian theaters unable to compete for the services of
home-grown musicians. Since San Giovanni had always
sought to engage superstars, it was the theater most vulnera-
ble to these changes. Bonlini's ruminations on the economic
changes apparent in 1720 (Le glorie, p. 183) note that

it used to be that if a singer of high rank and a voice of
rare beauty commanded more than 100 scudi, the salary
was considered excessive and exceptional (un oggetto
di meraviglia). [The ordinary rate was] a cause for the
invention of the label a cento vinti [a 120] for an
expensive singer. But that proverb has fallen into disuse
because in our time an ordinary salary is often greater
than the exorbitant sum of 1,000 zecchini....This has
led to the immodest pretensions of all singers and has
brought negative consequences to theatrical interests.

One of the clearest evidences that Bonlini's perspective was
generally valid is that, in contrast to the continued practice
of casting castrati in male leads, Sant' Angelo rapidly shifted
to the use of females (and relatively unknown ones, at that)
in male roles.

Even as performers divided their attention between
Venice and other venues, the demand for certain attributes
of performance (excellent voices, affective performance)
was increasingly met by occasional works given under
private auspices. A robust increase in the performance of
serenatas and other entertainments at ambassadorial functions
(Suppl. 5a) occurred. Academic assemblies at which any
member of the educated public was welcome, irrespective
of social rank (Suppl. 7), were also in ascent. The Albrizzian
Society, which hosted these gatherings, established the first
public library in Venice. Altogether, the number of docu-
mented meta-operas more than doubled. This rise was dis-

proportionate to a twenty percent increase in the number of
operas given. This attests in part to strenuous polemics of
musical taste. Advocates of taste, as opposed to virtuoso
excess, often preferred the serenata. The rise of amateur
music-making concurrently led to the augmentation of
orchestras at private functions by players (generally noble-
men) trained by the principals. This accommodation of
personal involvement was a reincarnation of the engineer-
ing expertise noblemen had contributed to the staging of
opera a generation earlier. The void caused by the absence
of physical war was filled by an intellectual battle between
partisans of the Ancients and Moderns. The debate was a
sharp one, its divisions evident in the growing divide
between the classical subjects treated at San Giovanni
Grisostomo and the more fanciful and increasingly satirical
ones found at Sant' Angelo and San Moise.

The great champion of the Ancients was Pietro Meta-
stasio, a Neapolitan whose rise to fame between 1724 and
the end of the decade was phenomenal. Metastasio's
subjects, though straight from the annals of ancient history,
found a following less for their grounding in the glorious
past than for their subtle characterizations and dramatic
intricacies. In contrast to the quasi-historical subjects with
fictional overlays which had filled the Venetian stage for
a half century, Metastasio's works were characterized by
inevitable conflicts of personal affection and patriotic duty,
the seemingly insoluble moral dilemmas they posed, and
denouements hinging on seemingly unimportant physical
cues which led to a central moment of revelation. Audiences
found in these dramas a new cause for attention to the text.
Metastasio's works soon became so firmly entrenched in

the opera world that many dominated European stages for
the balance of the century.

One asset of the dramma per musica, and of our
knowledge of it, was the arrival towards the end of the
decade of the sons of some of Britain's leading families, who
sought to determine, after two decades of Italian opera at
the Royal Academy in London, how to establish an Opera
of the Nobility. Their brief presence made a significant
contribution to the survival rate of scores for the decade.
English attention to Venetian opera was loosely associated
with the ascension of George II (1727), who inherited his
father's box at San Moise but seems rarely, if ever, to have
used it.

The composer best represented by surviving scores is
Vivaldi, whose operas and other works are largely preserved
in Turin. As Vivaldi increasingly appeared elsewhere, his
services to Sant' Angelo (and San Moise) became halting.
His reputation abroad grew by leaps and bounds. By the end
of the decade he had become (in succession to Pollarolo, who
died in 1723) a figure of great fascination to the emperor,
Charles VI. With one exception he eschewed Metastasian
subjects. They appealed mainly to the English, whose love
of antiquities was generally greater still than that of Venetian
nobles. The fact that Metastasio was Neapolitan inspired
Neapolitan composers (e.g., Vinci, Leo, and Porpora) to set
his texts, but the same composers merely passed through
Venice. They did not linger there.

The nemesis of those who favored the Ancients was a
free spirit from Bologna named Giuseppe Maria Buini. Buini
wrote the texts for many of his own good-humored musical
works. The modern Bolognese singers who had been

352

gathering in Venice for years were mercilessly satirized by
Benedetto Marcello in // teatro alla moda [The Theater in
Vogue] of 1720, but that did nothing to diminish their ranks.
Il teatro is generally taken to refer especially to practices
at Sant' Angelo, a theater founded by his forebears. Marcel-
lo, a prolific composer of pastoral and dramatic cantatas,
was a pillar of the Ancients. His landmark work, settings

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

they constituted an singular monument to literary and
musical classicism. Yet Marcello's antiquity was strikingly
different from that of Metastasio.

Documentary accounts of Venetian opera are given
generously in avvisi, in the perfunctory records of the papal
legate, and, from 1725, in the Diario ordinario. English
diplomatic letters containing relevant content also survive

The 1720s: Chronology

1720/1 Paride

[PARIS]
A dramma per musica (5)
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo
With a ballo
rs Without dedicatee
In this variant of the myth recounted in 1706/5, Paris, the son of Priam and Hecuba, having been raised
by shepherds on Mt. Ida for his safety, had now reached manhood. He had successfully defended the
interests of Troy in a naval battle and was falsely believed to be dead when the action began.
Paride opened on 13 January 1720 (NV), when it produced universal satisfaction. The principal singers
 Bartolomeo Bartoli (Paride), Antonio Zannoni (Priamo), and Faustina Bordoni (Enone)  were
all under German protection (by the houses of Darmstadt, Bavaria, and the Palatine respectively).
Orlandini's post as maestro di cappella to the Grand Duke of Tuscany and his membership in the
Accademia Filarmonica of Bologna were cited in the libretto. Following his entry on this work, Bonlini
provided an important historical note (quoted in the overview) about the overall decline in the economic
health of the opera houses.

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1720-29) 353

La figlia should have opened early in the official Carnival period. A license to print the libretto was
issued on 8 January 1720; title-page of the libretto was dated 1719. It was a short, comic work apparently
given by a troupe (it contains no cast list). As staged, it could have been an early prototype for singing-
teacher genre soon to be popularized in the intermezzo repertory. Attilio Cestari (Manteca), the
impresario, announced in the libretto that this would be his final production for San Fantin, because
he and his casts were discouraged by frequent disturbances and insults in the theater. Instead of giving
pleasure and making people smile, his entertainments only seemed to elicit outrage. He begged the
audience to suffer the imperfections of this short work (which, he said, had been put together in a few
days) in silence.

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 537; Groppo 541; Wiel 182; Alm 688

Armida delusa* Music by Giuseppe Maria Buini
[ARMIDE DELUDED]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1720-01-24
Without dedicatee

In this account, Armide (Francesco Miniati), a figure from the First Crusade in many previous libretti,
and the famous enchantments of her palace were countered by the magic swords of Ubald (Domenico
Borghi) and Guelph/Guelfo (Margarita Gaspari), who were sent by Geoffrey/Goffredo.

This third drama was first performed on 24 January 1720 (A). A license to print the libretto had been
issued on 22 January 1719 [M.V.], although the title-page was dated 1720. A note from Buini says
that the work was written in a few hours. The impresario Francesco Rossi was taken to task by the
Council of Ten on 30 January for failing to pay the instrumentalists and stage crew punctually.>

Griselda Music by Giuseppe Maria Orlandini
[GRISELDA]

A dramma per musica Text by Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1720-05-08

Dedicated to George [Lord] Parker*
The shepherdess Griselda, seen by the mythical king Walter/Gualtiero of Sicily at a hunt, becomes the
object of his affection, later his wife, and then the mother of his daughter Oronta, who is raised as a
commoner. Oronta later weds Conrad/Corrado, the son of Walter, who in this account feigns repudiation
of Griselda to trap his enemy Otto.*

in the years 1720, 1721, and 1722 (London, 1730) and is therefore likely to have been in the same entourage as Wright, who was still present
in Venice in February 1721.

5 In Giovanni Boccaccio's Decameron the emphasis was on the cruel tasks which Walter/Gualtiero imposed on his peasant wife to allow her
to demonstrate her complete commitment to him.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Griselda opened on 8 May 1720 (A). It and Gl'inganni (1720/5) were the first works to be given during
the Ascension fair since the 1640s. With the exceptions of Gio. Battista Carboni of Mantua (Gualtiero)
and Rosaura Mazzanti of Florence (Griselda), the principal singers were Bolognese.

Zeno's text had first been set by Antonio Pollarolo (1701/5) for San Cassiano. Orlandini's musical setting
had first been performed in Mantua in 1717. An intermediate version of the work, given in Recanati
early in 1720, contained additional music by Tinazzoli.

GP inganni fortunati Music attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini
[THE FORTUNATE DECEPTION]

A pastorale per musica Text attributed to Belisario Valeriani'
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With Elpina e Silvano* SORTING DATE: 1720-05-08

Dedicated to Count Giovanni Negrobon?

In this short Arcadian plot, derived from La caccia in Etolia Modena, 1716) but reminiscent of 1717/12,
the beautiful Atalanta, raised in the wild, renounced her wedding vows to Meleager, despite his having
presented her with a boar's hide from a Calydonian hunt. Adopting the assumed names of Amarilli
and Tirsi, the two met and fell in love once again. The first Venetian performance of Gli'inganni was
given on 8 May 1720(A). A license to print the libretto had been issued on 4 May. The plot of Handel's
Atalanta (HWV 35; London, 1736) was derived from this text.

1720/7 La verita in cimento Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[TRUTH IN CONTENTION]
A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Palazzi and Domenico Lalli
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)

 Damira was loved by Mahmud, who was married to Rustena. Both women bore him sons on the same

day. The illegitimate Melindos and the legitimate Zelim were raised with mistaken identities, which
complicated their apparent rights of succession to the throne. An opening was announced for the 12th,
then reported to have occurred on 26 October 1720 (NV), when the work was received with universal
satisfaction (A); a license to print the libretto had been issued on 3 October. The production was still
running on 23 November (A), apparently with a revised first act.'6

 Antonio Barbieri (Mamud), who was to sing in twenty-two later operas in Venice, made his Venetian
debut in this work. A tenor, Barbieri was noted for his skills in vocal inflection and ornamentation,
for which reason he served as maestro di manieri at the Ospedale de' Mendicanti (1736-67).'' During
his first years in Venice he enjoyed the protection of Vivaldi's patron, Prince Philip, Landgrave of Hesse-
Darmstadt. La verita also included Girolamo Albertini (Ze/im), who was protected by Prince Karl of
Hesse-Kassel. Anna Maria Strada (Rosane), who was employed by Count Gio. Battista Colloredo, the
governor of Milan, made her Venetian debut in this work.'*

BS The libretto for this work was the first to identify the Romans Giuseppe and Domenico Valeriani, who
were pupils of Marco Ricci, as its scenery painters. By 1721, they were given their own box at the theater.
Swiney recommended them in 1727 to the Royal Academy as the two greatest men in their profession."
They had illustrious careers in Venice through 1731.

Teodorico Music by Giovanni Porta
[THEODORIC]

A dramma per musica Text by Antonio Salvi
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With intermezzi SORTING DATE: 1720-11-19

Dedicated to Eleonora Rambaldo!

The Ostrogothic king Theodoric aspired to emulate Odovacar, the king of the Heruli. The historical
figure conquered much of the Italian peninsula in the last years of the fifth century. Among the highlights
of his long reign were his siege [491] and conquest [493] of Ravenna and his imprisonment of Pope
John I. The fictional Theodoric depicted here imprisoned Odovacar (an apparent substitute for the
pope), where he taunted him with false offers of his daughter Hostilia, who was loved by the Greek
prince Antigonos. The first Venetian performance of Teodorico was given on 19 November 1720 (NV).
lit was received with universal satisfaction (A). A license to print the libretto had been issued on
the 9th. Francesco Guicciardi sang in the title role with Gaetano Borghi (Odoacre) and Faustina Bordoni
(Ostilia). The text was reset by Buini for performance at the Teatro Formigliari, Bologna, in 1728.
Arias in D-Mbs

Listed as Bonlini 543; Groppo 547; Wiel 183; Alm 694

Lucio Papirio dittatore' Music by Antonio Pollarolo
[Luctus PAPIRIUS DICTATOR]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Agostino Piovene
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1720-12-26

Dedicated to Theophilus Hastings

Lucius Papirius led the Romans to war against the Samnites in the fourth century BC.TM As set by Predieri
for Sant' Angelo five years earlier (1715/1), the figure of the dictator's daughter, Papiria, was introduced.
She became the wife of Quintus Fabius, the son of the consul Marcus Fabius. The first Venetian
performance was on 26 December 1720 (A); a license to print the libretto had been issued on 15 December
1720. The title-page was dated 1721. Gaetano Borghi portrayed Lucius, with Faustina Bordoni as his
daughter, and Diana Vico (who frequently took male roles) as Quintus Fabius. The work opened grandly,
outside the temple of Jupiter, where slaves could be seen pulling a carriage over a bridge across the
Tiber.

A different adaptation of Zeno's text, which had first been set by Caldara (Vienna, November 1719),
was used in Handel's arrangement of Giacomelli's Lucio Papirio (HWV A6; King's Theatre, London,
1732). Revised versions were set by Porpora (San Cassiano, 1737) and Hasse (Dresden, 1742). The
text was in use through the time of Paisiello, who set it for Naples in 1767.
