The plot focuses on the wish of Antigone (Antonia Margherita Merighi), the only surviving offspring
of Oedipus, that the order of the tyrant Creon (Antonio Barbieri) prohibiting the burial of her brother
Polynikes/Polinice be defied. Texts for the prologue and intermezzi were published separately.
This concert production of the work previously given at San Cassiano (1718/6), ifit was indeed a third
opera of this cycle, must have been substituted for a poorly received work (presumably Vivaldi's Filippo
[1720/10]) around 15 January 1721. The production of Antigona is in a class of its own, since concert
performances of operas in public theaters were otherwise unknown in Venice. However, the theater
managers could have been parading Pasqualigo's impeccable standing among Arcadians to redress
the harsh portrayal of theatrical decadence unleashed (especially vis-a-vis Sant' Angelo) in Marcello's
recently published satire J] teatro alla moda.

Nerone' Music by Giuseppe Maria Orlandini
[NERO]

A tragedia per musica Text attributed to Agostino Piovene
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With an abbattimento, a ballo, and a giuoco SORTING DATE: 1721-02-11
Without dedicatee

This account of the life of Nero emphasizes the ambitions of his mother, Agrippina, and his own
treacherous dealings with his first wife, Octavia, in order to pursue his second, Poppea. The subject
had various partial predecessors in Venetian opera history, among them Monteverdi's L incoronazione
di Poppea (text by Businello; 1642), Pallavicino's Nerone (text by Corradi; 1678/8), and Pollarolo's
Il ripudio d'Ottavia (text by Noris, 1699/3).

Nerone was first performed onc. 11 February 1721 (A) with deafening applause (indecibile applauso).
A license to print the libretto was issued on 30 January 1720 M.V.; the title-page is dated 1720. Gaetano
Borghi sang in the title role, with Faustina Bordoni (Ottavia), Francesca Cuzzoni (Poppea), and Diana

 Its printing license was issued on 10 October 1720. The title page was also dated 1720, suggesting that it appeared before the end of the
year. Although Vivaldi has generally been taken (on the basis of an interpretation of the title-page drawing) to be the chief target of the work,
two of the three Sant' Angelo operas staged immediately prior to this license (1719/7, 1720/3) were by Buini; the third (1719/10) was anonymous.
(Vivaldi's La verita in cimento and Filippo both opened after the satire had gone to press on 10 October 1720.)

> The title in Bologna was La fedelta coronata; the work opened on 14 June.

* With roles for Aurilla and Cola (see listings in Suppl. 4). Wiel (Teatri, p. 63) also lists Dorisbe e Petronio, for which there is no confirmation.
However, it was in the repertory of the same performers and had been given with the work immediately preceding at San Moise.

35 Although dedicatees were sparse in this year, it is known that three English gentlemen, one being Charles Lennox, the duke of Richmond,
were frequenting the theaters in February (Mercurio storico, xxxviii, 40).

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1720-29) 359

Vico (Agrippina). Orlandini's setting had nearly four dozen performances between 1723 and 1738.
Piovene's text was also set by Giuseppe Vignatti for performance in Milan at the end of 1724.

The libretto carefully notes the grand scale of the scenes, particularly the vast courtyard, fitted out
for the coronation of Tiridates, shown at the opening of the work, and the vast hall in which machines
representing the four elements (Earth, Air, Fire, Water) descend in the third act.

Edward Wright described both scenes in considerable detail. His account of the scenery in this Nerone
seems suspiciously close to St. Didier's of Pallavicino's Nerone (1678/8), but apparently the battle
scene (abbattimento) from the earlier work was intentionally revived. In the coronation scene, he said,
the emperor and empress appeared in a chariot drawn by an elephant. Wright related that the Head,
Trunk, and Eyes...move as if alive, and Tiridates believes he is so....All of a sudden, as soon as the
Emperor and Empress are dismounted...the Triumphal Chariot is transform'd into an Amphitheatre,
and fill'd with Spectators. The Elephant falls all in pieces, and out of his Belly come a great number
of Gladiators...so that he seems in a moment to be transform'd into a company of arm'd Men, who
make a Skirmish, all in time to the Musick.**

Wright's account also noted that in the hall scene were represented the four Elements, emblematically,
in Picture; these, opening themselves, form'd two Palaces, those of Love and Hymen. These again were
transform'd into the Palace (or Temple) of Mars, all surrounded with Weapons of War. This Scene
was so finely imagin'd, and the Lights so well dispos'd, that I think it was the most entertaining Sight
I ever saw upon a Stage.* Alberto Bruni was the director of these two scenes.

Score in D-B;** arias in D-B (3), Hs, Mbs, Swl (5); F-Pc, Pn; GB-Cfm, Ob (Tenbury); US-Wlc

Il pastor fido Music by Carlo Luigi Pietro Grua
[THE FAITHFUL SHEPHERD]

A tragicommedia pastorale (5) Libretto adapted by Benedetto Pasqualigo
Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With intermezzi SORTING DATE: 1721-02-11
Without dedicatee

In this classic Arcadian tale, the conflicting lines of love are framed with such artifacts of antiquity
as sacrificial victims and oracular messages. Bonlini termed the text a royal drama and pointed to
its earlier performance in Turin (without music).*!

The first Venetian performance, on 11 February 1721 (A), was received with satisfaction. A license
to print the libretto had been issued on 26 January 1720 M.V.; the title-page is dated 1721. The libretto
was printed in Padua. Its twelve roles were taken (in Venice) by ten singers. Among them, the intermezzo
performers Rosa Ongarelli and Antonio Ristorini were cast within the drama as Corisca and a satyr.
The principal nymphs were Antonia Merighi (Amarilli) and Anna Maria Strada (Dorinda), with
Girolamo Albertini and Chiara Orlandi [sic] as the shepherds Mirtillo and Silvio.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

The textual history of Guarini's // pastor fido is too lengthy to recount here. In association with staging
involving music, it can be traced to the tragicomedia pastorale printed both in Venice and in Ferrara
in 1590, in both cases for the wedding of Carlo Emanuele, the duke of Savoy, and Caterina of Austria.
Cori were required at the ends of acts from 1594. Because it was reprinted so many times, all kinds
of miscellany (annotations, figures, poems) became attached to it. A large number of editions from
1602 carried a dedication to Vicenzo Gonzaga. After 1630 there were many fewer new prints. The best
known production in the decade preceding Grua's setting was Handel's (HWV 8; 1712).

L'inganno fortunato Music attributed to Giuseppe Boniventi
[THE FORTUNATE DECEPTION]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from G. B. Sara by Bartolomeo Pavieri
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1721-10-11

Dedicated to Antonio Litta

The Hindustani ruler Arbakes (Andrea Costa) was under siege by the troops of Antillus. Much of the
drama in this short work hinges on the fate of his daughter Armilla (Luigia Villanova), who, disguised
as a man, has been taken prisoner. L 'inganno fortunato was first performed on 11 October 1721 (A),
when it was greeted with universal applause. A license to print the libretto had been issued on 27
September 1721.

Cimene Music attributed to Girolamo Bassani and Matteo (?) Lucchini*
[XIMENE]

A tragedia da cantarsi (5) Text by Benedetto Pasqualigo
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With Vespetta e Scannacapone; balli SORTING DATE: 1721-10-18

Without dedicatee

As in II pastor fido, Pasqualigo explains that he has made an adaptation of language, medium, and
theatrical culture by adapting this text from Corneille's Le Cid (1636).* In this story set in Seville,
Ximene (of Toledo) was obliged by duty to follow her beloved Rodrigo, the murderer of her father,
the count of Gormas, to his death. Cimene was first performed on 18 October 1721 (A), when it was
well received, although the cast, which included Rosaura Mazzanti (Cimene) and Giovanni Rapaccioli
(Rodrigo), was little known.

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1720-29) 361

Plautilla Music by Antonio Pollarolo
[PLAUTILLA]

A dramma per musica Text by Vincenzo Cassani
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1721-11-22

Dedicated to Francesco Ravaschieri*

The plot concerned the succession to the imperial seat held by Septimus Severus [d. 211 AD]. It was
a condition of the emperor's will that his son Bassianus [= Caracalla] could succeed him only if he
married Plautilla. When the widow Julia Domna sent her other son, Geta [209-212], to fetch Plautilla
from Carthage, Bassianus fell in love with Marcia but tried to conceal his infidelity by accusing the
other couple of illicit relations. Plautilla was first performed on 22 November 1721 (A). Gaetano
Berenstadt (Bassiano) made his Venetian debut in this work, which included Antonio Bernacchi (Gera),
Vittoria Tesi (Giulia), and Francesca Cuzzoni (Plautilla). Marcia is never actually seen (or heard).
Arias in D-SW1

Listed as Bonlini 554; Groppo 558; Wiel 190; Alm 705

La fede ne' tradimenti Music attributed to Carlo Luigi Pietro Grua
{FAITH IN THE MIDST OF TREACHERY]

A dramma per musica Text by Girolamo Gigli*
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1721-11-26

Dedicated to Gaetana (Aurora) Sanseverino

The anonymous writer of the dedication of the libretto, which was revived from the work earlier given
at San Fantin (1705/7), praised the contributions of the dedicatee to the Arcadian academies, thus setting
a certain tone of expectation for the work itself. The subject came from well-worn but fictionalized
Spanish history featuring Fernando, the count of Castile; Sancho, the king of Navarre (who had died
before the story began); Garcia, the king's son; and Anagilda, the king's daughter.

La fede opened on 26 November 1721 (A), when it was received with universal satisfaction. A license
to print the libretto had been issued on the 13th. The text, previously used by G. Fabbrini (1689) and
by C. F. Pollarolo (Bologna, 1690; San Fantin, as above), Caldara (Rome, 1711, as Anagilda), and L.
A. Predieri (as La fede, Florence, 1718; as Anagilda, Turin, 1719), remained in circulation through
the 1750s.

No musical sources known
Listed as Bonlini 553; Groppo 557; Wiel 193; Alm 704

Gl' eccessi della gelosia Music by Tomaso Albinoni
[THE EXCESSES OF JEALOUSY]

Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1721-12-27

Dedicated to Domenico Grillo, Nob. Gen.

The Roman army had reached the wall of Jerusalem, which was defended by the cruel tyrant Herod
Agrippa (Giovanni Paita) who zealously protected his wife, Mariane (Rosaura Mazzanti).' In this account
a portrait which Mariane had sent to Cleopatra precipitated much of the action. G/'eccessi was first

& Dedicated to an anonymous Venetian senator
The story is taken from history of the fourth century AD, when Constantine, while guarding properties
in Gaul, took as his second wife Fausta, the daughter of Maximinus. Their son Constantine was opposed
by the hero Julius Flavius Crispus, a son of Constantine born to the British commoner Minervina.
Successful in battle, Flavius returned to discover that his brother had fallen in love with Arismene, the
daughter of his enemy Merentius, whom he has killed.

 This work was first performed on 17 January 1722 (A), when it was received with universal applause.'
A license to print the libretto had been issued on 20 December 1721 for 1722. The title-page is dated
1722. An innovation of the libretto (not followed in subsequent works) was that it indicated voice parts.
Antonio Bernacchi (contralto) sang in the title role with Gaetano Berenstadt (contralto; Flavio
Costantino), Vittoria Tesi (contralto; Fausta), and Francesca Cuzzoni (soprano; Arismene).* The
stellar machine of the production was a celestial globe showing the four principal parts of the world.

Or  The Rhineland prince Arminius (Nicola Grimaldi) married Thrusnelda (Vittoria Tesi) but later fought
her father, Segestes (Francesco Guicciardi), the head of a trio of Roman legions, in the first century.
Although announced for the 7th, the first Venetian performance of L'Arminio was given on 14
November 1722 (A, NV). The libretto had been dedicated on the 1 0th. The work had earlier been given
in Pratolino. Sant' Angelo appeared to take its cues from San Giovanni Grisostomo in offering balli
of the nations and of arts and sciences. It seems likely, however, that this was done somewhat
satirically, since each ballo was to become slightly mad (impazzisco).

a Dedicated to Robert Walpole

Oo Inearly Rome, Romulus (Antonio Bernacchi), the first king of the Romans, noting an insufficient supply
of women, raided the nearby hills, kidnaped Sabine women, and took them to Rome, where they were
raped in the hope of generating a new population. After many battles, Romulus shared power with Tatius
(Antonio Baldi), the king of the Sabines. Romolo was first performed on 28 November 1722 (NV)
with much applause (A). The sacred oak, a favorite prop in San Giovanni Grisostomo's depictions
of Roman history, was featured in Act One. Military instruments accompanied the ordination of priests
in the same act, and the trumpets of battle were conspicuous in the final scene of Act Three.

1722/10 Timocrate* Music by Leonardo Leo
[TIMOCRATES]
A dramma per musica Text by Domenico Lalli
i Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1722-12-26
& Dedicated to Johann Philipp Franz of Schenborn

In this round-robin plot, the Cretan king Timocrates (Nicola Grimaldi) was responsible for murdering
the son of the widow Ramira (Vittoria Tesi). Disguised as the warrior Klymenes, he attracted her amorous
interest. Maintaining his disguise, he also tried to court Ramira's daughter, Eriphyle/Erifile (Benedetta
Sorosina), who was officially engaged to Cresphontes (Francesco Guicciardi), Timocrates' rival.
 Timocrate was first performed, with applause, on 26 December 1722 (A); the title-page is dated 1723.
In the curtain-raising first scene, Timocrates emerged from a ship to face the edge of a horrid jungle
(a staple of Sant' Angelo scenery) as military instruments played.

TM4 Walpole was the young son of the Chancellor of the British Exchequer. His father (also Robert; 1676-1743) was a prominent Whig politician.

*8 The prince-bishop of Wiirzburg (1719-24) and duke of Franconia may have been in Venice to recruit musicians (and artists) to his Residenz,

instrumentalist Gio. Battista Platti, a noted oboist and a recognized contributor to the early keyboard sonata, moved from Venice to Wiirzburg
in the same year. The locution principe...d' Erbipoli in the libretto refers to Herbapolis, the famous botanical garden established at Wirzburg

1723/1 Mitridate, re di Ponto, Music by Giovanni Maria Capelli

vincitor di se stesso
[MITHRIDATES, KING OF PONTOS]

A dramma da cantarsi Text by Benedetto Pasqualigo

Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)

With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1723-01-05
wz Without dedicatee

The historical Mithridates (Antonio Bernacchi), the king of Pontos, was a staunch enemy of the Romans.
He invaded the Roman province of Asia (in what is now the southwest part of Turkey) but failed
to conquer it. Pharnakes (Antonio Baldi), his son by his first marriage, was conquered by Julius Caesar.
Xiphares/Sifarre (Antonio Pasi), his son by his second marriage, was put to death. Despite the continuing
war, Mithridates enjoyed a passionate caprice with Ismene (Marianna Laurenzani) on the island of
Ephesos. The story was said to have been derived from Plutarch via Racine.

OO Mitridate was first performed on 5 January 1723 (A). A license to print the libretto had been issued
on 26 December 1722. Although the avvisi (A) report that the work was greeted with universal applause
at its opening, the papal legate's notes (NV) indicate that a disgrace occurred on the same occasion
when a machine which was supposed to be moved prior to a balletto collapsed.*!

A Aria in D-B
Listed as Bonlini 568; Groppo 572; Wiel 213; Alm 720

 The text was essentially the same as that used in Paulati's setting for San Cassiano (1712/8). After

numerous performances (of what is presumed to have been Paulati's setting) on the Italian peninsula,
Albinoni reset the text for the wedding of the electoral prince Karl Albrecht and Maria Amalia of Austria
(Munich, 1722). The production had opened by 30 January 1723 (NV). Licenses to print the libretto
were issued on 7 January 1723 and 8 January 1722 [M.V.]. The libretto for Venice is dated 23 January
1723.

Bajazette Music attributed to Francesco Gasparini**
[BAYEZID]

A tragedia per musica Text attributed to Agostino Piovene
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1723-05-05

Dedicated to Joseph, Prince of Hesse-Darmstadt*

The proud Turkish sultan Bayezid (Giovanni Paita) was defeated by Tamerlane (Francesco Briganti)
at the end of the fourteenth century. This account emphasizes the humiliating servitude into which
Bayezid and his wife were put. As Zamerlano, Gasparini's work had been given at San Cassiano as
1711/3 and in Reggio (fair of 1719). There had been many other productions in northern Italy during
the intervening years. This revival opened on 5 May 1723 (A) with universal applause. The dedicatee
was in attendance (NV). To suit the work better to the theater, Piovene said, the work now ended
with the sultan's death.

1723/6 Gli equivoci d'amore e d'innocenza Music by Francesco Gasparini
[THE MISUNDERSTANDING BETWEEN LOVE AND INNOCENCE]

Pa Dedicated to Giuseppe Maria Pallavicino, Nob. Gen.
O@ Leonora, the queen of Aragon, was given three choices for a possible husband. Her initial choice 

the army general Carlos Sanchez  caused enormous envy between his rivals, Ramirez and Ernesto.
Because the innocence and honesty of her love were demonstrated, the marriage proceeded. The first
Venetian performance of Gli equivoci, given on 24 November 1723 (A), was received with universal
applause. A license to print the libretto had been issued on the 10th. Faustina Bordoni made her first
public appearance in Venice in several years as Leonora. Joining her were Antonio Bernacchi (Sanchez),
Bartolomeo Bartoli (Ramirez), and Antonio Baldi (Ernesto).

1723/7 Armida abbandonata Music by Giuseppe Maria Buini
[ARMIDE ABANDONED]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Silvani
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1723-11-27
a Without dedicatee

In this episode inspired by Tasso's Gerusalemme liberata, the focus is on Rinaldo's magnanimous
flight from the charms of Armide. The location has been changed from the Fortunate Isles to Armide's
enchanted palace near Geoffrey's encampment, which is on a beach. Tancred is imprisoned there.
A ghost of Clorinda appears as an Amazon but does not sing. Some of the principal actions have been
assigned to characters other than those portrayed in Tasso's original.

@< & This version of Armida was first performed on 27 November 1723 (A) with applause. Anna Maria
Mangani sang in the title role with Giovanni Reina (Rinaldo) and Gio. Andrea Tassi (Zancredi). The
magic of Philomachus is depicted in the opening scene in his grotto. In the enchanted-forest scene in
Act Two, Rinaldo is held captive in a giant cypress, from which the ghost of Clorinda also appears.
Silvani's text had been used in Ruggieri's work (1707/9). Buini had earlier recounted the story in
productions at the Teatro Formigliari (Bologna, 1716) and as Armida delusa (1720/3). Some of the
sets in this production may have been recycled from L amore per forza (1721/9).

 This account is substantially less militaristic than Dolfin's, set by Sartorio as 1669/4, Today the Ticino is an Italian-speaking canton in
southeastern Switzerland. Legend holds that Berengar was an ancestor of the House of Sulzbach.

 Le Mercure galant, Nov. 1723, p. 968, suggests the opening date was the 17th, but the relevant avviso, attesting to the universal applause
with which the work was received, was written on the 16th.

' With debts to Silvani's // miglior d'ogni amore per il peggior d'ogni odio (1703/8; cf. Strohm, Opernarien, ii, 168). The tones of the two
works are strikingly different, however.

 Confirmed in Le Mercure galant, Dec. 1723, pp. 1216-7.

 Bonlini claimed that the text was little changed from Ruggieri's setting for Sant' Angelo in 1707, but without an extant full score, this cannot
be confirmed.

Il pid fedel fra gli amici Music by Michel Angelo Gasparini
[THE MOST FAITHFUL OF ALL THE FRIENDS]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giovanni Battista Guizzardi
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With ballo SORTING DATE: 1723-12-26

Dedicated to Camillo Borghese and Agnese ColonnaTM

The plot is loosely related to the campaign of Brennus (Gio. Battista Pinacci) in Ephesos (the ostensible
subject of 1690/1) but is mostly fictional. The victorious king has offered to sacrifice his sister Dori
(Maria Teresa Cotti) to the goddess Diana, but his plans have been thwarted because Prince Ormond
has fallen in love with Dori. The work was first performed on 26 December 1723 (A), when it was
received with universal applause. A license to print the libretto had been issued on 16 December 1723.
Score in D-ROu (seconda)

Listed as Bonlini 575; Groppo 579; Wiel 224; Alm 727

Gli sforzi d'ambizione e d'amore Music by Giovanni Porta
[THE EFFORTS OF AMBITION AND LOVE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Anton Maria Lucchini
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1724-01-05

Without dedicatee

In this fictional tale, Abanrides murdered the king Klyneas/Clinea, married his widow Nicaea (Anna
Maria Mangani), and was then himself killed. Nicaea was attracted to the young Aletes (Bartolmeo
Straparapa), who was actually the princess Kyllene/Cilene (Francoise Le Brett), her son's mistress,
in disguise. Meanwhile, Pharnakes (Gaetano Pinetti), Nicaea's prime minister, disguised his own son,
the true Aletes, as Nicaea's son, Aratos (Gio. Antonio Reina), in the hope that he would succeed to
the throne.

Gli sforzi was first performed on 5 January 1724 (A, NV), when it was received with universal applause
(A). It was still running on 8 February, when the Dutch merchant Jan Alensoon found the music to be
reasonably good but the singers, excepting the Florentine Mangani, mediocre.* Alensoon was himself
described in a caricature by Pier Leone Ghezzi (30 May 1724) as a Dutchman who travels the earth
to find...singers and instrumentalists to [teach him]...to sing well....His voice is so frightening it makes
people laugh; he sings bass and falsetto at the same time.*

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 576; Groppo 580; Wiel 228; Alm 728

1724/2 Ipermestra Music by Geminiano Giacomelli
[HYPERMNESTRA]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Antonio Salvi!
im Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1724-02-05
& Without dedicatee

The Egyptian prince Danaos (Gio. Battista Pinazzi), who had 50 daughters, sailed to Argos after a dispute
with his brother Aigyptos/Egito, who had 50 sons. While there he was told by an oracle that in his absence
his nephews would usurp the throne. He advocated that his daughters should wed their cousins
simultaneously and then stab their husbands on their wedding night. All the daughters obeyed except
Hypermnestra (Faustina Bordoni), who spared her cousin, the argonaut Lynceus (Antonio Bernacchi),
on account of his kindness.'"

ros1@) The first Venetian performance of Jpermestra was given on 5 February 1724 (A, NV). Alensoon, who
heard this work performed on 10 February, found the music difficult and the scenery inappropriate
but he praised the singers. He described Faustina Bordoni (/permestra) as the greatest singer then known,
Antonio Bernacchi (Linceo) as a high alto (hoogen alt) castrato, Bartolomeo Bartoli (Nicandro) as
a beautiful high soprano (schoone hooge Cant), and Gio. Battista Pinazzi (Danao) as a beautiful
(fraje) tenor.' Alensoon attended further performances on February 12, 17, 18, 20, 24, and 26.

a) The merchant also found many opportunities to meet Faustina Bordoni in private. These included a
concert at the home of Heer Molesworth, the English envoy to Turin, on the 11th; on the Grand Canal,
in the company of her singing teacher, Michel Angelo Gasparini, on the 14th; at her lodgings, on March
2nd; and in undetermined circumstances on March 7th.

- Salvi's text was set subsequently by several other Italian composers including Vivaldi (Florence, 1727).
Giacomelli's setting is said to have first been performed (at the Teatro Ducale, Parma) when the composer
was only eighteen years old [c. 1710], but no libretto survives.' A revival was given in Pesaro in 1733.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Upon the encouragement of the newly widowed Phythia/Fizia (Anna Maria Mangani), Antigonos
(Gaetano Pinetti), a duplicitous nobleman, was about to be crowned king of Macedonia when it is
discovered that the late king Demetrios had a surviving son, Philip (Gio. Antonio Reina). Philip, who
had been tutored by Socrates and Zeno, was now disguised, for reasons of security, as Amyntas/Aminta.
Although the outline of the text is attributed to Polybius and Plutarch, the unsigned argomento in the
libretto lamented that this version of the tragedy was written only as an entertainment, which is presently
adapted to the musical theater with the customary repugnant accommodations to that situation.!
Antigono opened on 15 February 1724 (NV). Alensoon, who attended a performance on the 19th, reported
that the work was completed by Porta after Albinoni was reported to be mortally ill.' According to
the merchant's report, Porta served as harpsichordist; Anna Maria Mangani was an artistic first lady.
Alensoon attended another performance of the work on the 27th.'

Aria in D-ROu

Listed as Bonlini 578; Groppo 582; Wiel 229; Alm 730

Scipione nelle Spagne Music by Tomaso Albinoni
[SCIPIO IN SPAIN]

A dramma per musica Text by Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1724-05-17
Without dedicatee

Zeno's libretto, previously set by Caldara for performance in Vienna in 1722, took as its background
the Roman conquest, under Scipio Africanus the Elder, of the Carthaginians in Spain. Scipio (Gio. Battista
Minelli) was captivated by the slave Sophonisba (Marianna Laurenzani), who was the daughter of the
captain of the Carthaginian forces. This version was significantly reduced to suit the limited scope of
Ascension operas. Scipione opened on 24 May (NV), the eve of Ascension, with universal applause
and ran for eighteen days (A) with good reviews and the attendance of many foreign visitors (NV).
A license to print the libretto had been issued on the 17th. Scarlatti's setting had been given in Naples
in the winter of 1713-14.'%

Laodice Music by Tomaso Albinoni
[LAODIKE]

A dramma per musica (5) Text attributed to Angelo Schietti
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With Li servi di corte SORTING DATE: 1724-10-14
Without dedicatee

After conquering the Scythians, Mithridates occupied Cappadocia and almost all of Greece. In this
improvisation on history, when he returned to his realm he found it in disarray. His sister and wife,
Laodike, had given birth to a son who was not his. This encouraged Gordias, the captain of his guard,
to scheme to overthrow Mithridates. Elements of the story resonate with those of Frigimelica-Roberti's
Mitridate Eupatore (1707/3) and Zeno's Mitridate (1729/12).

Laodice was first performed on 14 October 1724 (NV). A license to print the libretto had been issued
on 7 October 1724. The work (an unusually ambitious one for San Moise) was received with universal
applause (A) and was still running on 11 November. Anna Tessieri (nicknamed La Gird), then aged
fourteen, made her Venetian debut as Kleisthenes/Clistene.' Another Mantuan, Chiara Orlandi, sang
in the title role, with Angelo Maria Cantelli (Mitridate) and Felice Novelli (Gordio). The Mauro brothers
 Sebastiano, Antonio, and Gasparo had rented the theater from Almor6 Giustinian in July, apparently
for 400 ducats a year.'' Laodice and II nemico amante became the subjects of litigation brought by
the impresario Antonio Gaspari.'"

Arias in I-CF

Listed as Bonlini 580; Groppo 584; Wiel 226; Alm 732

Il nome glorioso in terra, santificato in cielo. Cf. Suppl. 5a.

Armida al campo. Cf. Suppl. 3a.

[ANTIGONE]

Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With Con la burla da dovero; changed to Despina e Niso'? SORTING DATE: 1724-11-07

Without dedicatee

This fully staged version of 1721/1 opened on 7 November 1724 (A, NV; Le Mercure galant, Dec. 1724,
p. 264), which was also the date on which a license to print the libretto was granted. Despite its having
been a production concocted in haste and based on a fourth edition of the libretto, Antigona was received
with universal applause (A). The cast included Lucia Lanzetta in the title role, with Teresa Peruzzi
(La Denzia; Giocasta) and Nicola Grimaldi (Osmene).

No musical sources known

1724/8 Il trionfo della virti Music by Gio. Francesco Brusa'!*
[THE TRIUMPH OF VIRTUE]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Pietro d'Averara
MM Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1724-11-18
& Dedicated to Marco Contarini, Nob. Ven.'!%

The conflict that pitted the Roman citizen Sulla against Marius, the leader of the plebes, produced a
strange outcome: after accruing more and more power to himself, Sulla suddenly declared a truce with
his enemy. The motivation was Sulla's aspiration to enable his son Elius Faustus to wed Alba Cornelia
in the face of a condition sought by the prospective bride's father, Titus Scipio, that Sulla restore the
tules of government of the Republic. D' Averara's eight roles were reduced to six to suit the needs

Tl nemico amanteTMTM Music attributed to Fortunato Chelleri
[THE INIMICAL LOVER] and Giuseppe Maria Buini
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Angelo Schietti
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
With Li servi di corte SORTING DATE: 1724-12-09~

Dedicated to Gio. Battista Fagia'?!

This variant of La pace per amore (1719/9) concerned the political conflict between Arsakes (who never
appears) and Adrastos (Felice Novello), heightened by the vacillating amorous intentions of the latter
towards Idalma (Anna Gir) and Berenice (Stella Fortunata Cantelli). The denouement employed as
its device the revelation of a mistaken identity. The work opened in the opulent temple of Osiris, where
the Persian prince Klymenes (alias Florio; the role was taken by the impresario Antonio Gaspari) abducted
Idalma on the beach at Tyre.

This production of this second opera opened between 9 and 16 December 1724 (A); the title-page
was dated 1724. Gaspari served as the impresario at San Moise throughout the autumn and winter seasons
of 1724-25, according to notarized papers filed by two members of current San Moise casts  Stella
Fortunata and her father, Angelo Maria Cantelli (Lucrino)  concerning II nemico amante and Laodice
(1724/5).' Stella Cantelli was apparently unhappy with her role. On some evenings when she and
her father failed to appear, the musicians who were present sang their arias.'?

1724/12 La Didone abbandonata* Music by Tomaso Albinoni
[DIDO ABANDONED]
A tragedia per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio'

With Brunetta e Barilotto' SORTING DATE: 1724-12-26
a Without dedicatee

In Virgil's familiar account, Aeneas was captivated by Dido, the founder and queen of Carthage. Although
she reciprocated his love, he felt compelled by duty to sail for Italy. Abandoned, she cursed the Trojan
cause and threw herself on a funeral pyre.

oo This production of Didone, the first in Venice based on a text by Metastasio, opened on 26 December
1724 (A).'" Its very great success in Venice, Florence and Milan was reported in the Mercure galant.'
Groppo added an uncharacteristic note of praise.'*? Marianna Benti Bulgarelli (La Romanina) was
cast as the tragic heroine, with Nicola Grimaldi as Aeneas. The same principals appeared in a production
in Reggio in the spring of 1725.'** Giovanni Orsato, whose previous services to Sant' Angelo are heavily
satirized in Marcello's // teatro alla moda (1720), served as impresario at San Cassiano in 1724-25.

 Recent discoveries by Miggiani suggest that the heroine was promised 2,400 for the season at San
Cassiano. Her fee was to be paid in three installments, but only the first was provided punctually. She
therefore threatened to quit the production. Her grievances were publicized ina satirical work, L opera
in commedia, published without date in Amsterdam.'*

Berenice' Music by Giuseppe Maria Orlandini
[BERENICE]

A dramma da cantarsi Text by Benedetto Pasqualigo'
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1725-01-20
Without dedicatee

The aspirations of the young Palestinian queen Berenice (Faustina Bordoni) and the powerful Roman
conqueror Titus (Carlo Scalzi) were threatened by the plan of Titus's father, Vespasian, to see his son
married to the noble Roman virgin Lavinia (Antonia Merighi). In a series of conflicts between love
and duty, Berenice, after following Titus to Rome, returned to her homeland. After his father died, the
Senate insisted upon Titus's marriage to Lavinia. To facilitate the marriage, Domitian (Gio. Carlo
Bernardi) persuaded the senators to declare Berenice an honorary citizen. In a show of virtue, she declared
Titus free to marry whom he must. To rise to the same moral level, Titus renounced marriage altogether.
Lavinia then married Domitian, who succeeded Titus as emperor [81-96 AD].

Berenice opened on 20 January 1725 (NV). The title-page indication for inverno 1726 appears to
be completely in error. Among unusual elements of the staging, the third act opened in a picture-gallery;
the River Tiber was seen in the finale; and one of the dances featured barbarian instruments (strumenti
barbareschi). Despite its ambitions, Berenice had a short run. Musical excerpts from Berenice were
used in Handel's pastiche Elpidia (HWV A1), which had its London premiere on 11 May 1725.
Score in B-Be; arias in B-Le; GB-Lgc, Ob; I-Vnm

Listed as Bonlini 588; Groppo 592; Wiel 233; Alm 739

ruler in Spain. The opening of Gli sdegni, which was delayed by personnel problems, apparently took
place shortly after 30 January 1724 M.V. with a depleted cast.'** The announced cast included Antonio
Gaspari (Rodrigo), Chiara Orlandini (his wife, Esilena), and Anna Gird (Evanco, the son of his enemy).
The dedicatee was so impressed with the singing of Anna Giro that he gave her 60 zecchini.'* She spent
half the money to buy a harpsichord made by Domenico da Pesaro. Gird's mentor, Antonio Vivaldi,
was accused of pocketing the other half, but the charges against him were later dropped.'TM
Gaspari's legal affidavits of 31 January give a vivid picture of the conflict between himself (as impresario)
and some of the singers. He complained that Angelo Maria Cantelli (Fernando) and his daughter, Stella
Fortunata Cantelli (Florinda), arrived for both the autumn and Carnival productions unprepared. Many
of his remarks alluded to the production of // nemico amante (1724/9), although he implied that all the
productions at San Moise (presumably including Laodice [1724/5] and Agide [1724/13] ) were affected.
He complained of the performers' insults and prejudices, their premature departures from rehearsals,
their having implicated him in a scandal, the poor example they set for other musicians, the fact that
they wanted changes in the arias and recitatives after the libretti had been printed, and that Stella Cantelli
pretended to have lost her voice on one occasion and sang in a low voice on others. On some evenings
she did not sing the arias but failed to advise other singers to take them in her place. He deferred the
start of Gli sdegni cangiati until such time as the Cantelli promised to be punctual.

Gaspari further objected to the announced departure of Felice Novelli (Giuliano) for Germany and Prague
with Antonio Denzio, given that Novelli had signed a contract for the autumn and winter seasons on
the preceding 27 March [1724]. Gaspari expected him to return by 20 May [1725]. He warned all three
singers that they would be required to repay his own losses should they further fail to meet their
contractual obligations.'**

L'amor eroico Music by Giovanni Francesco Brusa
[HEROIC LOVE]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Pietro Pariati
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1725-05-09

Dedicated to Edward Cary'**

Septimus Odaenathus/Odenato, the king of Palmyra, who was long a secret admirer of the Assyrian
princess Zenobia, refused an offer to marry the Persian princess Aspasia. Incensed, Aspasia's father
sent his general, Pharnakes, to declare war. Odaenathus won the battle, but in order to win the hand
of Zenobia he had to defeat her alter ego, a military captain, in battle.'*' L amor eroico opened on 9
May 1725, the eve of Ascension, and was expected to run for sixteen days (NV). A license to print
the libretto had been issued on 30 April. The text had been set as Zenobia e Radamisto, with music
by Fortunato Chelleri, for the emperor Charles VI (Barcelona, 1709).

L'inganno trionfante in amore Music partly by Antonio Vivaldi
[THE DECEPTION TRIUMPHANT IN LOVE]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Matteo Noris by Gio. Maria Ruggieri
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1725-11-17~

Dedicated to Stefano Pallavicino'

The plot, set previously by Perti as Laodicea e Berenice (1694/8), focuses on the attack of Antiochos
on Ptolemy. As an enticement to peace, the princess Cleonike was promised as a bride to the Egyptian
tuler. Ptolemy rightly suspected, however, that the claim made by Antiochos that Stresicreia was his
friend but not his wife was false. To make his boast appear to be true, however, Antiochos went through
the motions of banishing her. Misunderstanding his motives, Stresicreia ordered the death of Cleonike.'
The anticipated date of opening was 10 November 1725 (NV). A much later opening (shortly before
15 December) is suggested elsewhere (A). The Diario ordinario, perhaps judging by the expectation,
says it had opened by 24 November.' Writing on the 28th, Owen Swiney was critical of the small

1725/9 Turia Lucrezia Music by Antonio Pollarolo
[TuRIA LUCRETIA]
A dramma per musica Text by Domenico Lalli
rd Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1725-12-27
& Dedicated to Lothar Franz, Count of Schenborn'*

The ever-faithful Turia Lucretia sought to conceal the whereabouts of her husband, Quintus Lucretius,
by wandering through the streets of Rome tearfully calling for him and petitioning the Triumvirate to
free him. A spurious subplot, in which the young Lepidus fell in love with the heroine, was added to
this historical skeleton by Lalli.

Oe Turia Lucrezia was first performed on 27 December 1725 (A, NV), when it received common applause
(A); the dedication was signed on the preceding day. A license to print the libretto had been issued
on the 12th. The underground passage in which Quintus was hidden was shown in the opening and
closing scenes. The second act featured a library adorned with local and world maps.

Dedicated to Thomas Kirkpatrick'

This revised version of the work earlier produced at Sant' Angelo (1701/4) was in production by 28
December 1725, when Owen Swiney wrote that Teresa Zannucchi (Climene) was a beautiful figure,
in mens cloathes; acts well; does not sing amiss; but her voice is indifferent.'** Giovanni Dreyer sang

Cunegonda Music attributed to Antonio Vivaldi
[KUNEGUNDA]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Agostino Piovene
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1726-01-29
Without dedicatee

This account was derived from the work set by Gasparini as La principessa fedele (1709/8). The
production opened on 29 January 1726 (NV) with greater than usual satisfaction (A).'* Although
the text had been used before, a new license to print the libretto was issued on 22 January. Costanza
Posterla sang in the title role with Innocenzio Baldini (Ridolfo) and Luca Mingoni (Aladin).'*' The visual
conception appears to have been entirely different from that of Gasparini's earlier work. The principal
scenes of Act Two, for example, occurred in the harem (serraglio) in which Kunegunda was confined
during her African captivity.

Although Voltaire is not known to have had any knowledge of this work or its predecessor, the princess
Cunegonde of his satire Candide (1759) had adventures not unlike those related here. After her abduction
to South America, Cunegonde reappeared as a Muslim slave in Constantinople and was able to rescue
Candide in Egypt. In Voltaire's work, many opinions about Venetian opera were expressed by the
nobleman Pococurante [Doer of Nothing] at his country estate on the Brenta.

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 599; Groppo 603; Wiel 251; Alm 752; RV 707

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1720-29) 385

Siroes, the older son of Chosroes/Cosroe, and his brother Medarses each wanted to succeed to the Persian
throne.'** In this account the present king, Chosroes, having defeated Ashite, the king of Cambaia, became
the object of the revenge of Ashite's daughter, Emira. Assuming the male persona Idaspe, she became
Chosroes' political confidante. Her schemes resulted in his order to have his older, well-regarded son
Siroes, who was in love with Emira, executed. She confessed her true identity just in time to prevent
Medarses from killing his father. The action took place in Seleukia.

When Siroe was first performed on 2 February 1726 (NV) it elicited universal satisfaction (A). The
title-page was dated 1726; a license to print the libretto had been issued on 27 January 1725 [M.V.].
A report of the 20th in the Diario ordinario said that its applause was ever greater (sempre piit
grande).' Groppo, writing 41 years later, said the work made the name of its librettist immortal.'

In a letter of 16 February 1726, Metastasio wrote, My Siroe is praised much more than Didone was
last year.!' Bonlini echoed his report, saying that Siroe was universally appreciated and made the
name of its author immortal.! The cast featured Giovanni Paita (Cosroe), Nicola Grimaldi (Siroe),
Giovanni Carestini (Medarse), and Marianna Benti Bulgarelli (Emira). The scenery for this production
was designed by Marco Ricci and painted by the veteran Romualdo Mauro. The scenery topics were
nonetheless traditional and included an opening venue in the temple of the Sun, a royal park, and a
large town square, as well as various interior rooms.

Metastasio's text was reset by Vivaldi (RV 735) for productions in Reggio (spring 1727'%), Ancona
(summer 1738), and Ferrara (December 1738'). It was reset by Manna as 1743/4. Handel's setting
of an adaptation by Haym (HWV 24) had an ill-fated London premiere on 17 February 1728, when
it ran head-to-head with the first ballad opera to be given in England, The Beggar's Opera by John
Gay and Christopher Pepusch.

Listed as Bonlini 600; Groppo 604; Wiel 244; Alm 753, 754

I rivali generosi Music by Giuseppe Vignatti2
[THE GENEROUS RIVALS]

A dramma per musica Text derived from Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With Ceriletta e Tropotipo; balli SORTING DATE: 1726-05-26
Without dedicatee

In this text, which had been set by Marc' Antonio Ziani for San Salvatore (1697/3), Italy was ruled by
the tyrannical Visigothic king Vittigis (Angelo Zannoni). Belisarius (Giuseppe Ristorini) subdued the
enemy in Ravenna. The king's inability to forget his love for Elpidia (Vittoria Tesi), princess of Puglia,
precipitated new discord among her several admirers.

I rivali was first performed on 26 May 1726 (A, NV), the Sunday before Ascension. It closed on
13 June (NV). A license to print the libretto had been issued on 22 May. Swiney considered it the
worst [opera] I have ever heard, despite the fact that Nicola Grimaldi (Olindo) and Vittoria Tesi acted
very well in it.? Handel and Nicola Haym combined portions of the 1697 work with newer arias to
create the pastiche Elpidia overo Gli rivali generosi(HWV A1) for performance at the King's Theatre,
London, in May 1725.

Listed as Bonlini 604; Groppo 608; Wiel 260; Alm 758

Le frenesie d'amore Music attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini
[THE MADNESS OF LOVE]

A divertimento [comico] per musica Text attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1726-05-26
Without dedicatee

Le frenesie d'amore was the first Bolognese comic opera to be given in Venice. As /I savio delirante
it had been given during Carnival of the same year at the Teatro Formigliari in Bologna. It was amodern
adaptation of the commedia dell'arte. Set in Bologna, it features a learned but dramatically static
Doctor, the singing teacher Lindoro, the dilettante Flema, an old woman (Crespa), and her (mute)
serving maid (Zirina).** The staging emphasizes distinctions of social class: Bolognese dialect is
employed by the less well-educated characters, such as Crespa.

Le frenesie was first performed in Venice on 26 May 1726 (A, NV).2 It closed on 13 June (NV). In
what was to become the norm for early comic opera, it was performed by a troupe whose names were
not given in the libretto. Since singers for serious opera worked on individual contracts, it is possible
that the work was sung by comedians. On 22 May the financial debts of the Mauro (Antonio and
Gasparo), which reached back to 1722, were the subject of discussion before the Council of Ten. A

Vignatti was maestro di cappella of the court in Milan.

Imeneo in Atene Music by Nicold Porpora
[HYMENAEUS IN ATHENS]

A componimento dramatico Text by Silvio Stampiglia
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Summer (Assumption)
With Ceriletta e Tropotipo," balli SORTING DATE: 1726-09-20

Without dedicatee?

The young Hymenaeus, being of lowly estate, saw no chance of marrying the young noblewoman
Chlomyris/Clomiri with whom he had fallen in love. On one occasion, when an assembly of women
was attacked by a marauding group of corsairs, Hymenaeus killed the villains and liberated all the women
on the condition that he be permitted to marry his beloved. From this incident he came to symbolize
a happy groom. His name was frequently invoked at weddings.

Imeneo was first performed in Venice on 20 September 1726 (NV), specifically to coincide with the
continuing visit of Cardinal Ottoboni. A license to print the libretto had been issued on the 14th. Jmeneo
had ten performances, the last having been on 2 October (following a regatta).?? This work received
universal applause (A). Antonia Merighi sang in the title role, with Lucrezia Baldini as Chlomyris.
Imeneo had had its premiere in Naples in 1723. The text enjoyed modest popularity and was later set
by Terradellas (Venice, 1750/4) and Jommelli (Ludwigsburg, 1765).

1726/9 Dorilla in Tempe Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[DoRILLA IN THE TEMPE GORGE]
A melodramma eroico-pastorale Text by Anton Maria Lucchini
tr Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1726-11-09
& Dedicated to Count Antonio San Bonifacio

The Tempe River gorge, which lay between Mts. Olympus and Ossa, separated Thessaly from Macedonia.
In this anachronistic plot, the setting is pastoral and there are no historical associations, although there
is a token role for Admetos (Lorenzo Moretti), the king of Thessaly. His daughter Dorilla (Angela
Capuano) was loved both by Nomio and by Elmiro (Maria Maddalena Pieri). Elmiro was pursued by
the nymph Eudamia (Anna Gird), who in turn was loved by Filindo. Nomio revealed himself to be Apollo
and blessed the unions of both Dorilla with Elmiro and of Eudamia with Filindo.

OOn Dorilla was first performed on 9 November 1726 (A, NV)," the date of dedication of the libretto. A
report of the 16th states that Dorilla was enjoying much greater attendance than the work at San Moise
(L'amor indovino, 1726/8). Dorilla was produced at the theater of Count FrantiSek Antonin von Sportk
in Prague in the spring of 1732.'* A revised version was later given at Sant' Angelo (1734/2).?

218 Sporek (1662-1738 ) was the High Commissioner of Bohemia. His family's estate at Lysa (on the Elbe some twenty miles from Prague)
encouraged him to visit Dresden and Leipzig, where he became acquainted with the music of J. S. Bach, from whom he commissioned four
masses. He was also a great fan of the corno da caccia. He was a prolific author and patron of works on religion and philosophy. This led
to his indictment for violation of Bohemia's strict censorship laws and the confiscation of his vast library in the early 1730s.

The text was a modified version of Gasparini's Flavio Anicio Olibrio (1708/3). It recounted the story
of Ricimer (Andrea Pacini), the liberation of his sister, Theodelinda (Lucia Facchinelli), and his
enslavement of Placidia (Anna d' Ambreville), the daughter of Valentinian. The title role (Diana Vico)
belonged to the general of the Roman army, who loved Placidia. The production opened on 25 November
1726 (A), when it elicited universal applause.! A license to print the libretto, which was dedicated
on the 23rd, had been issued on the 17th. Swiney praised the text, the music, and the performances
of Pacini and Vico.

Il trionfo d'Armida Music by Tomaso Albinoni
[THE TRIUMPH OF ARMIDE]

A dramma per musica Text by Girolamo Colatelli
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Advent (St. Andrew's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1726-12-02
Without dedicatee

Albinoni came late to this popular First-Crusade subject. Colatelli commented that he had moderated
the character of Armide to be modest rather than lascivious, in comparison to his earlier treatment
of the same story, set by Orgiani as L 'onor al cimento (1703/2). II trionfo was first performed on
2 December 1726 (A) before a great number of persons, among whom many are likely to have been
Neapolitan. A license to print the libretto was issued on 29 November. No cast list was given, perhaps
reflecting the restrictions of the theater, to which reference is made in the dedication.

Meride e Selinunte Music by Nicold PorporaTM*
[MERIS AND SELINUNTE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1726-12-26
Without dedicatee

In this tale of ancient Sicily, Meris/Meride, having killed a Syracusan noble, was sentenced to death
by King Dionysios, but his friend Selinunte offered to accept Meris's punishment in her place. Both
men loved Herikleia/Ericlea, the princess of Taormina, as did Timocrates, the king's aid.

Meride opened in Venice on 26 December 1726 (A), when it received applause. The title-page was
dated 1727. Licenses to print the libretto had been issued on 19 and 20 December. The Diario ordinario
of 18 January [1727] noted that Meride e Selimante [sic], in common with other works which had recently

Medea e Giasone Music by Francesco Brusa
[MEDEA AND JASON]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giovanni Palazzi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1726-12-27
Without dedicatee

In Greek mythology, the magician Medea's bewitching love for Jason enabled him to steal the golden
fleece. This account portrayed Jason's background, depicted the horrid forest in which Medea's
enchanted castle lay, and provided a role for Hypsipyle, the friendly queen of the island of Lemnos.
Medea was first performed on 27 December 1726 (A), when it received applause. It was still playing
toa full house on 18 January [1727]. A license to print the libretto had been issued on 22 December
1726. The cast included Angela Capuano (Medea), Maria Maddalena Pieri (Giasone), and Anna Gird
(Ussifile).

No musical sources known

L'Adalvaldo furioso Music by Giacomo Maccari
[ADALWALD IN A FuRY]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Anton Maria Lucchini
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1727-01-07
Without dedicatee

While the Lombard kingdom was under the joint rule of the widow Theodelinda and her son Adalwald
[d. 626], the Roman emperor Heraclius schemed to undermine the loyalty of the Lombard army.
Heraclius's ambassador exploited Adalwald's youthful interests in gambling, feasting, and going to
the baths. After gaining his confidence, Heraclius then offered him a potion which caused Adalwald
to kill twelve of his princes in a mad frenzy.! Adalvaldo, which indirectly mocked the excesses of
Carnival, was first performed on 7 January 1727 (A, NV), when it produced common satisfaction

Aldiso* Music by Giovanni Porta
[ALDIso]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Claudio Nicola StampaTM
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1727-02-02
Without dedicatee

Aldiso took the Indies as its setting. The hero (Lucia Facchinelli) inherited the throne of Cambaia,
the most florid of Indies cities, but thereby excited the envy of his uncle Mexanes (Andrea Pacini),
who disguised himself as his nephew in order to be confirmed as the new king. Aldiso's mother, the
Amazon Oronta (Diana Vico), devised a way to end the tyranny of Mexanes.

San Giovanni's last drama of the season opened on 8 February 1727 (NV).TM The title-page was dated
1726. A license to print the libretto was issued on 2 February 1727 (for 1726). The Diario ordinario
carried a report on the 15th which said that A/deo [sic] was one of the most beautiful works which had
been given in a long time. On the 23rd, Antonio Conti wrote that the decorations were better than
those of the preceding work [Meride; 1726/12] but that the poetry (composition) was so detestable
and the music so sad that he slept through an entire act.

Arias in D-Dlb; I-Vnm (terza)

Listed as Bonlini 614; Groppo 618; Wiel 246; Alm 768

Farnace' Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[PHARNAKES]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Anton Maria Lucchini?
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1727-02-10
Without dedicatee

Pharnakes, a son of Mithridates, was killed by his own sword in battle with the Romans. In retaliation,
his angry father sent troops to occupy Cappadocia, which was ruled by the widowed queen Berenice.
She became indignant after the abduction of her daughter Thamyris, sided with the Romans, and sought
the total destruction of Pharnakes.

The version of this work corresponding to the UCLA libretto 770 for Carnevale, the music in I-Tn
MS Giordano 36, and the printing licence issued on 5 February 1727 opened on 10 February 1727 (A,
NV). The title-page and score are dated 1726. The production of a revised version in the autumn of
1727 (corresponding to UCLA 779 and I-Tn MS Giordano 37) cannot be verified from the sources used

in this study. The alternative version may have been prefigured in a setting given (with anonymous

() Vivaldi was described in the libretto as the celebrated maestro employed by Prince Philip of Hesse-
Darmstadt. The cast included Maria Maddalena Pieri (Farnace), Angela Capuano (Berenice), and Anna
Gird (amiri). Farnace opened with an elaborate woodland scene in which Berenice's army could be
seen in the distance. Antonio Conti greatly preferred Vivaldi's Farnace to Porta's Aldiso (1727/2).
He found the libretto to be passable and the music to be very varied in its [achievement of] the sublime
and its [treatment of] the tender. When he sought in March to send arias from the work to Madame
de Caylus in Paris, he cited their vivacity and variety. Despite his enthusiasm, he nonetheless found
these arias to be inferior to the Psalms of Benedetto Marcello.

 Lucrezia Baldini, who had made her Venetian debut at San Samuele as Rosmilda in J rivali generosi
(1726/5), appeared here as Selinda. However, the complaints she filed with a notary suggest that the
production of Farnace as a third opera at Sant' Angelo may have been substituted for that of another
(La Venetia nascente, on a text by Benedetto Pasqualigo), in which she was to have sung.

- Farnace was produced, probably with revisions by Antonio Denzio, in the spring of 1730 at the theater
of Count Sporek in Prague. It found great approval there, according to a libretto annotation by Count
Wrtby.TM? Four other operas by Vivaldi were given in Prague over the next two years. Several singers
and instrumentalists previously active at Sant' Angelo (possibly including Vivaldi) participated in these
performances. Anna Gird sang in a number of later productions of Farnace (Pavia, May 1731; Mantua,
late January 1732; Treviso, c. 1737).TM*5 Vivaldi cancelled a production planned for the second opera
slot of Carnival 1739 in the Teatro Bonacossi in Ferrara after the first opera, a revival of his Siroe,
received a poor reception. Lucchini's text had a life of its own. It far surpassed in its durability the
earlier accounts of Morari and Lalli. It was performed in Spain and Portugal, in Belgium and Germany,
and in most cities of the Italian peninsula. Among its most notable later settings were those of Porta
(Bologna, 1731), Perez (Turin, 1751), Traetta (Naples, 1751), and Sarti (San Samuele, 1776).

In this altered version of the story as given by Herodotus, the widowed Spartan king Aristaios wanted

1727/5 L'incostanza schernita Music by Tomaso Albinoni
[INCONSTANCY DERIDED]
A dramma comico-pastorale Text by Vincenzo Cassani
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With Grilletta e PorsugnaccoTMTM and balli SORTING DATE: 1727-05-21
& Dedicated to Clement Augustus, Electoral Prince of Bavaria**!

Philander (Pio Annibale Fabbri) was voyaging abroad in search of amorous conquests when his ship
capsized off the coast of Kythera, where Aphrodite (Venus) resided.?* Supposing it to be an island
of shepherds, he was taken in by Uranius (Domenico Annibale) but made the tactical error of falling
in love first with Orsinda (Livia Bassi), the beloved of his host, and then with Corina (Giovanna
Gasparini; see below), the beloved of Daphnis (Antonio Pasi).

 L'incostanza was first performed on 21 May 1727 (A), the eve of Ascension, when it was received
with applause.* It appears to be the work in which Antonio Conti anticipated the debut of a woman
the likes of whom we have never seen. She is famous for her beauty and for her coqueteries.** Later
references suggest that the singer was Giovanna Gasparini.

OOv Cassani complained in the dedication that he was forced to reorganize the parts, cut entire scenes,
throw out the best arias, and make other compromises to accommodate the restrictions of time, the
wishes of the singers, and the music itself. A particular cause for eliminating scenes was to allow time
for the intermezzi, balli, cori, and other noble decorations ofa popular season. The brevity of spring
nights exacerbated the other problems, and he lamented the fact that all of these circumstances, which
rendered his work a sterile fantasy, might deprive the elector of his due glory. The fact that the work

25! Also the Archbishop of Cologne (1723-61). He was the son of Maximilian II Emanuel and of Theresa Kunegunda Sobieska as well as the
brother of the later emperor Charles VII. A recognized patron of arts, he authorized the construction of two palaces in Briihl.

252 In addition to being the legendary home of Aphrodite, Cythera/Kythera, an Ionian island first settled by Phoenicians but largely ruled by
Spartans in antiquity, was governed by the Venetian Republic from 1717 until 1797. Its honey was greatly prized. The setting also poses a
modern irony: among the recently discovered spoils of an ancient shipwreck off nearby Antikythera lie the remains of an astronomical calendar
with gears, dials, and hands used for tracking the positions of the sun and heavenly bodies as well as phases of the moon. The Antikythera
mechanism, as it is currently called, is by far the most advanced instrument for the measurement of time surviving from antiquity.

Albumazar Music attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini
[ALBUMAZAR]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini***
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With a ballo* SORTING DATE: 1727-05-21

Without dedicatee

The Turkish ruler Albumazar was in port on the shores of the Aegean, where his followers made a practice
of luring ships and capturing their occupants. The envoy Alsakides was sent to make treaties with the
stranded princes of the captured ships. During his stay a storm caused the wreck ofa small boat carrying
the singer Cirilla, who was en route to Catania (Sicily) in order to appear in an opera. With her were
her parents, Pomata from Bologna and Maroca from Florence.?*

This musical satire (justly called a scherzo musicale in the note to the reader) was first performed on
21 May 1727, when it was received with applause (A, NV).** A license to print the libretto was issued
on 10 May 1727. Like L'incostanza schernita, it was variously reported to have closed on 1 (DO) or
8 (NV) June. Both works were received with full applause. Pomata sang in Bolognese dialect. His
imitation of his daughter's dancing enticed the king to take lessons. The king then enlisted Pomata's
help in carrying a love-message to Cirilla, but first he required his new emissary to dress as a Turk and
to learn a few words of Turkish.

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 618; Groppo 622; Wiel 272; Alm 773

Le Srenesie d'amore Music attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini
[THE MADNESS OF LOVE]

A divertimento per musica Text attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini
Performed at San Salvatore SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1727-06-01

Without dedicatee

This revival of 1726/6 played during the Ascension season of 1727. Since it is not mentioned by name
(in A, NV, or DO), it may have succeeded A/bumazar, with an opening on 1 June. Its run would have
been very brief. Le frenesie may have been the object of a reference by Antonio Conti to the prospect
of a species of comic opera...ofa completely ridiculous nature, in consequence of which. ..[itis] very
agreeable in this country, where they do not know how to laugh philosophically.?*'

Il Bertarido, re de' longobardi Music by Giuseppe Boniventi
[BERTARIDE, KING OF THE LOMBARDS]

A dramma per musica Text derived from Antonio Salvi
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With La cantatrice;? balli SORTING DATE: 1727-10-25
Without dedicatee

Several accounts of the affairs of the Lombard kingdom after the death of Aribert had been given in
earlier operas. In this treatment, which is more fanciful than that of Flavio Bertaride (1705/8), after
Bertaride fled and was taken in by the king of Hungary, false rumors of his death were circulated.
Bertarido opened on 25 October 1727 (NV). It was still running on 15 November. A license to print
the libretto had been issued on the 12th. Filippo Finazzi sang in the title role, with Rosa Croce as his
mother (Rodelinda), Teresa Zanardi as his sister (Edvige), and Alessandro Veroni as his prospective
brother-in-law (Grimoaldo). One ballo was performed by Moscovites and Flemings.TM Corneille's
account (Pertharite, 1651) had been adapted by Haym for Handel's Rodelinda, regina de' Longobardi
(HWV 19, 1725).

Il regno galante Music by Giovanni Reali?
[THE GALLANT REIGN]

A melodramma per musica Text by Michel Angiolo Boccardi
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With Serpilla e Pillone* and balli SORTING DATE: 1727-11-08

Dedicated to Antonio Ferdinando Gonzaga, Duke of Guastalla

In this tale from Greek mythology, after Theseus (Felice Castelli) killed the minotaur, he fell in love
with various Amazons, among them Anthiope (Teresa Peruzzi, La Denzia) and Thomyris (Rosa Giacinta
del Maino). The region around Themiscyre (Thermodon), where they lived, was then ruled by Orontes
(Margherita Flora), the uncle of Anthiope and husband of Thomyris.

Il regno opened on 8 November 1727. A license to print the libretto (for I/ regno delle donne) had
been issued on 4 October 1727; the libretto was dedicated on the 25th of that month. The virtuous
harmonies of the Venetian violinist Giovanni Reali, now maestro of the dedicatee's cappella, are cited
in the dedication as an important component of this poetic caprice, but Boccardi noted that dramatic

1727/10 Orlando [furioso] Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[ROLAND IN A RAGE]
A dramma per music Text attributed to Grazio Braccioli
im Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With Serpilla e Bacocco SORTING DATE: 1727-11-15
x Without dedicatee
 This tale, inspired by Ariosto via the texts used at Sant' Angelo in 1713/5 and 1714/6, was recommended

in the libretto for its established reputation as an attractive entertainment. Orlando furioso opened
on 15 November 1727 (NV). A license to print the libretto had been issued on the 9th (A). Five arias
were taken from earlier works by Vivaldi,' but this version had little in common with Orlando finto
pazzo (1714/5).2

BS Orlando lent itself to the kinds of scenery with which Sant' Angelo should have been well supplied.
Alcina's enchanted palace, with its surrounding gardens and a distant view of the tempestuous sea,
was the centerpiece of Act One. The cave scene and the wooded countryside in which Angelica and
Medoro were to be married were important components of Act Two. The temple of Hecate, with the
statue of Merlin, dominated Act Three.

ee Despite its earlier success, Orlando may not have been well received in this production, since it was
succeeded on 10 December (an unusual date for openings) by a revised version of Vivaldi's Farnace
(1727/3). The principal singers in both works  Lucia Lancetti (Orlando), Benedetta Serafina (Angelica),
Anna Giro (Alcina), Maria Catterina Negri (Bradamante), and Casimiro Pignotti (Medoro)  were
relatively little known at the time. A revival was given in Brno in 1735 and pastiches based on this
version of Orlando were given in Bergamo (1738), Vicenza (1738), Este (1740), and Bassano (1741).

In all of these cases, extensive new material was added at the end of Act | and the beginning of Act

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Without dedicatee

In the strife between the Athenians and King Minos of Crete, the infant Ariadne (the daughter of Minos)
was kidnaped and raised as the daughter of the Theban prince Archeos. After an oracle told the Athenians
that their wars with the Cretans would end only if they placated King Minos, they sent seven young
men to Crete to participate in the games held there. The only means of saving them and the young women
who were sacrificed to the minotaur was to overcome the beast. Theseus took up the challenge in the
hope of saving the life and winning the hand of Ariadne, who was one of the hostages.'

Arianna opened on 22 November 1727 (NV). A license to print the libretto had been issued on the
13th. On the 29th Antonio Conti wrote to Madame de Caylus that [Antonio] Pasi (Alceste) does
marvelous things (faits des merveilles) but that a virtuosa from Bologna [Giovanna Gasparini, in the
role of the hostage Carilda] excels him, and, it is claimed, is in no way inferior to Faustina [Bordoni].
Conti also said that Nicolini? (Zeseo) at 75 was the greatest actor of our theaters, but [even though]
he speaks more than he sings, nonetheless he is greatly applauded, for he expresses all the passions
with vivacity.?* He made no comment on Facchinelli, who sang in the title role.

Conti also remarked that while he did not particularly like Nicolini's combat with the minotaur, he found
the horrible magnificence of the scenery, especially the labyrinth, well suited to the subject. The scenery
and its operation during the 1727-28 season were consigned to Sebastiano and Romualdo Mauro, who
in June 1728 appeared before the Council of Ten to reclaim debts owed them by Vicenzo, Antonio,
and Michiel Grimani. An adaptation of the same text was used in Handel's Arianna in Creta(HWV
32; 1733-34).78

Score (Act 2) in GB-Lbl (copy in US-We); arias in GB-Cfm

1727/13 Ormisda* Music by Bartolomeo Cordans*
[ORMISDA]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Apostolo Zeno
V1 Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1727-12-28~
si Without dedicatee
-

The Persian king Ormisda (Alessandro Veroni) intended to pass over his elder son, Chosroes (Filippo
Finazzi), in determining the line of succession in order that his younger son, Arsakes (Giacinta Spinola),
might ascend to the throne. Chosroes responded with military force. Although Corneille's model was
acknowledged, the work passed to the Venetian stage from Vienna, where Caldara's setting had been
given on the emperor's name-day (4 November) in 1721. Handel used an adaptation of Zeno's text,
with arias borrowed from Vinci, Hasse, Orlandini, and others, in his lost pastiche Ormisda (HWV A3;
King's Theatre, London, 1730).?8

 2 Ormisda, which was reported on 3 January 1728 to have opened in recent days,
have gone into production between the 27th and the 30th of December to avoid conflicts with other
openings and church feasts at the start of January. The title-page is dated 1728. A license to print the
libretto had been issued on 18 December 1727. The splendors of the Persian court were suggested by
depictions of the royal park, the royal harem, the underground temple of Mithras, and the royal baths.
Groups of priests and satraps as well as Persian and Armenian pages were employed in the staging.

Oo The infant Floridano, heir to the throne of Phoenicia, was kidnaped by corsairs as he was being taken

to Egypt by a nurse. In adulthood he was known as the royal painter Ismero. He fell in love with Arnea,
his long-lost sister, who now ruled Phoenicia. The cast is not identified in the libretto but is likely
to have included members of the Denzio troupe. Amore e fortuna was performed as the second drama
on 31 December 1727 (NV).*' The title-page is dated 1728. The original version of Porta's work had
been produced in Naples (1725). Passarini's text had been set by Baseggio for productions in Rovigo
and Dolo in the autumn of 1712. Among later settings of this popular work, the Jesi production (1733)
involved a Venetian cast.

Argeno Music by Leonardo Leo
[ARGENES]

A dramma per musica Text by Domenico Lalli
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1728-01-17

Dedicated to Cardinal Pietro Ottoboni, Nob. Ven.

In the basic outline of this plot the usual threads of power and love were entangled, but the figures are
unusually exotic. Argenes is a Chinese emperor who makes peace with the Tartars by arranging for
the marriage of his daughter Ianthe to the Tartar prince Zamir and of Camor's daughter Myrtena to
his own cousin Cambyses. A fter the plans are well underway, an oracle persuades him to dissolve them
because Zamir will betray him. The action takes place in Nanking.

Argeno opened on 17 January 1728 (NV),** the date of dedication of the libretto. A license to print
the libretto had been issued on 11 January 1727 [M.V.]. Argeno was produced in Naples in 1731. Owen
Swiney reported on 13 February that in both Arianna e Teseo and in Argeno Nicolino [Nicola Grimaldi]
performed [in the title role] with deserved universal applause and with more spirit than he did when
he was younger.* Other members of the cast included Lucia Facchinelli (Jantea), Giovanna Gasparini
(Mirtena), Annibale Pio Fabbri (Zamiro), and Antonio Pasi (Cambice).

The Mauro brothers (Sebastiano and Romualdo), who were responsible for building and moving the
scenery, were still unpaid by the Grimani at the end of June, when they appealed to the Council of Ten.
Score (Venice) in Lam; score (Naples, inc.) in I-Mc; arias in D-MUs; GB-Cfm, I-Vc (Naples, 1731)
Listed as Bonlini 629; Groppo 633; Wiel 275; Alm 785

Rosilena ed Oronta Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[ROSILENA AND ORONTA]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giovanni Palazzi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1728-01-19

Dedicated to Leopold, Count Paar!

Rosilena (Benedetta Serafina), the only daughter of the late king Artabanos of Persia, was taken captive
after her father's death by Arsakes (Maria Catterina Negri), the king of Parthia. She was saved by the
young Armenian prince Ormond (Casimiro Pignotti), with whom she shortly fell in love. He was the
son of the widowed queen Oronta (Anna Gird). When Arsakes discovered her whereabouts, he sent
his army to Armenia to recapture her. Rosilena opened on 19 January 1728 (NV). A license to print
the libretto had been issued on the 15th, and the libretto itself (I-Rsc) was dedicated on the 17th.

az Dedicated to Count Ottaviano Vimercati?TM

In this mischievous paraphrase of Zeno's text, Walter/Gualtiero (Filippo Finazzi), the king of Thessaly,
who had married the shepherdess Griselda (Rosa Croce), demanded that their daughter Oronta (Teresa
Zanardi) be raised by a friend under an assumed identity in Athens. Tigranes (Giacinta Spinola), the
son of Gualtiero's friend, fell in love with the grown princess, although her identity remained a secret
known only to Tigranes's brother Conrad. After Griselda gave birth to a son, Gualtiero, falsely declaring
the child to have been fathered by the cavalier Ottone, demanded the return of his daughter to assume
her mother's responsibilities.

Oo This production of Griselda opened on 26 January 1728 (NV), the date of dedication of the libretto.
The title-page is dated 1728 at top and 1708 [sic] at bottom. Zeno's text was enormously popular and
had been set more than a dozen times. It remained in circulation in diverse adaptations and settings
until the end of the century. Albinoni's setting had been performed in Florence in 1703 (see also 1701/5).
Orlandini's setting (1720/4) followed a premiere in Brescia in 1716.

Nerina Music by Antonio Pollarolo
[NERINA]

A favola pastorale Text adapted from Dom. Maria Creta by Domenico Lalli
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1728-05-05

Dedicated to Ferdinand, Duke of Bavaria

In this Arcadian drama, Tirsi (Gio. Battista Pinacci) loved the nymph Nerina (Teresa Peruzzi), who
was descended from the ancient inhabitants of Tegeia. She has fallen in love with the young warrior-
shepherd Alcasto (Gaetano Majorana). Meanwhile Idreno (Elisabetta Uttini), the leader of the shepherds
of Tegeia, was eager that the rule of the province should fall to his daughter, the nymph Silvia (Antonia
Negri), who loved Tirsi.2!

Adapted from the earlier Filindo (1720/6), Nerina opened on 5 May 1728 (NV). It was to run for fifteen
days, but the Diario ordinario indicates that although the Ascension fair was concluded on the 20th,
the last performance of both Ascension operas was on the 23rd. Nerina is likely to be the work
anticipated on May Ist by Antonio Conti because it would present a new singer of whom they speak
very highly....? The chanteuse new to him was apparently Antonia Negri, although Gaetano
Majorana (Caffariello) was the more significant singer giving a Venetian debut. Majorana, a pupil
of Porpora, was a graceful figure on the stage and his performances over the coming decades were greatly
lauded.

Ezio Music by Nicole Porpora
[AETIUsS]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1728-11-21

Dedicated to the Count [Aloys Thomas Raymond] Harrach*

The Roman patrician Aetius, an illustrious captain under Valentinian, defeated Attila at the Battle of
Chalons (Gaul) in 451 AD. In this account, Aetius was unjustly accused of disloyalty.**

Ezio opened on 21 November 1728 (NV). The libretto was dedicated on the preceding day by the
impresario Domenico Lalli. Following a banquet given by the imperial ambassador, the dedicatee and
an assemblage of dignitaries including the French and Spanish ambassadors, the papal legate, and the
receiver of Malta attended the opening-night performance.* According to the Diario ordinario, Ezio
was received with universal applause. Nicola Grimaldi took the title role, with Domenico Gizzi
(Valentiniano), Lucia Facchinelli (Fulvia), and Antonia Negri (Onoria). On 9 December Antonio Conti
promised to send airs from the new work by Porpora to France.*" Metastasio's text formed the basis
for Handel's opera of the same name (HWV 29; 15 January 1732).

3!8 Heller (Cronologia, pp. 61f) says that a performance on 26 March was attended by Prince Elector Karl-Albrecht (subsequently Emperor
Charles VII) of Bavaria, who applauded enthusiastically. Unless the performance was private, 26 March seems a dubious date, since it was
the third Tuesday of Lent, while 26 May was the Sunday before a relatively late Ascension and thus a customary time for an Ascension opera
to have its first performance, but the work must have opened before that, because a letter written from Verona by Vivaldi on 3 May (loc. cit.)
suggests that it was already in progress. Vivaldi's 1737 production in Verona enjoyed great success. He promised Bentivoglio he would
produce another work with ballett for Ferrara, but he wished it to be given in the summer, when dancers charged less than they did during
Carnival (loc. cit.).

1732. Handel asked on 11 March 1729 that any mail be forwarded to him in the care of Joseph Smith (Baselt, Handbook, iv, 171), the English
banker who had taken up residence in Venice some years before. Smith, who became an extremely important patron of Venetian painting,
was married to the English singer [Mrs.] Catherine Tofts.

3 The designation Guglielmo Conte di Jersey Visconte Villiers de Dartmouth Barone de Hoo, Pari della Gran Bretagna in the libretto appears
to refer to William Villiers, the third earl of Jersey. Having inherited his title in 1721, he served in various court offices, such as that of Gentleman

various aspects of their situation. The story, situated in Agra, was said to be derived from the
