Even though its libretto was dedicated on 26 September 1728 by the impresario Antonio Grossatesta
(giving the impression that the work would have run in the autumn), this first drama did not open
until 27 December 1728 (NV). The title-page is dated 1729. The text had first been set by Caldara, with
ballet music by Nicol Matteis, for the emperor's birthday (4 November) in 1724. Among its later settings
were those of Giai (San Giovanni Grisostomo, 1738/3) and Ciampi (San Benedetto, 1759).

Giovanni Paita sang in the title role, with Francesco Bernardi (Senesino) as Chosroes and Faustina
Bordoni as Semira. The Diario ordinario* reported that, like Catone, Gianguir was received with
all-round approval (comune agradimento). Owen Swiney said that Faustina gain'd immortal Honour
this Carneval, but Senesino lost much reputation in y [the] first Opera [Gianguir]; he recovered some
of itagain in... .y* [the] second [Adelaide].** Antonio Conti on 18 December praised the rapport between
the decorations and the representation of the entire work, found the subject pleasing, and suggested
that the role of Zama [Lucrezia Baldini] provided a [real-life] portrait of the Czarina. He also indicated
that the production was financed in equal measure by Faustina Bordoni and the painter Sebastiano Ricci.

Doriclea repudiata da Cr eso" Music attributed to Giovanni Porta
[DoRICLEA REPUDIATED BY CROESUS]

A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Battista Corte*
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1729-01-05

Dedicated to Francesco CorrerTM

This drama, loosely derived from ancient history, involved not only Doriclea (Teresa Peruzzi) and Croesus
(Andrea Costa) but also Emirena, Arbakes, Pheraspes, and Solon. A second drama, Doriclea opened
on 5 January 1729 (NV, DO). A license to print the libretto (for J/ ripudio di Doriclea) was issued on
15 December 1728; the libretto was dedicated on the 29th; its title-page was dated 1729. Because of
poor attendance, the work was performed only three times.**' The work is more likely than the
performance to have sabotaged Doriclea, for only one casting change was made in its successor (1729/2).

Adelaide Music by Giuseppe Maria Orlandini
[ADELAIDE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Antonio Salvi
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a ballo and combattimento SORTING DATE: 1729-02-08

Dedicated to James, Duke of Hamilton>

Adelaide was the widow of the tenth-century Italian king Lothar, who had been murdered by Berengar.
She was rescued by the German king Otto I. The first Venetian performance of Adelaide was on 8
February 1729 (NV); the libretto had been dedicated on the 6th. The premiere performance had been
given at the Cocomero in Florence in 1725.3?

Inthe Venetian production the singers  Giovanni Paita (Berengario), Francesco Bernardi (Senesino)
(Ottone), and Faustina [Bordoni] (Adelaide)  were appealing.*** The performance was sufficiently
attractive to have pulled the audience away from San Giovanni Grisostomo at the end of Carnival (see
below). The British consul, Col. Elizeus Burges, wrote that y* [the] whole town is so taken up with
y competition between Farinelli [Carlo Broschi] and Faustina that we think and talk of nothing else.
Y lady's strength lies chiefly among y foreigners, especially y English and French; but y* Eunuch
has almost all y* Italiens on his side, a powerful band, and esteem'd by much y best judges of musick.*4
Circumstantial evidence suggests that Zanetti's caricature of Bernardi, who did not subsequently appear
on the Venetian stage, was based on his performance either in this work or in its predecessor, Gianguir
(1728/10).

Salvi's text formed the basis for Handel's Lotario (HWV 26), which opened in London on 2 December
1729. Vivaldi set the text for performance in Verona (RV 695) in 1735.35 Elements of the story are
still present in Giovanni Schmidt's libretto Adelaide di Borgogna, set by Rossini in 1817.

1729/4 Semiramide riconosciuta Music by Nicold Porpora
[SEMIRAMIS RECOGNIZED]
A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
im Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1729-02-12
&o Dedicated to Sir John Buckworth***

In contrast to the earlier texts of Moniglia (1670/4 et al.) and Silvani (1714/1), Metastasio's account
centered on the selection of a spouse by the Baktrian princess Tamyris. The prospective suitors included
both Semiramis (here considered to be Egyptian), who was disguised as her son, and her brother Mirteos,
who believed Semiramis to be dead.

OO The Venetian production opened on 12 February 1729 (NV). Lucia Facchinelli sang in the title role,
with Antonia Negri as the princess (Zamiri), Nicola Grimaldi as Semiramis's estranged Indian husband
(Scitalce), Carlo Broschi (Farinelli) as the Egyptian prince (Mirteo), and others. The English resident
wrote to the duke of Newcastle on the 11th (see 1729/3) that Venice was so taken up with...y* [the]
competition between Farinelli [Carlo Broschi] and Faustina that we think and talk of nothing else.
Handel's Semiramide (HWV A8; London, 1733) employed this text but borrowed most of its music
from Vinci, whose own setting had its first performance in Rome on 6 February 1729.

1729/5 Sulpizia fedele Music by Antonio Pollarolo
[SULPICIA THE FAITHFUL]
A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Boldini***
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With La cantatrice, balli SORTING DATE: 1729-05-22
& Dedicated to Countess Margarita Giusti Borra
Oo@ The love poems of Sulpicia (first century AD) described many years of happy marriage to Calenus and

included many references to sensual pleasure. This Sulpicia (Costanza Pusterla), a Roman noblewoman,
is promised in marriage to her countryman, the jealous Lentuolus (Giovanni Carestini), who poses as
the late king of Syracuse and is thus presumed to be married to Queen Ermesena (Rosa Mancini). Sulpizia
opened on 22 May 1729 (NV), the Sunday preceding the feast of Ascension. According to the Diario
ordinario, Sulpizia was intended to be the only work given at San Samuele during the fair of Ascension,TM!
but it may have had a poor reception, since it was soon replaced by Dorinda (1729/6).

preserved in GB-Lam (see Mamy, La Musique, p. 380, and Gibson, Royal Academy, both relying on earlier work by Strohm). Buckworth's
stay in Venice continued until 6 March (see NV).

Dorinda Music by Giovanni Battista Pescetti and Baldassare Galuppi
[DoRINDA]

A pastorale per musica Text attributed to Benedetto Pasqualigo*
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With La cantatrice and balli SORTING DATE: 1729-06-06

Dedicated to the Marchioness Vidoni*?

In this reworking of La fede riconosciuta (Vicenza, 1707),* Dorinda (Anna Bolognese), a shepherdess
from Delos, was abandoned by Silvio (Giovanni Carestini), a shepherd from Eleusis. After she stole
into his homeland disguised as Fileno, Nicea (Maria Cattanea) fell in love with her/him.

Dorinda opened on 6 June 1729 (NV).*# Received with all-round satisfaction, it can only have
tun for a few days. The Ascension fair closed on the day this work opened. The last performance of
Dorinda should have been on the 9th, since theaters could remain open for three days after the fair closed.

La Dori Music attributed to multiple composers**
[Dori]

A pastorale eroica Text attributed to Pietro d'Averara

In this revised version of J/ Filindo (1720/6; as Nerina, 1728/6), the nymph Dori was, among the
shepherds of Delphos, the last descendant of an ancient line of royalty. They proposed to elect her their
leader, but discovering that she was loved by both Cileno and Filindo, they agreed that one should be
her consort and the other their political leader. The cast members are not identified.

the claim of its title-page that it was given in the autumn can be confirmed by the fact that on 16

Onorio Music by Francesco Ciampi***
[Honortius]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Domenico Lalli, Giovanni Boldini
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1729-11-27

Dedicated to Luca Casimiro degl' Albizzi*'

Ina plot said to be based on Corneille, the Vandal-turned-Roman general Stilicho/Stilicone (Filippo
Giorgi) had a daughter, Termanzia (Francesca Cuzzoni Sandoni), and a son, Eucherius (Castoro Antonio
Castori[ni]). Anxious for their futures, he arranged the marriage of his daughter to the young emperor
Honorius [395-423], whom he had served as guardian. His son had meanwhile fallen in love with Placidia
(Maddalena Pieri), the later emperor's sister, but there was opposition to the intended marriage. The
tension between these two marriage arrangements forms the basis of the plot. Onorio opened on 27
November 1729 (NV). It was still running when the theaters were closed on 15 December, by which
time it had enjoyed a total of eleven performances.*** Nicola Grimaldi sang in the title role.

1729/12 Mitridate* Music by Giovanni Antonio Giai
[MITHRIDATES]
A dramma per musica (5) Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Domenico Lalli
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1729-12-26
a Dedicated to William Morris*

Mitridate was the last five-act work to be given in Venice through 1750. Pharnakes was the most gifted
son of Mithridates, the king of Pontos, as well as the step-son of Laodike/ Laodice. From her first marriage
to the elder Tigranes, king of Armenia, Laodike had three sons, one of whom had now made a pact
with Mithridates. In a subplot Eupatra, the daughter of Mithridates and Laodike, had been sent to Pontos
with the captain Gordias, but after the pair fell into the hands of Roman troops, Eupatra was raised as
Aristia, with whom the unaware Gordias, her brother, had now fallen in love.

QOL Mitridate opened on 26 December 1729 (NV, DO).* It can be verified from the Giustiniani accounts'
that this second drama enjoyed fifteen performances, which, allowing for religious feasts, indicates
that it ran until c. 15 January 1730. The dedicatee and other English gentlemen were still in Venice
on the 20th. The castrato Nicola Grimaldi sang here in the title role. Carlo Broschi took the role of
Pharnakes, with Francesca Cuzzoni Sandoni (La Parmigianina) as Aristia. The British resident, Col.
Burges, wrote on 20 January (apparently of this work) that Farinello [Carlo Broschi] draws hither
a great many Strangers to hear him. The Virtuosi do all agree there never was such a Voice as his in
y* world before; besides, he is young and a very good Figure upon y* Stage....

- Giai's was the third (revised) setting of Zeno's text. Best known for its earlier performance in Caldara's
setting (Vienna, 1728), it was last set by Sarti (Florence, 1779). The story traverses some of the same
ground as Frigimelica-Roberti's Mitridate Eupatore (1707/3) and Schietti's Laodice (1724/5).

The 1730s: Overview

Ge Doge Giovanni Mocenigo's ten-year tenure as
doge (1722-32) was noted for its social excesses
YAKS and moral decline, the next two doges  Carlo
Ruzzini (1732-35) and Alvise Pisani (1735-41)  enjoyed
substantial diplomatic careers. Ruzzini was a negotiator of
European stature. Pisani exhibited a substantial interest in
public well-being. Some evidences of this were vested in
the Accademia Albrizziana and the Ospedale della Pieta.
Despite such investments, the declining influence of the Most
Serene Republic was increasingly hard to hide. Legions of
central Europeans arrived, while countless desperate
noblemen risked their dwindling savings on ventures in India
or the New World.

The decline in Venetian power generally and in the
lagoon's drawing power is apparent from an overall decrease
of twenty per cent in the number of operas given and almost
forty per cent in the number of meta-operas. In theatrical
affairs, the most consequential shift of the decade was caused
by the resurgence of comedy performed in a wholly new
manner  with music. Evidences abound that music had
played a minor role in comedies for a long time (Song and
Season, Chs. 4.1, 8.1). The question of authorship of such
works is a contentious one, since scripted comedy was still
arelative novelty. In contrast to opera librettists, comedians
were not accustomed to editing their works with a view
towards publication. Comedians were still engaged in
troupes, though audiences of the time began to single out
individual figures. One of the stars of Giuseppe Imer's troupe
was the young widow Zanetta Farassi Casanova (mother of
Giacomo). Musical satires of serious opera performed at San
Samuele gradually changed the course of Venetian opera.
Experiments with musical comedy inspired Carlo Goldoni,
whose later impact on Venetian theater was hardly evident
when he resumed residence in Venice in 1732.

Meanwhile, opera continued on its set course. The
composer who enjoyed the greatest respect in the 1730s, at
least at San Giovanni Grisostomo, was Johann Adolf Hasse,
a Saxon trained in Naples. In 1730, after extraordinary
successes with Artaserse (1730/7) and Dalisa (1730/8),
Hasse took the Venetian virtuosa Faustina Bordoni as his
wife. Bordoni's own successes in London in the 1720s and
her extravagant fees, in combination with Hasse's assimila-

tion of diverse musical cultures, rendered the pair singular
examples ofa rising synthesis of musical values which came
to identify European taste. Despite a subsequent 25-year
tenure in Dresden, the composer and his wife maintained
ties with Venice for the rest of their long lives. Hasse's
works were also well regarded in Vienna, for many were
on texts by Metastasio. The works also had reprieves in
London. Singers such as Carlo Broschi (Farinelli) and
Gaetano Majorana (Caffariello) competed for the distinc-
tion of singing the most difficult virtuoso passages in operas
of the time.

In contrast to the Hasse-Metastasio axis of opera, the
repertory of Sant' Angelo, which was equally active, drifted
towards revivals and pastiches. Its most energetic composer,
Vivaldi, spent more time managing touring companies
scattered from the provinces of northern Italy to those of
Central Europe, than at home. Apart from the faithful but
aging Albinoni, Sant'Angelo employed such novices as
Bartolomeo Cordans, Antonio Galeazzi, and Gio. Battista
Lampugnani. Among the newcomers, the one with the
greatest musical future was Baldassare Galuppi, who would
eventually become maestro di cappella at San Marco. Many
of Sant'Angelo's singers were, like Galuppi, Venetian.
Among its many economies, Sant' Angelo increasingly cast
women in male roles.

The spring season became entrenched in three theaters
 Sant' Angelo, San Moise, and San Samuele. Two spring
works of the decade stand out  the Hasse/Metastasio
Dalisa (1730/8) and the Vivaldi/Goldoni Griselda (1735/5)
 but each for different reasons. Dalisa, which starred
Bordoni, was one of the most expensive works, on a cost-
per-day basis, ever to be produced in Venice. Even so, it lost
money. Since the house was packed for every performance,
this indicates that at the wages it offered, San Samuele stood
no chance, ever, of making ends meet. Griselda represented
one of the few interactions between Vivaldi and the young
Goldoni. It was also the only work by Vivaldi ever to be
produced at San Giovanni. Memorable as Goldoni's account
of the interaction is, it appears that an important message
was left unsaid: either the working relationship was as
unacceptable to Vivaldi as it was to Goldoni, or the product
of their collaboration was poorly received.

FIGURE 26. Productions by theater, 1720s vs. 1730s.

On balance, the reputations of the smaller theaters were
increasingly eclipsed by those of the star providers. San
Samuele was now the third most active venue for operas but
a distant one behind San Giovanni, which trailed Sant' An-
gelo (Figure 26). Activities of San Cassiano and San Moise
withered. The autumn/winter continuum developed a bipolar
symmetry insofar as comedy troupes gave great publicity
to their autumn opening nights, while the opera houses
trumpeted the last nights of Carnival.

| @ Other sf

The survival rate of scores (almost thirty per cent) is
improved over that of recent decades. In particular, many
works by Hasse and Vivaldi have been preserved. However,
statistics mute the role of extant scores from performances
given elsewhere and/or with different casts. Among news
sources, avvisi are preserved for most years. The residues
of many which are lost can be found in the Diario ordinario.
The quality of the papal legate's records declines, but the
quantity remains steady.

Selim, gran Signor de' Turchi Music by diverse composers
[SELIM, LEADER OF THE TURKS]

A dramma per musica Text by Antonio Lucchini
Performed at Santa Margherita SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Ircano innamorato* SORTING DATE: 1730-01-22

Dedicated to Giorgio Querini, N. V.

While Siileyman ruled in the Orient [1520-1566], his son Selim feigned madness as a means of self-
preservation. Siileyman's sexual conquests were legendary, and in this work (loosely based on Ottoman
history) his abduction of Asteria, the intended bride of the king of Armenia, set the foundation for the
drama that ensued. By 1730 the Campo Santa Margherita had become an important, if secondary, venue
for Carnival entertainments. On 22 January a bull-chase took place there, and the date would have
been a natural focus (in terms of Venetian traditions) for the re-opening of this theater. The letter of
introduction was signed by Lodovico Pasetti e Compagni, the apparent operators of the theater.

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 653; Groppo 657; Wiel 308; Alm 812

Artaserse Music by Johann Adolf Hasse'
[ARTAXERXES]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio'
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1730-02-11

Dedicated to William Cowper

Artaxerxes (who was already dead in the concurrent production of Statira at Sant' Angelo, 1730/6) played
a pivotal role in this episode from ancient Persian history. His father, Xerxes, had been killed by the
ambitious prefect Artabanos, who hoped that disarray among the king's survivors would facilitate his
ownascent. While Artaxerxes had arranged for the murder of Darius (as in Jdaspe, 1730/4), he discovered
the plot of Artabanos soon enough to defend himself and the throne.

This well-received work, the first by Hasse to be produced in Venice, opened on 11 February 1730.
It can have had no more than eleven performances (fewer than the number of scores surviving, since
Shrove Tuesday fell on the 21st. According to the Diario ordinario, Artaserse drew the biggest crowds
and enjoyed the most praise of any work given in this season. The cast included Filippo Giorgi
(Artaserse), Francesca Cuzzoni (Mandane, his sister), Nicola Grimaldi (Artabano), Carlo Broschi
(Arbace), and Maria Maddalena Pieri (Semira, Arbake's sister). Col. Burges, the British resident, rated
Cuzzoni's the next best voice in Italy after Farinelli's and said she had the sweeter pipe of the two.!
The libretto for the Venetian production notes that in performance the work was significantly abridged.
Vinci's setting of the same text opened almost simultaneously (4 February 1730) in Rome. The broad
popularity of Hasse's setting is indicated by the rapidity with which it went into production elsewhere.
Within the year it was performed in Genoa, Bologna, Turin, and Lucca. It was revived in Venice as
1734/3; a revised version was also given in London in that year. Over the course of the next decade
it was also produced in Madrid, Graz, Ljubljana, Dresden, and elsewhere. Metastasio's text was longer-
lived than Hasse's setting and was set by Cimarosa (Turin, 26 December 1784) among others.

The season of 1729-30 may have been the most spectacular in the theater's history. The castrato Nicola
Grimaldi (Nicolino) received 12,400 Jire for his appearances in four works, of which this was the

In this improbable mixture of history and mythology, the German emperor Otto (Angelo Amorevoli)
was about to marry Edith (Anna Gird), the daughter of the French king, Philip, when he suddenly fell

Otto's younger brother Henry (Antonio Pasi).

running) on 19-21 November for a three-day centenary commemorating the end of the plague in 1630.

 The text of this work had been set by Albinoni as 1724/12. Sarri's original (the music for which had

been composed for a Neapolitan production in February 1724) had its Venetian premiere on 24
November 1730 (NV). The dedicatee was in Venice at the time of this opening.**

Oe Metastasio's original text and Sarri's setting of it had been praised in 1724 for the composition of the
words, being by a famous author, and for the music of the maestro di cappella Domenico Sarro. Also
cited were the virtuosi who perform, among whom may be distinguished the Cavalier Nicola Grimaldi,
cast as Aeneas, whom he represents marvelously; the virtuosa Marianna Benti Bulgarelli, detta la
Romanina, who takes the part of Dido; and the virtuosa Antonia Merighi, who takes the part of Iarbas,
the king of the Moors ....' The first two of these singers had appeared in Albinoni's setting (1724/12).
Grimaldi was the only survivor in the 1730 Venetian production from the original Neapolitan cast. Lucia
Facchinelli now took the role of Dido, with Antonio Barbieri as Iarbas.

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1730-39) 421

The enormous jealousy existing between Stateira and Barsina, the wives of the late Alexander the Great,
was explored in this revised version of La costanza combattuta in amore (1716/6). The high-born Stateira
was the daughter of Darius, the king of Persia, while Barsina, the daughter of a vassal of Darius, was
of lower birth.* It was Barsina who prevailed in a contest for the interests of the royal prince Leonatus.
She bore Alexander's (last) child, whose entry into the world prompted the need to reconsider the division
of Alexander's conquered lands.*

e The casting of Maria Giovanna Gasparini (Statira) and Rosa Maddalena Cardina (Barsina) suggests
the possibility that in its actual staging J/ trionfo could have been understood to represent the long-
standing competition between Bolognese and Venetian singers at Sant'Angelo. The well-known
Gasparini, from Bologna, enjoyed the patronage of Philip, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt. The Venetian
Cardina, who subsequently was cast in male roles, was appearing in her first season.

 The date offered is speculative, since no documentation for the performance has come to light. The
topic would have suited any part of the winter season, which was curiously devoid of St. Stephen's
openings, even though it was constrained by a relatively early date for Shrove Tuesday (13 February).

Listed as Bonlini 667; Groppo 671; Wiel 319; Alm 827!

1731/2 Massimiano Music by Giuseppe Maria Orlandini
[MAXIMINUS]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Pietro Pariati
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1731-01-06~
a Dedicated to Edward Walpole

Maximinus, the emperor of Rome from 235 to 238, consolidated the peace begun under Diocletian,
in whose name he built the great baths near what is now the Piazza della Repubblica. In this account
(derived from 1711/7*), Maximinus had renounced the throne, but the current emperor, Constantine,
had married his daughter, Fausta, to advance his own political agenda. Maximinus then attempted to
persuade Fausta to betray her husband.**

@ This second drama opened onc. 6 January 1731 (NV),* but since the 6th was the feast of Epiphany
and theaters were also closed on the 8th, the actual date is more likely to have been the Sth or the 9th.
The winter season of 1731 was a lackluster one. There were no openings in December 1730 and those
of January caused little comment. Venice, Austria, and Saxony were preoccupied with the threat of
war to the east. Nicola Grimaldi sang in the title role, with Antonio Barbieri (Costantino) and Lucia
Facchinelli (Fausta). The libretto noted that the scenery painters and engineers were the brothers Giuseppe
and Domenico Valeriani from Bavaria.

Romilda Music by Bartolomeo Cordans
[ROMILDA]

A dramma per musica Text by Carlo Pagani-Cesa
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With // vecchio pazzo in amore SORTING DATE: 1731-01-06~

Dedicated to Marquis Scipione Sacrati*'

Romilda (Chiara Orlandi), the widow of Alkhan (Antonio Gaspari), the king of the Huns, led a reclusive
life in a castle on the edge of the sea near Aquileia. Her daughter Agila (Maria Mona), who remained
at home, fell in love with Siegfried (Cecilia Delfini), a prisoner in the castle, but Siegfried turned out
to be her brother Rodewald in disguise. Romilda, which opened on c. 6 January 1731 (NV),* enjoyed
much applause.

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 665; Groppo 669; Wiel 314; Alm 825

Armida al campo d'Egitto Music attributed to Antonio Vivaldi
[ARMIDE IN CAMP OF THE EGYPTIANS]

A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Palazzi
Performed at Santa Margherita SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Lidia e Ircano SORTING DATE: 1731-01-20~
Without dedicatee

Palazzi explains in his preface that in honoring the enduring drama of a famous poet [Tasso], he has
preserved the place and the principal characters but has diversified the story of Armide. Although
it cannot be determined exactly when this revival of 1719/7 opened, the model of the preceding year
together with the knowledge that this was a year with a very short Carnival season suggest an opening
in mid-January 1731. The second and third acts were significantly shortened from the 1719 version.

1731/8 Artanaganamenone Music attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini
[ARTANAGANAMENONE]
A dramma tragichissimissimo Text attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini
im Performed at San Moise SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With Perrica e Varrone (?) SORTING DATE: 1731-05-02
a Without dedicatee
Oo Modeled on the spirited idea of the [spoken] tragedy Rutzvanscad il giovine (Suppl. 3a), the text was

a satire on plots claiming a foundation in ancient history. Malmocor, the tyrannical king of the Arabian
desert, sent his general Ormondonopalach to defeat Sardanapalapeo. The general took Miradaclea, the
wife of Sardanapalapeo, and her infant son, Artanaganamenone, as hostages. This dramma
tragichissimissimo for the fair of Ascension opened on 2 May 1731 with full applause. It had been
given three years earlier in Bologna under the title Malmocor. A sequel concerning the lives of the same
figures was produced at Sant'Angelo as JI re dispietato (1747/11).

Listed as Bonlini 671; Groppo 675; Wiel 316; Alm 832

Spinning fantasy from Adriatic mythology, the libretto relates that a magnificent temple, sacred to Venus,
arose on the Venetian shore. This frustrated Neptune (Giovanni Carestini), who, being unable to seduce
the beautiful nymph Adria (Anna Maria Peruzzi), disguised himself as the shepherd Amyntas. Each
year when one of the many foreigners who frequented the shore was sacrificed to Cynthia, the act was

 Goldoni's Enea in Lazio is an elaboration of the same plot. Bonlini (MS, p. 221) indicates that Maccari set the same text to music for performance
in Treviso some years earlier, but no libretto from such a performance survives. (Quadrio maintained in 1744 that the music for the present
work was by Giacomo Maccari [see Della Seta, Relator, p. 83].)

Fidarsi e bene, Music attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini*

ma non fidarsi e meglio
[To BE FAITHFUL IS GOOD, BUT TO BE UNFAITHFUL IS BETTER]

Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1731-05-09~

Fidarsi may be indebted to the comic intermezzi of Polissena vedova e Don Chilone filosofo (1722).*!
Here the roles were for the widow Rosilda, her servant Dorisbe, and the hypocritical philosopher Zenone.
The action took place in a countryside with a view of a palazzo. The libretto indicates that the work
was intended for the Ascension fair. That only the opening of Artanaganamenone (1731/8; 2 May)
can be confirmed for this season could indicate that this work succeeded it a week later, that the two
works played in alternation, or that Artanaganamenone was so popular that Fidarsi was not given.

426 A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

CO In a period of relative peace with the Romans, Hannibal went to Bithynia to enjoy the protection of
King Prusia (here called Nicomedes), but he was discovered there by a Roman legate and killed. The
account, derived from Plutarch, was mediated by Corneille's La morte d'Annibale. This first drama
of the season opened on 14 November 1731 (NV) with applause [given] as much for the composition
..as for the performers who presented the work. This is a significant comment, since most members
of the cast were then unknown. Angelo Amorevoli sang in the title role with Gaetano Valletta (Nicomede)
and Giustina Turcotti (Elisa).* The production enjoyed a good attendance through 15 December.*

1731/12 = Scipione il giovane Music by Luca Antonio Predieri
[ScIPIO THE YOUNGER]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Gio. Francesco Bortolotti
im Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1731-11-19
w Dedicated to Richard Wynne
Oe Antiochos, the king of Syria, took Scipio Africanus, the eldest son of Publius Scipione, prisoner. Most

of the story, which involved Antiochos's infatuation with his prisoner's wife, Domizia, is invented,
though it is indebted to Piovene's Publio Cornelio Scipione (1712/2). San Giovanni's first drama
of the season opened on 19 November 1731 (NV). It was found to be pleasing enough, both for the
composition and for the famous singers, who included Antonio Bernacchi (Scipione), Faustina Bordoni
(Domizia), and Antonio Barbieri (Antioco). Of many works in which Bernacchi appeared, those of this
season seem most likely to have elicited Zanetti's caricature of the castrato's endless trail of notes.!

Alessandro nell' Indie Music by Giovanni Battista Pescetti'
[ALEXANDER IN INDIA]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Birina e Golpone;'TM a combattimento SORTING DATE: 1732-01-30
Without dedicatee

Metastasio's text was already well known: Vinci's setting had been given in Rome in 1730 and Handel
had set an adaptation of it (Poro, re dell Indie; HWV 28) for London.' It was assumed that the reader
of the libretto would know the work by reputation, for its argomento said only that the principal action
of the drama was shaped by Alexander's generosity towards Poros. In the actual event, the Indian queen
Cleophis/Cleofide, who loved Poros and sought an alliance between her kingdom and his, played a
pivotal role. Metastasio's text was carried forward in settings such as that of Cimarosa (Rome, 1781).
This third drama opened on 30 January 1732 (NV) with applause." The cast, which included Filippo
Finazzi (Alessandro), Gaetano Valleta (Poro), and Giustina Turcotti (C/eofide), was little known. The
temple of Bacchus was shown in the both the first and third acts.

Gl'evenimenti di Ruggiero" Music attributed to Tomaso Albinoni
[THE ADVENTURES OF ROGER]

A dramma per musica Text by Antonio Marchi
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Serpilla e Bacocco; Dorina e Nibbio; Tilla e Pancrazio' SORTING DATE: 1732-02-06

Dedicated to Paolo Martinengo'*

In this revised version of Alcina delusa da Ruggiero (1725/7), the Norman invader Roger I defeated
the Byzantine rulers of Bari in 1071 and the Arabs of Malta in 1090. He conquered Sicily in 1091. He
also established a Norman outpost in Antioch and fought in the First Crusade. His son, Roger II, who
was named King of Sicily, captured the Amalfi coast and Naples in the 1130s.

Gl'evenimenti opened on 6 February 1732 (NV). The title-page was dated 1732; licenses to print libretti
were issued on 25 January 1732 and 30 January 1731 M.V. Felice Novelli sang in the title role, with
Maria Laurenti Novelli (A/cina) and Veneranda Pendesich (Bradamante). On 11 February a representative
of the Council of Ten delivered an order requiring that the singers perform every night without fail

1732/3 Il Demetrio Music by Johann Adolf Hasse
[DEMETRIOS]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Pietro Metastasio by Giovanni Boldini
im Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1732-02-10
is) Dedicated to Charles Sackville, Count of Middlesex'!

One of Metastasio's most popular libretti, Demetrio was based on the life of the Syrian ruler of the
second century BC after the usurpation of his empire by Alexander Balas. Before fleeing, Demetrios
consigned his infant son (also named Demetrios) to his faithful vassal, Phoeniceus/Fonicio, and the
child was raised with the name Alcestes. Alcestes ascended through the ranks of Alexander's army.
He fell in love with Alexander's daughter, Cleonike, before his true identity was discovered.

oo This third drama opened, in the midst of a period of frigid weather, on 10 February 1732 (NV). A
license to print the libretto had been issued on 1 February 1732. The production was praised as a marvel,
as much for the music as for the magnificent scenes and singers.""! The cast included Antonio Bernacchi
(Alceste), Faustina Bordoni Hasse (Cleonice), and Antonio Barbieri (Fenicio).

oO The text for Demetrio had first been set by Caldara for the imperial court in November 1731.'!? Hasse's
setting had been given there in February 1732.!? Hasse's work was to be performed at San Cassiano
(1737/2); under the title Cleonice, for Friedrich Christian, the Electoral Prince of Saxony, at Sant' Angelo
(1740/1); and under the original title at San Giovanni Grisostomo (1746/14). Vivaldi adapted it for
performance in Ferrara for Carnival 1737. He was instructed to shorten the recitatives because operas
that last for four hours are unacceptable in Ferrara.''4 Metastasio's text was to be set by roughly 50
other composers over the next century.

1732/4 Le metamorfosi odiamorosi in Birba trionfale
nelle gare delle terre amanti Music by Salvatore Apolloni'
[THE LOVE-HATE METAMORPHOSIS OF THE TRIUMPHANT UPSTART
IN THE COMPETITION BETWEEN THE LANDS OF LOVERS]

A [satirical] dramma per musica Text by Antonio Gori''
M1 Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Winter (Giovedi Grasso)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1732-02-21~

Dedicated to Madama la Moda"

This text was pivotal both in marking the debut of the Gori troupe at San Samuele and in cleverly quoting
from recent operas, forming a pastiche of parodies. On the surface it concerns the affairs of the reigning
queen Mestre (a widow) and her daughter Malghera.'"* Falling in love with Prince Carpeneo [Gaetano
Casali] of Chiassi, the queen [Agnese Amurat] abandons her maternal duties and thus precipitates serious
conflict with her daughter [Zanetta Farussi Casanova]. After the Oracle of Delphi enters the drama,
the Lilliputian prince Striccheroch [Pietro Gandini],'? who is vice-regent of a foreign government,
falls in love first with Malghera and then with her mother. Bottenigo [Giuseppe Imer], the prince of
Bagoli, who loves Malghera, threatens to wed Mestre for spite, but ends up with Malghera.' The
particulars of the story were said to have been much disputed among previous authors.'?!

Some satirical elements of the work concentrated on manners and customs including speech (discourse
between foreigners and natives in general'), dress (Act Three opens in the noted tailor's gallery),
and scenery (Act One opens in the stereotyped woods with a view of the sea). There were snippets
from classical plots featuring Dido (1724/12), Cato (1728/9), Semiramis (1729/4), and Elagabalus.'
Even musical instruments were grist for this satirical mill.'* Several arias in Leo's Catone in Utica
(1728/9) were paraphrased. Bottenigo's final toast offered the dictum, Let's do what the women in
comedies do: Let each woman rule for one day in turn.

LORS Le metamorfosi seems to have run at the end of Carnival 1732.' The troupe members are identified
in the libretto only by satirical names. Zanetta Casanova, who left the troupe in 1735, took the score
for Le metamorfosi with her. It was produced in Warsaw, with her participation, in 1748 as Le conteste

was active as an instrumentalist by 1716, was engaged at a violinist at San Marco and at San Samuele from 1727 (I-Vas, PS, Busta 153, f.
93v), was an examiner of candidates to enter the instrumentalists' guild in the 1740s, and remained active through the 1750s.

1732/5 Euristeo Music by Johann Adolf Hasse
[EURYSTHEOS]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Domenico Lalli
im Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1732-05-21
& Dedicated to the Most Noble English Nation'?

Eurystheos, the infant prince of Argos, was found in the woods near the temple of Jupiter. He was raised,
under the name Ormontes, by Tersander, the custodian of the temple, together with Tersander's daughter
Erginda. The grown Ormontes (Gaetano Majorana) commanded the armies of Cisseos (Gregorio Babbi),
the king of Macedonia, and slew his enemy Epigenes. Until his identity was revealed, he sought the
hand of princess Aglatida (Francesca Cuzzoni Sandoni).

Oo Euristeo opened on 21 May 1732 (A).'* The date coincided with the death of the doge Alvise III
Mocenigo, for which reason the Ascension fair itself was not permitted to open (cf. 1732/6).'*!
Nonetheless, Euristeo was still receiving applause on 7 June and had its last performance on the 9th.'
Zeno's text had first been set by Caldara for performance at the imperial court in Vienna in 1724.'3

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

In this satire on the financial dilemmas of theaters, the poor musician Alipio loved the Bolognese singer
Lispina, who was pursued by the rich Baron Seccagine. In an echo of Marcello's J/ teatro alla moda,
Lispina was accompanied by her meddlesome mother (Sempiterna) and her servant (Mamolo), while
her performances were managed by the impecunious impresario Saltobello and his assistant Volpino.
To obviate damaging testimony, Saltobello recommended that they form a new company in a faraway
land where they would be respected and well compensated. After the baron learned to sing and Volpino
to play the archlute, the baron agreed to fund the troupe. The three Bolognese roles were sung in
Bolognese dialect, but the casting for them is unknown. Groppo labeled the work ridiculous.'TM
Chi non fa was first performed in Venice on 21 May 1732 (A). Like Euristeo, it ran despite the death
of the doge on the eve of Ascension. The original production had been given in Bologna in 1729. Chi
non fa was revived under the title // protettore alla moda (1747/9).

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 683; Groppo 687; Wiel 330; Alm 844

L'ortolana contessa Music attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini and others
[THE GARDENER WHO WAS A COUNTESS]

A divertimento comico Text attributed to Giuseppe Maria Buini
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1732-06-02
Without dedicatee

The subject of the shepherdess-turned-countess was essentially one which could have originated in
an intermezzo but is here elaborated for a cast of eight. Celindo, the unmarried son of the wealthy
Monsieur Panicone, is unable to respond to the love of the countess Ardelinda. He has fallen in love
instead with the peasant Lauretta. The cast members are not named. L'ortolana contessa was first
performed on 2 June 1732 (A), the date of election of the new doge, Carlo Ruzzini. Although Groppo
characterized the work as ridiculous,'*> it was said to have been received with high praise.'* Its final
performance was on the 9th, when both the theatrical season and the festivities in celebration of the
new doge ended.'3

No musical sources known

1732/9 L' Issipile Music by Giovanni Porta
[HyYPSIPYLE]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Pietro Metastasio'*!
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1732-11-22
a Dedicated to Karl-Albrecht, Elector of Bavaria

In this story taken from Greek mythology, Thoas, the king of the Aegean island of Lemnos, had arranged
for the marriage of his daughter Hypsipyle to Jason, the prince of Thessaly. Their enemies, the Thracians,
led by Hypsipyle's spurned suitor, Learchos, conspired to sabotage the pair.

OOo The production of this first opera, which was in rehearsal by 15 November, opened on 22 November
1732 (A) to universal applause. The theater was newly refurbished to improve both its appearance
and its acoustics. '*? Nonetheless, the well-worn temple of Bacchus was employed in Act One. Antonia
Merighi sang in the title role, with Filippo Giorgi (Toante), Venturin Rocchetti (Giasone), Giuseppa
Pircher (Learco), and the Bavarian Anna Rosa (Rodope). Metastasio's text had been set earlier in 1732
by Porpora (Teatro delle Dame, Rome), Hasse (San Bartolomeo, Naples), and Francesco Conti (Imperial
court, Vienna). While it enjoyed extensive success elsewhere, it was set only two further times for Venice
 once by Gassmann (San Moise, 1758) and once by Marinelli (La Fenice, 1796).

A Scores in A-Wgm; I-MC, Tn (inc.); arias in I-Ne

1732/10 La caduta di Leone, Music by Giuseppe Antonio Paganelli'

imperatore d'Oriente

1732/11 Nitocri Music by Giuseppe Sellitti'*
[NiTROCRIS]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Apostolo Zeno by Domenico Lalli
i Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1732-12-26~
a Dedicated to Count Carlo Prata

The ancient Egyptian queen Nitocris (Antonia Merighi) was celebrated for her beauty and her virtue.
One of the famous pyramids outside Memphis, then the capital of Egypt, was, according to legend,
built in her honor. The murder of her brother led to her ascension to the throne of Armenia, but she
remained unmarried, a subject probed here. Of the two Egyptian generals who were in love with her
sister, Emirena, it was Mirteos (Carlo Broschi) who prevailed on the stage. Meanwhile, the royal prince
Ratese (Filippo Giorgi) hoped for the hand of the queen.'*

< #  Asthe second opera, it is probable that Nitocri opened on or about 26 December 1732, although no
notice of it has come to light. It is remotely possible that it opened closer to the start of Carnival (11
January 1733). Zeno's text had previously been set by Caldara (Vienna, 1722). The stage props included
Egyptian obelisks. Contrasts of bright light and darkness were used to heighten the visual drama. The
scenery designer was Girolamo Mingozzi Colonna, identified in the libretto as a member of the Capitoline
Academy (Rome).

A Scores in D-B, Dlb; arias in US- BEm (opera 2.a)
Listed as Bonlini 688; Groppo 692; Wiel 339; Alm 850

 Argenide recounts the shipwreck of Idomeneos, the king of Crete, who vowed to kill the first person

who arrived on his beach if the god Neptune would spare his life. When this proved to be his own son,
the marriage of Princess Argenide, which (hypothetically) occurred just before the curtain was raised,
was disrupted. The story was embroidered with frivolous subplots. Argenide opened on 15 January
1733.'% It was still running on 7 February (A). Teresa Peruzzi sang as Argenide, with Gregorio Babbi
as Idomeneos.

6 The Neapolitan Sellitti (1700-77) was chiefly active in Naples and Rome.

Nitocris (a name shared by a Babylonian queen), according to Herodotus, avenged her brother's murder by building an underground reception
room, inviting the suspects to dine there, and then allowing the Nile to flood the premises. This legendary event does not seem to have been
re-enacted in the dramma per musica. Nitocris, who ruled at the end of the sixth dynasty (to 2195 BC) was arguably the earliest female ruler
in recorded history. Like the roles of many servants, nymphs, and shepherds, those of Mirteo and Ratese have no historical foundation.

Adriano in Siria Music by Geminiano Giacomelli
[HADRIAN IN SYRIA]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Pollastrella e Parpagnacco;'* balli SORTING DATE: 1733-01-30

Dedicated to Sicinio Pepoli'

The emperor Hadrian [117-138 AD] (Antonio Barbieri), in conquering the Parthians, had taken their
princess Emirena (Anna Rosa Bavarese) as his captive. He soon fell in love with her. Already engaged
to Sabina (Antonia Merighi), he was torn between love and duty. A fter marriage, his infidelities continued
and his hostility towards Emirena's lover, Pharnaspes (Carlo Broschi), was marked. Adriano opened
on 30 January 1733'* with universal applause (A). Metastasio's text had first been set by Caldara
for performance in Vienna on 9 November 1732. It remained in use through the rest of the century.
With revisions, it was the basis for Pergolesi's work of the same name (Naples, 1734).

The widowed Armenian queen Berenice, who was universally disliked for her ferocious spirit,

Giovanna Guaetta (Idrena).

1733/4 L'ambizione depressa Music by Baldassare Galuppi
[AMBITION THWARTED]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Giuseppe Papis'
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1733-05-13
& Dedicated to Henry Bouverie, Count of Radnor'
 In this quasi-pastoral plot, Berenice (Elisabetta Moro), the princess of Argos, believed herself to be

more beautiful than Juno. Her father offered her hand as a reward to whomever could cure her of her
narcissistic obsession, which was unacceptable to the local culture. The Mycenaean prince Hydaspes
(Francesco Grisi) disguised himself as a shepherd to pursue this goal. Hydaspes in turn was pursued
by the princess Emirena (Maria Camati), who was dressed as a huntress. L ambizione depressa was
first performed on 13 May 1733 (A). It closed on the 31st.

1733/5 Ginevra Music by Giuseppe Sellitti'
[GINEVRA]
A dramma per musica Text by Antonio Salvi, rev. Giovanni Boldini
ry Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1733-05-13
& Dedicated to the Prince of Ardore'
CO Following Ariosto (here termed the Tuscan Homer), the tale of the Scottish princess Guinevere/Ginevra

(Antonia Negri), which had been set by Pollarolo under the title Ariodante (1716/8), is related with
particular emphasis on the pursuit of the duke Polynexos (Antonio Baldi), despite the official interest
of the foreign prince Ariodante (Felice Salimbeni). Ginevra was first performed on 13 May 1733, when
the drama was found to be plausible.' The production closed on the 31st (A). A work of the same
title, set by Antonio Galeazzi, was given in Jesi in the same year by a cast which included Giuseppa
Pircher (Ginevra) and Elisabetta Moro (Polinesso).' Vivaldi's setting (RV 716) opened in Florence
on 17 January 1736.' Among many later settings of the work was that of Bertoni (San Samuele, 1753).

1733/6 Montezuma Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[MONTEZUMA]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Girolamo or Alvise Giusti!
im Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With Drusilla e Poliperconte;'* SORTING DATE: 1733-11-14
Mergellina e don Narciso; and balli
& Without dedicatee

Montezuma, the leader of the Aztecs, was conquered by the Spanish explorer Cortez in 1519. This plot
deals with the final days of Aztec rule. The historical background of the story, a distinct departure for
the Venetian stage, was to be more popular in the nineteenth century than in the eighteenth.' The account
itself was little different from countless tales spun from European antiquity. Montezuma's daughter
Teutila fell in love with Ramirez, the brother of his Spanish conqueror. A fter various adventures involving
disguises, oracles, and threatened human sacrifices, Teutila and Ramirez succeeded to the throne jointly.

 & Vivaldi's firstnew work for the Venetian stage in five years opened as the opera prima at Sant' Angelo
on 14 November 1733 (A). Found to be agreeable, it was noted especially for its very beautiful
dances,' which were by Giovanni Gallo. Massimiliano Miller sang in the lead role, with Anna Gird
as his wife (Mitrena), Giuseppa Pircher (Teutile), and Francesco Bilanzoni (Fernando Cortes). Among
the progeny of the text was a setting by Pasquale Anfossi (Reggio, 1776). Spontini's Fernand Cortez
(Paris, 1809) was based on a different source. The opening scene was situated in the lagoon of
Mexico,'' which divided the imperial palace from the Spanish quarter. An Aztec sacrificial ceremony
was depicted in the next but last scene of Act Three. Antonio Mauro was the set designer.

and a package of costumes (un involto di roba da vestire) to enjoy in my memory (oc. cit.).

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Berenice Music by Francesco Araya'?
[BERENICE]

A dramma per musica Text derived from Antonio Salvi!
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1733-12-26

Dedicated to the Marchioness Vidona'

After Cleopatra Berenice succeeded to the Egyptian throne [first century BC], according to this account,
the Romans feared that through marriage she would align Egypt with Pontos, then ruled by Mithridates.
Alexander, the son of Ptolemy Alexander, was dispatched from Rome, where he had been educated,
to crush this possibility by seeking her hand in marriage. The work was situated in Alexandria, and
the scenes of Act Three featured a picture gallery and a mausoleum of the ancient Egyptian kings.
Berenice opened on 26 December 1733 (NV)! and was still running on c. 11 January 1734 (A). The
Neapolitan castrato Gaetano Majorana sang as Alexander,' with Lucia Facchinelli as Berenice and
Carlo Broschi as Demetrios. Araya's setting had been given in Florence in 1730; the text itself had
first been set by Perti (Pratolino, 1709). The best known setting was to be that of Handel (Berenice,
Queen of Egypt; HWV 38), which was produced at Covent Garden (May 1737). Salvi's account offers
an interesting contrast with that of Pasqualigo, set by Orlandini as 1725/1.

Arias in B-Bc

Listed as Bonlini 695; Groppo 699; Wiel 347; Alm 857

Candalide Music by Tomaso Albinoni!
[CANDALIDE]

A dramma per musica Text by Bartolomeo Vitturi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With Drusilla e Poliperconte; balli (cori) SORTING DATE: 1734-01-05
Without dedicatee

The Egyptian king Zanthyppos/Santippo (Angela Zannucchi) had fallen in love with the dowry of
the Persian princess Candalide (Rosa Cirili). While her travel to his homeland was still in progress,
Emirena, the daughter of one of his generals, came to his notice. She was engaged to Gusman (Francesco
Bilanzoni), another general, who returned victorious from battle only to discover that Emirena had been
disloyal. Candalide departed as the wedding of Zanthyppos and Emirena (Marta Arigoni) was about
to begin.' The action takes place in Memphis [the predecessor of Cairo].

Candalide was first performed, as the second opera, on 5 January 1734 (A, NV)' with universal
enjoyment (A). Albinoni seems to have been recalled from retirement to fill in for the absent Vivaldi,
who was staging revivals of two of his works (Zamerlano and Adelaide) at the new theater of the

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

L'Olimpiade Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[THE OLYMPIAD]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Pietro Metastasio by Bartolomeo Vitturi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1734-02-17
Without dedicatee

Heeding the advice of an oracle, Kleisthenes/Clistene (Marc' Antonio Mareschi), the tyrannical king
of Sikyon (on the Peloponnesian coast), separated his twins. He sent his son away to be raised under
a new identity and kept his daughter Aristeia (Anna Caterina Della Parte) nearby, where she grew to
be a beautiful young woman. He then offered her hand in marriage to the winner of the next Olympic
games. The noble Megakles (Francesco Bilanzoni), a frequent winner, fell in love with her. After being
attacked by bandits on the island of Crete, his life was saved by the stranger Lycis/Licida (Angela
Zannucchi). Lycis pined for the banished Argene (Marta Arrigoni), who was now disguised as a
shepherdess Licori. A medal enabled the king to determine that Lycis was his long-lost son.'

L 'Olimpiade was first performed, with applause, as the fourth opera!*! on 17 February 1734 (A, NV).'

It was the first work by Metastasio to be given at Sant' Angelo, which may have been trying to right
the wrong caused by audience preference for Artaserse (1734/3) at San Giovanni Grisostomo over its
own recent offering, Dorilla in Tempe (1734/2). The lifetime of Metastasio's text, first set by Caldara
for Vienna in 1733, endured through the setting of Cimarosa (Vicenza, 1784). Among its notable settings
was the pastiche version (with music by Riccardo Broschi, Hasse, Ariosti, and Porpora) given in London
the following autumn and the revised version of Goldoni, which was to be heard at San Giovanni
Grisostomo in Pergolesi's setting (1738/6). Almost all of the scenes  woods, countryside, grottos,
meadows  were exterior but apparently opulent. The final scene, outside a temple dedicated to Jupiter,
featured laurel and olive groves. Antonio Mauro designed the sets.

Score in I-Tn; arias in US- BEm

Listed as Bonlini 699; Groppo 703; Wiel 344; Alm 861; RV 725

version was first performed on 20 February 1734 (A, NV).'TM Benigna reports that it was last performed
from 19:00 to 24:00 O.V. on 9 March [the last night of Carnival] and notes the participation of Carlo

whose beautiful daughter Agariste married Megakles.

Tirsi Music anonymous
[Tirst]

A dramma pastorale Text adapted by Pietro Chechia
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1734-02-22

Without dedicatee''

Tirsi was first performed on 22 February 1734 (A).' It is unclear whether it was an adaptation of (a)
Lemene's La ninfa Apollo (1709 et al; see 1734/7), (b) Creta's Filindo (1720/6), or (c) Nerina, Lalli's
revision of Filindo (San Samuele, 1728/6). Groppo and Sartori supported the first. Chechia's adaptation
as it appears in US-LAu (c) suggests the third, since it consists of a new title-page attached to the 1728
libretto. If the actual case is (c), then the cast list is highly improbable, since the singers who appeared
at Ascension 1728 would not have abandoned San Giovanni Grisostomo at the height of Carnival in
1734 to sing at San Moise. A revision of the 1720 work (b) to accommodate some characteristics (e.g.,
role names) from 1728 is a distinct possibility. Half a dozen provincial productions of Filindo in the
1720s involved Pietro Denzio (probably as impresario), and San Moise was his main base.

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 701; Groppo 705; Wiel 351; Alm 863'

La ninfa Apollo Music by Baldassare Galuppi
[THE NYMPH APOLLO]

A favola pastorale Text adapted from Francesco de Lemene by Giovanni Boldini
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With La Pelarina;TM balli SORTING DATE: 1734-05-30

Dedicated to Carlo Salvetti?'

This popular pastoral, newly set by Galuppi, used essentially the same text as the 1709 work (Suppl.
5b), 1730/10, and 1734/6. At its opening performance, on 30 May 1734 (NV), La ninfa was received
with much appreciation (A). Prominent Neapolitans were particularly conspicuous at the concurrent
fair. The cast included Teresa Cotti (Filli), Livia Barbieri (Lilla), Angelo Maria Monticelli (Elpino),
and Giuseppe Appiani (Tirsi). The staging was undoubtedly more elaborate than that of the favola

5 Benigna, Memorie, f. 52. This was Farinelli's last appearance in Venice. He was engaged to sing, under Porpora's direction, at the Opera

of the Nobility in London from October 1734.

Tamiri Music by Baldassare Galuppi?TM
[THOMyYRIS]

A dramma per musica Text by Bartolomeo Vitturi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)

Dedicated to Pedro Cebrian y Agustin, Count of Fuenclara>

When the Scythians fought the Greek forces of Constantinople, the handsome prince Klearchos (Castoro
Antonio Castorini), who was in charge of the defense, was taken prisoner. Thomyris, the queen of the
Massagetes, who was loved by two generals of her army (Pellegrin Tomi? and Giuseppe Todeschini),
fell in love with him. This first drama opened on 17 November 1734 (A, NV). A license to print
the libretto was dated 9 November 1734, which was also the date of dedication of the libretto. It appears,
however, that Tamiri was already being prepared for Sant' Angelo on 16 October.

Demofoonte' Music by Gaetano Maria Schiassi?!
[DEMOPHON]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1734-12-26

Dedicated to Francesco Caraffa, Prince of Colobrano"!

Anoracle of Apollo demanded that a Thracian virgin be sacrificed to the god every year. King Demophon
(Annibale Pio Fabbri) was reluctant to comply. His son Timanthes (Antonio Bernacchi) was officially
engaged to the Phrygian princess Creusa (Giustina Gallo) but was secretly married to Dirkeia/Dircea
(Anna Maria Peruzzi), the current choice for the annual sacrifice. Unaware of his son's marriage,
Demophon sent his other son, Cherintos (Gioachino Conti, Egiziello), to fetch Creusa. It was
subsequently discovered that Dirkeia was actually Demophon's daughter. Cherintos, who will wed
Creusa, proves to be Demophon's true heir." Conti, a celebrated singer of coming decades, was making
his Venetian debut.

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1730-39) 443

Demofoonte opened in Venice on 26 December 1734 (A, NV), when it was received with general
appreciation and applause.?'? Fabbri, who was in the service of the emperor, and Conti were both
making their Venetian debuts. Metastasio's text had first been set by Caldara for performance in Vienna
on 4 November 1733. Schiassi's setting was the second of some 75 that can be counted through the
end of the century. The scenery, designed by Antonio Joli, invested particular effort in the arrival of
the Phrygian princess, whose entry was accompanied by the sound of barbarous instruments. The
temple of Apollo was shown in a state of utter confusion.

The libretto was the subject of some considerazioni addressed in a didactic letter from Edvardo Edesimo
to one of his friends dated 23 February 1735."* This letter was written in response to a libretto sent
to the writer, who obviously did not witness the production. At the start he emphasized the importance
of good taste, which he defined as an internal sentiment of pleasure' which needs to be expressed
in the details as well as the central subject. He then examined the way in which each character furthers
the drama. His opinion of Metastasio, whom he labeled learned and prudent, is extremely laudatory.'
He praised the nobility, splendor, and sweetness of [the works of] Apostolo Zeno, even while
acknowledging that in some quarters his debts to French drama were regarded as overly abundant.!
After this grand assessment of drama from the Greeks and Latins to his own times, he offered to show
his modest work, but it does not form part of this publication.

Score in B-Bc
Listed as Bonlini 705; Groppo 709; Wiel 353; Alm 868

Lucio Vero Music by Francesco Araya
(Lucius VERuS]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Apostolo Zeno
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1735-01-04

Dedicated to Nicole Benedetti, Duke of Ferentillo'

In this resetting of Zeno's text (C. F. Pollarolo; 1699/9), Pellegrin Tomi from the ducal chapel sang
in the title role, with Antonia Negri Tomi (La Mestrina) as Berenice. Although the text remained
popular throughout the century, this was the only later setting given in Venice. A second drama, it
opened on 4 January 1735 (A, NV), one day before the start of Carnival (NV). During the decades since
the text had first appeared, it had been set by several composers including Albinoni (Ferrara, 1713),
Gasparini (Rome, 1716), and Ariosti (London, 1727).'* Traetta was the last composer to set it (for St.
Petersburg, 1774).

1735/2 L'Anagilda Music by Antonio Gaetano Pampani!
[ANAGILDA]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Antonio Zaniboni'
mM Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival?)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1735-01-05~
& Dedicated to Leopoldo Ottavio della Torre [Torriano], Count of Valsassina and Taxis!

The story, generally considered to be a pastoralized version of La forza della virtit (1692/7), may be
indebted as well to the text of the Anagilda set by C. F. Pollarolo for Reggio Emilia (1685).Here the
story was related from the point of view of Rodrigo's brother, Accosta, the prince of Castile. Its action
took place in Toledo. Angela Zannucchi sang in the title role with Giacomo Zacchini as Sancio and
Alessandro Erba as Rodrigo. One scene featured a gallery of portraits of the kings of Castile.

 According to Groppo, the work had only two performances. The lapse was probably caused by the
death of the doge on 10 January rather than any deficiencies of the work. If the production opened
between the Sth and the 8th, it did not reopen after the installation of the new doge, Alvise Pisani, on
the 17th. Since San Cassiano had been closed for a number of years, it was an unfortunate time to relaunch
opera productions there.

1735/3 La clemenza di Tito Music by Leonardo Leo
[THE CLEMENCY OF TITUS]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Pietro Metastasio by Domenico Lalli
M1 Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1735-01-29
@ Dedicated to the Baron Hopken and Sig. Carlson?

CO The clemency of Titus, the son of Vespasian and emperor of Rome from 79 to 81 AD, was extended
in this work towards two young noblemen who were condemned by the Senate to die for their treachery.
This second drama was first performed on 29 January 1735 (A, NV).6 Annibale Pio Fabbri sang
in the title role, with Antonio Bernacchi (Sesto) and Gioacchino Conti (Annio) as the noblemen. The
scenery included recreations of the Campidoglio and Palatine Hills of Rome. Metastasio's libretto had
first been set by Caldara for the emperor's name-day (4 November) in 1734. It became enormously
popular. The longest-lived of later settings has been that of Mozart, on a text revised by Caterino Mazzola.
It was first given in Prague on 6 September 1791.

1735/4 Caio Fabrizio Music by Johann Adolf Hasse
[CAIUS FABRITIUS]
A dramma per musica Text attributed to Apostolo Zeno
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1735-02-12
& Dedicated to Marchioness Ippolita Calcagnini'

The residents of Tarento, when succumbing to the advancing Romans, enlisted the help of Pyrrhos,
the king of Albania/Epiros and Macedonia. His friend Megades (who at the time was believed to be
the king) was killed in a battle preceded by a stampede of elephants. The delegation of Romans who
came to make peace was headed by Caius Fabritius. The negotiations were enlivened in this account
with plots involving Pyrrhos's wife (Bircenna) and Caius's daughter (Sestia).

Oo This third drama opened on 12 February 1735 (NV) and cannot have run for more than a week.
Pellegrin Tomi sang in the title role, with Castoro Antonio Castorini (Pirro), Maria Camati (Bircenna),
and Antonia Negri (Sestia). Numerous surviving scores demonstrate that Caio Fabrizio was already
well known from previous performances elsewhere. Among these was a production opening on 27
December 1732 for the inauguration of the Teatro Arciducale in Mantua. Caldara had been the first
to set the text (in 1729) for performance at the Viennese court. Hasse's work had had its first performance
in Rome on 12 January 1732. Handel conducted a pastiche (HWV A9) based mainly on this work in
London in December 1733. Caio Fabrizio was given in Naples in the winter of 1734, in Dresden in
the next summer, and in Berlin in 1766.

Cesare in Egitto Music by Geminiano Giacomelli
[CAESAR IN EGYPT]

A dramma per musica Text by Giacomo Francesco BussaniTM?
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1735-11-24

Dedicated to Louis, Count of SalbourgTM

Bussani's libretto (Giulio Cesare in Egitto), set by Sartorio as 1676/6, concerned the conflict between
political duty and its defiance by the passions of love. It had been the basis for Handel's like-named
work (HWV 17; 1724). Among its other settings was that of Predieri (Rome, 1728). Cesare was first
performed in Venice on 24 November 1735 (A), but it had been staged in Milan the preceding January.
Cesare was still running on 3 December. The journalist Trebbi called it a marvel (A). The cast
included Felice Salimbeni (Giulio Cesare), Vittoria Tesi Tramontini (his wife, Cornelia), Angelo
Amorevoli (Jolomeo), and Margherita Giacomezzi (his sister, Cleopatra).

This story, first set by C. F. Pollarolo as 1703/4 and reset as the pastiche 1722/5, was situated in

the title-page was dated 1736. In this production Angelo Tramontini took the title role, with Felice
Salimbeni and Giovanni Cupilli as his sons Casimir and Alexander. Margherita Giacomazzi was cast
as Eirenike, whom both sons loved.

Elisa, regina di Tiro Music by Baldassare Galuppi
[ELISSA, QUEEN OF TYRE]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from A. Zeno and P. Pariati by Domenico Lalli
Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli* SORTING DATE: 1735-12-27

Dedicated to Franz Wilhelm Rudolf, Count of Hohenems

In this adaptation of Astarto (1708/7), which opened on 27 December 1735 (A, NV), Abdastartos, the
king of Tyre, was killed by his nurse's son, Sychaios, who ruled for the next twelve years. His daughter
Elissa (Antonia Negri Tomi), who succeeded him upon his death, was eventually married to Abdastartos's
son, Astartos, who presented himself as Klearchos (Rosa Maddalena Cardina).* In comparison to the
version of 1708, the reworking is, atypically, more dignified than its model in its brevity, its de-emphasis
of disguise, and its substitution of balli for the celebrated intermezzi of Vespetta e Pimpinone, which
were first performed with the 1708 work. The title-page is dated 1736.

L' Alessandro nell' Indie Music by Johann Adolf Hasse?"
[ALEXANDER IN INDIA]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio, rev. Michel Angiolo Boccardi
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With unspecified intermezzi* and balli SORTING DATE: 1736-01-28

Dedicated to the Marquis [Antonio?] Botta?

Metastasio's text on Alexander's last campaign (1730) had been set at least seven times previously.
Under the title Cleofide, Hasse's version (and his earliest setting of a work by Metastasio) had first
been given in Dresden 13 September 1731. Its earliest setting in Venice was Pescetti's (1732/1). Vivaldi
adapted Hasse's version for performance in Ferrara for the Carnival of 1737. He was instructed to shorten
the work because operas which last four hours are unacceptable in Ferrara.**

This third drama, first performed in Venice on 28 January 1736 (A),** received the full applause
of the city (NV). Angiolo Amorevoli sang in the title role, with Castoro Antonio Castorini (Poro) and
Vittoria Tesi Tramontini (Cleofide). The production was still in progress on 11 February, when Hasse
wrote to Francesco Riva, the secretary to the duke of Modena, that the work was having a better reception
than he ever would have imagined. The theater is always full. We have had twelve recitations so far;
only four remain. By the time they are finished, we hope to have sold 12,000 bollettini, something which
is very rare in Venice, even with the best companies. The current one at San Giovanni Grisostomo is
weakened by the absence of our gifted Felicino [Salimbeni]; all the merit of our work is attributed either

oO8 The production of Goldoni's first opera seria opened on 9 May 1736 with ordinary applause (A,
NV). Like works for Giovedi Grasso, this one required a relatively small cast of five. The production

the end of Carnival. On the 1 8th the French ambassador, Charles-Frangois de Froullay, invited the work's
ballarine to a luncheon with his mother. This aroused the suspicion ofa Venetian government agent.

Il Demetrio Music by Johann Adolf Hasse
[DEMETRIOS]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1737-01-15

Dedicated to Count Francesco Perlongo

This revival of 1732/3 opened on 15 January 1737 (NV).* Vivaldi twice declined to provide a work

for this slot at San Cassiano, first because he was offered only 90 zecchini, then, when offered 100

zecchini, because he regarded San Cassiano as poorly organized, yet [having] high ticket prices. Also

he was preparing works for performance in Ferrara. In the actual event, he was prohibited from entering

Ferrara by the papal legate, so two works by Hasse (this one and Alessandro nell'Indie, [1736/1] with

revisions by Vivaldi) were substituted for the ones Vivaldi had planned (his own Ginevra [RV 716,

Florence, 1736] and Olimpiade [RV 725], 1734/4)2*!

In both locales, Demetrio found much favor with gentlemen (cavalieri), somewhat to Vivaldi's dismay.

The role of Cleonike was taken by Lucia Facchinelli in Venice and by Anna Gire in Ferrara. The cast

for San Cassiano also included Felice Salimbeni (A/ceste) and Pietro Baratti (Fenicio). Demetrio was

revived, after 1737/4, for the last two nights of Carnival.?

In this parody of earlier serious dramas, the Venetian slave Mirmicaina (known as Regina [the Queen]
in Venice) is about to be crowned the Turkish empress when the emperor, Albumazar, is told by
Ruskamar, the keeper of his harem, that a beautiful white woman has been discovered on a Black
Sea beach. The emperor promises Mirmicaina to Ruskamar if his new discovery, Lucretia, is pleasing

to the emperor. Before such a pairing can occur, the short, fat Lucretia and the tall, thin Mirmicaina

oo Lugrezia was given by the comedy troupe in the tempo della commedia in 1737. While this is an
ambiguous designation, circumstantial evidence suggests that it was given in the later half of Carnival
1737.78 By one account, the audience only laughed at Mirmicaina, with whose coronation the work
opens. Singing in Venetian dialect,*' she exhorts  in contrast to the friends, Romans, countrymen
of Julius Caesar  bastards, soldiers, eunuchs, common people, and rabble to court my favor by
speaking Italian ... even if you are Islamic.**

en Under Goldoni's direction the comedy troupe at San Samuele regularly ridiculed the pretentiousness
of modem representations of antiquity, particularly the false use of Graeco-Roman settings in the staging
of works by Zeno and Metastasio. However, models predating Goldoni seem to exist for this work.?
The choice of roles could also have been influenced by Buini's scherzo musicale called Albumazar
(1727/6), which dealt with Turkish-Bolognese (as opposed to Turkish-Venetian) relations. In a
mischievous introduction, Goldoni said that the displacement of people from their customary venues
and time-frames should be attributed to poetic license. The text lingered in the public mind and reappeared
as a farsa giocosa set in 1800 by Vittorio Trento for San Moise.

Artaserse Longimano Music by Gaetano Antonio Pampani?TM*
[ARTAXERXES LONGIMAN]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Pietro Metastasio by Giovanni Boldini
Performed at Sant'Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1737-02-19

Dedicated to Zaccaria Canal, N. V.2%

This tale about Xerxes was related through the deeds of the young Artaxerxes Longiman. The Greek
captain Themistocles traveled incognito in Persia to ask his enemy for asylum. Although his intention
was hostile, Themistocles was torn between the generosity of his unwitting host and his loyalty to his
homeland. His dilemma was resolved when the noble Xerxes, facing death, asked for peace with the
Greeks.

This third drama opened on 19 February 1737 (A, NV). Lorenzo Ghirardi sang in the title role, with
Cesare Grandis as Themistocles. Another hint of the possibility that Sant' Angelo's winter season was
a memorial to the recently deceased Caldara lies in the fact that this work, given in succession to Ciro
(1737/1), was based on Metastasio's Temistocle. Caldara's setting of it for the emperor's name-day
(4 November 1736) was his last composition.

No musical sources known

Listed as Bonlini 728; Groppo 732; Wiel 371; Alm 893

Rosbale Music by Nicole Porpora
[ROSBALE]

A dramma per musica Text by Claudio Nicola Stampa
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1737-11-23

Dedicated to Luis Reggio y BranciforteTMTM

Rosbale was surprised by the military force called forth by the Tartar emperor Sirbakes in order to restore
the Moghul throne (on which Rosbale now sat) to the deposed Sarabes. When Rosbale's own son was
killed in battle by Sirbakes, he made it a condition of peace that should Sirbakes also die, Sarabes's
only daughter would ascend the Tartar throne. This came to pass.

Rosbale, the first work to be produced under the new impresario Carlo Goldoni, had its premiere on
23 November 1737 (NV). It was reported to have been well received (assai applaudita) and thus
to have drawn a very full house (pienissimo |'uditorio) (A). The Neapolitan Francesco Tolve sang in
the title role, with Carlo Scalzi as Sirbace.* Scalzi had probably returned from England with Porpora,
who resigned from the Opera of the Nobility after composing the wedding music for the prince of Wales
(May 1736) and briefly resumed his post at the Incurabili.

Antonio Joli's sets and the staging generally were highly imaginative. Situated in the Moghul capital,
Agra, the work opened showing it set for a military siege. The forces were divided by the Gemma River,

28 | ampugnani (1708-88) was born and died in Milan but he worked in various venues including Venice and London. His musical style was

somewhat like that of Vivaldi but its reception was often indifferent.

OGL This resetting of Zeno's Merope (1712/1) had most recently been treated by Giacomelli for San Giovanni
Grisostomo as 1734/5. The new production opened on 28 December 1737. It was reported to have

Rossi (Polifonte) and Anna Gird (Merope). L oracolo was revived with minor revisions at the Karntnertor
Theater, Vienna, during Carnival 1742.

3 Latilla (1711-88), born in Bari and trained in Naples, was making his debut as a composer of opera seria. He thereafter enjoyed the patronage
of Romans and Britons and toured extensively, returning to Venice in the 1740s as a popular composer of opere buffe. He served as maestro
di coro of the Pieta in Venice from 1753 to 1766.

3' The date is confirmed in the Diario ordinario, No. 3187, p. 11.

38 Vivaldi was to have been in Ferrara to produce an opera at the Teatro Bonacossi, but his plans were disrupted by the papal legate, Cardinal
Ruffo, who prohibiting Vivaldi from entering the city because of his friendship with Anna Gird. The edict was acknowledged by Vivaldi
on 16 November. Vivaldi protested when his benefactor Bentivoglio subsequently suggested the production should take place without him.
He wrote on the 25th, I never play in the orchestra, except on the opening night, because it would be beneath my dignity to work as an
instrumentalist. I no longer stay in the same house with the Giro [sisters]...in fact for my house in Venice I pay 200 ducats.... (Io mai suono
in orchestra, salvo che la prima sera, perche non degno di far il mestiere del suonatore....In casa con le Gird io non sto mai...in Venezia una
e la casa mia, che paga 200 ducati..., Heller, Cronologia, pp. 62f).

3! Diario ordinario, No. 3190, p. 10; Mancini et al. (Teatri, i/2, 39) give 30 December as the opening date. Antonio Vinciguerra, the count
of Collalto, was a leading patron of the Karntnertor theater in Vienna, where this work was mounted in 1742. The Viennese theaters had been
closed throughout the 1740-41 season in observance of the death of the emperor Charles VI (20 October 1740). Talbot speculates in Vivaldi
(Master Musicians, 3rd edn., p. 169) that the composer's trip to Vienna in 1741 may have been motivated by a plan (necessarily aborted) to
produce L'oracolo during that season. Vivaldi's final lodgings were in the K4rntnerstrasse, near the theater. In June 1741, a month before
his death (on 27 July), Vivaldi sold several concertos to the count.

gone to San Giovanni Grisostomo with friends. On the 17th he left his pas de deux at home, causing
total commotion and scandal. Vivaldi proposed not to pay him for these performances.*

Angelica Music by Giovanni Battista Lampugnani
[ANGELICA]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Carlo Vedova
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1738-05-11

Dedicated to Francesco III d'Este, Duke of Modena*

This account of the love of Angelica (Anna Mazzoni) and Medoro (Giovanni Tedeschi) was written
by a librettist who considered himself to be an accidental poet with no previous experience. He was
given eight days, he claimed, to write the text. His objective was to give natural and clear expression,
which was said to have been derived from the tragedy Anglica e Medoro by Mons. Dolfin.* Angelica
was first performed on 11 May 1738 (A), the Sunday before Ascension, with full applause (NV).*
Its purpose was to entertain the numerous foreign nobles here (A).*! The dedicatee and two princesses
of Modena arrived on the 14th (NV).

Aria in I-Bc

L'Olimpiade Music adapted from Giovanni Battista Pergolesi
[THE OLYMPIAD] by Johann Adolf Hasse
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Pietro Metastasio by Carlo Goldoni
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1738-11-22

Dedicated to Giuseppe de Baeza**

This setting was first performed in the sumptuous theater of San Giovanni Grisostomo on 22 November
1738 with considerable applause (A).*? The cast included Faustina Bordoni (Aristea) in her next-to-last
season in Venice and Antonio Barbieri (Clistene) in his final production. The staging, undoubtedly
more lavish than that for Sant' Angelo, featured grand vistas of the countryside, moved to a site near
the Olympic games, and featured the temple of Jupiter, where the winning athletes were crowned.
Metastasio's text had been set by Vivaldi and staged at Sant' Angelo (1734/4) under Lalli's direction.
The work was now produced under Goldoni's administration.** Hasse later (1756) reset the entire text
for Dresden.

Achille in Sciro Music by Pietro Chiarini
[ACHILLES ON SCYROS]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Pietro Metastasio by Bartolomeo Vitturi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With Larinda e Vanessio;*' Lucilla e Pandolfo; SORTING DATE: 1739-01-10

Serpilla e Bacocco
Dedicated to Michel Bernardo, N. V.
Achilles, who was to become the hero of the Trojan War and a central figure in Homer's liad, was
hidden by his mother on the island of Scyros to enable him to avoid the war. There, while he was
disguised as a girl, he fell in love with Deidamia, the king's daughter. This second opera was first
performed on 10 January 1739 (A, NV). Francesca Poli was cast as Achille, with Maddalena Mollarini
as Deidamia. Metastasio's text had first been given in Caldara's setting at the court theater in Vienna
in 1736. Legrenzi's setting of Bentivoglio's text of the same title had been staged in Ferrara (1663)
and Venice (1664; cd. Suppl. 2a).
