Feraspe Music by Antonio Vivaldi
[PHERASPES]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Francesco Silvani by Bartolomeo Vitturi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1739-11-07

Dedicated to Marquis Ferdinando Monti*4

Ancient Persian lines of succession were confused by the fact that Darius had had two wives  Stateira
and Roxane. He had one son by each. Upon his death, his lands were to be divided between them. This
account emphasized the efforts of Pheraspes, his son by his first marriage, to reconsolidate the empire.
Vivaldi's last opera opened on 7 November 1739 (PV).** The performances were well attended and
the singers merited applause, according to Pallade Veneta. The Neapolitan Andrea Masno sang in
the title role, with Catterina Fumagalli (Statira), Elena Venier (Rosane), and Giacomo Zaghini (Astiage).
Writing from Rome in the same year, the French statesman Charles de Brosses paraphrased Tartini's
observation on the very different receptions of Vivaldi's operas and his instrumental works by saying,
Vivaldi...has been hissed for the first and praised for the [second].*

Because they were not paid promptly, the singers brought suit against Vivaldi in ensuing months.
This financial reversal may have contributed to Vivaldi's ill-fated departure from Venice. His name
had disappeared from the roster of the Pieta the preceding April, following a sharp dispute with his
brother-in-law, the scenographer Antonio Mauro, over a cancelled Carnival production in Ferrara the
preceding winter.**! In August 1739 Vivaldi had been succeeded as maestro di coro at the Pieta by the
Neapolitan Gennaro d' Alessandro. However, the Florentine marquis Albizzi wrote to Vivaldi twice
in November 1739 regarding dancers whom he was sending to Venice for the coming Carnival at
Sant' Angelo.** This suggests that Vivaldi's departure from Venice was arranged on short notice.
No musical sources known

Candaspe, regina de' sciti Music by Giovanni Battista Casali
[CANDASPE, QUEEN OF THE SCYTHIANS]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Bartolomeo Vitturi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1739-12-30

Dedicated to Friedrich Christian, Electoral Prince of Saxony

Many prisoners were taken during a battle between Scythia and Constantinople. Various amorous
fantasies developed between the natives and the prisoners. Candaspe (Catterina Fumagalli), the queen
ofthe Scythians, was quite taken with the young, handsome Learchos (Rosa Gabrielli). Their intentions
were thwarted when two generals returned home with more prisoners, including Ergonda (Elena Venier),
the wife of Learchos, and Gusman (Francesco Amorevoli), her father. The new impresario at Sant' Angelo
was Giovanni Felice Dini.

Candaspe opened on 30 December 1739, when the performance was attended by the dedicatee. Some
copies of the libretto have a printer's date of 1739 and a dedication to Frederick Christian, while others
have a printer's date of 1740 and no dedication.* The prince's minister, the count of Wackerbarth,
found both the libretto and the music to be bad but the dance numbers passable.>

The 1740s: An Overview

he 1740s brought to Venetian theaters changes
Sie affected the most fundamental aspects of
their activities. The relationship between comedy

and opera was radically and permanently altered. The
number of houses functioning and the modes in which they
operated were redefined. Old age and emigration depleted
the roster of personnel. This reversed the trend of earlier
decades, when Venice had been a magnet to aspiring singers
and composers. Venetian musicians gravitated to lands were
no Italian was spoken  from the British Isles to the
growing cities in Poland, Russia, and Scandinavia. Yet the
decade is difficult to characterize in a few words. This was
nota time for reflection. It was a decade of frenzied activity.

The doge Pietro Grimani (1741-52) was an erudite
former ambassador to Vienna and London, where he was
an honorary member of the Royal Academy. Though a friend
of Goldoni, he was not well-liked by ordinary Venetians.
As he confronted a series of continuing wars to the east,
Venice endured the constant threat of devastating contagions.
Its economic fortunes continued to decline. In 1740 and
again in 1745 the Council of Ten issued sternly worded
edicts on masking. The suppression of gambling (1744) was
a corollary measure.

Entering into the polyphony of comedy and opera were
the voices of individual theaters. While Sant' Angelo and
San Giovanni Grisostomo  the most steadfast supporters
of serious opera  continued to stage drammi per musica
into the later 1740s, comedy took the upper hand at both.
The reasons diverged. San Giovanni Grisostomo was forced,
by a fire at San Samuele on the last night of September 1747,
to host its displaced troupe until San Samuele reopened the
following spring. Its drammi per musica sputtered to quiet
death in 1751. Sant' Angelo made a wholesale conversion
to prose comedy in 1748.

The newly refurbished San Samuele proved to be a
versatile house that offered the opulence (one could say
ostentation) for which San Giovanni had long been known.
These details cannot be represented accurately in Figure 27,
but they give some sense of the changing fortunes of the
1740s in relation to the preceding decade. (The story is
continued in Figures 28 and 29.)

The most turbulent, but perhaps also the most innova-
tive, theater was San Moise. When Latilla's La finta camer-
iera, which was the first Neapolitan-style comic work given
in Venice, was performed there in 1743, it transformed the
theatrical landscape overnight. Theater-goers, accustomed
to Bolognese musical farce and Venetian quasi-musical prose
comedy and satires, were entranced by the acting, rather than
the singing or drama, in Latilla's work and others like it.
Within a year the opera bernesca (or dramma giocoso per
musica) was supplanting the long sacrosanct dramma per
musica.

Opera buffa (used here to designate varied species of
comedies set to music) brought with it changing conventions
of performance and theatrical management. Opere buffe were
initially performed by resident troupes led by a capo comico.
Theaters which hosted both drammi per musica and opere
buffe faced the problem of resolving conflicts between opera
impresari, who were usually engaged for several years at
atime, and troupes, which could be itinerant. Like spoken
comedies, opere buffe were inclined to run for shorter
periods and to be changed more often. Their lengths were
highly variable. The intermezzi given with opera productions
became more substantial. The transition is clearly evident
at Sant'Angelo in 1746-47, where intermezzi were newly
devised for three or four singers. San Moise was quick to
follow suit.

In addition to becoming a staple of the Ascension fair,
comic opera penetrated the earlier part of the autumn season.
However, the spring season came under stringent government
scrutiny by the end of the decade. In 1749, an Ascension
opera season was authorized by a one-vote majority. By
this time, spoken plays were also increasingly valued. Their
production was an attractive financial alternative to opera,
for the costs of a troupe were modest compared to those of
celebrated singers and ballet troupes.

Venice was not left wholly without drammi per musica,
but appreciative audiences for them were dwindling. The
diminution is reflected in the fact that reports of Venetian
opera disappeared from most weekly news reports by the
1745-46 season, although a few still mentioned selected
theatrical works through 1752. Apparently, riportisti did not

FIGURE 27. Productions by theater, 1730s vs. 1740s.

attach much significance to comic opera. The appearance
of Groppo's catalogue in 1745 was coincident with the
collapse of serious opera. The catalogue appealed to
collectors of libretti and other artifacts of opera, that is to
the remaining defenders of the dramma per musica. Yet the
de facto arbitrator of the genre wars was Carlo Goldoni, who
expressed ambivalence about the setting of his comedies to
music. (They thrived either way.)

Surviving manuscripts sources demonstrate renewed
interest in the phenomenon of opera, however altered it might
be. Some represent productions given far from Venice,
though aria collections testify to the enthusiasm of students
and amateurs in imitating what they saw and heard on the
stage. While the percentage of all Venetian productions
which were revivals increased, music itself was more nearly
ubiquitous in public and private life than it had ever been.

This revival of the work sometimes called Demetrio opened on 27 January 1740 (PV). It had been given
previously as 1732/3 and 1737/2. The dedicatee, who had arrived in Venice on 21 December 1739 (NV),|

said of the premiere that he could ask only for more music. The fact that Hasse was his court composer

undoubtedly colored his opinion. The prince's presence inspired an unusually obsequious dedication

by Vitturi.

The Saxon minister, August Joseph Ludwig of Wackerbarth, wrote that it was the best work of the season,
despite the mediocrity of the voices, and noted that he was enclosing some examples of it. He said
that the balli and decorations were nothing special but that the composition of the music was generally

' Alm, Catalog, p. 588, reports the 19th.

approved. Cleonice is also likely to be the work which Lady Mary Wortley Montagu reported on 15
February to have heard from the prince's box, but she had no comment on the performance. Another
observer, Johann Casper von Goethe, wrote on 16 February 1741 that Cleonice was not as good as
Adriano in Siria (1740/2). Attendance was low, he said, and that the theater was littered with filth. The
leading lady, Signora [Catterina] Fumagalli, sang louder but no less beautifully than all the others.
On a second visit, Goethe found the music, staging, costumes, performance, and the theater itself all
to have been glorious (herrlich).

[HADRIAN IN SYRIA]
A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
im Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)

Ie) Metastasio's text, which remained popular through the end of the century, had first been set for Venice

by Giacomelli as 1733/2. This setting had its premiere on 6 February 1740 (A), when it was noted for
its sweet poetry and music (PV). Friedrich Christian, who attended the premiere, found that the music
was good enough and somewhat better than that of the preceding work at San Giovanni Grisostomo
[Ottone, 1739/6] but that the dances were less good.

For the last night of Carnival (1 March), a special box (in the form of a cabinet) was arranged for
the prince. It was framed by five other boxes which were covered in brocades and damask. They glittered
in the reflected candlelight. The performance, which began at 22:00 O.V., included the very best singers,
drawn from many remote places by a generous stipend, and a highly selected orchestra of the most
accomplished players of various instruments. The performance ended at 3:00 O.V., after which a great
banquet was given in honor of His Royal Highness. The entire stage was turned into a most beautiful
machine, illuminated by many candles...and the ballo began.*

Another account (NV) notes that the theater was illuminated by 160 torches and five great crystal
chandeliers holding 300 candles. It claims that the royal dinner began after the first act of the opera

German timekeeping, which is evident also in Goethe's Reise, which relates that an ordinary performance of the same work in mid-February
lasted from 8 to 11. On various systems of recification, including Goethe's, see Song and Season, Table 5.3.

1740/4 Gustavo primo, re di Svezia Music by Baldassare Galuppi
[Gustav I, KING OF SWEDEN]
A dramma per musica Text by Carlo Goldoni
MM Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1740-05-25
& Dedicated to Marquis Giovanni Giacomo Grimaldi'$

In Goldoni's first opera seria, Christian, the second king of Denmark, subjugated the Swedes and took
four hostages, including Gustav, the young son of his enemy, King Henry of Vasa. The people of Liibeck
liberated him from his Danish prison and he was eventually elected king of his people [1523]. The plot
treats a fictional episode in which the Swedish senator Ernest rescued Clotilde, the baby sister of Gustav,
who grew up disguised as Dorisbe, while Gustav was raised as Learchos.'

Oo Gustavo primo was first performed on 25 May 1740. The cast included Pompeo Basteris (Ernesto),
Maria Camati (Ergilda), Lorenzo Girardi (Learco), and Marianna Imer (Dorisbe).'* According to Goldoni,
the work was designed with the singers' merits in mind.'? In particular, he tried to make the roles of
the two donne relatively equal, perhaps because Marianna Imer (here the seconda donna) was the daughter
of his longtime colleague Giuseppe Imer. The work was produced in Modena and Este in 1754.

 Prince Friedrich Christian of Saxony attended the premiere but left no comment on the work.? Lady
Mary Wortley Montagu, who attended a performance on | June,! was similarly reticent. A contemporary
account relates that the drama itself was well received, but the skill and agility in dancing of Madame
Teresa Le Conte of Turin, which commanded the respect of everyone and elicited universal applause,
was much more distinguished.

of a Genovese notary, was to spend the years 1741-43 as Genovese consul in Venice.

' Much of the plot (which seems to have been drafted before the end of 1738) is subjected to a fairly free political treatment. The historical

one by Silvani (La costanza in trionfo, 1696/10), in which the Swedes were the oppressors (as they had been earlier in the eighteenth century)
and the Danes the oppressed. The disposition of Swedish power was of interest in Poland (and thus ostensibly to the Saxon prince) because
of the Swedish wars of the early eighteenth century, during which most of the fighting took place in Poland.

'' Diario ordinario, No. 3563, pp. 8f.

(as computed by Benigna [Memorie, f. 71] ) was the eighth [consecutive] month of winter on account of the serious cold which prevailed

Zenobia Music by Guglielmo Sbacci
[ZENOBIA]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Pietro Metastasio by Bartolomeo Vitturi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With Serpina e UbertoTM and balli SORTING DATE: 1740-11-12

Dedicated to Lodovico Vidiman [=Widman] and Quintilia Rezzonico

This was a pastoralized version of the ancient tale of the virtuous Armenian princess Zenobia, who
loved the Parthian prince Tiridates but was here commanded to secretly wed the prince Rhadamisthos.
Tiridates subsequently engaged in the battle which introduced the work. Zenobia opened on 12 November
1740.7

Although Cesare Gargante's flowery dedication of the libretto for Zenobia proclaimed it a famous drama
from a celebrated pen, it seems to have been upstaged by Pergolesi's intermedio, in which the final
duet by Vinci caused greatly applause. Domenico Cricchi, who greatly extended the reputation of
Pergolesi's work, was praised for both his acting and his singing.' Barbara Stabili sang in the title role,
with Laura Bambini (Tiridate) and Carlo Dardocci (Radamisto). Metastasio's text was in use until 1800.
Its earliest settings were those of 1740  by Predieri (Vienna, 28 August) and Porpora (Naples, 19
December, as Tiridate) as well as Sbacci.

No musical sources known

Listed as Groppo 759; Wiel 397; Alm 923

Candace, overo Li veri amici Music by Gio. Battista Lampugnani
[CANDACE, OR THE TRUE FRIENDS]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Francesco Silvani by Domenico Lalli
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1740-11-19

Dedicated to Andrea d'Oria, Prince of Melfi?

As an autumn work, this adaptation of J veri amici (1712/8) is likely to have opened between 19 and
26 November 1740. It had been produced in Milan (the composer's city of origin) in 1732. Silvani's
text had also been set by Vivaldi (as RV 704) for performance in Mantua in 1720. The text was again
revived as Evergete (1748/8). Francesca Bertoli sang in the title role with Mariano Nitolini (Evergete),
Gio. Battista Pinacci (Amasi), Giuliano Terdocci (Lagide), and Angela Zanuchi (Tilame).

tales of the same figures fashioned by Bentivoglio (1669/3) and Marchi (1698/7).

1740/7 Oronte, re de' sciti Music by Baldassare Galuppi
[ORONTES, KING OF THE SCYTHIANS]
A dramma per musica Text by Carlo Goldoni
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli and a combattimento SORTING DATE: 1740-12-26
& Dedicated to Giovanni Giuseppe Maria Tomasi, Duke of Palma'
 In this fictional story which borrows names from antiquity, Orontes, the king of the Scythians, asked

Decebalos, the king of Dacia, for the hand of the princess Artalike. The aversion of both the princess
and her twin brother, Alcamenes, to Orontes caused Decebalos to withdraw his consent. Orontes prepared
a gruesome revenge, but Alcamenes's war against the Thracians provided a distraction. Goldoni's first
work for San Giovanni Grisostomo opened on 26 December 1740 (A).! The libretto had been dedicated
on the 23rd. Goldoni's text was reset in 1742 by Paolo Scalabrini for performance in Graz. In 1745
Jommelli and Hasse set it for Hamburg.

 Goldoni claimed that the music. ..was divine, the sets splendid, the actors superb, and the production
as a whole an enchanting spectacle.* Gio. Battista Pinacci sang in the title role, with Francesca Bertoli
as Artalike. Goldoni described the latter (whom he called Bagnoli) as a Roman whose singing matched
the beauty of her face and the vivacity of her spirit. She was good in male roles, he said, but she wanted
arole in which she could show offher feminine charms and graces. He described Pinacci, a Florentine,
as severe in manner, strong in action, and a baritone in range. Goldoni found the sets of Joli exceptional
and thought his own contribution was above his own average, although dramaturgically it was not the
purest of tragedies. He suggested that this was because he always tried to write his plays for the characters
of those who would perform in them.*

Goldoni's account explores the conflict between the heirs of King Darius from his first and second
marriages. From the first came Roxane (Bortola Gallo), who married his nephew Arbakes (Giovanni
Manzoli). From the second came Darius, whose widowed mother, Stateira (Antonia Cerminati), came
to occupy the Persian throne. After the death of Darius, however, Stateira enjoyed an intimate relationship
with Arbakes, while Roxane gradually transferred her affections to Darius's nephew, Learchos (Filippo
Elisi).> Statira opened on 10 May 1741," which was the date of dedication of the libretto. The text
was reset for later productions by Porpora (1742/1), Maggiore et al. (1751/5), and Scolari (1756).

1741/5 Tigrane Music by Giuseppe Arena*!
[TIGRANES]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Francesco Silvani
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With operazioni militari and balli SORTING DATE: 1741-11-18
& Dedicated to Count Prospero Valmarana, P. V.*
oo Tigranes II the Great (Lorenzo Gherardi) was allied with Mithridates (Francesco Tolve), whose

daughter Cleopatra (Vittoria Tesi Tramontini) he married. There were many other settings of the text,
including those of Gluck (Crema, 1743), Dal Barba (Verona, 1744), and Lampugnani (1747/6). The
work remained popular throughout the century. Arena's work opened on 18 November 1741 and was
to have a total of eighteen performances. The libretto was dedicated by Goldoni, the current impresario
of the theater, on the 17th.

Ow The theater management had recently been reorganized such that there were seven directors in charge
of dancers, painters, costume-makers, porters, operatives, and servants, while there were eleven others
for the selection of musicians, maestri, librettists, and the orchestra.** It may have been on account
of this reorganization that much comment was directed towards Tigrane. Its dances, scenery, and costumes
were applauded. The final scene, in the temple of Jupiter, must have been macabre. Instruments of
sacrifice were shown and urns were prepared for the victims.

 The theater's acoustics were held to have sabotaged the music. Giuseppe Galli-Bibiena, who was called
in as an acoustic consultant, considered it a flaw that the theater was square rather than egg-shaped.
To remedy this, he dug two holes under the orchestra to make little wells at the edges of the stage.
His modifications were considered a success.*

 Exact figures for ticket sales indicate that the overall attendance was mediocre, with gross sales of 6,730
bollettini to occupants of the boxes and rentals of 539 scagni. The gross revenues were 26,920 lire from
the boxes and 1,342 from the parterre, producing a total of 28,262 lire. Arena was paid 2,420 lire for
his services. The theater netted 850 ire from the sale of libretti after paying a gift (regalo) to Goldoni.**

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1740-49) 475

Oo Merope opened on 26 December 1741.* The production had twenty-one performances. Zeno's text
had been set by Gasparini (1712/1) and Giacomelli (1734/5) and remained in use into the next century.

 On 13 January 1742 Merope was warmly praised for its sumptuous costumes, music, and magnificent
scenery.*' Between Acts One and Two games of chance (giochi di lotta) were played ona float shaped
like an amphitheater. The succeeding production at San Giovanni Grisostomo (Porpora's Statira, 1742/1)
was terminated after only three performances in order to revive Merope. The libretto for the revival,
which consisted of another nine performances, was dedicated to ladies. Vittoria Tesi [Tramontini]
sang in the title role, with Francesco Tolve as Polyphontes.

 Merope was a stellar financial success. It enjoyed bollettini sales of 9,141 for the first run and 4,686
for the second, with proceeds of 36,564 lire and 18,744 lire respectively. Sales of scagni were
correspondingly robust, totaling 909 for the first run and 422 for the second. Folding-seat rentals added
proceeds of 2,384 lire and 844 lire respectively. The gross income from all these sources was 58,536
lire. Jommelli's regalo was 2,684 lire, with a later supplement of 12 zecchini.

BOE The final set featured the mausoleum of Cyrus, where a grotesque scene was transformed into a festive

La Zanina, maga per amore Music derived from Giuseppe Maria Buini
[ZANINA, THE SORCERESS OF LOVE]

A dramma per musica Text by Giuseppe Maria Buini
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1742-05-02

Without dedicatee

The character of La Zanina is both simple and satirical. Fidalbo has switched his amorous interests
from Zanina to Emirena, who has already been claimed by Celindo. Emirena's father, Armano, has
his own plans for his daughter's future. The work was billed as an opera bernesca when it was given
in Vienna in September 1747.

La Zanina opened on 2 May 1742. Antonia Bertelli sang in the title role (in Bolognese dialect) with
Pellegrino Gaggiotti (Armano). Both performers, who were well known interpreters of comic intermezzi,
had appeared in the original production, given near Bologna (S. Giovanni in Persiceto) for the Accademici
Candidi Uniti in the autumn of 1737. Other members of the cast included Domenico Negri (Fidalbo),
Caterina Bassi Negri (Emirena), and Angela Romani (Celindo). The impresario at San Moise was now
Cesare Gargante, formerly of Sant' Angelo.

No musical sources known

OGL Metastasio's text on the Persian ruler had been set by more than a dozen composers since 1730. Artaserse

1742/6 Bajazet Music attributed to Andrea Bernasconi*
[BAYEZID]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Agostino Piovene by Giacomo San Vitale
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1742-10-15~
& Dedicated to the Ladies
Sac) Piovene's text, first set by Gasparini as Tamerlano (1711/3), had had revivals in Reggio (1719) and

Venice (1723/4). Bernasconi's setting was itself to be revived in Munich (1754) and Prague (1762).
Quite uncharacteristically for San Giovanni Grisostomo, the season's first opera, which represented
several new initiatives simultaneously, opened before 17 October 1742, when Girolamo Zanetti wrote
a caustic commentary on every aspect of the production.

SE The sets, by Galli-Bibiena (the theatrical designer for the empress Maria Theresia), cost more than 1,000
ducats. While Groppo reported that the most sumptuous scenes made by Sig. Bibiena. ..[constituted]
a perfect architecture,*' Zanetti said they were not beautiful and noted that in them Gothic, Greek,
and Roman elements were intermixed. Some columns seemed to stand in the sea.** Zanetti found
Piovene's text to be antique.

IoE@) Zanetti saved his most cutting comments for the singers, among whom were Gio. Battista Pinacci in
the title role, Settimio Canini (Zamerlano), Vittoria Tesi (Asteria), and Giustina Turcotti (/rene). Zanetti
found that Tesi, although old, recited well but sang badly, as usual. He described Canini as a blind
tenor with one eye [who was] undeserving. Pinacci, an alto, came across to him as a raging beast.
Turcotti sang very well but was fat to the point of deformity and could not move about the stage.

OOo Minor changes were made to this text concerning the second wife of Alexander the Great, which had
previously been set by Porta as La costanza combattuta in amore (1716/6) and by Galeazzi as II trionfo
della costanza (1731/1). The scenery was recycled from earlier works. Barsina, the first opera to be
given at San Cassiano since 1738, opened on 10 November 1742. The title-page carries indications
for both MDCCXLII and MDCCXLIII. The libretto could have been reprinted for a revival following
the brief production of Atalo (1742/9). Anna Cosimi appeared in the title role with a predominantly
Roman cast. The Empress Maria Theresia and her consort attended an opening of the same work in
Vienna on 5 June 1743.TM A version revised by Antonio Denzio was given in Munich in 1747.

Owe Considering the popularity of Metastasio's text on the subject of Semiramide riconosciuta, it is curious

that Jommelli reverted to Silvani's earlier one, once set by C. F. Pollarolo (1714/1). Semiramide opened,
with sets by Galli-Bibiena and choreography by Joseph Salamon, on 26 December 1742. As the curtain
rose, Semiramis's chariot was carried onto the stage by Moorish slaves. The most carefully described
scene was the second of Act Two, in which the temple of the Sun was of Gothic architecture. It opened
into three arcades from which the Sacred Wood could be seen. Vittoria Tesi Tramontini sang in the
title role, with Giacomo Zaghini (Memnone), Giustina Turcotti (Aspasia), and Domenico Bucella (Oronte,
the king of the Arabs).

after one nightTM and a revival of Barsina (1742/7) was mounted forthwith. Chintzer's work enjoyed
a revival (as La verita nell'inganno) in Munich in 1747.

Siroe Music by Gennaro Manna!
[SIROES]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Pietro Metastasio by Domenico Fabris'
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1743-02-09

Dedicated to the Ladies

Siroe opened on 9 February 1743. Giacomo Zaghini took the title role, in a cast including Gio. Battista
Pinacci (Cosroe), Vittoria Tesi Tramontini (Emira), and Giustina Turcotti (Laodice). Vinci's setting
had been given as 1726/2 and 1731/6. Among many further settings of this popular work, Haym's
adaptation of the text for Handel's like-named work (HWV 24) had been produced in London in 1728.
Zanetti found Siroe to be moderately good. He said that the sets were less bad than most of those
made by [Galli-]Bibiena but claimed that the architect's machine representing Immortality was silly
(una freddura) and of little relevance to the work. The four cloud-machines that descended on little
transparent columns were beautiful and good.'!' The scenery changes were apparently introduced
in conjunction with the architect's new acoustical remodeling of the theater.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

La Contessina Music attributed to Giacomo Maccari
[THE LITTLE CounTESsS]

A commedia per musica (operetta buffa) Text by Carlo Goldoni
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1743-02-13~
Without dedicatee

La Contessina, written in the autumn of 1742 while Goldoni was still serving as Venetian consul to
the Republic of Genoa, was given by comedians at San Samuele in the winter of 1743." Its opening
cannot be dated to the day or week, since the rest of the theater's repertory is undocumented.

Often considered the first dramma giocoso con musica to be given in Venice, the work was received
with great enthusiasm (riusci a meraviglia). The vain little countess was the daughter of Count
Baccellone Parabolano. Lindoro, the son of the rich merchant Pancrazio, has fallen in love with her
after only six days in Venice, but she, being in search of a cicisbeo, shows little interest in him. The
gondoliere Gazzetta also plays arole in the plot. The classic conflict between an impoverished nobility
and a rich bourgeoisie had been a staple of French comedy since the time of Louis XIV.

The cast is not given in the libretto. Sacchi's troupe had left San Samuele to go to St. Petersburg in
1742 and that of Falchi, from the Bavarian court, had now been engaged. Goldoni wrote the title role
for Signora Baccherini of the new troupe. She was beautiful and no less astute than [Elisabetta] Passalac-
qua, the dramatist wrote.'?

The text had a long success. It was revived at San Giovanni Grisostomo in the autumn of 1754'"4 and
was later set by such figures as Lampugnani (Milan, 1759) and Piccinni (Verona, 1775). Calzabigi's
revision was set by Floriano Gassmann both in Italian (Vienna, 1771; Pavia, 1782 et al.) and in Danish
translation (Copenhagen, 1778). It was also used by Cimarosa (Bologna, 1778) and others.''*

No musical sources known

Listed as Groppo 784; Wiel 430; Alm 9511'S

also affected indirectly by the fear that a contagion in Messina could be imported by arriving visitors.

 The production was something of a singers' reunion. In his first Venetian appearance since 1729,
Giovanni Carestini's singing in the title role did him great honor, according to Girolamo Zanetti.
Celebrated for his major roles in several Handel operas, Carestini was later praised by Charles Burney
for his powerful and clear voice [he was first a soprano, later an alto], by Hasse for his perfect style
of singing, and by Quantz for his extraordinary virtuosity.''? In her only Venetian appearance
postdating Vivaldi's death, Anna Gird appeared as Fulvia. Giuseppe Santarelli took the role of the
emperor Valentinian, who loved Fulvia despite her betrothal to Aetius.

1743/7 La finta cameriera Music by Gaetano Latilla
[THE FALSE CHAMBERMAID]
A divertimento giocoso Text attributed to Giovanni Barlocci'
im Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1743-05-22
&y Without dedicatee
aXe) La finta cameriera, which opened on 22 May 1743 (A)'?! and met with universal applause, is regarded

as the first Neapolitan-style comic opera (or opera bernesca') given in Venice. It is an acknowledged
descendent of the commedia per musica called Gismondo (Naples, 1737; text by G. A. Federico). The
influence of commedia dell'arte is evident in its characterizations. Giocondo (Elisabetta Ronchetti),
a young man from Leghorn/Livorno, has presented himself as Alessandra to become a servant in the
house of Pancrazio (Giuseppe Ristorini), an elderly Florentine gentleman living in Rome. Pancrazio's
daughter Erosmina (Costanza Rosignoli) is engaged to Don Colascione (Francesco Baglioni) but falls
in love with the new maid.! Other roles include those of Betta (Ginevra Magagnoli), Dorina (Viviana
Bosellini), and Filindo (Luigi Ristorini). Its performers were all from Bologna.

 According to Girolamo Zanetti, the work was considered moderately beautiful. The oldest of the
performers was twenty-three.'TM* As the two weeks of its production passed, Zanetti's reports became
steadily more enthusiastic. On the 24th he described it as an opera ridicola which was starting to please
to excess, particularly on account of certain duets. On the 29th he termed it an opera burlesca which
was still very pleasing. On the 31st it was styled an opera bernesca again pleasing to excess. By
now, the portrayer of Don Colascione (Francesco Baglioni) was receiving special praise for making

"8 Benigna, Memorie, f. 83, entry of 21 maggio, with addendum for giugno.
"? Quoted from Dale E. Monson, Carestini, Giovanni, GO, iii, 731.

' According to NG, the current text was by Gennaro Antonio Federico, with revisions by Barlocci. According to the Groppo MS, p. 275,
La finta cameriera was derived from a prose comedy by Simone Falconio Pratoli; the original date would have had to be anterior to 1738.
However, the actions of Giocondo seem curiously reminiscent of the episode in Richardson's novel Pamela (London, 1740-41) in which Mr.
B. hid in a closet of the servant Pamela as she undressed before going to bed. Goldoni prepared a dramatization of Richardson's Pamela, or
Virtue Rewarded (London, 1740) in Italian in 1741 (cf. Suppl. 2c for the 1750 production). He wrote in his memoirs (p. 283) that according
to the French definition, Pamela was a drama, but the public found it interesting and entertaining, and among all my works given up to that
point, this is the one which was the most successful.

i) This Carnival revival of 1743/7, which had been given at Sant' Angelo during the preceding spring,'*

must have been given before La Fiammetta.' The title-page date is 1744. The cast now included Maria
Angela Paganini (Giocondo), Pellegrino Gaggiotti (Pancrazio), Anna Querzoli Laschi (Ersomina),
Grazia Melini (Betta), and Filippo Laschi (Don Colascione).

 The production of La finta cameriera marks the reopening of San Moise after a year and a half of musical
inactivity. During the 1742-43 cycle, in which music was absent, the theater seems to have been rented
to Medebach for comedies which newly included acrobatic interpolations by members of the Raffi
troupe.' It may also represent the first efforts of Angelo Mingotti, a significant contributor to the

' The cast definitely belongs to the 1743-44 cycle, not to the 1744-45 cycle. The production of this work has to have preceded La gara per
Ja gloria (Suppl. 5b), which is a pastiche based collectively on this work, La Fiammetta (1744/2), and Orazio (1744/4).

 Goldoni implies this in the preface to vol. xvii of his collected works (Ortolani, TO, i, 752). He suggests that Gasparo Raffi, a Roman, began
bringing his troupe to Venice in 1740. His daughter Teodora was to marry Medebach; his daughter Maddalena was to marry Giuseppe Marliani,
who aspired to become a comedian. Medebach eventually yielded to Marliani's requests and made him the Arlecchino ofa troupe which included
the two Raffis. They performed at San Moise. Goldoni mentions the appearance of the Raffi troupe during Carnival periods, but the Medebach
troupe can only have performed at San Moise when operas were not being given, i.e., in all of 1742-43, in the autumn of 1743, and selected
later years.

transplantation of the Neapolitan opera buffa,'*' to run the theater. Trading on the great popularity of

1744/1 Temistocle* Music by Andrea Bernasconi et al.
[THEMISTOCLES]
A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
rT Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1744-01-11
& Dedicated to the Ladies
OO In this setting of Metastasio's text (liberated from the adaptation of Giovanni Boldini, which had been

used at Sant' Angelo in Pampani's Artaserse Longimano, 1737/5), the enormous respect Themistocles
enjoyed for his personal qualities enabled the Athenian general to win over his enemy Xerxes (Ventura
Rocchetti), who unexpectedly declared a truce with the Greeks. Bernasconi's work had been performed
in Padua (1740) and Lucca (1741). This revival opened on 11 January 1744 with universal applause
(A).' The original production was given in Padua on 6 June 1740. Cristoforo del Rosso sang in the
title role with Ventura Rocchetti (Serse) and Catterina Fumagalli (Aspasia).

1744/2 La Fiammetta Composer(s) unknown
[FIAMMETTA]
An opera bernesca in musica Librettist unknown"
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1744-01-15
az Without dedicatee

This popular work, situated in Bologna, featured eight characters. Fiammetta (Maria Angela Paganini)
disrupted the quiet lives of the old man Geronio (Pellegrino Gaggiotti) and his children Flaminio (Caterina
Castelli) and Filaura (Agata Sani). The notary Signor Imbroglio (Giovanni Benvenuti) was required
to sing and dance. The role of Monst Bigid (Filippo Laschi), the French tailor, was also a satirical one.
Six professional dancers were named in the libretto.

Oo La Fiammetta opened on 15 January 1744 (A). The text seems to have been derived from a spoken
comedy given in Florence in the autumn of 1743.' The publisher's date for Venice is 1743 M.V. The
work appears to have been given prior to La gara per la gloria but evidently before Orazio, which limits
its time of opening to January 1744." Fiammetta was given in Graz and Hamburg in 1745 and bore
other progeny in Copenhagen in the late 1750s.'*

'' Miggiani's Sulle tracce della troupe Mingotti reveals that the arms of the Michiel family link a series of libretti (preserved in I-Vnm)
to each other and to works produced by Mingotti (or his brother Pietro).

' Also reported in the Diario ordinario, No. 4133, p. 11.

'S The role of Fiammetta reached back through Neapolitan stage works to a reputedly Spanish origin. See, for example, the favola pastorale
called La Fiammetta d'Ibernia (Naples, 1626).

opened in Lamberto's studio, where a harpsichord was in use as the maestro demonstrated to his
pupil Lauretta (Grazia Melini) how to sing the aria A gitata navicella, which describes the vicissitudes
of the heart on the rough seas of love.'?

Orazio opened on 6 February 1744.'** Groppo maintains that itopened in the autumn of 1743 and
continued during the winter of 1744, but no confirmation of the earlier opening can be found.'** As
performed in Venice, Orazio had numerous aria substitutions. Its text had been set by Pietro Auletta
for performance in Toledo in 1737. Latilla's setting was in heavy use in Italy through 1754. As I] maestro
di cappella the text was given ina variety of other settings throughout Europe between 1750 and 1800.

Cesare in Egitto Music by Antonio Colombo
[CAESAR IN EGYPT]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Giacomo Fr. Bussani by Carlo Goldoni'
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1744-05-13

Dedicated to the Ladies'

In this revised version of 1735/7, Pompey hoped to retire in peace in Egypt with his wife Cornelia
(Giustina Gallo) but instead lost his life after Ptolemy (Carlo Carlani) enlisted help in defeating Cleopatra
(Bortola Gallo). Julius Caesar (Giovanni Carestini) prevailed. Cesare, which was later set by Sarti and
Piccinni, was set in Alexandria. It opened on 13 May 1744 (A).'*' Goldoni's revisions to Bussani's
well-worn libretto had been made for the San Giovanni Grisostomo setting (1735/5) by Giacomelli.
The work was shortened for this springtime production.

Origille Music attributed to Antonio Palella'
[ORIGILE]

An opera bernesca in musica Text attributed to Antonio Palomba
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With balli and La contadina astuta' SORTING DATE: 1744-10-18~
Without dedicatee

The action in this story, inspired by the Chanson de Roland, is situated in a village. Its aim, according
to the libretto, is to demonstrate the correction of the vice of vain ambition.'TM The person in need
of correction is Martin/Martano (Giuseppe Ambrosini), who, pretending to be a gentleman, makes love
to the lady Origile (Anna Guadagni). She is otherwise the object of the affections of the warrior
Ranier/Raniero (Giovanna Rossi).

Origille was the first of two autumn works given at San Moise in 1744 and must therefore have opened
ata relatively early date. On the probable sequence of works there, see Don Saverio (1744/9) and Emira
(1745/1). The production was praised in the libretto for its representation and the music for its
harmony. Performed at the Teatro Nuovo in Naples in December 1740, it was one of the first opere
buffe to be given in northern Italy (Ravenna, 1742; Mantua, summer 1744). However, Groppo reported
that in Venice it met with minimal (pocchissimo) applause.'

No musical sources known

Listed as Groppo 802; Wiel 441; Alm 971

Madama Ciana Music by Gaetano Latilla'
[MADAME C1ana'7]
A dramma giocoso per musica Text adapted by Giovanni Barlocci'*
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With concerti SORTING DATE: 1744-11-03
Without dedicatee

In this satire on Florentine manners, Panicone (Pietro Pertici) is the father of Madame Ciana (Anna
Isola) and the proud, condescending Sfrappa (Francesco Baglioni), who represents the Order of the
Waning Moon.' The first two singers were well known as performers of comic intermezzi. This
adaptation also contained roles for two favorites of the preceding year  Orazio (Filippo Laschi) and
Fiammetta (Viviana Bosellini). The two concertos (one for oboe, one for violin), which were substituted
for balli, were intended to accompany water sports (giochi d'acque).

Madama Ciana opened on 3 November 1744 (PV). Although succeeded by La liberta nociva on 22
November, it was revived (as 1744/12) on 5 December.' The text had earlier served for an opera scenica
(Bologna, 1733). Latilla's musical setting had been presented as Don Marzio, overo L'ambizione delusa

' Palella (1698-1761) was a Neapolitan composer of both sacred and theatrical music.

Don Saverio Music by Giuseppe d' Avossa'
[DON SAVERIO]

A commedia per musica Text attributed to Antonio Palomba
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
Given with balli'TM SORTING DATE: 1744-11-14~
Without dedicatee

In this satire on manners, the rich Neapolitan merchant Palmiero (Nicola Setaro) loves Violante (Anna
Guadagni). Violante is really the Roman Emilia in disguise; she has come to Naples to spy on Edward
(Giovanna Rossi), her estranged lover. Edward has now fallen in love with Clarice (Anna Merichi
Ferramonti). Don Saverio (Antonia Ambrosini), the merchant's son, returns from a three-year stay in
Genoa eager to demonstrate his command of foreign manners of speech and dress.

According to the libretto, Don Saverio opened in autumn.' The date of opening given here is conjectural.
The production continued after Christmas, which suggests wide appeal but also indicates that it opened
in the later part of the autumn (i.e., St. Martin's or St. Andrew's).

No musical sources known

Listed as Groppo 805; Wiel 442; Alm 974

Ipermestra Music by Christoph Willibald von Gluck
[HYPERMNESTRA]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1744-11-21
Without dedicatee

Danaos (Ottavio Albuzio), the king of Argos, plotted that his daughter Hypermnestra (Vittoria Tesi
Tramontini) should murder her husband Lynceus (Lorenzo Ghirardi) on their wedding night. Through
a convoluted plot, she spared his life and was able to reconcile all the distrusting parties. Ipermestra
opened on 21 November 1744 (A).' Metastasio's text, first set by Hasse for performance in Vienna
(8 January 1744), remained in use for a century.' Later settings included those of Bertoni (San Samuele,
1748/3), Galuppi (Milan, 1758), Naumann (San Benedetto, 1774), and Astaritta (San Benedetto, 1789).

La liberta nociva Music by Rinaldo di Capua!
[A DAMAGING FREEDOM]

A dramma giocoso per musica Text adapted by Giovanni Barlocci'
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With concerti, a ballo, and a gioco SORTING DATE: 1744-11-22
Without dedicatee

Another work in the bernesca tradition, La liberta opens with Dorimene (Eugenia Mellini Fanti) disguised
as the pilgrim Costanzo, who sits by the bank of the Tiber lamenting the infidelity of his mistress;
Dorimene's real love is Flavio, a gentleman from Ancona. Other key roles were those of the German
Baron Zuffre (Francesco Baglioni) and his servant Dirindina (Viviana Bossellini).' The production
opened on 22 November 1744.'*! The original one had taken place in Rome in 1740. Act Three was
terminated by a mock festa di ballo and gioco, which took place in a salon illuminated for the final
scene. The work was replaced by a revival of Madama Ciana (1744/12) on 5 December, suggesting
that it was not well received. Similarly, the concertos for oboe and violin performed at the ends of Acts
One and Two found little favor.'

No musical sources known
Listed as Groppo 804; Wiel 433; Alm 973

L'ambizione delusa Music by Rinaldo di Capua'
[AMBITION DELUDED]

A dramma giocoso per musica Text attributed to Giovanni Barlocci'*
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
Given with concerti SORTING DATE: 1744-12-05
Without dedicatee

The revival of Madama Ciana (1744/8) on 5 December 1744 appears to have taken this title, which
corresponded to its original alternative title (Rome, 1738). La liberta nociva, which had succeeded it
in the St. Martin's period, was quickly replaced by a revival of Madama Ciana. Groppo gives the
impression that the revival was distinct from the reprise of L ambizione delusa, after La forza d'amore,
for the last nights of Carnival 1745 (Suppl. 5b). A practical way to make the work seem different would
have been to revert to the original title. The libretto identifies it as being a work for Carnival 1745.

Semiramide riconosciuta Music by Johann Adolf Hasse'*
[SEMIRAMIS RECOGNIZED]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1744-12-26

Dedicated to Robert, Viscount d'Arcy, Earl of Holderness'*'

To Venetian audiences, the subject of Semiramis was familiar from the earlier works set by Pollarolo

(1714/1), Porpora (1729/4), and Jommelli (1742/8).'** This production reiterated favorite scenes of

theater audiences generally  great palaces, ships at sea, military encampments, disguises, and the

sun-worship of Zoroastrians. An addendum to the argomento underscored the great fame of the librettist.

It appears that a text of such grandeur was thought especially suitable for the dedicatee. The Venetian

production of this work, which had also run in Naples from 4 November, opened on 27 December 1744

(A).' The work was so well received that the run of its successor, Antigono (1745/3), was abruptly

terminated to reinstate it.'" Vittoria Tesi Tramontini sang in the title role with Giovanni Carestini

(Scitalice), Lorenzo Ghirardi (Mirteo), and Girolama Giacometti (Jamiri). The scenery was by Romualdo

Mauro.

in B-Bc, Br; D-Dlb, Lemi, W; F-Pn; I-Bc, Vc, VIRE (autograph, 1750);'! S-Skma; US-We; arias
in I-Be

[THE FALSE CHAMBERMAID]

Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With concerti at the end of Acts I and II SORTING DATE: 1744-12-26~
Without dedicatee

The cast for this third, slightly altered, production of La finta cameriera in little more than eighteen
months. included Eugenia Mellini Fanti (Giocondo), Pietro Pertici'' (Pancrazio), and Anna Querzoli
Laschi (Erosmina), now with Filippo Laschi (Moschino) and Francesco Baglioni restored to the role
of Don Colascione. The concerti offered background music for views of the sea. Its earlier productions
were 1743/7 and 1743/11.

1745/1 Emira Pastiche, possibly derived from Leonardo Leo
[EmMiRA]
An opera bernesca Librettist unknown
im Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Given with Serpina e Uberto;!TM a ballo SORTING DATE: 1745-01-16~
& Without dedicatee

CO Enmira playfully described the love of the heroine (Anna Guadagni, who was required to dance) for
Celindo (Giuseppe Guadagni), and of her brother Leandro (Nicola Setaro) for Eugenia (Anna Merichi
Ferramonti).'* Similarities in cast structure link Emira with Origille (1744/7) and Don Saverio (1744/9),
placing all three in one continuum from autumn 1744 through mid-Carnival 1745.' Emira must have
opened early in Carnival (which began officially on 9 January) but after the substantial run of the well-
received Don Saverio. When, after several recitations, the singers found no applause for their
improvisations, they left Venice in desperation, after which the theater was closed.' However,
the text was recycled, in one case being set by Gioacchino Cocchi (San Salvatore, Ascension 1756).

A No musical sources known!'
Listed as Groppo 808; Wiel 458;' Alm 977

1745/2 La forza d'amore Music by Baldassare Galuppi?
[THE POWER OF LOVE]
A dramma giocoso per musica Text attributed to Demetrio Panicelli?'
rr Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With concerti SORTING DATE: 1745-01-30
H Without dedicatee
oLORG) In the plot, two eligible Venetian young women reject potential suitors to act out time-warped fantasies

about male vocations. Talestri (Eugenia Mellini Fanti) imagines herself to be a medieval knight, while
Doralice (Anna Isola) fancies herself a renaissance poet. Some of Manfredonio's arias may have been
modified by Francesco Baglioni, who sang in that role. La forza d'amore opened on 30 January 1745
(A).? As in the two works most recently given at San Cassiano, the first two acts concluded with
concertos. The first accompanied the depiction of water games (giochi d'acque); the second tableau
again took Apollo's palace as its backdrop. According to Groppo, Abbot Panicelli was displeased with
the work and had kept it out of circulation for some years.

' Cited (as La serva padrona) in Groppo MS, p. 275.

'5 A dramma per musica of the same title had been set by Leonardo Leo for performance in Naples (1732, 1735) and by G. B. Marchi for
performance in Milan (1737), but the roles of the earlier works were different.

6 These were the only three works given in Venice in which five of the six members of the cast  Nicola Setari (not Letari, as Wiel gives
in Teatri, p. 156), Anna Guadagni, Anna Merichi Ferramonti, Nicoletta Petina, and Giuseppe Ambrosini  appeared. Giuseppe Guadagni,
who did not appear in Origille, made an appearance during the Ascension season of 1751 at Sant' Angelo. Given the bounds of the economic
year and the knowledge that Emira was the last work given in the winter of 1745 at San Moise, the sequence of all three is reasonably clear,
even if the exact dates remain fuzzy.

Antigono Music by Andrea BernasconiTMTM
[ANTIGONOS]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1745-02-13

Dedicated to Count Giacomo San Vitale

In Metastasio's version of the story, the Macedonian king Antigonos fell in love with the Egyptian
princess Berenice and arranged to marry her. On the day of the wedding a violent mutual passion overtook
his son Demetrios and the intended bride. It was because of Antigonos's infatuation, according to this
account, that Alexander was able to invade Macedonia.

Antigono opened on 13 February 1745 (A). In the Venetian production, Ottavio Albuzio sang in the
lead role, with Vittoria Tesi Tramontini (Berenice), Giovanni Carestini (Demetrio), and Lorenzo Girardi
(Alessandro). Despite the celebrated credentials of the librettist, the work was so poorly received that
the production was terminated after a few performances and Semiramide was revived. Nonetheless,
Antigono was remounted in Treviso in 1752. Metastasio's text, first set by Hasse for performance at
Hubertusburg (near Dresden) on 10 October 1743, remained in use through 1860.

No musical sources known

Listed as Groppo 810; Wiel 455; Alm 979

L'ambizione delusa. Cf. Suppl. 5b.

opened on 22 May 1745 (A), the date of dedication of the libretto." It ran for two weeks, during which

L'Olimpiade Music by Ignazio Fiorillo
[THE OLYMPIAD]

A dramma per musica Text adapted anonymously from Pietro Metastasio
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1745-05-22
Without dedicatee

This popular story had formed the subject of previous works by Vivaldi (1734/4) and Pergolesi/Hasse
(1738/6). In this version the work was shortened and the role of Alcandro eliminated. The cast included
Domenico Bonifacci (Clistene) and Maria Venturini (Aristea). L 'Olimpiade opened on 22 May 1745
(A),'" the Saturday before Ascension, and ran for two weeks. According to Groppo, the aria in Act
2, Scene 7, accompanied on the oboe and bassoon by the Besuzzi brothers, was a show-stopper. While
his report that the applause was universal echoes the account found in Pallade veneta, his continuation
that the bassoon carried the major part of it?'* contained his own observation.

Lo scialaquatore alla fiera Music by Giuseppe Orlandini et al.
[THE SQUANDERER AT THE FAIR]

A dramma giocoso Text attributed to Ambrosio Borghese?!*
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Summer (Assumption)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1745-10-04
Without dedicatee

Lo scialacquatore is a satire on the Ascension fair. The opening scene features a piazza in Venice
[with] a view of shops displaying merchandise. Rosaura (Elisabetta Ronchetti), the daughter of Pancrazio
(Alessandro Cattani), loves Flavio (Emanuele Cornaggia), who is disguised as Delfina. Her brother
Don Pasquale (Carlo Paganini) loves the real Delfina (Maria Angela Paganini), a comedienne, but marries
Lindora (Rosa Tagliavini). The first Venetian production of Lo scialaquatore opened on 4 October
1745 (A),?' when it enjoyed full applause (PV). It was so popular that it was revived after / rigiri
delle cantarini (1745/8) on 26 December." Only eleven of the original twenty-six arias were retained
from Florence, where the work had had its first performance on 14 September 1744.

to five. Of these only three (Pandolfo, Lucinda, Fiorlindo) are common to both. New roles for Celio

1745/8 I rigiri delle cantarine Music by Francesco Maggiore
(THE TRICKS OF SINGERS]
A dramma giocoso per musica Text by Bartolomeo Vitturi
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)

ra) Dedicated to Sua Eccellenza Nomen Nescio
 In this satire on opera companies, Olimpia (Elisabetta Ronchetti) and Ersina (Maria Angela Paganini)

are singers, Fulvio (Carlo Paganini) an impresario, Tarquinio (Alessandro Cattani) a maestro di musica,
and Fabio (Margherita Cavalli) a copyist. Ridolfo (Francesco Amorevoli) loves Olimpia but marries
Berenice (Rosa Tagliavini), the previous mistress of Lelio (Emanuele Cornaggia), who is disguised
as Sigismondo. J rigiri opened on 26 November 1745, when it pleased many (PV). The pleasure may
not have been long-lived, for a revival of Lo scialaquatore (1745/6) opened on 26 December.*

1745/9 Ariodante Music by Georg Christoph Wagenseil?*
[ARIODANTE]
A dramma per musica Text adapted anonymously from Antonio Salvi
Performed at San Giovanni Grisostomo SEASON: Autumn (St. Andrew's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1745-11-26
& Dedicated to John Hobart?
 Pollarolo's setting of Salvi's text (1716/8; revived as 1718/9) was greatly celebrated in its time. Handel's

setting (HWV 33) opened at Covent Garden, London, on 8 January 1735, and could have been known
to the dedicatee. Wagenseil's version was significantly reduced from earlier ones. The cast included
Filippo Elisi (Ariodante), Giacinto Cestini (Dalinda), and Ottavio Albuzio (Donaldo). Catterina Ascheri
sang in the role of Ginevra, which, in Pollarolo's setting of 1716, had brought instant fame to Faustina
Bordoni. The story was revived in Simone Mayr's setting ofa text by Gaetano Rossi (Ginevra di Scozia),
which was given for the inauguration of the Teatro Nuovo, Trieste, in 1801.7

 Ariodante, Wagenseil's first opera, opened on 26 November 1745 (A). The composer was present for
the production. The time-slot would have suited Wagenseil's stature as a relative novice, for he was
both a novice and a foreigner. An invitation to compose the work may have been related to the fact
that the new resident of his employer, Maria Theresia, the queen of Hungary and Bohemia, had presented
his credentials to the Venetian government during the last week of October. The same diplomat was
also to serve as imperial ambassador to Venice.

Oe The libretto included a complaint that the work in its present form had been cut, adapted, and given
new aria texts to accommodate new music, and that music in Italy was now abused everywhere, since
anyone had the authority to change whatever he wished, even the title.?" These defects may have been
remedied when the work was given in Vienna (15 May 1746).

Oe The text was revised from that of Braccioli (1713/5) but was now described as a dramma giocondo.

The scenes resemble those of Vivaldi's setting (1714/5) but are more vividly described. The cast included
Felice Novelli (Or/ando), Regina Gonzales (Angelica), Anna Bastiglia (Medoro), and Angelica Saitz
(Alcina). The libretto for this version of Orlando was the first to be doubly dated (e.g., as 1745/6 M.V.).

medico ignorante burlato dalla vedova di spirito, et al.) and ever-changing casts, the intermezzi were
performed in Dresden and Prague, 1747; Rome, 1749; Florence, 1752; Graz, 1754; and Vienna, 1766.7

1746/1 La vedova accorta' Music by Ferdinando Bertoni et al.2"7
[THE WARY WIDOW]
A dramma giocoso per musica Text attributed to Ambrosio Borghese
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1746-01-15~
& Dedicated to Gentlewomen

In this comedy, first given in Florence in 1745, Maria Angela Paganini took the role of Lisetta, a widow
who serves as governess to the sisters Rosaura (Elisabetta Ronchetti) and Isabella (Rosa Tagliavini).
Their brother Filiberto fancies a rich husband for one of them and has arranged for Giorgione (Carlo
Paganini) to meet them. Other potential suitors include Monsiti la Mode (Alessandro Cattani) and the
humble Ernesto (Emanuele Cornaggia).** The action takes place in Padua. The dedication of the libretto
speaks somewhat apologetically about the humorous (scherzevoli) representations of this year and asks
ladies of heroic soul not to despair, nor to believe that the values they cherish have been abandoned.*

oo Given that Lo scialaquatore had a revival starting on 26 December 1745, the printer's date of 1746
must indicate the correct year for this work, notwithstanding the title-page designation Carnovale 1745.

on 8 February, it seems likely that this work would have opened shortly after the official start of Carnival

1746/2 Armida abbandonata* Music by Andrea Adolfati et al."
[ARMIDE ABANDONED]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Francesco Silvani?

& Without dedicatee
 Silvani's libretto had been set several times previously for Venetian stages, starting with the work of

Ruggieri (1707/9). This version may have foreshadowed the production given in Bologna in 1758. The
printer's date is 1746. Sartori (2732) dates it 1745. The relatively large cast (reckoned by the standards
of San Moise) and use of popular intermezzi suggest a work for the height of Carnival.

y-39 The scenery, described in extensive comment in the libretto, was by Giovanni Battista Moretti, who
is identified as a Venetian professor. The opening scene, depicting the cave of the wizard Philomachus,
featured collections of sea shells, books, globes, and mathematical instruments. His magic was said
to be based on natural phenomena. The cast included Angelica Saitz (Armida), Regina Gonzales
(Tancredi), and Anna Bastiglia (Rinaldo). An unidentified singer took the role of Philomachus.

 Five productions based on Metastasio's text had previously been given in Venice as 1730/7 (Hasse),

Filippo Elisi sang in the title role, with Catterina Aschieri as Mandane. The window of time during

La fata meravigliosa' Music by Giuseppe Scolari
[THE MARVELOUS FAIRY]

A dramma giocoso Text provisionally attributed to Ambrosio BorgheseTM*
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1746-02-08
Without dedicatee

Carmenta (Maria Angela Paganini), the Marvelous Fairy, lived on a mythical island ruled by Asmiro
(Emanuele Cornaggia), who was transformed by turns into a stag and a shepherd. Through her magic
she could transform herself into many creatures and could change the land, turning caves into ports,
and so forth. At the end of the work she revealed herself among the clouds.

This production opened on 8 February 1746. The printer's date is 1746, although the title-page date
(obviously erroneous) is 1745. A role for anew character (personaggio) was added.** The work opened
with shepherds performing a short concerto on various unidentified instruments. In the Act-One scene
containing a ballo, an orca surfaced from the deep sea and, after spitting out an important actor,
transformed itself into a magnificent sea shell. It was on this shell that the fairy and eight dancers,
representing the marine deities, offered the ballo. The work was given in Vienna on 29 September 1748,
when it was applauded for its scenery and machines.

No musical sources known
Listed as Groppo 823; Wiel 449; Alm 993

Armida al campo Music by multiple composers
[ARMIDE IN CAMP]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Francesco Silvani
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli and combattimenti SORTING DATE: 1746-05-18
Without dedicatee

The original version of this story* was first set for Venice by Ruggieri as 1707/9. This pastiche version
for the Ascension season is likely to have opened on 18 May 1746. The work opened in a Turkish
graveyard outside Jerusalem, where Armide (Angelica Saiz) arrived in a carriage pulled through the
air by dragons. The baili that ended the first two acts depicted Turks and Franks respectively.*' Horses,
camels, and elephants were seen in Geoffrey's camp at the end of the work. The cast included Giuseppe
Nicola d'Albertis (Goffredo), Emanuele Cornaggia (Rinaldo), and Teresa Castelli (Clorinda).

No musical sources known

Cassiano. This could indicate common authorship, although it may only be that the dedications were written by the same impresario.

La Sacendiera Music anonymous
[THE HOUSEKEEPER??]

A dramma giocoso Librettist unknown
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1746-05-18
Without dedicatee

In this comic work of uncertain authorship, set in Leghorn, Filauro (Nicola Gotti) is believed to have
died but poses under the name of Lucindo to find out what relationships his widow Elisa [singer
unidentified] may be cultivating. Elisa's housekeeper Checchina (Maria Angela Paganini) is being courted
by two common prospects  the avaricious Baldone (Carlo Paganini) and the impoverished count Don
Scialappa (Alessandro Cattani). An untitled libretto for the balli was published separately. The production
is likely to have opened on 18 May 1746. La facendiera had a revival at Turin in 1751.

Orazio [e] Curiazio Music by Ferdinando Bertoni
[THE HORATIANS AND THE CURIATIANS]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Simeone Antonio Sografi*
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1746-05-18~
Dedicated to the Ladies

Although the ancient Roman Horatians (orazi) warred with the Alban Curiatians (curiazi), they were
linked by marriage: Marco Orazio was the husband of Sabina Curiazio, whose loyalties were torn. Here
the Curiazi have a newly invented sister, Camilla (Giacinta Forcellini), who is loved by Orazio (Giovanni
Tedeschi), and another conjugal link is planned. For her protection, she is disguised as a man.
Orazio is likely to have opened on 18 May 1746. An untitled libretto for its balli was published separately.
The orchestra is likely to have included the violinist Giacomo Casanova, who was employed at San
Samuele between 1746 and 1748. The outlines of the plot, based on Pierre Corneille's Horace (1640),
may have been conveyed through Vincenzo Grimani's libretto for G. F. Tosi (1688/5). Some of the
names and details were changed in Sografi's text as set by Cimarosa (Venice, La Fenice, 26 December
1796; further revised for J.-J. Imbault, Paris, 1802). Salieri's Les Horaces (Vienna, 1786) was another
derivative of the same plot. Gli orazi ed i curiazi was Bertoni's best received opera seria.

Score in I-Vnm (Rome, 1746);?* aria in I-Ve

Listed as Groppo 824; Wiel 471; Alm 994

Lo starnuto d'Ercole. Cf. Suppl. 5c.

Eurimedonte e Timocleone. Cf. Suppl. 5c.

Cesare in Egitto Music attributed to Antonio Colombo?*
[CAESAR IN EGYPT]
A dramma per musica Text adapted from Giacomo Fr. Bussani by Carlo Goldoni
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Summer (Assumption)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1746-10-08
Without dedicatee

This production of Goldoni's rewrite (1735/7) of Bussani's text (1676/6) was essentially the same as
that presented at San Samuele as 1744/6, but the casting was entirely changed and the balli were omitted.
When the work opened, on 8 October 1746 (PV), it elicited full appreciation (pieno aggradimento).
It seems unlikely to have had a long run, for Venice experienced floods in the later part of October
1746. The cast now included Sebastiano Emiliani (Giulio Cesare), Geltruda Giorgi (Cornelia), Annonciata
Scarabelli (Cleopatra), Domenico Negri (Zolomeo), and Gaetano Guadagni (Achilla). The same cast
took the work to Treviso immediately after the Venetian run was concluded.

Sbacci's setting of Metastasio's popular text had first been given as 1740/5. Caterina Bassi Negri now

only basis for dating this work is by the process of elimination, which indicates its slight importance.

Alcibiade Music by Giuseppe Carcani
[ALKIBIADES]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Aurelio Aureli by Gaetano Roccaforte**
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1746-10-29
Without dedicatee

In this work the Athenian general Alkibiades (Giuseppe Santarelli), a pupil of Socrates, was disguised
as Orestes and was secretly married to Creusa (Barbara Stabili). Elements of the story were retained
from 1679/7. Alcibiade opened on 29 October 1746.7 A license to print a translation from the French
account of this story into versi Italiani had been issued on 5 November 1736.

 Ina production found to be very pleasing (PV), the balli were especially notable. The first act featured

personaggi), and the third a play-within-a-play in which, to the sound of voices and instruments,
the dancers depicted The Triumph of Ariadne and Bacchus as it might take place in the current
delicious autumn season.*! In keeping with the Venetian debut of the dance company of Francesco
Turchi, scenari for all three balli were published separately. A separate libretto for the mascherata was
also published. Turchi's troupe remained active in Venice until 1766.

Armida Music by Ferdinando Bertoni
[ARMIDE]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Bartolomeo Vitturi
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With / marito vizioso SORTING DATE: 1746-12-26
Without dedicatee

Vitturi's account of this familiar tale appears to have been newly written. The text enjoyed revivals
in settings by Bertoni (1780) and Cherubini (1782), in both cases with the title Armida abbandonata.
Armida opened on 26 December 1746. The title-page is dated 1747. Rosa Gabrielli sang in the title
role with Giuseppe Ant. Paganelli (Rinaldo) and Anna Medici (Tancredi).

The scenes are lavishly described in the libretto. Act One opened in a countryside setting which featured
brooks and their grassy banks as well as statues of the Four Seasons on pedestals. In Act Two paintings
of the principal battles for the liberation of Jerusalem hung on the walls of Armide's palace. The sun
set over the sea in Act Three.

Vinci's original setting of Metastasio's text was the basis for a production given in Rome in January
1728, while Carlo Broschi (Farinelli) had made his Venetian debut in Leo's version (1728/9). Despite
its earlier origins, the text seems to have enjoyed its greatest popularity between 1745 and 1755, when
at least seventeen productions were based on it.

This revival could have opened at the end of 1746. The title-page gives the date as Carnovale 1747.
Domenico Panzacchi sang in the lead role, with Barbara Stabili as Marcia. The dancers, who were now
given a prominent place in libretti for San Cassiano, were the same as in Alcibiade. Turchi's balli
represented The Judgment of Paris (II giudicio di Paride), various comedians, and The Palace of Pallas
(La reggia di Pallade), choreographed with a set made of crystal. Libretti for the three ba//i were
published separately.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

This revival of the work given at the Teatro Pubblico in Reggio Emilia in 1741 appears to have been
the choice of its dedicatee. The text resembles those on the same subject by Silvani (set by Perti in 1683/3)
and Noris (set by Pollarolo in 1698/4). Caio Marzio opened on 21 January 1746 M.V. (PV), when it
brought audiences full satisfaction. It shared the same casts of singers and dancers as Catone in Utica
(1746/15), which it directly followed. Giuseppe Santarelli sang in the title role with Barbara Stabili
(Vetturia).

The final entertainments for each act were elaborate. Act One ended with various concerted dances
(varie concertate danse) celebrating the conversion of Ulysses' companions back into men by Circe.
Act Two was followed by pleasing dances (balli piacevoli) presented by nymphs and shepherds in
a bacchanal. After Act Three, Galatea descended onto the shore, where she encountered Neptune
and other marine gods. All of them danced together.

Pompeo in Armenia Music attributed to Giuseppe Scarlatti?
[POMPEY IN ARMENIA]

A dramma per musica Text attributed to Bartolomeo Vitturi?
Performed at Sant' Angelo SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1747-01-21~
Without dedicatee

After the Roman general Pompey imprisoned Tigranes and subjugated Armenia, his enemy Mithridates
interceded and humbled Pompey. Given the constraints of an opening (1746/13) on 26 December,
followed by the production of two new works (this and 1747/5) as well as the revival of an old one,
all completed by the start of Lent (22 February), it seems probable that Pompeo, which had been given
in Pisa in 1744, would have been scheduled to open in the middle of January 1747. Scipione (1746/12)
was revived soon after its opening, suggesting that Pompeo was not well received. The cast included
Daniel Barba (Pompeo), Anna Medici (Tigrane), and Rosa Gabrielli (Laodice).

O@ This tale was a shortened version of 1741/4.' In it Tigranes has fallen in love with Cleopatra, the

La finta pazza Music anonymous
[THE WOMAN WHO PRETENDED TO BE MAD]

A dramma giocoso per musica Text anonymous
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With I/ marchese del Bosco; balli SORTING DATE: 1747-05-10
Without dedicatee

Pandolfo, who is here the guardian ofa hospital for mad women, is also the tutor of the well-born Corinda,
who is on the brink of marrying Florante. Delfa, who is in love with Florante, poses as a madwoman
and interrupts the wedding celebration planned by Pandolfo. Cianfrone, who loves Corinda, poses as
an astrologer and employs his own means of upsetting the plans. The action takes place in Rome. An
untitled libretto for the balli was published separately.

This production, which opened on 10 May 1747 (DO, PV), marked the inauspicious debut of Angelo
Mingotti as the theater's impresario. The intermezzo was greatly applauded, but the drama itself
received a cool reception, both for its poetry and for its performance. The problems likely issued
from the inexperience of the cast (see also 1747, Suppl. 5d). The Pisan singer Costantino Compassi,
who was to appear in many later works, made his Venetian debut as Pandolfo. All remaining members
of the cast were Bolognese.

The title, which can be traced back to a Monteverdi work of 1627, was perennial but resemblances
by the mid-eighteenth century were tenuous at best. Francesco Sacrati's La finta pazza, set to a text
by Giulio Strozzi (Venice, 1641), had been a good-humored work featuring a veritable army of gods
and mythical heroes  Ulysses, Juno, Minerva, Jupiter, Venus, and many others  together with a
court musician who was a eunuch and a chorus of buffoons. This account is clearly unrelated. On recent
contributions to the authorship, see 1745/7.

No musical sources known

Listed as Groppo 843; Wiel 486; Alm 1013

Il protettore alla moda Music anonymous
[THE STYLISH PROTECTOR]

A drama giocoso Text derived from Giuseppe Maria Buini
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1747-10-28~
Without dedicatee

After San Samuele was gutted by fire (30 September 1747), its troupe moved to San Giovanni Grisostomo
for the 1747-48 season. Its relocation created a hiatus in the comedy offerings which normally opened
in October. // protettore should have benefitted from these circumstances. The action portrayed in the
libretto begins on the last night of Carnival. The text was derived from that of Chi non fa non falla
(1732/6).

I protettore contained three serious and four buffo roles. Doralice (Anna Castelli), the mother of the
prima donna Diacinta (Annonciata Garrani), is relieved to have reached the last night of Carnival.?*
Costantino Compassi played the role of the protector, Monst Voragine, with Felice Novelli as the
impresario Saltobello, and Matteo Bevilaqua as the poet Volpino.

The production was very well received not only for the celebrated buffo, but [also] for the sumptuous
costumes and stupendous sets, among which there were those imitating the theater boxes, which were
specially painted for this production. It is not surprising that the work was quickly revived after
an ill-received production of La vanita delusa (1747/12).

No musical sources known

Listed as Groppo 846; Wiel 484; Alm 1016

C@0 This musical satire on a dramma per musica, which is a sequel to Artanaganamenone (1731/8), was
performed by comedians at Sant'Angelo in the autumn of 1747. While a specific date of opening is
elusive, it is known to have been received with great applause.* This appears to have been the first
work produced under the management of Gasparo Gozzi and his wife, Luisa Bergalli. In relation
to Artanaganamenone, miscellaneous guards, soldiers, and Arabian priests disappeared. Role names
were changed in minor ways. Malmocor was still a tyrant on the Arabian desert. His daughter Papinubia
was now engaged to marry Garganastare, the king of Euboca, whose cousin Miradaclea, the widow
of Sardanapalos, was enslaved by Malmocor. The action took place in Thermopolis.

L' Adriano Music by Vincenzo Ciampi*
[HADRIAN]

A dramma per musica Text adapted from Pietro Metastasio'*
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's?)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1748-01-16~
Without dedicatee

Metastasio's popular text (usually called Adriano in Siria) had been set for Venice by Giacomelli (1733/2)
and Giai (1740/2). In real life Teresa Castellani (Sabina) was engaged to marry Gio. Antonio Donini
(Adriano), adding a contemporary overlay to the plot. Ciampi's setting was sufficiently popular to justify
a performance (as Adriano in Siria) in London in 1750. While the date of opening is unknown, the
production can be sequestered to the 1747-48 cycle. Its roster of singers and dancers exactly duplicated
that of Arminio (1747/10), which opened in November 1747. Although L Adriano could have opened
just after Christmas 1747, it is more likely, because of the relatively long Carnival period (9 January-27
February) in 1748, to have opened in early to mid-January.

Score in I-MOe; arias in Favourite Songs (London, 1750)

The production of Jpermestra, beginning on 22 May 1748, marked the reopening of the Teatro di San
Samuele following the fire on 30 September 1747. The theater, which had been rebuilt in 55 days, now
had one less tier of boxes. The Imer troupe was to return to San Samuele in the autumn of 1748. *Angela
Catterina Riboldi sang in the title role with Domenico Panzacchi (Danao) and Giuseppe Ricciarelli
(Linceo). Gluck's setting of Metastasio's text had been given in Venice as 1744/10; this version was
significantly abbreviated. An untitled libretto for one of the balli was published separately.

In eighteenth-century Venice, cicisbei were noblemen who served as official escorts to noblewomen
to whom they were neither married or engaged. The couples cross lines of social class in this satire,
in which the wealthy but squandering Giscone and the vain but poor Lindoro (the first and second

cicisbei) are both in love with the aspiring singer Modulina, a mock noblewoman. The gentleman Ottavio

Litre cicisbei is likely to have opened on 22 May 1748. It ran long enough for two arias to be changed,
but the new arias may have been for its revival after the very short run of Orazio.* Its popularity,
which clearly overshadowed interest in other works planned for Sant' Angelo, such as La finta frascatana
(Suppl. 1), was the lone success of the otherwise unfortunate tenure of Luisa Bergalli Gozzi as impresaria
(1747-48). Charles Burney commented favorably on a later production of the work.

Although Orazio was the best known of Auletta's works, the text appears to have been a thinly disguised
remake of La gara per gloria (1744, Suppl. 5b), revived during the preceding Carnival at San Moise
as La partenza fortunata (1748; Suppl. 5b). It is otherwise linked with the later pastiches // maestro
di musica (Barcelona, 1750; Paris, 1752), L impresario abbandonato (Verona and Turin, 1748; Munich,
1749), and La scolara alla moda (Florence, 1760). Groppo reports that Orazio was performed only
three times during the spring of 1748 before being scrapped for a revival of Li tre cicisbei (1748/4).

La semplice spiritosa Music attributed to Giovanni (?) Fiorini?25
[THE SPIRITED SIMPLETON]

A dramma giocoso per musica Adapted from Carlo Goldoni*
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Autumn (St. Luke's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1748-11-04~
Without dedicatee

La semplice spiritosa begins with a depiction of the mysterious pomp with which Venice is wed to
the Adriatic on the feast of Ascension. Doralba (Livia Segantini) and her niece Rosmira (Rodegonda
Travaglia), who have come to witness this spectacle, are assisted by Ergasto (Anna Bastiglia) and Orazio
(Giuseppe Cosmi). The balli were choreographed by Giovanni Battista Nesti (Scaramuccia). La
semplice spiritosa, first performed in Florence in 1747, has to have preceded La scuola moderna (1748/9),
which was based on a revised version of the text, apparently with different music.
