OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1740-49) 515

Given with balli** SORTING DATE: 1748-11-30~
Without dedicatee

Groppo claimed a relationship of the text to that of La semplice spiritosa (1748/6),*TM but the similarities
were, for the times, superficial, although the casting was entirely the same.*** Four of the characters
(Agnesa, Arnoldo, Menecchina, Orazio) were renamed (as Drusilla, Belfiore, Leonora, Lindoro). Drusilla
is a mistress of love and deceit rather than truth (maestra di amori e di finzioni piuttosto che di
scienza).* The parte buffa is entirely changed.** The role of Belfiore (Carlo Paganini) has been
extended. The text for La scuola moderna, first given in Florence (autumn 1745), was printed
anonymously in 1748. The music for the work given under the titles La maestra (London, winter 1749)
and La maestra di scola (Verona, autumn 1749), usually now credited to Ciampi, merits re-evaluation.
The schedule of other offerings at San Moise suggests that this elaboration of La semplice spiritosa
probably opened towards the end of November 1748.

The staging appears to have been different from that of La semplice spiritosa. The Venetian-ness of
the scenery is more emphatic, probably reflecting the influence of Goldoni. Drusilla (Maria Angela
Paganini) sits making lace and Leonora (Caterina Baratti) crochets as the work opens. The characters
are provocative in their remarks. The widow Doralba (Livia Segantini) has promised her niece Rosmira
(Rodegonda Travaglia) to the count Belfiore (Carlo Paganini). Belfiore allows his pupil Lauretta (who
has a cold) to sing one aria (Lungi da questo core, Barbaro ingrato amore) to show off her
accomplishments. With her sister, Ninetta, she also sings a duet parodying the genre.** Drusilla is
eventually paired off with the manipulative Ergasto (Anna Bastiglia), who professes to idolize the
mysterious pomp with which Venice is wed to the Adriatic.

Bertoldo is generally reported to have opened on 26 (or 27) December 1748, but Groppo is quite
unambiguous in his dating of 4 January 1749. With various changes of scene and aria,**' he may simply
be saying that the work was revived soon after a late- December opening or preview performance, since
it had no earlier production.

According to Ortolani, the production was a raging success.*** The work was produced at the Teatro
Obizzi, Padua, for the fair of St. Anthony in 1750. There it opened on 11 June.** It was presented by
seven singers and eight dancers. Ciampi's work was reproduced in Milan (at the Ducale, 1750) and
in Rome (at the Argentina, 1751).** Revised versions were given under the titles Bertoldo in corte in
Paris (1753), Bertoldino alla corte del re Alboino (Potsdam, 1754), and Cacasenno alla corte del re
Alboino (London, Covent Garden, 1755). Favourite Songs from this last version were published in that
year and in 1762. The Paris version, later parodied in Favart's Ninette a la cour (1755), played a key
role in the querelle des bouffons (1753) and became a model in the development of opera comique.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Anagilda is a stage name for Sancia (Livia Segantini), the daughter of the king of Navarre. After
her brother Garcia (Caterina Baratti) ascended the throne, he lured Fernando, the count of Castile (Anna
Bastiglia), into a trap by offering him his sister's hand in marriage. Elements of the plot can be traced
back to Silvani's La forza della virtii (1692/8). This version, however, contains roles only for those
named plus Elvira (Rodegonda Travaglia), a fictional sister of Garcia. The action takes place at the
border of Navarre and Castile.

The title-page is dated Carnovale 1749, but a specific date of opening is elusive. Groppo's placement
suggests that it occupied a fairly late position in the 1748-49 cycle. Although the text was later well
received in settings by Sarti (1758) and Scalabrini (1772), this production was unsuccessful and probably
met an early demise. The intermezzi, based on new texts by Goldoni and set to music by Ciampi, may
have fared better.>**

The text was purportedly derived from the earlier comedies 1 ligamatti (1675) and II castigamatti (1695,
both listed in Suppl. 3a) by don Domenico Balbi.* The literal meaning of the name Arcifanfano was
old beak, figuratively meaning someone of vituperous attitude. In this particular case the term implied
vanity unsuited to one's station in life. Each mad person had a character flaw of a different kind (too
greedy, too euphoric, too shy, too angry, too happy). A notable role was that of Bad Government (Mal
Governo, sung by Berenice Penni), who was given to extravagance. Francesco Baglioni sang in the
title role.

Arcifanfano opened on 26 or 27 December 1749.*"' The title-page indication is Carnovale 1750.
A libretto for a ballo with the same title as the opera was published separately. Theatrical dance seems
to have been satirized in this work: the two existing balli are presented respectively (1) by madmen
and madwomen and (2) by the king of the lunatics, who introduces the maestro di ballo Persignach.*
Textual critics claim that the libretto suffered on account of the music. Tettings by Duni (as L Isle des
foux, 1760), Scolari (Lisbon, 1768), and Dittersdorf (Esterhazy, 1776) were better received.* The work
was revived in Venice as 1750/10 and again in 1755 (Suppl. 2d), now with somewhat altered music.

The 1750s: An Overview

WEN asparo Gozzi, the quintessential Venetian nobleman
eG of his time, was highly literate but his fortunes
SE were rapidly deteriorating. His family was mired
in unending property disputes. In league with his learned
wife, Luisa Bergalli, Gozzi attempted to rescue the struggling
Teatro Sant' Angelo in 1747-48 by assuming its management.
The arrangement soon failed; Sant' Angelo was converted
into a comedy house. Girolamo Medebach succeeded the
Gozzi, and he in turn engaged Carlo Goldoni (1748-49) to
write fully scripted comedies. For the theater it was a bright
new beginning. For the dramma per musica it was a turning
point. The audience response to Goldoni, after its preceding
year under the Gozzi, was so striking that Sant' Angelo
signed Goldoni on to a four-year contract in March 1749.
For an annual salary of 450 ducats, he was to provide eight
comedies, two theatrical works, and miscellaneous
adaptations each year. This ratio became the norm for other
theaters. It significantly altered the balance of power between
opera and comedy.

Goldoni's advertised reform of comedy precipitated a
pamphlet war which began as soon as these contracted works
began, in the autumn of 1749. The rivalry between Goldoni
and his nemisis, Pietro Chiari, which grew more bitter every
year, did not peak until 1760. Milestones of Goldoni's reform
included such works as // teatro comico (1750), which was
more a tract than a drama, and his adaptation of Richardson's
Pamela (also 1750; Suppl. 2c), which was the first spoken
play to be performed in Venice without masks. Goldoni's
discontents at Sant' Angelo led him to move to San Salvatore
in 1753 on a ten-year contract. It offered him 600 ducats a
year for the same number of works per year. Medebach
responded to Goldoni's abandonment by hiring Chiari at
Sant' Angelo.

A legal dispute between Medebach and Goldoni's
publisher, Bettinelli, clouded three theatrical years, from the
autumn of 1753 until Lent 1756. The rush to print comedies
was itself'a novelty, since until the later 1730s the ephemeral
scenari which were scribbled on paper and posted in the
wings of theaters had been considered adequate. The
subtleties of character and language in the social satires of
Goldoni and some of his contemporaries were such that
utmost care in dress, language, and gesture was required in

portrayals. The bitter insults which increasingly flew
between Chiari, Goldoni, and occasionally the Gozzi
engaged public interest and thereby increased the readership
of printed editions. Goldoni, who seemed to find personal
advantage in every adversity, enjoyed the friendship of
Venice's leaders. Before abandoning Venice for Paris (1762),
he dedicated a collected edition of his works to the doge
Francesco Loredan.

San Giovanni Grisostomo's brief accommodation of
comedians (1747-48) coincided with Gozzi's short tenure
at Sant'Angelo. The rebuilt San Samuele, which recalled
its displaced comedy troupe in 1748, was a showplace of
unprecedented grandeur. Crystals sets and chandeliers
completed its stunning interior in 1753. The theater began
to charge admission for daytime tours of its premises. Now
that comedy had taken on a life of its own, San Samuele
suddenly chose to become a venue for opera. It was a roost
not for the dramma per musica but rather for the collabora-
tions of Goldoni and a native son, Baldassare Galuppi. In
1753, San Samuele's comedy troupe resettled in Lisbon.

At the end of 1755 a new opera house for the nobility,
San Benedetto, was opened as a home for the dramma per
musica, but it was not destined to attract rave reviews. In
keeping with its emphasis on serious opera, its period of
operation was largely limited to the winter. Its main support
came from noblewomen who were friends of Pisana Giustin-
ian Lolin, the wife of Michele Grimani (long associated with
San Samuele), who was San Benedetto's manager. Although
gutted by fire in 1776, the theater was rebuilt and survived
into the nineteenth century.

Figure 28 compares opera productions by theater in the
1740s and 1750s. Figure 29 compares opera and comedy
productions within the 1750s. What may seem to have been
evenhanded treatment of comedy and opera at San Moise
in Figure 29 was not that at all. A turbulent period of
experimentation, involving the production ofa large number
of titles, was followed by another of lassitude. Finding
himself called to alien states in 1752, Angelo Mingotti
sublet the theater but also collected rents from a caffe on its
premises.

Increasingly Venice drew only composers in the early
stages of their careers. It experienced difficulty it retaining

FIGURE 29. Productions by genre in the 1750s.

indigenous ones if they achieved success. Theatrical op-
portunities abounded in Central and Eastern Europe, in
Denmark and Sweden, and in the British Isles. Giuseppe
Sarti, best known for his later activities in Russia, made a
Venetian debut at the end of 1752. Gioacchino Cocchi was
perhaps the one composer of the time who remained fixed
in Venice (his works were performed at San Samuele, San
Salvatore, and San Cassiano). Giuseppe Scolari, Giuseppe
Scarlatti, and Floriano Gassmann forged links between
Venetian opera and the stages of Vienna and other cities to
the north and east. All three composers had commissions
at San Moise.

Despite Goldoni's tenure as a dramatist there, San
Salvatore produced more operas in the 1750s than it had in
recent decades. San Cassiano flourished less from the

proceeds of its stages than from those of gambling (and,
some claim, prostitution) in designated boxes. At least here,
the role of the theater as a space for dubious private pleasures
increasingly overshadowed its role as a place for the public
performance of drama.

In some respects, life on the squares of Venice competed
with offerings in its theaters. Ad hoc acrobatic shows,
juggling demonstrations, and displays of exotic animals filled
the Piazza at Carnival and during the Ascension fair.
Scientific ventures quenched the thirst for spectacle with
well-advertised demonstrations in theaters of anatomy and
astronomy. General admission was sometimes offered to
academies of music and painting. It was as if the splendors
of the stage had oozed out onto the walkways and canals
of Venice.

526

Financial incentives motivated these changes. In January
1754 the Council of Ten instituted a provision which
required opera impresari to provide a deposit of 3,000 (later
4,000) ducats in order to mount productions in the autumn-
winter cycle. Spring productions were treated separately and
required a deposit of 2,000 ducats. It seemed to be a matter
of slight concern that many of these productions were weary
repetitions (and outright travesties) of earlier ones.

Opere buffe and comedies remained popular to the extent
that they were performed well, though once Goldoni left the
city, there was considerably less public discussion about
prose theater. The Gozzi continued to innovate, particularly
through their explorations of folklore, both local and exotic.
Yet obstacles at the institutional level seemed increasingly
insurmountable. The Most Serene Republic had ruled the

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Adriatic for most of a millennium, but its ruling city was
ruinously underfunded. The short-term solution of selling
off its antiquities, one trophy at a time, was demoralizing.
Yet it met with an enthusiastic response from the bourgeois
travelers, who patronized the new markets of collectibles
such as musical scores and instruments. In the steadily more
European Venice which was emerging, the culture of print
began to serve the market for news in 1760, when Gasparo
Gozzi's Gazzetta veneta appeared. In the same year his
brother, Carlo, attempted to revive improvised comedy.
Venice, however, was poised for its final breakdown. The
theater, dissociated from the fabric of indigenous personal
and civic life, withered.

Intent on finding a husband, Alcimena (Maddalena Ferrandini), the princess of the Fortunate Isles, invited

anumber of worthy candidates to her court to participate in various races, tournaments, and hunts. Among
the candidates were Fochino (Sebastiano Emiliani), the prince of China; Taiko-sama? (Giuseppe Rossi),
the prince of Japan; and Diomiro (Antonio Amati), the prince of Liliput.* They had seven days to prove
themselves.' An untitled libretto for a ballo was published separately. Stieger and other sources give
the opening date as 26 December 1749, but it is unconfirmed and probably incorrect. After six recitations
of II protettore alla moda (1749/12), San Cassiano was closed. It reopened on 10 January 1750, when

anew work, apparently this one, opened.

1750/3 Il mondo della luna Music attributed to Baldassare Galuppi
[A TRIP TO THE Moon]
A dramma giocoso per musica Text by Carlo Goldoni
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli' SORTING DATE: 1750-01-29
& Without dedicatee

The text was inspired by Cyrano de Bergerac's Voyage dans la lune'' (1650), with accretions from
the comedy Arlecchino imperatore nella luna (Paris, 1684).'? The false astrologer Ecclitico'' (Alessandro
Renda) deludes Buona Fede (Francesco Baglioni) into believing he has been transported to the moon
by staging various fantasy scenes after dark in the garden of his house. On stage, the spaceship is pulled
by two ponies.

Ow Il mondo della luna opened on 29 January 1750."* It was revived at San Cassiano for the last three days
of Carnival 1751 (Supplement 5b). Both balli, choreographed by Domenico Minelli, were substantial.
In the first, a transparent globe (representing the moon) was observed by an astrologer, who attributed
great significance to it. The moon then opened to reveal two lunar men and two lunar women.

o The text was phenomenally popular. In addition to Galuppi's setting, which was in use through 1760,
music was also written by Piccinni (Milan, 1770), Haydn (as Die Welt aufdem Monde, Esterhazy, for
a royal wedding in the summer of 1777), and Paisiello (as // credulo deluso, Naples, 1774; under the
original title, St. Petersburg, 1783). There were also productions in Lisbon (1765, 1791).

1750/7 Il mondo alla roversa

o sia Le donne che comandano Music attributed to Baldassare Galuppi
[THE WORLD UPSIDE DOWN, OR WOMEN IN POWER]
A dramma bernesco per musica Text attributed to Carlo Goldoni
im Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1750-11-14
& Without dedicatee

The concept of a world ruled by women was originally meant to represent the realities of modern
European politics. The first half of the eighteenth century had brought Queen Anne to the throne of
England, Elisabetta Farnese to that of Spain, and Maria Theresia to that of Austria. With respect to
stage works, however, Ortolani calls attention to the long tradition of female warriors (amazzoni) in
Italian works and works from antiquity, such as Aristophanes' Lysistrata. In the splendor of their court,
on an imaginary island in the Antipodes, the women have an exhilarating life in which all activities
are tailored for their benefit. Mocking Roman triumph scenes, the triumphal carriage in which the women
arrive is pulled by a chained group of men. Masculine spoils decorate the atrium in which the work
opens. A council composed entirely of women is convened in Act Two. Trumpets and timpani play
as the women prepared for combat.
CO II mondo, which had a cast of seven singers and ten dancers, opened on 14 November 1750. It enjoyed
universal applause. The performers included Serafina Penni (Cintia), Agata Sani (Tulia), and
Annunciata Manzi (Aurora). Goldoni's text was later set by Paisiello for performance in Florence
(1764).?

OOw This production of Merope opened on 19 November 1750. In it Giovanna Cesatti sang in the title role
with Gaetano Majorana (Caffariello) as her son (Epitide), Gaetano Ottani (Polifonte), and Pietro Serafini

Outside Venice, Merope was also set by such composers as Giuseppe Scarlatti (Rome, 1740) and Tomaso
Traetta (Milan, 1776). It was last heard in a setting by M. A. Portogallo (Lisbon, 1804).

1750/9 Il paese della Cuccagna Music attributed to Baldassare Galuppi

A commedia per musica Text by Carlo Goldoni

 In the fabulous land of Cuccagna, where there is universal abundance, the simple-minded Pandolino

(Francesco Baglioni) awaits the arrival of Pollastrina (Costanza Rossignoli) for their wedding. As the
work opens, he has just learned that the boat on which she was traveling has capsized. The governor
and various officials come to his rescue.* Apart from Orontes/Oronte, the characters in I] paese were
associated with intermezzi (e.g., Lardone, Pollastrina) or opere bernesche (e.g., Madama Cortese,
Madama Libera). The ballo given at the end of the work was a contradance introduced by instruments.

but the text remained in use through 1777.

La mascherata' Music attributed to Gioacchino Cocchi*!
[THE MASQUERADE]

A dramma comico per musica Text by Carlo Goldoni

With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1750-12-27

Dedicated to Carlo Filippo Cottone*

In this plot, which is rooted in the traditions of the commedia dell'arte, the Roman cavalier Silvio (Angela
Conti, known as La Taccarina) is engaged to Aurelia (Agata Sani), whose life is complicated by her
aunt, the widow Vittoria (Annunciata Manzi), and the unassuming silk-merchant Beltrame (Girolamo
Piani). The action, which takes place during the Carnival period in Milan, opens in Beltrame's silk factory.
The characters reveal their aspirations in the masks they assume for the Carnival promenade: Silvio
appears as Apollo, Aurelia as Daphne, Vittoria as a Florentine, Beltrame as a Neapolitan, his fashionable
wife Lucrezia as a Venetian, the witty scholar Menichino as a German, and Beltrame's friend Leandro

1751/1 L'opera in prova alla moda Music by Gaetano Latilla
[THE STYLISH OPERA REHEARSAL]
A dramma giocoso per musica Text attributed to Giovanni Fiorini
im Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
Given with balli SORTING DATE: 1751-01-23~
& Without dedicatee
e This satire on theatrical manners was populated by the maestro Calimodrio (Francesco Carattoli), four

virtuose, the poet Lirazza (Filippo Sedotti), and the head musician Semolino (Cattarina Flavis, called
La Guantarina). As the work opened, they were rehearsing the final scene of a music-drama called
Urganostocor (Suppl. 5b). All were beholden to Captain Saracca (Francesco Baglioni). According to
the libretto, the work was written in an evening by an Indian who lacked other ways of passing the
time.
 L'opera in prova must have opened in January 1751, perhaps around the 23rd. As a regular production,
it closed (with the end of Carnival) on 20 February. The first ballo involved so many scenes that they
were metered one per night at a designated point in Act One.** Urganostocor constituted the whole
of Act Three* and was performed (without the rest of the opera) on the last three nights of Carnival.

Le donne vendicate Music attributed to Gioacchino Cocchi
[WOMEN VINDICATED]

A dramma giocoso per musica Text by Gioacchino Cocchi
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1751-01-30
Without dedicatee

This playful study of female character, set in Bologna, features four women (Doralice, Eleonora, Emilia,
and Livietta) and four men (Casimiro, Volpino, Flaminio, and Roccaforte). The women have allied
themselves against Volpino (Giovanni Leonardi). Roccaforte (Girolamo Piani) defends the women.
The balli were scored for ten dancers. Le donne vendicate was first performed on 30 January 1751 (A,
PV). For this production mirrors were mounted on the exterior of the theater boxes, creating an unusual
impression of space.' Piccinni's setting of the text was given in Rome in 1763.

Demetrio Music by David Perez
[DEMETRIOS]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1751-05-19

Metastasio's text was familiar to Venetian audiences from the settings of Hasse (1732/3; 1737/2; 1746/14)
and Gluck (1742/4). Perez's own setting had had its premiere in Palermo ten years earlier. The text
remained in use into the late nineteenth century. Its last known setting was by Raffael Coppola (Turin,
1877). In the 1751 production, which opened on 19 May 1751 (PV), Colomba Mattei sang as Cleonike.

1751/6 La pastorella al soglio Music by Gaetano Latilla
[THE SHEPHERDESS ON THE THRONE]
A dramma per musica Text by Giovanni Carlo Pagani-Cesa
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Spring (Ascension)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1751-05-19
ze Without dedicatee

The Bohemian duke Ulderich (Domenico Panzacchi) fell in love with the shepherdess Beatrice (Agata
Rizzi) while she was washing clothes. He wooed her, married her, and shared power with her. These
events stirred the jealousy of Ermelinda (Rosa Tartaglini), whom he had previously courted.*!

 La pastorella was first performed on 19 May 1751 (A) with six singers and eight dancers. The ballo
degli chej (Czech danceTM) was censored by the Council of Ten on the 29th and ordered removed from
the work. To assure that no effort would be made to reinstate the dance, the Council also mandated
that instrumentalists be enjoined from participating in the performance. This ruling may have
foreshadowed another in which, early in 1752, the Council of Ten outlawed the opening of opera houses
and masking during the next Ascension fair.TM*

1751/7 Griselda Music by Gaetano Latilla
[GRISELDA]
A dramma per musica Text by Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)

This reappearance of Zeno's well-worn text, which had been set for Venetian productions by A. Pollarolo
(1701/1), Orlandini (1720/4), Albinoni (1728/3), and Vivaldi (1735/5), was only a midpoint on its long
trajectory. Settings by Piccinni and others kept it in use through the end of the eighteenth century. The
cast for the 1751 version featured Pietro Morighi (Gualtiero) and Prudenza Sani Grandi (Griselda).
 While no exact date of opening is known, the libretto was dedicated in November, and an opening in
the middle of the month is probable. When Griselda was given, mirrors were again mounted on the
outside of all of the boxes (see 1751/3). Groppo makes it clear that the desired effects of this practice,
which was also used in Naples, were dramatic,** not (as some recent commentaries have claimed) social.

Il conte Caramella Music attributed to Baldassare Galuppi
[COUNT CARAMEL]
A dramma comico per musica Text by Carlo Goldoni
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)
Without incidental items SORTING DATE: 1751-11-13
Without dedicatee

The libretto carefully identified two serious roles (Olimpia, the wife of the count, and her lover, the
Marquis Ripoli); two half-serious ones (the countess's gardener, Dorina, and the count, who, although
thought to have died, has posed as a pilgrim); and three buffi (the servant Ghitta, the peasant Cecco,
and the tambourine player Brunoro). The underlying text has been traced to a work by Joseph Addison.**
Rustic ways are emphasized.

I conte Caramella opened on 13 November 1751.*7 It was also given for the last four nights of Carnival
(12-15 February) in 1752.* Francesco Delicati sang in the title role, with Catterina Zipoli (Countess
Olimpia), Salvatore Consorti (the Marquis), and Bartolomeo Cherubini (Brunoro). I] conte had numerous
reprises over the next fifteen years, many of them in Germany.

The 1748 reconstruction of San Samuele favored its rise as a venue for musical works. San Samuele
quickly became the premiere theater for opera buffa in Venice, thereby eclipsing the ailing San Cassiano.
The once peerless San Giovanni Grisostomo, the bastion of the dramma per musica for three quarters
of a century, now concentrated on comedies.

Scores in A-Wn; D-Wm, Wa; I-Gl, Mr; arias in US-BEm

Listed as Groppo 894; Wiel 539; Alm 1068, 1076

GI'impostori Music attributed to Gaetano Latilla
[THE IMPposToRS]

A dramma per musica Librettist(s) unknown?
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's?)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1751-11-15~
Without dedicatee

Somewhat derivative of plots in recent works, this drama features the tutor Aniceto (Francesco Baratti),
his daughter Elmira (Anna Querzoli Laschi), and her beloved Don Valerio (Filippo Laschi), who poses
as a gentleman of means. One aria added to the final scene was in French. No exact date of opening
is known, but the production seems to have started in November. A work with the same title, set by
Rinaldo di Capua, was given in Modena in 1751. According to Groppo, G/ impostori had a reprise
in winter 1752, preceding / tre cicisbei.'' This appears to mean that the work was brought back after
an unsuccessful trial of L isola d'amore.

Le pescatrici Music attributed to Ferdinando Bertoni
[THE FISHERWOMEN]

A dramma giocoso per musica Text by Carlo Goldoni
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1751-12-26

Dedicated to Louis Henri, the Marquis of Pons

Based on the model of ecloghie pescatorie, this work is constructed somewhat like a pastorale. It features
two comely fisherwomen, Nerina (Serafina Penni) and Lesbina (Marta Davia), each of whom is engaged
to the other's brother. The story is complicated by Lindoro (Salvatore Consorti), the prince of Sorrento,
whose appearance causes Nerina and Lesbina to betray their social aspirations, much to the
disappointment of their fiances. Lindoro is searching for the long-lost princess Eurilda (Catterina Zipoli),
who is falsely believed to be the daughter of the elderly fisherman Mastriccio (Bartolomeo Cherubini).
The action takes place on the beach of Taranto.

Le pescatrici was first performed on 26 December 1751. The dedication was signed on the 24th by
the impresario Prospero Olivieri. The work was extremely popular over the next two decades, eventually
achieving fourteen productions. The text was the fifteenth ofa group of sixteen which Goldoni produced
within four years (1748-52). The text was set, with revisions, by Haydn (Esterhazy, 1770) and Gassmann
(Vienna, 1771) among others.

Scores in D-B, Dlb, Wa; P-La; arias in F-Pc; US-BEm (fine 1752), Bp, CAi*

Listed as Groppo 898; Wiel 549; Alm 1072

L'isola d'amore Music by Gaetano Latilla
[THE ISLAND OF LOVE]

A commedia in musica Text attributed to Gasparo Gozzi
Performed at San Moise SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1751-12-26
Without dedicatee

In this allegorical text the Island of Love is the home of youth. Purgonio (Francesco Baratti) is the ruler
of the island and Erodidascalo (Giuseppe Lecini) is its minister of love. The custodians of the island
are Finetta (Anna Querzoli) and Aspasia (Agata Ricci).

The opening date has to have been 26 December 1751 (GL). Gasparo Gozzi wrote to Luigi Pomo on
4 January 1752 (GL 126), reporting on the good reception his work was enjoying and noting that he
enjoyed singing some of the ariette to himself. He was pleased that he did not have to pay for the printing
of the libretti, but he spoke in rather disparaging terms of the impresario, [Pietro] Mingotti. Despite
Gozzi's positive impression of the reception, L isola was soon followed by a revival of its predecessor,
Gl'impostori (1751/9). However, it was revived in Treviso at the start of 1753. Metastasio's like-named
intermezzo, set by Sacchini in 1766, was popular into the 1780s.

No musical sources known

Venceslao Music by Antonio Gaetano Pampani
[WENCESLAS]

A dramma per musica Text by Apostolo Zeno
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1752-01-10~
Without dedicatee

This text was first set by C. F. Pollarolo (1703/4) and was subsequently produced in pastiche settings
(1722/5; 1723/3; 1735/8). Giuseppe Tebaldi sang in the title role in this version with Pietro Morighi
(Casimiro), Prudenza Sani Grandi (Lucinda), and Rosa Tartaglini (Erenice). The libretto was published
in MDCCL2 [sic]. Other factors suggest an opening in early January.

No musical sources known

Listed as Groppo 897; Wiel 543; Alm 1071

Le virtuose ridicole Music attributed to Baldassare Galuppi
[THE RIDICULOUS VIRTUOSE]

A dramma giocoso per musica Text by Carlo Goldoni
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Winter (Carnival)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1752-01-17~
Without dedicatee

Le virtuose, which was indebted to Moliere's Les Precieuses ridicules, makes fun of the pretensions
of female academicians (the virtuose of the title) in villeggiatura. The work features the philosopher
Aphrodisia (Catterina Zipoli), the poet Pegasino (Gio. Filippo Delicati) and poetess Melibea (Serafina
Penni), the singer Armonica (Cecilia Moblan), the historian Gazetta (Giovanni Leonardi), and the know-it-
all token male, Ser Saccente (Bartolomeo Cherubini), who sprinkles his pronouncements with Latin
phrases, plus the straight man Erideno (Salvatore Consorti).

On 22 October 1751 Goldoni wrote that he was glued to his desk from morning to night on a schedule
which prevented him from frequenting the theaters. This text and that of Le pescatrici completed his
cycle of sixteen comedies for San Samuele. Since both were intended for Carnival and Le pescatrici
opened immediately after Christmas 1751, Le virtuose must have opened in mid-January (1752).
The musical ignorance of Armonica was here likened to the spoiled but artless singer satirized in
Benedetto Marcello's I teatro alla moda. In the finale of Act Two, all of the performers played
instruments. The dance troupe of Pierre Aubri attracted much attention. The text was reset by Paisiello
(Parma, 1765) and Ottani (Dresden, 1769).

Score in D-W

Listed as Groppo 901; Wiel 550; Alm 1075

1752/6 I portentosi effetti della Madre Natura Music attributed to Gius. Scarlatti
[THE MIRACULOUS EFFECTS OF MOTHER NATURE]

A dramma giocoso per musica Text by Carlo Goldoni
V1 Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Autumn (St. Martin's)

With balli SORTING DATE: 1752-11-11
& Dedicated to Catterina Loredan Mocenigo, Nob. Ven.

This work, derived from Calderon, was situated on the island of Majorca, where the prince Celidoro
(Filippo Laschi), locked in a tower from childhood, has been released and discovers the appeal of the
opposite sex. This disrupts the plans of Ruggiero (Francesco Rolfi), who is married to the princess Lisaura
(Clementina Spagnuoli). The work opens with a thunderstorm, which indicates that Jupiter is in a bad
mood. Goldoni writes in the dedication that although the imperfections of both drammi per musica
and drammi buffi are so numerous that neither is appropriate for women of high merit, it is hoped that
this text might be thought suitable for wedding festivities. It suggests that the dedicatee and her groom
are both descended from the queen of Cyprus (Caterina Cornaro).

Owe Although GDN gives the opening date as 10 November, surviving libretti were dedicated on the 11th.
The balli were presented by a company of ten dancers headed by Francesco Sabioni plus two soloists
 Teresa Zambelli and Lodovico Ronzio. The text was reset by Piccinni as Le vicende della sorte
(1761). In February 1753 it was pointed out that when operas were given at San Samuele, decorations
now regularly festooned the boxes. Mirrors and lanterns were especially popular.

Listed as Groppo 904; Wiel 548; Alm 1079

OPERA PRODUCTIONS (1750-59) 541

La Calamita de' Cuori Music by Baldassare Galuppi
(Miss AMOROUS CALAMITY' ]

A dramma giocoso Text by Carlo Goldoni
Performed at San Samuele SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's)
With a ballo SORTING DATE: 1752-12-26

Dedicated to the Most Noble Ladies of Venice

Calamita de' Cuori is the nickname for Bellarosa (Serafina Penni), whose personality is contrasted
to that of the love-sick Albina (Clementina Spagnuoli) and the ill-tempered Belinda (Agata Ricci). The
potential suitors and protectors are the faithful Armidoro (Francesco Rolfi), the charming Giacinto
(Filippo Laschi), the braggart Saracca (Giovanni Leonardi), and the avaricious Pignone (Niccola Petri).
The production also included a company of nine dancers and four independent ballarini. Bellarosa was
required to dance a minuet in Act One.

This enormously popular work was first performed on 26 December 1752 (GDN)."' The title-page is
dated 1753. When Serafina Penni appeared on-stage on 14 January, she was greeted by a standing
ovation. The production may have run until early February. La Calamita proved to be one of
Goldoni's best-known melodramas. It was later reset for performance in Vienna by Salieri (1774) and
Cimarosa (1792).

Alessandro nell' Indie Music by Gaetano Latilla et al.
[ALEXANDER IN INDIA]

A dramma per musica Text by Pietro Metastasio
Performed at San Cassiano SEASON: Winter (St. Stephen's?)
With balli SORTING DATE: 1752-12-26~

Dedicated to the Most Noble Ladies of Venice

This was the fifth production based on Metastasio's popular text to be given in Venice in twenty years.
The dedication of the libretto was provided by the virtuosi, who would have included Domenico Pignotti
(Alessandro), Mariano Nicolini (Poro), Domenica Casarini Latilla (Cleofide), and Giuseppe Bettenbrich
(Erisena). The choreographer was Domenico Lupis (Paita). The printer's date of the libretto is 1753;
the available time for an opening was from just after Christmas through early January.

 Betnbrich in the libretto.

* Sarti (1729-1802) was from Faenza. He was currently maestro di cappella at the Teatro della Pergola in Florence, although he spent most
of the following decade in Copenhagen. This was his second opera and his first for Venice.

542



85 Te., Mont Blanc.

A NEW CHRONOLOGY OF VENETIAN OPERA

Domenico Negri (Alexander the Great) is cast with Domenica Scogli (Aminta), Chiara Marini (Elisa),
and Cecilia Maublanc (Zamiri) as well as Leopoldo Burgioni (Agenore) in this pastoral drama. /] re
pastore could have opened at almost any time between 26 December and the end of January. While
the story is silly enough to have suited the last nights of Carnival, it was the only work to be given during
the winter season at San Moise, and this favors an opening early in the period. As a newcomer to the
Venetian theater, Sarti attracted no notice during this Venetian debut.

The text was officially written for performance at Schenbrunn in May 1752, with the music of Giuseppe
Bonno, at the command of the empress, Maria Theresia, but Sarti's setting had been given at the Teatro
Sole, Pesaro, during Carnival 1751. Mozart's setting (K. 208) was performed at the Archbishop's palace,
Salzburg, in April 1775. Sarti, who was to spend a year (1766-67) as maestro at the Pieta in Venice,
became an important figure in the dissemination of Venetian opera and Italian music more generally,
both in Denmark, where he served as court Kapellmeister for the decade 1753-63, and in St. Petersburg,
where he provided music for the court for nearly twice that long (1782-1801).
